questions.question: If upon delivery there are any problems in regards to the transportation temperature of easily perishable food products, one should report it to Finnish Food Safety Authority.
questions.description: If there are any problems with the quality of delivered products, they should be returned to the supplier and reported to the driver.

questions.question: In a cramped or nearly full storage facility, food products that can easily perish can be stored on the floor if it has just been washed.
questions.description: Easily perishable food products must always have shelves or a platform in storage facilities. Food products can never be stored on the floor.

questions.question: Own-check plans are always the task of employers and superiors.
questions.description: Superiors are responsible for making sure that all employees know the company's own-check plan as well as their responsibilities in the plan. Working according to the own-check plan itself is the responsibility of everybody in the company.

questions.question: It is important to visually monitor cleanliness on a daily basis in addition to regular cleaning.
questions.description: Everyone working in a food premises must constantly monitor its cleanliness.

questions.question: Frozen foods can be defrosted on a kitchen table if the liquid from the melting does not pour onto the table.
questions.description: All frozen foods must be defrosted in cold storage units. When defrosting, one must make sure that the defrosting product does not pour liquid onto any other food products placed or stored in the cold storage unit. Defrosted or just partially defrosted products can not be frozen again.

questions.question: Properly heated food products can not contain bacteria that causes food poisoning.
questions.description: Even properly heated food products can contain food poisoning causing bacteria; the bacteria can spread to the food due to bad handling hygiene or dirty equipment during e.g. chopping or serving.

questions.question: All dangerous food poisoning microbes need oxygen to grow.
questions.description: Most of the bacteria that cause food poisoning are facultative anaerobic bacteria, which means that they can grow in either the presence or absence of oxygen.

questions.question: Food poisonings can be prevented by using single-use protective gloves.
questions.description: Single-use protective gloves must be used when handling very easily perishable food products. Protective gloves make it easier to work when employees must change tasks quickly.

questions.question: The slime that appears on the surface of meat products is caused by harmful microbes.
questions.description: Some harmful microbes produce slime. For example, slime appearing on the surface of a sausage is a sign of it perishing. Slime-producing microbes reproduce quickly in food products e.g. when the product is stored or served in too high temperatures.

questions.question: Campylo bacteria is naturally found in fowl and poultry.
questions.description: Campylo bacteria and salmonella are found naturally in fowl and poultry. Both bacteria are destroyed when the meat is cooked thoroughly to over 75 degrees Celsius.

questions.question: In vegetables, only perished areas that can be noticed visually are health hazards.
questions.description: Due to cultivation and treatments the surface of vegetables can have impurities which can not be seen with the bare eye. Harmful microbes can also be on areas that are not visually perished. Vegetables are a health risk when they are not washed properly before use.

questions.question: Packages for non-easily perishable food products must have a label indicating their best-before date.
questions.description: Packaging labels for non-easily perishable food products show the best-before date. The accuracy of the date is determined by the product's shelf life. The product may be used after the date if its sensory qualities, such as smell, taste and look are impeccable.

questions.question: Blanching can be used to improve the lastingness of chopped vegetables during freezing.
questions.description: Blanching, which means rapid boiling, stops frozen vegetables' enzymic activity by destroying microbes on their surface.

questions.question: The correct concentration of detergent significantly affects the cleaning result.
questions.description: Detergents and disinfectants must be measured out in accordance with the manufacturer's instructions. A solution that is stronger than recommended does not usually guarantee a better cleaning result, and a solution that is diluted too much may give a worse result.

questions.question: Women that are pregnant should not eat vacuum-packed salmon due to the higher risk of listeriosis.
questions.description: Risk food products are products that have not been heated and have a long selling time. Vacuum-packed salmon has not been heated and has a long selling time. The vacuum-package does not prevent listeria from reproducing because listeria can grow in conditions without oxygen. Proper cold storage does not prevent the risk either because listeria can reproduce in refrigerator temperatures.

questions.question: Wooden utensils are well suited for professional kitchens if they are washed in a washing machine on a sufficiently hot program.
questions.description: Wooden utensils should not be used in professional kitchens, as they do not withstand repeated washes in a washing machine. Materials must very durable in order to cope with repeated washes, like for example plastic and steel utensils that are meant for food product related use.

questions.question: Coffee cream and milk may be stored in room temperature, because they will be added to hot coffee.
questions.description: Milk and cream are easily perishable food products, and they must be served cold.

questions.question: Easily perishable food products that have been up for retail sale can be frozen and sold as frozen foods.
questions.description: The preparation of frozen foods requires the ingredients to be perfect quality. Frozen foods must be prepared, cooled and frozen without any delay. Frozen foods are prepared only by appropriate production centres. Freezing is allowed in bakeries, households and farm households only if the areas and equipment are approved by officials.

questions.question: Pasteurisation of milk destroys listeria bacteria.
questions.description: Pasteurisation of milk is a process that destroys listeria bacteria. Milk is pasteurised when heated to 72°C for about 15 seconds.

questions.question: If a can of canned food has bloated and become larger, the contents inside the can must not be tasted.
questions.description: Bloated, enlargened cans can contain a dangerous toxin called botulin. Even a very small amount of botulin can be lethal.

questions.question: Sour milk spoils faster than milk.
questions.description: The pH value of milk is 7, which means it is neutral. The pH value of sour milk is lower, which means sour milk is acidized. It is harder for bacteria to reproduce in acidized milk products than in neutral products.

questions.question: You can wear disposable gloves instead of washing your hands when preparing food in a restaurant tent.
questions.description: Washing your hands thoroughly and often enough is the basis for safe food handling and general hygiene, and it is important to also wear disposable gloves, for example.

questions.question: Food products are always safe if the best before date has not yet expired.
questions.description: A food product may be contaminated even if there are still several days until the best before date. Contamination may be caused by unhygienic tools or work environment and incorrect temperatures, for example.

questions.question: You can touch the inside surfaces of food packaging if you have just washed your hands.
questions.description: You should always try not to touch the inside surfaces of food packaging.

questions.question: Microbes are destroyed when meat is minced.
questions.description: When meat is minced, the bacteria on its surface spread throughout the minced meat.

questions.question: Pet dogs can not be taken inside a café even with the permission of the owner of the café.
questions.description: If the owner gives permission, a pet dog can be taken inside the customer areas of a café. Guide dogs are always allowed inside customer areas, even without asking for permission.

questions.question: Moulds can not create mould toxins.
questions.description: Some moulds can create mould toxins such as mycotoxins and aflatoxins. Because of this mouldy products should not be used.

questions.question: Food served in a lunch buffet must remain at +60 degrees celsius for the entire duration of the serving.
questions.description: If food that has been prepared by heating or cooking is not served immediately, it must be kept at a temperature of at least 60 degrees throughout the entire serving.

questions.question: Blue cheese contains living mould.
questions.description: Clean, controlled and living moulds are used when producing blue cheese. The moulds create various taste ingredients in the cheese.

questions.question: If a product has been cooled once already, heating it again must be done very carefully.
questions.description: Reheating cooled food must be done very carefully to make sure its microbiological quality stays good. Heating the product thoroughly to 70 degrees Celsius should be possible. Because of this a microwave oven is not a good tool for reheating, because different ingredients in the food will heat in different ways.

questions.question: Freezing in a sufficiently cold temperature improves the lastingness of products.
questions.description: Products can be stored by freezing them, but one must notice that freezing affects the quality of different food products. For example, fish, meat and baked goods dry up easily during freezing, so the quality of products stored in freezing must be checked regularly.

questions.question: Unpeeled and peeled carrots will last the same amount of time as long as they are stored in the cold.
questions.description: Earthy and dirty, untreated root vegetables will last long in appropriate cold storage units, but all treatments will worsen their lastingness.

questions.question: If food is prepared to be served later, the finished products must be cooled as soon as possible for storage.
questions.description: Hot, cooked food must be cooled to under 6 degrees Celsius in under 4 hours. Cooling large amounts of products requires the use of actual cooling devices, from which the cooled products must be moved to their appropriate cold storage units.

questions.question: Reheated products must be heated to +75 degrees celsius before serving.
questions.description: Reheated food products, such as appropriately cooled food that has been prepared the previous day, must be thoroughly heated to +75 degrees before serving.

questions.question: Cleaning plans are not a part of own-check plans.
questions.description: Cleaning plans are an important part of own-check plans. Cleaning plans include instructions and schedules for cleaning.

questions.question: A cooked food product can be cooled outside or in front of an open window if there is no separate cooler for that purpose.
questions.description: Food products must never be cooled or stored outside. If there is a need to cool cooked products, there must be a designated cooling cabinet or other sufficient cooling space for it. Small batches can also be cooled in a cold bath.

questions.question: There are no microbes in dried food products.
questions.description: Dried products last well due to having no water that bacteria could use to reproduce. However, the microbes have not been destroyed in dried products and the products can contain spores of bacteria, moulds or yeast.

questions.question: The amount of sugar a product contains does not affect its lastingness.
questions.description: Highly sugared products, such as jams, marmelades and sweets do not perish easily because sugar changes the state of water so that microbes can not reproduce.

questions.question: Food products containing preservatives will also spoil.
questions.description: Preservatives only slow down the spoiling done by microbes. In the European Union all allowed preservatives have an E-code.

questions.question: All monitoring logs made for own-check plans must be stored for at least a year at the workplace.
questions.description: Only stored monitoring logs can prove that the own-check plan has been adhered to.

questions.question: Domestic water pollution is often caused by human faeces.
questions.description: Norovirus and Campylobacter enter the domestic water supply mainly through municipal wastewater, and Campylobacter also through animal faeces. Inadequate dosing of disinfectant chemicals can also cause contamination.

questions.question: The monitoring logs made for own-check plans, e.g. logs of temperature measurements, must be stored at the workplace for 6 months.
questions.description: Logs must be stored for at least 1 year after selling a product. The information included can be used to trace errors and problems.

questions.question: All cold storage units in food production areas must contain a thermometer.
questions.description: The monitoring and logging of temperatures is an important part of the . Thermometers are a vital tool for this and must be used.

questions.question: Chefs are allowed to handle money and prepare food without washing their hands in between.
questions.description: Notes and coins contain a lot of microbes, and you must always wash your hands after handling money before you start cooking.

questions.question: Blanching can be used to improve the lastingness of chopped vegetables during freezing.
questions.description: Blanching, which means rapid boiling, stops frozen vegetables' enzymic activity by destroying microbes on their surface.

questions.question: Sour milk spoils faster than milk.
questions.description: The pH value of milk is 7, which means it is neutral. The pH value of sour milk is lower, which means sour milk is acidized. It is harder for bacteria to reproduce in acidized milk products than in neutral products.

questions.question: Food products are always safe if the best before date has not yet expired.
questions.description: A food product may be contaminated even if there are still several days until the best before date. Contamination may be caused by unhygienic tools or work environment and incorrect temperatures, for example.

questions.question: Microbes can not reproduce in dry products.
questions.description: Microbes need water to reproduce. Microbes will not reproduce in dried products but dried products can contain spores of bacteria, moulds or yeast.

questions.question: Chefs do not require a hygiene proficiency passport if their employment is not permanent.
questions.description: Chefs handle easily perishable food products in their work. This means that chefs must pass a hygiene proficiency test at least 3 months after starting their work.

questions.question: When unprotected, cooked and uncooked food products must be stored in separate areas.
questions.description: Unprotected cooked and uncooked food products must have separate storage areas to prevent cross-contamination.

questions.question: Coffee cream and milk may be stored in room temperature, because they will be added to hot coffee.
questions.description: Milk and cream are easily perishable food products, and they must be served cold.

questions.question: Earth can contain lots of food poisoning causing bacteria.
questions.description: Earth can contain e.g. bacillus cereus or clostridum bacteria. Earthy vegetables must be treated and stored such that the earth does not spread onto other food products.

questions.question: Only supervisors carry out the activities described in the own-check plan.
questions.description: Everyone working in a food premises is responsible for carrying out the activities described in the own-check plan.

questions.question: Food that is being served while cold must have its temperature measured and marked down.
questions.description: Temperature measurements of food that is being served are a part of own-check plans. The results of the measurements must be mark down in the monitoring logs of the own-check plans and then stored at the workplace for 1 year.

questions.question: Food product employees can use wedding and engagement rings while handling easily perishable goods.
questions.description: Jewellery can not be used when working with food products. No matter how well hands are washed, a large amount of harmful microbes can stay under rings and can later contaminate food products being handled.

questions.question: Raw milk is not suitable for small children, elderly people, pregnant women or people who have a severe disease.
questions.description: Because raw milk has not been pasteurized it can contain disease causing bacteria. The most important bacteria that are a threat to food product safety in raw milk are EHEC, campylo, listeria and salmonella bacteria.

questions.question: Health inspectors can not inspect restaurant kitchens.
questions.description: The work of health inspectors requires making inspections in food production areas such as food stores and restaurants.

questions.question: Flies are a hygienic risk for food products.
questions.description: Flies can spread microbes that are harmful or hazardous to the human health onto food products and are a risk because of this.

questions.question: A food poisoning epidemic is a situation where at least 10 people have become sick with similar symptoms after consuming the same food product or ingredient.
questions.description: A food poisoning epidemic means a situation where at least 2 people have become sick with similar symptoms after consuming the same food or drink.

questions.question: If food does not taste spoiled it can not cause food poisoning.
questions.description: Many food poisoning causing bacteria can reproduce in food without causing changes that can be noticed with the senses (visually, taste etc.)

questions.question: When food products are stored in the correct temperatures, the microbes in the products will not be able to reproduce and grow into dangerous quantities too quickly.
questions.description: Microbes can not be fully prevented from getting into food products. However, correct temperatures will slow down or prevent the microbes in food from reproducing and growing in hazardous amounts.

questions.question: Visually clean work surfaces guarantee their microbiological cleanliness.
questions.description: Microbiological cleanliness can not be guaranteed by using just the bare eye. Correct cleaning methods and equipment, as well as regular and proper cleaning, guarantee the cleanliness much better. Samples can also be taken of the cleanliness of specific surfaces if required.

questions.question: Bacteria spores are destroyed when products are boiled (+100 degrees Celsius).
questions.description: Bacteria spores are destroyed only during sterilization. In excess pressure the temperature is raised to about 145 degrees Celsius and this way bacteria spores are also destroyed.

questions.question: Products in protective gas packages contain microbes.
questions.description: Products in protective gas packages always contain some microbes. The protective gas is used to prevent microbes that require oxygen from growing.

questions.question: A biowaste container that is kept closed can be stored in the kitchen's storage area at room temperature for a few days.
questions.description: Waste must be stored in a designated area that is sufficiently separated from other operations and food products.

questions.question: The same broom can be used for cleaning the floor and work surfaces.
questions.description: Floors contain a lot more microbes than work surfaces. If floor brooms are used for work surfaces, the microbes on the floor will spread to the work surface from the broom.

questions.question: Oiva is a system which helps to assess the food product safety of different workplaces.
questions.description: Municipality food control authorities do routine inspections at workplaces. Oiva is the publishing system for the results of these inspections, and is co-ordinated by Ruokavirasto.

questions.question: People who have been infected with salmonella always have diarrhoea.
questions.description: The symptoms of salmonella infection include nausea, diarrhoea, high temperature and headache. Not everyone with the infection has symptoms.

questions.question: A delivery load that contains meat and fish products can be safely left at room temperature for three hours pending transfer into cold storage.
questions.description: The cold chain of perishable food products must not be interrupted at any point in the supply chain.

questions.question: Food can be tasted with the fingers.
questions.description: Food must never be touched with the fingers if it is not necessary. Spoons should be used for tasting.

questions.question: Food that has been heated once is always sterile.
questions.description: Heating food does not make it sterile. Heating might not destroy all of the spores of bacteria and moulds. Microbe growth can start again from the spores in the right conditions, which can cause the food to become perished. Ready food can also be contaminated after heating by e.g. hands of employees.

questions.question: Mould and bacterial spores can also be found in dry food products.
questions.description: Spores are more resistant than bacteria to their surrounding conditions, especially heat, drought and chemical agents.

questions.question: Handling money can transfer harmful microbes into food products.
questions.description: Money and easily perishable unpackaged food products should not be handled simultanously, as money can have microbes in it that jeopardize food hygiene.

questions.question: Intestinal bacteria cannot spread from hands to food.
questions.description: Intestinal bacteria can spread to food even from the hands.

questions.question: Whipping is one way to improve the shelf life of cream.
questions.description: If you whip cream, you process an unpackaged perishable food product, which shortens its shelf life.

questions.question: Yersinia bacteria has been found on fields and in fresh vegetables that have been spoiled during storage.
questions.description: Yersinia is destroyed when heating a product to over 70 degrees Celsius. Fresh vegetables are often served non-heated, so possible yersinia is not destroyed. Yersinia can also reproduce during storage in refrigerator temperatures.

questions.question: Smoking is allowed at the loading docks of kitchens.
questions.description: Loading docks are a part of food production areas; smoking is not allowed in food production areas.

questions.question: Food production areas do not need a written cleaning plan if the procedures have been discussed carefully with the personnel and everyone knows their tasks.
questions.description: The cleaning and washing program always needs to be part of the food production area's own-check plan. The own-check plan is produced on paper before starting activities in the food production area.

questions.question: If a member of staff becomes infected with salmonella while abroad, he or she cannot spread the infection in Finland.
questions.description: Most cases of salmonella infection are acquired abroad, and an infection acquired abroad can also spread in Finland.

questions.question: Disinfecting work surfaces does not compensate for regular, careful washing.
questions.description: Work surfaces must be cleaned and washed regularly after each phase of work, and disinfecting can improve the overall cleaning result.

questions.question: Working areas and surfaces must be cleaned regularly during work shifts and after work is over.
questions.description: Regular cleaning, done every 2-4 hours, of working equipment and surfaces with clean cleaning equipment, substances and water gets rid of leftover pieces of food, dust and other dirt that protects microorganisms and is used as living space by the organisms.

questions.question: Food poisoning bacteria cannot multiply in vacuum packaged food products.
questions.description: A vacuum package does not prevent bacteria from multiplying. Anaerobs, ie. food poisoning bacteria that multiply in spaces free from oxygen can also multiply in vacuum packages.

questions.question: There may be flies in a food premises even if the waste management is well organised.
questions.description: Flies in the premises are always a sign of inadequate cleaning.

questions.question: Liquid soap is to be used when washing the hands.
questions.description: Liquid soap is hygienic. The dispenser of the liquid soap should be one which can be pressed with the forearm instead of the hands.

questions.question: When preparing a own-check plan, all essential food product risk monitoring must be explained.
questions.description: It is essential for the plan to think which parts of done activities are ones where microbes can reproduce and how risks will be monitored, as well as what actions must be taken to fix risk situations.

questions.question: If upon delivery there are any problems in regards to the transportation temperature of easily perishable food products, one should report it to Finnish Food Safety Authority.
questions.description: If there are any problems with the quality of delivered products, they should be returned to the supplier and reported to the driver.

questions.question: The post-contamination of a cooked product can be prevented by using appropriate and clean storing containers.
questions.description: Good hand hygiene, clean working equipment and hygienic storing containers protect cooked products from post-contamination due to hazards that affect the safety of the product after heating it.

questions.question: When receiving food products it is enough to check their temperature.
questions.description: When receiving food products it is also required to check the products' appearance, the quality of the packaging and the packaging markings with the senses (visually etc.).

questions.question: An establishment's own-check plan is in effect for 10 years at a time.
questions.description: The own-check plan must be updated if need arises. It is useful to go over the plan regularly and to assess whether or not there have been changes in the establishment's functioning or protocols that require changes to made in the plan as well. Changes in the regulations of the food industry may necessitate changes in own-check plans as well.

questions.question: Food control authorities must approve a company's own-check plan to allow the company to begin its activites in the industry.
questions.description: Approval from authorities is not required to start activities. The plans are part of the companies' personal documents, which authorities will check and intervene in if problems are noticed.

questions.question: Dishes do not need to be pre-washed before being put into a washing machine if the washing temperature is hot enough.
questions.description: Dishes must always be pre-washed before being put into a washing machine. It is important to get rid of protein spots with cool water so that the protein does not stick to the dishes in hot temperatures. The biofilm that the protein creates acts as a living space for microbes.

questions.question: A grated carrot spoils faster than an entire carrot.
questions.description: Treating a carrot and grating it shortens the time it lasts. During grating microbes spread onto the carrot and water inside the carrot becomes available for the microbes to use. Grated products also have more surface area than intact products; microbes, especially ones that require oxygen, are suitable to live on the surface of products.

questions.question: A food production area means an area in which food is prepared.
questions.description: A food production area is any building, room, part of a room or some other indoor or outdoor space where food meant to be sold or otherwise handed onwards is prepared, stored, transported, kept on sale, served or treated in some other way.

questions.question: After washing one's hands the tap must be closed using a hand towel, otherwise the hands can become dirty again.
questions.description: After washing the hands they must be dried using a single-use hand towel and the tap must be closed using the towel. This way any possible microbes on the tap do not spread onto the clean hands.

questions.question: The smaller the pieces of chopped vegetables, the longer their shelf life.
questions.description: The more you handle and chop food products, the shorter their shelf life is.

questions.question: Received food products must be stored where there is the most space for them in the storage facility.
questions.description: Received food products are stored based on the FIFO method (First In, First Out) which means that products already stored in the storage facility are moved to the front to be used or taken first, and any new products are placed behind or after any prior ones. This way the products are taken out of storage in the order they arrived in and the amount of wastage is reduced.

questions.question: Reheated products must be heated to +75 degrees celsius before serving.
questions.description: Reheated food products, such as appropriately cooled food that has been prepared the previous day, must be thoroughly heated to +75 degrees before serving.

questions.question: Smoking is allowed at the loading docks of kitchens.
questions.description: Loading docks are a part of food production areas; smoking is not allowed in food production areas.

questions.question: If a food product includes nuts it must say so on the package.
questions.description: Packaging markings must tell if the product contains ingredients that cause allergic reactions; the EU has a compiled list of these.

questions.question: Workers in the food industry, e.g. an online store sselling food products, must inform local food control authorities about their activities.
questions.description: All workers in the food industry must inform food control authorities about their activities. The informing must be done before beginning the activities. When founding a food industry workplace, e.g. a sausage factory, the activities must also be approved by the authorities.

questions.question: Small birds flying in a grocery store cause no harm as long as regular cleaning is carried out.
questions.description: Small birds must be prevented from entering food premises. They are a hygiene hazard.

questions.question: Kitchen surfaces and work stations must be washed once a day after one's work shift is over.
questions.description: Surfaces and work stations must always be cleaned properly fter every step or part of work and always whenever it is considered necessary based on visual information. A full cleaning and washing of these areas as well as floors and waste bins after emptying them must be done after the work shift is over, and more times if necessary.

questions.question: The slow cooling of food is one of the main causes of food poisoning.
questions.description: The slower food is cooled to under 8 degrees Celsius, the longer food poisoning causing microbes have time to reproduce quickly in optimal conditions. Food should be cooled to under 8 degrees in under 4 hours. When preparing large amounts of food at the same time, the cooling can take too long.

questions.question: Dirty root vegetables can be stored in cardboard boxes above meat products on cold room shelves.
questions.description: Dirt always contains many microbes. Dirty root vegetables must be handled separately from other products so that the microbes in the dirt do not spread to other food products.

questions.question: During food preparation one can sometimes go wash one's hands in the staff restroom.
questions.description: There must be a separate hand washing spot in immediate proximity to the food preparation area.

questions.question: Wounds on the hands should be covered with both a bandage and a single-use glove.
questions.description: When both a bandage and a single-use glove are used, the wound is protected well enough and is also made more waterproof.

questions.question: Organic food does not cause food poisoning as easily as "normal" food.
questions.description: Organic food is produced without fertilizers or pesticides. This does not affect food poisoning almost at all. The risk for food poisoning is the same between "normal" and organic food.

questions.question: Cleaning equipment must be cleaned once a week.
questions.description: Cleaning equipment must be cleaned after each use and must then be left to dry.

questions.question: A disinfectant detergent never needs to be replaced.
questions.description: It is possible for a disinfectant detergent to become ineffective against certain bacteria, and it is therefore important to change the detergent regularly.

questions.question: EHEC bacteria are intestinal bacteria.
questions.description: EHEC bacteria is found especially in the intestines of cattle. EHEC bacteria create toxins in the intestines of humans. The toxin often causes bloody diarrhea and very uncomfortable stomache pains.

questions.question: Food products can be used safely after the use-by date if they do not look or smell bad.
questions.description: Perished or contaminated products are not always possible to notice just by using the senses (visually etc.) Easily perishable food products' packages have a use-by date marked on them, and after this date has passed the product must not be used or sold.

questions.question: Listeria is destroyed when a product is heated to over 70 degrees Celsius.
questions.description: Because listeria is destroyed during heating, products that are not heated are risk food products: vacuum-packed and protective gas packed fish, meat and blue cheese and normal cheese produced from non-pasteurized milk.

questions.question: If there are other companies working in the same estate, then the food production area needs a waste disposal area separate from the other companies' areas.
questions.description: Waste disposal areas can be the same with other companies but the own-check plan's waste disposal instructions must show if the waste disposal and its contract only cover the food production area or the entire estate.

questions.question: Some viruses can last and stay reproductive in water.
questions.description: Viruses can not reproduce in water. However, they can remain able to reproduce later on for a long time while in water.

questions.question: Cooked and uncooked products should always be handled on different working surfaces and with different equipment.
questions.description: Microbes will spread to cooked products if they are handled with the same equipment or on the same surfaces as raw products.

questions.question: Coffee cream and milk may be stored in room temperature, because they will be added to hot coffee.
questions.description: Milk and cream are easily perishable food products, and they must be served cold.

questions.question: Bacteria in our environment can not be seen with the bare eye.
questions.description: Single bacteria can not be seen without using a microscope.

questions.question: Moulds and yeasts can reproduce in more acidized environments than bacteria.
questions.description: Most bacteria reproduce the best in the neutral zone. Moulds and yeasts can reproduce on a very broad pH zone, including products with acidity.

questions.question: Foreign frozen raspberries can be served without heating because the freezing destroys any possible disease causers.
questions.description: Foreign frozen raspberries must always be heated properly (boiling for 5 minutes) before serving because they may contain the norovirus. Freezing does not destroy disease causers that have gotten into the food product before freezing, because viruses stay able to spread for a long time in different conditions.

questions.question: Detergents (washing chemicals) must always be stored in their original packages.
questions.description: Only the original packages can be used to make sure that the correct detergent is being used for the situation.

questions.question: Bacteria spores are destroyed during sterilization.
questions.description: During sterilization (e.g. during canned food production) all microbes and bacteria spores are destroyed. This way easily perishable products will be able to last long in room temperature.

questions.question: Beer is produced with the help of beneficial microbes.
questions.description: Beer is produced with yeast fermentation. Yeast is also used when producing wine.

questions.question: Thawing frozen products in cold rooms or refrigerators is a hygienic risk because the thawing happens too slowly.
questions.description: If food products are thawed in room temperature, the products' surfaces will melt quicker than the insides. The surfaces will start to spoil even though the insides can still be frozen. Thawing in cold rooms takes a longer amount of time but the cold room's temperature will allow very few microbes to reproduce.

questions.question: Additives may be used in all food products.
questions.description: Only approved additives can be used in the preparation of food products. Additives must undergo a thorough safety assessment before they are approved for use.

questions.question: Own-check plans must not be changed.
questions.description: Own-check plans must be updated when changes happen in the workplace.

questions.question: The placement of biowaste bins outside a restaurant does not matter as long as they are not close to an entrance.
questions.description: A waste room's  or recycling area's biowaste bins must be covered from the sun and placed such that pests do not get to them.

questions.question: A disinfectant detergent never needs to be replaced.
questions.description: It is possible for a disinfectant detergent to become ineffective against certain bacteria, and it is therefore important to change the detergent regularly.

questions.question: Staphylococcus aureus is a food poisoning bacteria.
questions.description: The human skin, nose and mucous membranes can contain staphylococcus aureus. Good hand hygiene is important due to this.

questions.question: If an employee has infected wounds on his or her hands, he or she must not handle food products.
questions.description: Infected wounds contain large amounts of food poisoning causing Staphylococcus aureus bacteria. It is impossible to constantly prevent the bacteria from spreading to food products.

questions.question: Defrosting frozen foods in room temperature increases the risk of food poisoning.
questions.description: Frozen foods' surfaces will defrost faster than the insides. In room temperature the surfaces will become warm enough for microbes to grow even though the insides might still be frozen.

questions.question: Old and worn cleaning equipment can spread harmful microbes into food premises.
questions.description: It is important to make sure that cleaning equipment is always clean and in good condition.

questions.question: Bacteria spores can not be found inside the cans of canned food.
questions.description: Canned foods are produced with sterilization which destroys all bacteria spores.

questions.question: Bacteria reproduce very quickly in acidized products.
questions.description: Bacteria that are a threat to food product hygiene reproduce the best when in the neutral zone. Bacteria growth especially can be prevented by increasing the acidity of a product.

questions.question: It is not required to change single-use gloves worn on the hands if a phone is answered while wearing them.
questions.description: Only one phase of work can be done while wearing the same single-use gloves. If a phone is answered then the hands must be washed and the gloves must be changed.

questions.question: The proper washing of hands removes all harmful bacteria from the skin.
questions.description: Even proper washing of hands does not remove all bacteria. Small skin damage and undersides of nails affect the amount of bacteria. Hands must be properly washed between different phases of work.

questions.question: All easily perishable food products must be stored in temperatures under 6 degrees Celsius.
questions.description: This statement is correct, but one must notice that raw mince meat requires a storing temperature of at most 4 degrees Celsius, and fish and shellfish even while vacuum-packed must be stored between 0 and 3 degrees Celsius.

questions.question: Lactic acid bacteria often cause food poisoning.
questions.description: Lactic acid bacteria do not cause food poisoning. Lactic acid bacteria are not harmful if used in the treatment of food poisoning, but they have not been scientifically proven to be of any use either.

questions.question: Arriving products and cargo must be checked when received.
questions.description: The quality of arriving products must be checked and the temperatures of easily perishable products must be measured. The results must be written down.

questions.question: Suspicions of food poisoning are not a part of own-check plans because health officials will investigate the cause of disease if necessary.
questions.description: Own-check plans must have clear instructions for dealing with food poisoning cases and suspicions. Responsible people and methods of informing should be explained in the own-check plan.

questions.question: Berry kisels can be stored in room temperature because the sugar prevents the growth of harmful bacteria.
questions.description: Berry kisels must be stored in cool temperatures because they can perish due to the large quantity of water in them. The sugar in kisels does not prevent harmful bacteria from growing because the sugar density is much lower than in e.g. jams or marmelade.

questions.question: When preparing a own-check plan, all essential food product risk monitoring must be explained.
questions.description: It is essential for the plan to think which parts of done activities are ones where microbes can reproduce and how risks will be monitored, as well as what actions must be taken to fix risk situations.

questions.question: Freezing delays food spoilage.
questions.description: Contamination caused by microbes can be delayed by freezing food products, as freezing prevents microbes from growing.

questions.question: Dishes do not need to be pre-washed before being put into a washing machine if the washing temperature is hot enough.
questions.description: Dishes must always be pre-washed before being put into a washing machine. It is important to get rid of protein spots with cool water so that the protein does not stick to the dishes in hot temperatures. The biofilm that the protein creates acts as a living space for microbes.

questions.question: Cooked rice can be cooled in room temperature.
questions.description: Cooked rice is an easily perishable food product. In room temperature the microbes in the rice can reproduce very quickly and cause food poisoning.

questions.question: Yeasts often cause spoilage in acidic food products.
questions.description: Bacteria grow in a more restricted pH range than yeast and mould. Yeasts grow best in food products with a pH of 5.

questions.question: Marinating prevents meat from spoiling.
questions.description: Meat can contain harmful microbes even if it is marinated.

questions.question: Customer feedback is a part of the own-check plan.
questions.description: It is useful to pay attention to appropriate customer feedback when carrying out the own-check plan. Customer feedback can be viewed as a way to enhance quality of service. Feedback should be written down, discussed with the staff and utilized in developing procedures and protocols.

questions.question: The mould used to make mould-ripened cheese cannot grow anywhere else.
questions.description: The mould used to make mould-ripened cheese can grow on other food products. It causes mould to grow on the surfaces of food products that spoils them.

questions.question: Cooked rice is not an easily perishable food product.
questions.description: Dry rice lasts in room temperature. Cooked rice contains moisture and because of this it is an easily perishable product. Cooked rice must be stored under 6 degrees Celsius.

questions.question: Jewellery and watches must be removed from one's hands before washing hands.
questions.description: Jewellery and watches must always be removed before washing. They must also not be used while preparing food because they collect microbes which may travel into the prepared food and cause food poisoning risks.

questions.question: Botulism, a food poisoning caused by clostridium botulinum, is always a very weak food poisoning.
questions.description: Clostridium botulinum creates a very deadly toxin called botulin. The food poisoning caused by botulin can cause death.

questions.question: Sneezing spreads harmful microbes into the surrounding environment in the droplets/spray.
questions.description: There are lots of microbes in the respiratory system and mouth which can spread into the surroundings.

questions.question: Food production employees are allowed to wear colorless nail polish.
questions.description: Hands must not containt anything extra such as watches, jewellery, fake nails, nail polish or hand cream.

questions.question: Salmonella infections always cause severe symptoms. In other words it is impossible for the person carrying the salmonella to not know about it.
questions.description: It is possible for salmonella infections to not be noticed. One might not notice the infection at all, but can still spread the salmonella to others. In practice salmonella can only be spread if one's hands are not washed well after going to the toilet.

questions.question: Food poisoning causing bacteria can not be found naturally.
questions.description: Microbes are everywhere: in the air, water, earth, plants, animals and humans. Some of these microbes cause food poisoning.

questions.question: Disinfectants only work if the concentration is correct and they are left to work for the correct period of time.
questions.description: The effectiveness of a disinfectant depends on issues such as the concentration, how long it is left to work and the temperature of the solution.

questions.question: A porcelain plate that is chipped is a hygiene hazard.
questions.description: Only use dishes that have an undamaged surface.

questions.question: Beneficial microbes cannot be used in the production of cream cheese.
questions.description: Cream cheese is made using beneficial microbes.

questions.question: A bar of soap is unhygienic when used by staff in food premises.
questions.description: It is recommended to use liquid soap to wash your hands. A bar of soap is not hygienic enough.

questions.question: Unprepared root vegetables can temporarily be stored in a cleaning supply closet or another spacious place.
questions.description: Food products cannot be stored in places that are not meant for that purpose.

questions.question: The own-check plan only refers to measuring and recording temperatures.
questions.description: The purpose of the own-check plan is to help operators to manage the risks associated with food hygiene. Measuring and recording temperatures is an important part of the own-check system. Other areas of the own-check system include cleaning and tidiness as well as hygienic skills of the staff.

questions.question: A frozen product may be defrosted in room temperature if the product is needed quickly.
questions.description: Frozen products are always to be defrosted in coolers. If defrosting must be sped up, one can use the defrosting option on a microwave or the product can be kept in its packaging under cold running water.

questions.question: Sterilizing only destroys microbes capable of reproducing.
questions.description: Sterilizing destroys reproductive spores as well as bacteria spores. Canned foods are produced with sterilization.

questions.question: Bacillus cereus is not a food poisoning causing bacteria.
questions.description: Bacillus cereus is a food poisoning causing bacteria. Risk food products for this are e.g. raw milk and rice.

questions.question: Dirty root vegetables can be handled in the same area where desserts are produced.
questions.description: Dirt always contains many microbes. Dirty root vegetables must be handled separately from other products so that the microbes in the dirt do not spread to other food products.

questions.question: Frozen foods can be defrosted on a kitchen table if the liquid from the melting does not pour onto the table.
questions.description: All frozen foods must be defrosted in cold storage units. When defrosting, one must make sure that the defrosting product does not pour liquid onto any other food products placed or stored in the cold storage unit. Defrosted or just partially defrosted products can not be frozen again.

questions.question: Dirty root vegetables must have a separate work space.
questions.description: Dirt always contains many microbes. Dirty root vegetables must be handled separately from other products so that the microbes in the dirt do not spread to other food products.

questions.question: If the film/foil of a vacuum-package is loose or tensionless the package is damaged.
questions.description: The package has probably been broken and air has entered it. The lastingness of the product can not be estimated after this, because the use-by-date marked on the package is based on the assumption that the package contains no air (oxygen that microbes can use to grow.)

questions.question: A tool made of wood is a hygiene hazard.
questions.description: Wood is a porous material and can absorb water, dirt and detergents, and it can stay damp for a long time.

questions.question: Dirty root vegetables can be stored in cardboard boxes above meat products on cold room shelves.
questions.description: Dirt always contains many microbes. Dirty root vegetables must be handled separately from other products so that the microbes in the dirt do not spread to other food products.

questions.question: Food products containing preservatives never spoil.
questions.description: Preservatives only slow down the spoiling done by microbes.

questions.question: A microbiological sample of a food product can be placed in any container.
questions.description: A microbiological sample of a food product must always be placed in a container that is definitely clean.

questions.question: When a food industry workplace, e.g. a sausage factory, is being founded, the workplace must only inform local food control authorities about the activities.
questions.description: When a food industry workplace, e.g. a sausage factory, is being founded, an approval for the activities by local food control authorities is required.

questions.question: Food products can be sold after the last use-by-date if it is sold at a discount price.
questions.description: The last use-by-date must be marked on easily perishable food products. The products can not be used nor sold after this date.

questions.question: The same cleaning equipment can be used in both dining areas and food preparation areas.
questions.description: Kitchen facilities and customer areas must have separate cleaning equipment in order to avoid possible disease agents from transferring from one space to the other via cleaning supplies, such as table wiping rags.

questions.question: Oiva-reports must be placed at the entrance of the café, restaurant etc. so that customers can read them.
questions.description: Oiva-reports are published documents about routine inspections. These reports are also published online at www.oivahymy.fi

questions.question: Bacterial spores are more resistant than bacteria.
questions.description: When bacteria are in an environment where they cannot grow as easily, they turn into spores. Spores are more resistant than bacteria to heat and drought, for example.

questions.question: Salmonella bacteria can be found in fowl or poultry.
questions.description: Salmonella can be found in fowl or poultry. Due to the risk of salmonella, the meat of fowl/poultry must always be cooked to at least 75 degrees Celsius.

questions.question: The temperatures of cold storage equipment do not need to be measured if they feel cold enough.
questions.description: The temperatures of refrigerating equipment, drawers and cabinets must be measured and logged at the same time each day. Atypical measuring results are logged in the own-check forms and necessary measures are taken to restore the right temperature in that piece of equipment.

questions.question: During food preparation one can sometimes go wash one's hands in the staff restroom.
questions.description: There must be a separate hand washing spot in immediate proximity to the food preparation area.

questions.question: When roasting or cooking insects, there is no need to be especially careful.
questions.description: When insects are processed, they must be handled in the same way as other perishable food products.

questions.question: Food production employees are allowed to wear colorless nail polish.
questions.description: Hands must not containt anything extra such as watches, jewellery, fake nails, nail polish or hand cream.

questions.question: Detergents (washing chemicals) must always be stored in their original packages.
questions.description: Only the original packages can be used to make sure that the correct detergent is being used for the situation.

questions.question: Raw and cooked produce should not be handled at the same time or with the same utensils.
questions.description: Raw and cooked produce should be stored and handled separately. Surfaces should be properly cleaned in between handling raw and cooked produce. Unhygienic cleaning equipment can also contaminate the kitchen surfaces and cause microbes to spread. This type of spreading of microbes is called cross contamination.

questions.question: The acidity of food products affects the reproduction of bacteria in the products.
questions.description: Increasing the acidity of a food product makes it harder for many harmful microbes to reproduce. Because of this, lactic acid fermentation is a good traditional way to store e.g. vegetables. The fermentation is based on how lactic acid works. Lactic acid bacteria (LAB) is a good example of beneficial microbes, which has good health benefits. All microbes are thus not harmful for food products.

questions.question: Bacteria spores will stay alive even when a product is dried.
questions.description: Spores are the form of bacteria that will last. Spores are able to endure dryness, boiling, salting and the cold. Bacteria can not reproduce in dry products but they will survive as spores.

questions.question: When a new detergent is introduced into a kitchen, the cleaning plan in the own-check plan is updated.
questions.description: It is important that the own-check plan is always up to date. All changes to the own-check plan, e.g. introduction of a new detergent, must be updated in the cleaning plan.

questions.question: Heating food to 75 degrees Celsius or more is enough to destroy salmonella.
questions.description: Salmonella will be destroyed in heat treatment when food is heated to at least 75 degrees Celsius.

questions.question: Salmonella infections always cause severe symptoms. In other words it is impossible for the person carrying the salmonella to not know about it.
questions.description: It is possible for salmonella infections to not be noticed. One might not notice the infection at all, but can still spread the salmonella to others. In practice salmonella can only be spread if one's hands are not washed well after going to the toilet.

questions.question: Sour milk spoils faster than milk.
questions.description: The pH value of milk is 7, which means it is neutral. The pH value of sour milk is lower, which means sour milk is acidized. It is harder for bacteria to reproduce in acidized milk products than in neutral products.

questions.question: All E-numbered additives improve the lastingness of food products.
questions.description: Food products can be made to last longer by adding preservatives to them. In the European Union, allowed preservatives have an E-number: for example, E 200 is sorbic acid and E 296 is malic acid. Preservatives that are allowed can be found, along with other additives, in an E-number list. Some preservatives can be found naturally in berries and fruits, such as in lingonberries and citrus fruit. E-numbers are also used to identify additives other than ones that improve lastingness. For example, color additives do not improve the lastingness of food products.

questions.question: Bacteria in our environment can not be seen with the bare eye.
questions.description: Single bacteria can not be seen without using a microscope.

questions.question: Waste does not cause a hygiene risk because it is stored in separate containers.
questions.description: Bad waste management hygiene or food products getting into contact with waste can cause hygiene risks.

questions.question: Protective gloves are used to protect employees' hands from dirt, so that their hands do not need to be washed as often.
questions.description: Gloves are also used to protect food from microbes spread by hands. Gloves are a great way to keep work hygiene good when tasks must be changed quickly. Gloves must be changed regularly enough while working to keep hygiene good. It is also good to properly wash and dry one's hands when changing gloves. Gloves must always be changed immediately after touching door handles or taps.

questions.question: All food that is being served needs to be sampled daily.
questions.description: Taken samples must be placed into a container and then placed into a freezer. If food poisonings are suspected, then these samples must be available for research.

questions.question: Dirty root vegetables and pre-made food products can be stored in the same cold room.
questions.description: Dirt always contains many microbes. Dirty root vegetables must be handled separately from other products so that the microbes in the dirt do not spread to other food products.

questions.question: Waste bins in food premises may contain microbes that are a health hazard.
questions.description: It is important to make sure that waste bins are regularly emptied and that they are clean by washing them with appropriate detergents.

questions.question: All monitoring logs made for own-check plans must be stored for at least a year at the workplace.
questions.description: Only stored monitoring logs can prove that the own-check plan has been adhered to.

questions.question: There are no microbes in dried food products.
questions.description: Dried products last well due to having no water that bacteria could use to reproduce. However, the microbes have not been destroyed in dried products and the products can contain spores of bacteria, moulds or yeast.

questions.question: Food products are always safe if the best before date has not yet expired.
questions.description: A food product may be contaminated even if there are still several days until the best before date. Contamination may be caused by unhygienic tools or work environment and incorrect temperatures, for example.

questions.question: Vegetables and fruit must be washed prior to food preparation with water that meets the requirements of household water.
questions.description: Taps in any food preparation space must provide water that meets the requirements of household water, which is used in preparing and making food as well as by staff to wash their hands.

questions.question: Food production areas do not need a written cleaning plan if the procedures have been discussed carefully with the personnel and everyone knows their tasks.
questions.description: The cleaning and washing program always needs to be part of the food production area's own-check plan. The own-check plan is produced on paper before starting activities in the food production area.

questions.question: Working areas and surfaces must be cleaned regularly during work shifts and after work is over.
questions.description: Regular cleaning, done every 2-4 hours, of working equipment and surfaces with clean cleaning equipment, substances and water gets rid of leftover pieces of food, dust and other dirt that protects microorganisms and is used as living space by the organisms.

questions.question: BSE is also called mad cow's disease.
questions.description: Mad cow's disease is sometimes found in old cows. During slaughtering the carcasses must be checked so that contaminated meat is not used.

questions.question: You can wear disposable gloves instead of washing your hands when preparing food in a restaurant tent.
questions.description: Washing your hands thoroughly and often enough is the basis for safe food handling and general hygiene, and it is important to also wear disposable gloves, for example.

questions.question: Only old cold storage equipment must have a thermometer.
questions.description: All cold storage equipment in food production areas must have a thermometer.

questions.question: Wastebins do not need to be cleaned.
questions.description: Wastebins must not be broken, must include a lid and must also be cleaned regularly.

questions.question: Domestic water pollution is often caused by human faeces.
questions.description: Norovirus and Campylobacter enter the domestic water supply mainly through municipal wastewater, and Campylobacter also through animal faeces. Inadequate dosing of disinfectant chemicals can also cause contamination.

questions.question: Cleaning equipment do not need a separate storage area.
questions.description: It's not always necessary to have a separate storage space for cleaning equipment. Food production areas need a separate storage, maintenance and drying space if the food production area requires it for constructional reasons. It's important to make sure that there are no risks for food safety and the hygienic treatment, maintenance and storage of cleaning equipment are done properly. If necessary the working stages and functions has to be separated structually or timely.

questions.question: Cooling cabinets are used only for cooling food.
questions.description: Food should be cooled to less than 6 degrees Celsius within only 4 hours. When the products have been cooled they should be moved into another cold storage unit. Cooling cabinets are only used for cooling food (not storing.)

questions.question: All cold storage equipment must have a thermometer.
questions.description: Own-check plans require to monitor the temperature of cold storage equipment. If the equipment does not thermometers, the monitoring is impossible to do.

questions.question: High salt content prevents harmful microbes from multiplying in a product
questions.description: Strong salting of a product changes the state of its water so that microbes can not reproduce. However, salted products such as mushrooms must still be stored in cool temperatures to prevent microbes on their surface from perishing them.

questions.question: The own-check plan only refers to measuring and recording temperatures.
questions.description: The purpose of the own-check plan is to help operators to manage the risks associated with food hygiene. Measuring and recording temperatures is an important part of the own-check system. Other areas of the own-check system include cleaning and tidiness as well as hygienic skills of the staff.

questions.question: Frozen fish is thawed on the kitchen counter.
questions.description: Frozen food products are always thawed in a cold room.

questions.question: Norovirus is not spread in water.
questions.description: Norovirus infection can also be acquired from contaminated water.

questions.question: Food products are allowed to freeze during transport and this does not cause any harm.
questions.description: Food must not be frozen during transport as this will impair the hygienic quality of the food products. Perishable food products that require cold storage are transported in temperatures that do not exceed those set for storing perishable food products.

questions.question: The most hygienic way to dry your hands is to use a cloth towel.
questions.description: The most hygienic way to dry your hands is to use disposable hand towels.

questions.question: All monitoring logs made for own-check plans must be stored for at least a year at the workplace.
questions.description: Only stored monitoring logs can prove that the own-check plan has been adhered to.

questions.question: Vegetables stored in a vinegared liquid can be kept in room temperature.
questions.description: Sterilized, can-packed and unopened vinegared products can be stored in room temperature. Vinegared products will last long due to the high acidity, but opened packages must be stored in cool temperatures.

questions.question: A food poisoning epidemic is a situation where at least 10 people have become sick with similar symptoms after consuming the same food product or ingredient.
questions.description: A food poisoning epidemic means a situation where at least 2 people have become sick with similar symptoms after consuming the same food or drink.

questions.question: The placement of biowaste bins outside a restaurant does not matter as long as they are not close to an entrance.
questions.description: A waste room's  or recycling area's biowaste bins must be covered from the sun and placed such that pests do not get to them.

questions.question: Water is not necessary for microbes to reproduce.
questions.description: Dried products last well due to having no water that bacteria could use to reproduce. Microbes can't reproduce in dried products.

questions.question: Beneficial microbes cannot be used in the production of cream cheese.
questions.description: Cream cheese is made using beneficial microbes.

questions.question: When washing dishes, the prewashing must not be done with hot water.
questions.description: Prewashing must be done with cool-temperatured water. Too hot water can burn albumin spots onto the surface of the dish and create biofilm, which is a suitable growing environment for microbes.

questions.question: The results in Oiva-reports are not allowed to be read by customers.
questions.description: Municipality food control authorities do routine inspections at workplaces. Oiva-reports are published documents about these inspections.

questions.question: Cleaning equipment must be cleaned once a week.
questions.description: Cleaning equipment must be cleaned after each use and must then be left to dry.

questions.question: Production of cheese uses beneficial microbes.
questions.description: Clean, controlled and beneficial microbes are used in cheeses. During storage these microbes will create taste ingredients in the cheese.

questions.question: EHEC bacteria are intestinal bacteria.
questions.description: EHEC bacteria is found especially in the intestines of cattle. EHEC bacteria create toxins in the intestines of humans. The toxin often causes bloody diarrhea and very uncomfortable stomache pains.

questions.question: The purpose of own-check plans is to prevent mistakes and problematic situations from occurring during food preparation and serving.
questions.description: Good own-check plans as well as good knowledge of the own-check plan's contents by the personnel prevents problematic situations and makes it easier to identify the causes of any noticed problems.

questions.question: Waste does not cause a hygiene risk because it is stored in separate containers.
questions.description: Bad waste management hygiene or food products getting into contact with waste can cause hygiene risks.

questions.question: Vacuum-packages have the air removed from them.
questions.description: Vacuum-packages do not include any air and prevent microbes that require oxygen from reproducing.

questions.question: Bacteria toxins disappear when food is boiled.
questions.description: Some bacteria cause toxins in the food. If toxins have appeared in the food, they weill not disappear during boiling.

questions.question: EHEC bacteria are intestinal bacteria of cattle.
questions.description: This intestinal bacteria can only found in food products if the work hygiene is not proper during milking or slaughtering.

questions.question: A product can not be used for food preparation after the product's best-before date.
questions.description: Best before dates tell that the product's main attributes and characteristics will remain the same up to the marked date, as long as it is stored correctly. The product can be used and sold after the best before date. The usability and quality of the product can be checked using the senses (visually etc.) after the best before date.

questions.question: Food must not be served heated for over 2 hours.
questions.description: Food served / sold hot may be kept in a temperature-controlled bath (min +60 degrees) for a maximum of four hours, after which the food must be replaced.

questions.question: It is enough to visually monitor the results of cleaning and washing.
questions.description: The results of cleaning and washing and the need for cleaning needs to be monitored regularly. It is required to name a responsible person for this task in the own-check plan and to form a monitoring plan to use. As well as doing visual inspections, the monitoring can also be done by taking microbiological samples from work surfaces and equipment by for example using Hygicult sample strips.

questions.question: Pet dogs can not be taken inside a café even with the permission of the owner of the café.
questions.description: If the owner gives permission, a pet dog can be taken inside the customer areas of a café. Guide dogs are always allowed inside customer areas, even without asking for permission.

questions.question: You are allowed to use snus (nuuska in Finnish) while preparing food.
questions.description: The use of snus (nuuska in Finnish) is prohibited while preparing food.

questions.question: Washed, clean dishes can only be handled with clean hands.
questions.description: If clean dishes are handled with dirty hands, microbes and dirt will spread from the hands onto the dishes.

questions.question: When you clean a refrigerator, you only need to wipe away visible dirt as microbes do not multiply in such a cold place.
questions.description: Refrigerators must be cleaned regularly with appropriate detergents. Some microbes thrive and even grow at the refrigerator temperature.

questions.question: The use of snus (similar to chewing tobacco) is not allowed during food preparation.
questions.description: When handling food products personal hygiene is important; snus must not be used because of hygienic reasons.

questions.question: In Finland the milk found in cartons in stores is rarely pasteurized.
questions.description: In Finland the milk found in cartons in stores is almost always pasteurized milk. Only raw milk that has been bought directly from a dairy farm is not usually pasteurized.

questions.question: If a salmonella infection is asymptomatic, it cannot spread into handled food products via an employee.
questions.description: A salmonella infection can spread even if the person who carries it has no symptoms. This is why it is important to have a salmonella test before the employment starts.

questions.question: Intestinal bacteria can spread from hands to food.
questions.description: Intestinal bacteria can spread to food even from the hands.

questions.question: Salmonella infections can be symptomless.
questions.description: It is possible for salmonella infections to not be noticed. One might not notice the infection at all, but can still spread the salmonella to others. In practice salmonella can only be spread if one's hands are not washed well after going to the toilet.

questions.question: Own-check plans must include clear instructions on how to act when food poisoning suspicions are raised.
questions.description: When food is prepared for customers, food poisoning events must be planned for in advance. Own-check plans must include clear instructions for these events. It is important to notify health inspectors about suspicions immediately.

questions.question: BSE, also called mad cow's disease, is a food poisoning causing bacteria.
questions.description: BSE is not a food poisoning causing bacteria. BSE is caused by changes in the central nervous system of cows.

questions.question: If an easily perishable food product has been stored in too warm conditions, the product can still be stored until the use-by-date.
questions.description: The use-by-date is reliable only if the product has been stored correctly. Storing products in too warm conditions always makes the products last for shorter periods of times.

questions.question: If the dry storage rooms has no space elsewhere, food products can be stored on the floor of the room for a short time.
questions.description: Food products can not be stored on the floor even for a short time.

questions.question: You can leave your rings on your fingers while you wash your hands.
questions.description: A lot of dirt and microbes live under rings, which means that rings must be removed before washing your hands.

questions.question: Handling money can transfer harmful microbes into food products.
questions.description: Money and easily perishable unpackaged food products should not be handled simultanously, as money can have microbes in it that jeopardize food hygiene.

questions.question: You can touch the inside surfaces of food packaging if you have just washed your hands.
questions.description: You should always try not to touch the inside surfaces of food packaging.

questions.question: Moulds can not create mould toxins.
questions.description: Some moulds can create mould toxins such as mycotoxins and aflatoxins. Because of this mouldy products should not be used.

questions.question: Due to salmonella risks, fowl and poultry meat must always be heated thoroughly to over 75 degrees Celsius.
questions.description: Fowl/poultry can contain salmonella naturally. Salmonella bacteria must be alive to cause an illness. The meat of fowl/poultry is safe if it is heated thoroughly to over 75 degrees Celsius.

questions.question: Useful microbes are used in baking.
questions.description: Yeast is used in baking to make dough rise.

questions.question: Botulism, a food poisoning caused by clostridium botulinum, can be lethal.
questions.description: Clostridium botulinum creates a very deadly toxin called botulin. The food poisoning caused by botulin can cause death.

questions.question: The washing and treatment of vegetables worsens their lastingness.
questions.description: For example, carrots that have not been treated will last for weeks when properly stored, but when they have been washed, peeled and grated they become an easily perishable product.

questions.question: Chefs can use their work shoes during their travel to and from their workplace.
questions.description: Work shoes must not be worn outside the workplace to prevent microbes from spreading into the food production area.

questions.question: Pet dogs can be taken inside a café with the permission of the owner of the café.
questions.description: If the owner gives permission, a pet dog can be taken inside the customer areas of a café.

questions.question: Campylo bacteria is destroyed when a product is heated properly.
questions.description: Campylo bacteria and salmonella are found naturally in fowl and poultry. Both bacteria are destroyed when the meat is cooked thoroughly to over 75 degrees Celsius.

questions.question: Food production areas' food waste must be stored in cool temperatures if possible.
questions.description: Food waste should be stored in cold areas specifically meant for the waste if it is possible. However, it is rare to have so many cold areas that they can also be used separately for waste.

questions.question: A bar of soap is unhygienic when used by staff in food premises.
questions.description: It is recommended to use liquid soap to wash your hands. A bar of soap is not hygienic enough.

questions.question: Food product stores do not require an own-check plan.
questions.description: All workplaces in the food industry need to ensure the safety of their products with an own-check plan. Own-check plans are required in all food industry workplaces.

questions.question: Food production areas need to have a changing room.
questions.description: Employees need a changing room which has a separate storage space for clean work clothes.

questions.question: Sour milk spoils faster than milk.
questions.description: The pH value of milk is 7, which means it is neutral. The pH value of sour milk is lower, which means sour milk is acidized. It is harder for bacteria to reproduce in acidized milk products than in neutral products.

questions.question: Only reproductive microbes are destroyed during sterilization. Bacteria spores are not destroyed.
questions.description: During sterilization (e.g. during canned food production) all microbes and bacteria spores are destroyed. This way easily perishable products will be able to last long in room temperature.

questions.question: Own-check plans must not be changed.
questions.description: Own-check plans must be updated when changes happen in the workplace.

questions.question: The incorrect storing temperature of food is a major cause for food poisoning.
questions.description: If food is stored in too warm temperatures, microbes that cause food poisoning will reproduce quickly. Because of this the temperatures of cold storage units and freezers must be monitored regularly using thermometers.

questions.question: The own-check system involves monitoring how quickly food products cool down to storage temperature.
questions.description: Monitoring temperatures is an important part of the own-check system.

questions.question: It is not required to change single-use gloves worn on the hands if money is handled while wearing them.
questions.description: Only one phase of work can be done while wearing the same single-use gloves. If money is handled then the hands must be washed and the gloves must be changed.

questions.question: Guide dogs are allowed inside food product stores.
questions.description: Guide dogs are always allowed in areas meant for customers. However, no animals can be taken inside food product handling areas or storage areas.

questions.question: Vegetables and fruit must be washed prior to food preparation with water that meets the requirements of household water.
questions.description: Taps in any food preparation space must provide water that meets the requirements of household water, which is used in preparing and making food as well as by staff to wash their hands.

questions.question: Food products stored in protective gas do not have to be stored in the cold.
