questions.description: Protective gas protects a food product's surface from drying up and enzymic darkening, but the products must still be stored in the cold just like similar products with no protective gas.

questions.question: Mould and bacterial spores can also be found in dry food products.
questions.description: Spores are more resistant than bacteria to their surrounding conditions, especially heat, drought and chemical agents.

questions.question: Waiters and servers are not required to have headwear.
questions.description: Waiters and servers are allowed to work without headwear.

questions.question: Food tasting must be done with a spoon.
questions.description: Food must never be touched with the fingers if it is not necessary. Spoons should be used for tasting.

questions.question: Heat and humidity accelerate vegetable spoilage.
questions.description: The correct storage temperatures and moisture affect the shelf life of vegetables.

questions.question: The slime that appears on the surface of meat products is caused by harmful microbes.
questions.description: Some harmful microbes produce slime. For example, slime appearing on the surface of a sausage is a sign of it perishing. Slime-producing microbes reproduce quickly in food products e.g. when the product is stored or served in too high temperatures.

questions.question: Cold storage units should not be filled beyond their set fill limits because the food products might not stay cold enough.
questions.description: The fill limit is an instruction on usage by the producer of the cold storage unit. The limit should not be crossed because food products outside the limit will not stay cold enough.

questions.question: Frozen vegetables may contain listeria bacteria.
questions.description: Listeria can be found in unheated food products such as fresh vegetables and products made from these.

questions.question: Raw milk can contain yersinia.
questions.description: Raw milk has not been pasteurized. Yersinia is destroyed when milk is heated to over 70 degrees Celsius; in other words it is destroyed when the milk is pasteurized.

questions.question: The contents of a bulged can of food can be used for food preparation if the product is properly heated.
questions.description: All causes of food poisoning are not eliminated by heating. The contents of a bulged (ie. faulty) can of food must be discarded.

questions.question: Food poisoning causing bacteria are found naturally.
questions.description: Microbes are everywhere: in the air, water, earth, plants, animals and humans. Some of these microbes cause food poisoning.

questions.question: The toxins contained in fresh morel mushrooms can not be removed by only roasting the mushrooms.
questions.description: Morel mushrooms must be boiled twice for at least 5 minutes and washed thoroughly between the boilings.

questions.question: If an employee has inflamed wounds on their hands, they must not handle easily perishable food products.
questions.description: A person with inflamed wounds or other inflamed areas on their hands or other visible skin must not handle unpacked food products. Small wounds in the hands must be cleaned and protected with a water-proof bandage, and single-use gloves must be used.

questions.question: Guide dogs are allowed inside food product stores.
questions.description: Guide dogs are always allowed in areas meant for customers. However, no animals can be taken inside food product handling areas or storage areas.

questions.question: A disinfectant detergent never needs to be replaced.
questions.description: It is possible for a disinfectant detergent to become ineffective against certain bacteria, and it is therefore important to change the detergent regularly.

questions.question: Cooked rice left at room temperature is a good breeding ground for various microbes.
questions.description: Bacillus cereus is one of the bacteria that causes food poisoning; it cannot be completely stopped from spreading to food products. Bacillus cereus is found in almost all food products. It is most commonly spread through rice dishes and vegetables.

questions.question: After washing dishes must be dry before they can be piled for storing.
questions.description: Harmful microbes multiply in damp conditions, so dishes must be allowed to fully dry before piling.

questions.question: Food production employees are only allowed to wear their work outfit at their workplace, the food production area.
questions.description: The work outfit can only be worn inside the food production area; this prevents microbes from spreading into the area from the clothes.

questions.question: Raw milk contains less microbes than pasteurized milk.
questions.description: When milk is pasteurized a large amount of microbes gets destroyed. For example listeria, salmonella and EHEC bacteria are destroyed during pasteurization. The bacteria in raw milk have not been destroyed with heat treatment.

questions.question: Working areas and equipment must always be cleaned by using plenty of water.
questions.description: Water is an important part of cleaning and washing. Water acts as a solvent and substance that transports dirt away. However it is also important to dry the surfaces and equipment properly, because microbes grow and reproduce easily in moist environments.

questions.question: Waste bins can be placed in the dry food storage room if there is no other place for them.
questions.description: The waste management of food premises must be arranged so that waste and food products do not come into contact with each other.

questions.question: Cleaning equipment storage rooms must be cleaned regularly.
questions.description: All parts of a food production area must be cleaned regularly according to the cleaning plan.

questions.question: Microbes reproduce in dry products.
questions.description: Microbes need water to reproduce. Microbes will not reproduce in dried products but dried products can contain spores of bacteria, moulds or yeast.

questions.question: Some toxins produced by moulds in food will withstand heating and cause food poisoning even though the mould itself can get destroyed.
questions.description: Mould toxins can withstand much higher temperatures than the mould itself.

questions.question: Food products that have been thawed only once can be refrozen as long as they are packed in hygienic packaging.
questions.description: You must never refreeze food products that have already been thawed.

questions.question: Food products must never be cooled or stored outside.
questions.description: Food products must not be cooled or stored outside. All equipment and products, e.g. boxes containg baked goods, must be stored inside.

questions.question: Food must not be served heated for over 2 hours.
questions.description: Food served / sold hot may be kept in a temperature-controlled bath (min +60 degrees) for a maximum of four hours, after which the food must be replaced.

questions.question: Heat and humidity accelerate vegetable spoilage.
questions.description: The correct storage temperatures and moisture affect the shelf life of vegetables.

questions.question: Milk can be stored at room temperature during the breakfast service.
questions.description: Milk and cream are perishable food products and they must be served cold.

questions.question: Temperature affects the speed of microbe reproduction.
questions.description: Temperatures are very important for the reproduction abilities of microbes. All microbes have their own optimal temperatures where reproduction is the fastest.

questions.question: Hard rye bread (crisp bread) is not an easily perishable food product.
questions.description: Hard rye bread is a dry food product, and because of this microbes can not reproduce in it. Hard rye bread can be stored in room temperature.

questions.question: You can wear disposable gloves instead of washing your hands when preparing food in a restaurant tent.
questions.description: Washing your hands thoroughly and often enough is the basis for safe food handling and general hygiene, and it is important to also wear disposable gloves, for example.

questions.question: Any water can be used for washing potatoes as they have soil on them.
questions.description: Potatoes must always be washed with water that meets the requirements for domestic water.

questions.question: Listeria bacteria are not destroyed when a product is frozen.
questions.description: Freezing does not destroy microbes. Listeria can also reproduce in frozen foods.

questions.question: Salmonella bacteria can be found in fowl or poultry.
questions.description: Salmonella can be found in fowl or poultry. Due to the risk of salmonella, the meat of fowl/poultry must always be cooked to at least 75 degrees Celsius.

questions.question: Raw and cooked food products must always have separate cold storage spaces.
questions.description: If only one cold-store is available, raw products are placed on the lower shelves and cooked ones on the top shelves in order to avoid risking contamination.

questions.question: Bacteria are always harmful on human skin or in the intestines.
questions.description: Beneficial bacteria exist on the skin and in the intestines that protect humans from harmful bacteria and strengthen the immune system.

questions.question: A food manufacturer is responsible for date labelling (best before date or use by date).
questions.description: A food manufacturer or packer is responsible for correct date labelling.

questions.question: Bacteria spores are not destroyed during boiling.
questions.description: Bacteria spores are destroyed only during sterilization. In excess pressure the temperature is raised to about 145 degrees Celsius and this way bacteria spores are also destroyed.

questions.question: The acidity of food products affects the reproduction of bacteria in the products.
questions.description: Increasing the acidity of a food product makes it harder for many harmful microbes to reproduce. Because of this, lactic acid fermentation is a good traditional way to store e.g. vegetables. The fermentation is based on how lactic acid works. Lactic acid bacteria (LAB) is a good example of beneficial microbes, which has good health benefits. All microbes are thus not harmful for food products.

questions.question: Food products containing food poisoning bacteria can always be noticed by bad smells and other visual perishing symptoms.
questions.description: Food poisoning bacteria can not be noticed using the senses (visually etc.) in food products. Perished food products might contain food poisoning bacteria, but the bacteria might not cause any changes in the appearance of the food product.

questions.question: Moulds can not create mould toxins.
questions.description: Some moulds can create mould toxins such as mycotoxins and aflatoxins. Because of this mouldy products should not be used.

questions.question: Food served in a lunch buffet must remain at +60 degrees celsius for the entire duration of the serving.
questions.description: If food that has been prepared by heating or cooking is not served immediately, it must be kept at a temperature of at least 60 degrees throughout the entire serving.

questions.question: Waste bins to be used in kitchens must be water-proof and easily cleanable.
questions.description: Waste bins to be used in kitchens must be water-proof so that waste liquids do not pour onto the floor. They must also be easy to clean so that the cleaning process during emptying is as easy as possible.

questions.question: Minced meat lasts as long as unprepared meat if it is packaged in a vacuum container or vacuum bag.
questions.description: Minced meat requires that it be stored in a maximum temperature of +4 degrees celsius, whereas whole meat can be stored in +6 degrees celsius.

questions.question: Officials will prepare an own-check plan for new companies in the food product industry.
questions.description: Companies in the food product industry must prepare their own own-check plan when starting their activities. The plan must be followed and updated when needed.

questions.question: Workers in the food industry, e.g. the owner of a small café, must inform local food control authorities about their activities.
questions.description: All workers in the food industry must inform food control authorities about their activities. The informing must be done before beginning the activities. When founding a food industry workplace, e.g. a sausage factory, the activities must also be approved by the authorities.

questions.question: Irradiation can be used to destroy microbes in dairy products.
questions.description: Irradiation destroys microbes in dry herbs and spices.

questions.question: Products that have gone through ultra-high-temperature treatment (UHT) can be stored in room temperature.
questions.description: During UHT products are sterilized with quick heating. Unopened packages can be stored in room temperature because most bacteria spores have been destroyed.

questions.question: Sugar can contain microbes.
questions.description: Sugar is dry, so microbes do not grow in it. However, salt can contain spores of bacteria, moulds or yeast.

questions.question: When raw frozen chicken is thawed it releases liquid that can contain salmonella.
questions.description: Raw fowl/poultry meat can always contain salmonella, which will not be destroyed in a freezer. If the meat contains salmonella it will also certainly be in the liquid.

questions.question: Cooked rice left at room temperature is a good breeding ground for various microbes.
questions.description: Bacillus cereus is one of the bacteria that causes food poisoning; it cannot be completely stopped from spreading to food products. Bacillus cereus is found in almost all food products. It is most commonly spread through rice dishes and vegetables.

questions.question: The washing and treatment of vegetables worsens their lastingness.
questions.description: For example, carrots that have not been treated will last for weeks when properly stored, but when they have been washed, peeled and grated they become an easily perishable product.

questions.question: The purpose of the own-check plan is not to manage food-related health hazards.
questions.description: One of the most important objectives of the own-check plan is to manage food-related health hazards.

questions.question: Waste bins can be placed in the dry food storage room if there is no other place for them.
questions.description: The waste management of food premises must be arranged so that waste and food products do not come into contact with each other.

questions.question: The temperatures of cold storage equipment do not need to be measured if they feel cold enough.
questions.description: The temperatures of refrigerating equipment, drawers and cabinets must be measured and logged at the same time each day. Atypical measuring results are logged in the own-check forms and necessary measures are taken to restore the right temperature in that piece of equipment.

questions.question: Microbes can not reproduce in dry products.
questions.description: Microbes need water to reproduce. Microbes will not reproduce in dried products but dried products can contain spores of bacteria, moulds or yeast.

questions.question: Customers and employees must have their own, separate toilets.
questions.description: Strict toilet and hand hygiene must be used in food production. This is not possible if toilets are shared with customers.

questions.question: It is not essential for hygiene whether hands are washed using liquid soap or soap blocks.
questions.description: Soap used for hand washing must be mild so that it will not damage the skin of the hands. The soap must be liquid and the soap dispenser must also be hygienic. Warm water is used for washing, and it is also important to properly dry one's hands after washing them.

questions.question: Freezing in a sufficiently cold temperature improves the lastingness of products.
questions.description: Products can be stored by freezing them, but one must notice that freezing affects the quality of different food products. For example, fish, meat and baked goods dry up easily during freezing, so the quality of products stored in freezing must be checked regularly.

questions.question: Small birds flying in a grocery store cause no harm as long as regular cleaning is carried out.
questions.description: Small birds must be prevented from entering food premises. They are a hygiene hazard.

questions.question: The norovirus is not destroyed when a food product is frozen.
questions.description: The norovirus lasts for long amounts of time and is able to spread even in the cold or in frozen foods.

questions.question: Officials will prepare an own-check plan for new companies in the food product industry.
questions.description: Companies in the food product industry must prepare their own own-check plan when starting their activities. The plan must be followed and updated when needed.

questions.question: Food products can be used after the last use-by-date if the product does not look spoiled.
questions.description: The last use-by-date must be marked on easily perishable food products. The products can not be used nor sold after this date.

questions.question: There must be an appropriate washing place for large machines and dishes in the food premises.
questions.description: A cleaning plan is made for every machine and device to specify an appropriate place for washing each one of them.

questions.question: Vacuum-packed smoked fish does not contain microbes.
questions.description: Vacuum-packages do not include any air and prevent microbes that require oxygen from reproducing. However, the products can still contain microbes that can survive without oxygen.

questions.question: Easily perishable food products do not require a storage instruction label if it is a commonly known product.
questions.description: Packages of easily perishable food products always require a label indicating the last day of use and storing instructions. The shown date is valid only for unopened products that have been stored in the right temperature.

questions.question: The placement of biowaste bins outside a restaurant does not matter as long as they are not close to an entrance.
questions.description: A waste room's  or recycling area's biowaste bins must be covered from the sun and placed such that pests do not get to them.

questions.question: Pet animals can carry food poisoning causing parasites and protozoa.
questions.description: Pet animals can carry different disease causers in their fur, paws and feces. Pet animals can not be allowed inside food preparation areas. Pet animals are allowed in dining areas if the merchant allows it.

questions.question: Guide dogs are allowed inside food product stores.
questions.description: Guide dogs are always allowed in areas meant for customers. However, no animals can be taken inside food product handling areas or storage areas.

questions.question: A cooked meal and the raw ingredients used to prepare it can be stored in the same container during transport.
questions.description: Cooked meals and raw ingredients are always stored separately in their own clean containers.

questions.question: If an easily perishable food product has been stored in too warm conditions, the product can still be stored until the use-by-date.
questions.description: The use-by-date is reliable only if the product has been stored correctly. Storing products in too warm conditions always makes the products last for shorter periods of times.

questions.question: Plants can be displayed and sold anywhere in a grocery store as long as adequate ventilation is provided.
questions.description: Plants must be located as far as possible from unpackaged perishable food products. There are lots of microbes on the surface of plants and in the soil, and these may spread to food products.

questions.question: A tool made of wood is a hygiene hazard.
questions.description: Wood is a porous material and can absorb water, dirt and detergents, and it can stay damp for a long time.

questions.question: Freezing delays food spoilage.
questions.description: Contamination caused by microbes can be delayed by freezing food products, as freezing prevents microbes from growing.

questions.question: Washed, clean dishes can only be handled with clean hands.
questions.description: If clean dishes are handled with dirty hands, microbes and dirt will spread from the hands onto the dishes.

questions.question: In Finland the milk found in cartons in stores is rarely pasteurized.
questions.description: In Finland the milk found in cartons in stores is almost always pasteurized milk. Only raw milk that has been bought directly from a dairy farm is not usually pasteurized.

questions.question: When handling food products, employees should not touch their skin if possible.
questions.description: The skin and mouth contain large amounts of different bacteria, including food poisoning causing bacteria. Because of this touching the skin should be avoided when working with food products.

questions.question: Biofilm means plastic wrap that is specially made for food products.
questions.description: Biofilm can form onto e.g. the surface of a plate if prewashing is done with too hot water before proper dishwashing. Too hot water can burn albumin spots onto the surface of the dish and create biofilm, which is a suitable growing environment for microbes.

questions.question: Drying makes an easily perishable food product a long-lasting one.
questions.description: Microbes need water to reproduce. Getting rid of water in any ingredients is a very effective way of stopping perishing. Drying is one of the oldest known preserving methods. Dry products last long when they are stored dry during all transportation and storing phases. As long as the products stay dry, microbes in them can not reproduce.

questions.question: Acidity in a food product prevents the reproduction of bacteria.
questions.description: Bacteria that are a threat to food product safety reproduce the best in the neutral zone. Because of this the growth of these bacteria can be prevented by increasing the acidity of a product.

questions.question: The state and cleanliness of the waste management room does not affect the kitchen's hygienic quality.
questions.description: The waste management room must also be kept organised and clean. A dirty waste management room and badly cleaned waste bins can collect pests and spread microbes that are harmful for food products.

questions.question: Chefs are required to have a hygiene proficiency passport even if their employment is not permanent.
questions.description: Chefs handle easily perishable food products in their work. This means that chefs must pass a hygiene proficiency test at least 3 months after starting their work.

questions.question: Easily perishable food products that require cold storage must be served at a temperature below +8 degrees celsius.
questions.description: During serving easily perishable food products that require cold storage may be +12 degrees celsius at most. The maximum serving time is 12 hours, after which the products must be discarded.

questions.question: The shelf life of spices can be prolonged by radiation.
questions.description: UV, infra red and gamma radiation can be used to destroy microbes from for example spices and pastries that are made to last for long periods of storage.

questions.question: Only old cold storage equipment must have a thermometer.
questions.description: All cold storage equipment in food production areas must have a thermometer.

questions.question: Ice makers do not need to be washed because microbes do not multiply in such a cold environment.
questions.description: Ice makers must be washed regularly. Ice makers and utensils for picking up ice must be kept clean and in good condition, and their lids must be kept closed to prevent dirt from entering the machines. The high number of microbes in ice cubes causes a deterioration in the quality of food products and even food poisoning.

questions.question: The own-check plan only refers to measuring and recording temperatures.
questions.description: The purpose of the own-check plan is to help operators to manage the risks associated with food hygiene. Measuring and recording temperatures is an important part of the own-check system. Other areas of the own-check system include cleaning and tidiness as well as hygienic skills of the staff.

questions.question: Food production employees are only allowed to wear their work outfit at their workplace, the food production area.
questions.description: The work outfit can only be worn inside the food production area; this prevents microbes from spreading into the area from the clothes.

questions.question: Bacteria spores are always found inside the cans of canned food.
questions.description: Canned foods are produced with sterilization which destroys all bacteria spores. The sterilization has failed bacteria spores are found inside the can.

questions.question: BSE is also called mad cow's disease.
questions.description: Mad cow's disease is sometimes found in old cows. During slaughtering the carcasses must be checked so that contaminated meat is not used.

questions.question: Officials will prepare an own-check plan for new companies in the food product industry.
questions.description: Companies in the food product industry must prepare their own own-check plan when starting their activities. The plan must be followed and updated when needed.

questions.question: A biowaste container that is kept closed can be stored in the kitchen's storage area at room temperature for a few days.
questions.description: Waste must be stored in a designated area that is sufficiently separated from other operations and food products.

questions.question: Restaurants must have an own-check plan.
questions.description: All workplaces in the food industry need to ensure the safety of their products with an own-check plan. Own-check plans are required in all food industry workplaces.

questions.question: Dirty root vegetables must have a separate work space.
questions.description: Dirt always contains many microbes. Dirty root vegetables must be handled separately from other products so that the microbes in the dirt do not spread to other food products.

questions.question: Microbes reproduce the fastest in their own optimal temperatures.
questions.description: All microbes have their own optimal temperatures where reproduction is the fastest. In the insides of humans and animals, the temperature range between 20 and 45 degrees Celsius is the best for microbes. Anything hotter or colder than this causes microbes to reproduce slower.

questions.question: Fever and the flu are good reasons for a food product employee to not go to work.
questions.description: Food products should not be handled when one has a fever or the flu because causes of the disease spread easily by coughing or sneezing.

questions.question: Even in small cafés the same cleaning equipment can not be used to clean the customer areas and the kitchen.
questions.description: If the same cleaning equipment is used, microbes can easily spread from customers to the kitchen in the equipment.

questions.question: Due to salmonella risks, fowl and poultry meat must always be heated thoroughly to over 75 degrees Celsius.
questions.description: Fowl/poultry can contain salmonella naturally. Salmonella bacteria must be alive to cause an illness. The meat of fowl/poultry is safe if it is heated thoroughly to over 75 degrees Celsius.

questions.question: Pasteurizing and ultra-high-temperature processing (UHT) mean the same thing.
questions.description: Ultra-high-temperature processing is done in much higher temperatures than pasteurizing. UHT destroys most bacteria spores and because of this products that have been treated with UHT can be stored in room temperature.

questions.question: The temperatures of cold storage equipment do not need to be measured if they feel cold enough.
questions.description: The temperatures of refrigerating equipment, drawers and cabinets must be measured and logged at the same time each day. Atypical measuring results are logged in the own-check forms and necessary measures are taken to restore the right temperature in that piece of equipment.

questions.question: In commercial kitchens, it is necessary to nominate the people in charge of the own-check plan.
questions.description: Designated persons who have been trained for the task are responsible for the various areas of the own-check plan.

questions.question: Pasteurized dairy products can be stored unopened in room temperature.
questions.description: Pasteurizing does not make it possible to store dairy products in room temperature. UHT-treated dairy products can be stored in room temperature if they are unopened.

questions.question: When food products are stored in the correct temperatures, the microbes in the products will not be able to reproduce and grow into dangerous quantities too quickly.
questions.description: Microbes can not be fully prevented from getting into food products. However, correct temperatures will slow down or prevent the microbes in food from reproducing and growing in hazardous amounts.

questions.question: In Finland the milk found in cartons in stores is almost always pasteurized milk.
questions.description: Only raw milk that has been bought directly from a dairy farm is not usually pasteurized.

questions.question: If the temperature of food that is to be served while warm is too low it must not be marked down on the own-check plan's monitoring logs.
questions.description: Measured temperatures must be marked down in the own-check plan's monitoring logs, even if they are too high or too low. The logs must also contain information on what fixing procedure has been made to correct the incorrect temperature.

questions.question: If food is prepared to be served later, the finished products must be cooled as soon as possible for storage.
questions.description: Hot, cooked food must be cooled to under 6 degrees Celsius in under 4 hours. Cooling large amounts of products requires the use of actual cooling devices, from which the cooled products must be moved to their appropriate cold storage units.

questions.question: Trichinella spiralis is a parasite of salmon.
questions.description: Trichinella spiralis is found in the non-inspected meat of pigs, boar, horses and bears.

questions.question: Chicken eggs never contain salmonella.
questions.description: Chicken eggs can contain salmonella, although the risk is small in Finland.

questions.question: Food that is being served while hot must be at least 55 degrees Celsius during the entire serving period.
questions.description: Food that is being served while hot must be kept at over 60 degrees Celsius during the entire serving period. The temperature must be measured and marked down in own-check logs.

questions.question: Unprepared root vegetables can temporarily be stored in a cleaning supply closet or another spacious place.
questions.description: Food products cannot be stored in places that are not meant for that purpose.

questions.question: Kitchens in hospitals should have separate spaces for different work phases such as the treatment of root vegetables, baking and dishwashing.
questions.description: When each work phase is done in its own separate area the work is hygienic and the risk of cross-contamination is smaller.

questions.question: When receiving products one must make sure that they are moved into their appropriate, separate storage areas as soon as possible after the receival check.
questions.description: Products should be moved into their own storage areas as soon as possible after the receival check. Easily perishable food products can not be stored in room temperature for longer than 10-15 minutes.

questions.question: An animal can be slaughtered in a restaurant if a special permit has been granted.
questions.description: It is prohibited to slaughter animals in restaurants.

questions.question: Food production employees are not allowed to wear colorless nail polish.
questions.description: Hands must not containt anything extra such as watches, jewellery, fake nails, nail polish or hand cream.

questions.question: If you drop a steak onto the floor, you can use it as long as you fry it.
questions.description: A steak that has fallen onto the floor must never be used for cooking. Food products must never be stored on the floor.

questions.question: The checking of food and the monitoring of temperature when receiving food products is a part of the own-check plan.
questions.description: The correct storing temperatures affect the lastingness and safety of food. The monitoring of temperature by measurements is an important part of the own-check plan when receiving food products.

questions.question: An establishment's own-check plan is in effect for 10 years at a time.
questions.description: The own-check plan must be updated if need arises. It is useful to go over the plan regularly and to assess whether or not there have been changes in the establishment's functioning or protocols that require changes to made in the plan as well. Changes in the regulations of the food industry may necessitate changes in own-check plans as well.

questions.question: If a salmonella infection is asymptomatic, it cannot spread into handled food products via an employee.
questions.description: A salmonella infection can spread even if the person who carries it has no symptoms. This is why it is important to have a salmonella test before the employment starts.

questions.question: Irradiation can be used to destroy microbes in dairy products.
questions.description: Irradiation destroys microbes in dry herbs and spices.

questions.question: Food poisoning only spreads by contaminated food products or drinking water.
questions.description: Food poisoning can also spread due to bad work or hand hygiene. Food poisoning bacteria such as salmonella can spread human-to-human without any intermediate due to bad hand hygiene. Disease carriers without symptoms can also spread salmonella to other people.

questions.question: Bacteria toxins disappear when food is boiled.
questions.description: Some bacteria cause toxins in the food. If toxins have appeared in the food, they weill not disappear during boiling.

questions.question: Disinfected work surfaces contain no microbes.
questions.description: Correctly done disinfection reduces the amount of microbes excellently on work surfaces and equipment. However, a disinfected work surface is not sterile.

questions.question: Organic food does not cause food poisoning as easily as "normal" food.
questions.description: Organic food is produced without fertilizers or pesticides. This does not affect food poisoning almost at all. The risk for food poisoning is the same between "normal" and organic food.

questions.question: If a member of staff becomes infected with salmonella while abroad, he or she cannot spread the infection in Finland.
questions.description: Most cases of salmonella infection are acquired abroad, and an infection acquired abroad can also spread in Finland.

questions.question: Products that have gone through ultra-high-temperature treatment (UHT) can be stored in room temperature.
questions.description: During UHT products are sterilized with quick heating. Unopened packages can be stored in room temperature because most bacteria spores have been destroyed.

questions.question: If one's hands are clean, the temperature of food can be checked with the fingers.
questions.description: It is not possible to see how microbiologically clean one's hands are if only using the bare eye. Microbes can spread from the fingers to cooked food; when measuring the temperature of food a thermometer which can be easily cleaned must be used.

questions.question: The contents of a bulged can of food can be used for food preparation if the product is properly heated.
questions.description: All causes of food poisoning are not eliminated by heating. The contents of a bulged (ie. faulty) can of food must be discarded.

questions.question: Bars of soap are to be used when washing the hands.
questions.description: Microbes on the hands will spread onto bar soap. Because of this bar soap is not hygienic enough.

questions.question: Using own-check plans takes a lot of time and resources.
questions.description: Well-planned own-check plans saves time and resources. Resources used for monitoring can be focused on the most important areas, activities and control points. Resources can also be focused on the most effective preventive actions. In problematic situations correct procedures will be known and mistakes can be fixed quickly.

questions.question: Bacteria can reproduce in more acidized environments than moulds and yeasts.
questions.description: Bacteria that are a threat to food product safety reproduce the best in the neutral zone. Because of this the growth of these bacteria can be prevented by increasing the acidity of a product.

questions.question: Bacteria spores are destroyed during sterilization.
questions.description: During sterilization (e.g. during canned food production) all microbes and bacteria spores are destroyed. This way easily perishable products will be able to last long in room temperature.

questions.question: Cooked rice can be cooled in room temperature.
questions.description: Cooked rice is an easily perishable food product. In room temperature the microbes in the rice can reproduce very quickly and cause food poisoning.

questions.question: Products that have gone through ultra-high-temperature treatment (UHT) can not be stored in room temperature.
questions.description: During UHT products are sterilized with quick heating. Unopened packages can be stored in room temperature because most bacteria spores have been destroyed.

questions.question: Cooked and uncooked products should always be handled on different working surfaces and with different equipment.
questions.description: Microbes will spread to cooked products if they are handled with the same equipment or on the same surfaces as raw products.

questions.question: A cleaning and washing program must be included in the own-check plan.
questions.description: Areas that need to be cleaned, washing and cleaning methods for each area and specific cleaning equipment and substances (if required) must be listed in the own-check plan. The effectiveness of the cleaning must be checked visually daily and the responsible person has to log results for example once a week or always when abnormalities are noticed.

questions.question: Oiva is a system which helps people to self-assess the food product safety of their workplace.
questions.description: Municipality food control authorities make Oiva-reports about the workplaces they inspect. It is not a part of the workplace's self-assessment.

questions.question: You can touch the inside surfaces of food packaging if you have just washed your hands.
questions.description: You should always try not to touch the inside surfaces of food packaging.

questions.question: Cleaning rags must be changed regularly.
questions.description: The hygiene of cleaning rags in areas with food products is very important. The rags must be washed and changed regularly so that they will not spread food poisoning bacteria or microbes.

questions.question: Parboiling can be used to prolong the shelf life of frozen vegetables.
questions.description: Parboiling, in other words rapid boiling, prolongs the shelf life of frozen vegetables, because enzymatic activity in the product stops and the microbes on the surface are destroyed.

questions.question: The shelf life of food products can be extended by irradiating them.
questions.description: Only dried aromatic herbs, spices and vegetable seasonings are allowed to be irradiated. The purpose of irradiation is to eliminate bacteria and insects as well as to prevent the product from sprouting, for example.

questions.question: Food products containing preservatives never spoil.
questions.description: Preservatives only slow down the spoiling done by microbes.

questions.question: The more microbes there are in a cleaning cloth, the worse it smells.
questions.description: Microbes are usually odourless microorganisms that are invisible to the naked eye.

questions.question: If food is prepared to be served later, the finished products must be cooled as soon as possible for storage.
questions.description: Hot, cooked food must be cooled to under 6 degrees Celsius in under 4 hours. Cooling large amounts of products requires the use of actual cooling devices, from which the cooled products must be moved to their appropriate cold storage units.

questions.question: Headwear is used in kitchens to protect the employee's hair from getting dirty.
questions.description: Headwear is used to prevent the employee's hair from getting into the prepared food.

questions.question: The correct concentration of detergent does not have any effect on the cleaning result.
questions.description: Detergents and disinfectants must be measured out in accordance with the manufacturer's instructions. A solution that is stronger than recommended does not usually guarantee a better cleaning result, and a solution that is diluted too much may give a worse result.

questions.question: Vegetables and fruit must be washed prior to food preparation with water that meets the requirements of household water.
questions.description: Taps in any food preparation space must provide water that meets the requirements of household water, which is used in preparing and making food as well as by staff to wash their hands.

questions.question: An employee handling unpacked, easily perishable food products can not have nail polish while working.
questions.description: Nail polish can not be worn when handling easily perishable food products because the polish can break off into the products. Microbes also have good growth environments to reproduce under nails and nail polish. Nails and hands must be kept in good condition when working with food products.

questions.question: Food production areas' waste bins must be cleaned regularly.
questions.description: The cleanliness and hygiene of waste bins must be taken care of regularly. Waste bins in kitchens should be cleaned always after they are emptied.

questions.question: The monitoring logs made for own-check plans, e.g. logs of temperature measurements, must be stored at the workplace for 6 months.
questions.description: Logs must be stored for at least 1 year after selling a product. The information included can be used to trace errors and problems.

questions.question: If a salmonella infection is asymptomatic, it cannot spread into handled food products via an employee.
questions.description: A salmonella infection can spread even if the person who carries it has no symptoms. This is why it is important to have a salmonella test before the employment starts.

questions.question: Microbes are destroyed when meat is minced.
questions.description: When meat is minced, the bacteria on its surface spread throughout the minced meat.

questions.question: The mould used to make mould-ripened cheese cannot grow anywhere else.
questions.description: The mould used to make mould-ripened cheese can grow on other food products. It causes mould to grow on the surfaces of food products that spoils them.

questions.question: The use of snus (similar to chewing tobacco) is not allowed during food preparation.
questions.description: When handling food products personal hygiene is important; snus must not be used because of hygienic reasons.

questions.question: Food poisoning is always caused by bacteria that has been accidentally let into food.
questions.description: Food poisoning can often be caused by storing food for too long in hazardous temperatures, too slow cooling or ineffective heating. These are situations where bacteria have had time to reproduce and multiply.

questions.question: Waste does not cause a hygiene risk because it is stored in separate containers.
questions.description: Bad waste management hygiene or food products getting into contact with waste can cause hygiene risks.

questions.question: Some microbes can reproduce even in food products that are in a protective gas package.
questions.description: Protective gas packages contain little or no oxygen. This prevents microbes that require oxygen from growing. However, the product can also contain microbes that do not need oxygen.

questions.question: Own-check plans do not need to include clear instructions on how to act when food poisoning suspicions are raised.
questions.description: When food is prepared for customers, food poisoning events must be planned for in advance. Own-check plans must include clear instructions for these events. It is important to notify health inspectors about suspicions immediately.

questions.question: Cleaning equipment storage rooms must be cleaned regularly.
questions.description: All parts of a food production area must be cleaned regularly according to the cleaning plan.

questions.question: If an easily perishable food product has been stored in too warm conditions, the use-by-date marked on the package is no longer reliable.
questions.description: The use-by-date is reliable only if the product has been stored correctly. Storing products in too warm conditions always makes the products last for shorter periods of times.

questions.question: The own-check plan of a food production area is done by a municipality health inspector.
questions.description: Workplaces in the food industry must create their own own-check plan that suits their activities. The plan is supposed to ensure the safety of food products, good lastingness and the following of official rules and directives.

questions.question: Bacterial spores are more resistant than bacteria.
questions.description: When bacteria are in an environment where they cannot grow as easily, they turn into spores. Spores are more resistant than bacteria to heat and drought, for example.

questions.question: A cheese roll packed in a tight plastic wrap is protected from microbes.
questions.description: A cheese roll is a perishable food product that is stored and served cold. In addition to being wrapped in plastic film, make sure that it is kept in the correct storage and serving temperatures.

questions.question: Salmonella bacteria can be found in fowl or poultry.
questions.description: Salmonella can be found in fowl or poultry. Due to the risk of salmonella, the meat of fowl/poultry must always be cooked to at least 75 degrees Celsius.

questions.question: Food products can be used safely after the use-by date if they do not look or smell bad.
questions.description: Perished or contaminated products are not always possible to notice just by using the senses (visually etc.) Easily perishable food products' packages have a use-by date marked on them, and after this date has passed the product must not be used or sold.

questions.question: Sour milk spoils faster than milk.
questions.description: The pH value of milk is 7, which means it is neutral. The pH value of sour milk is lower, which means sour milk is acidized. It is harder for bacteria to reproduce in acidized milk products than in neutral products.

questions.question: Food poisoning microbes can only spread through the air.
questions.description: Food poisoning microbes can be transmitted into food in many ways such as via hands, soil, contaminated water or airborne dust particles. Rodents, insects and birds can also spread food poisoning microbes.

questions.question: Dishes do not need to be pre-washed before being put into a washing machine if the washing temperature is hot enough.
questions.description: Dishes must always be pre-washed before being put into a washing machine. It is important to get rid of protein spots with cool water so that the protein does not stick to the dishes in hot temperatures. The biofilm that the protein creates acts as a living space for microbes.

questions.question: In Finland the milk found in cartons in stores is almost always pasteurized milk.
questions.description: Only raw milk that has been bought directly from a dairy farm is not usually pasteurized.

questions.question: Washing machines do not need to be washed separately, because the washing temperatures are hot enough to destroy harmful microbes.
questions.description: Washing machines, as well as their dust filters and other removable parts, must be washed and dried regularly. The surfaces of the machines must also be swiped and the lids left open so that the machine's inside dries.

questions.question: Vacuum-packed smoked fish does not contain microbes.
questions.description: Vacuum-packages do not include any air and prevent microbes that require oxygen from reproducing. However, the products can still contain microbes that can survive without oxygen.

questions.question: An entire block of cheese spoils faster than cheese that has been sliced.
questions.description: The spoiling of a product usually starts on the surface. The surface contains a lot of oxygen and some amounts of microbes have always been spread onto the surface during production and packing. Products with lots of surface area always spoil faster than similar products that are still in their original entire form.

questions.question: Safety data sheets are the same thing as the instruction manual of a device.
questions.description: Safety data sheets include the most important information about detergents (washing chemicals) and also include first aid instructions.

questions.question: Actions made after noticing mistakes or abnormalities in the packaging or quality of food products during receival checks must be logged in the own-check plan.
questions.description: Mistakes or abnormalities noticed in the quality or packaging of food products must be logged into the own-check plan. It is also required to detailedly log what actions are made after noticing a mistake or abnormality and who is responsible for informing for example the supplier of the products about it.

questions.question: The same cleaning equipment can be used to clean the customer areas and the kitchen in small cafés.
questions.description: If the same cleaning equipment is used, microbes can easily spread from customers to the kitchen in the equipment.

questions.question: Dirty root vegetables and pre-made food products can not be stored in the same cold room.
questions.description: Dirt always contains many microbes. Dirty root vegetables must be handled separately from other products so that the microbes in the dirt do not spread to other food products.

questions.question: The human skin naturally contains microbes.
questions.description: Especially the face, scalp, mouth, nose etc. contain microbes. Food poisoning causing Staphylococcus bacteria can also be found on the skin.

questions.question: The fresh fish that has been up for retail sale during the day can, with the decision and permission of the store, be smoked during the evening and then sold.
questions.description: Fish that has been on the sales counter can not be smoked for the next day's sales. This is against the ethics of food product law and deceives consumers. If fish has been up for retail sale during the day, its sales time must not continue by smoking it.

questions.question: Hand washing areas must be cleaned regularly.
questions.description: A dirty hand washing area is a risk for hand hygiene.

questions.question: If a summer restaurant is located next to a lake with clean water, the water in the lake can be used for washing fruits.
questions.description: All food preparation requires the use of water that is tap water quality.

questions.question: The results in Oiva-reports are not allowed to be read by customers.
questions.description: Municipality food control authorities do routine inspections at workplaces. Oiva-reports are published documents about these inspections.

questions.question: Using food, that has been served at a buffet table, as an ingredient for preparing new foods increases food poisoning risks.
questions.description: Food that is at a buffet table is often in room temperature and available to be taken by customers themselves. This means that food poisoning causing bacteria spread to these foods easier and reproduce quicker in them. The risk of food poisoning increases when the same foods are used to make new ones. Food from buffet tables must not be used again in food preparation.

questions.question: Pasteurized dairy products can be stored unopened in room temperature.
questions.description: Pasteurizing does not make it possible to store dairy products in room temperature. UHT-treated dairy products can be stored in room temperature if they are unopened.

questions.question: Staphylococcus aureus is not a food poisoning bacteria.
questions.description: Staphylococcus aureus is a food poisoning bacteria. The human skin, nose and mucous membranes can contain staphylococcus aureus.

questions.question: Blue cheese contains living mould.
questions.description: Clean, controlled and living moulds are used when producing blue cheese. The moulds create various taste ingredients in the cheese.

questions.question: The lastingness of food products can also be improved during treatment by using hygienic work methods, clean surfaces and equipment.
questions.description: Ingredients and their handling equipment must be kept separate from cooked products to prevent cross-contamination. For example, differently colored cutting boards and equipment for different food groups, such as vegetables, fish, meat and cooked food helps to prevent cross-contamination.

questions.question: Food that is being served while hot must be at least 60 degrees Celsius during the entire serving period.
questions.description: The temperature must also be measured and marked down in own-check logs. The food can be kept in service while hot for a maximum of 4 hours.

questions.question: In vegetables, only perished areas that can be noticed visually are health hazards.
questions.description: Due to cultivation and treatments the surface of vegetables can have impurities which can not be seen with the bare eye. Harmful microbes can also be on areas that are not visually perished. Vegetables are a health risk when they are not washed properly before use.

questions.question: Customer feedback is not a part of the own-check plan.
questions.description: Customer feedback is part of a company's own-check plan. The own-check plan should also explain how feedback is used.

questions.question: Single-use gloves are used to protect the food preparer from microbes on the food products.
questions.description: The first priority of using single-use gloves is to protect the food products from microbes on the hands.

questions.question: The surfaces of work station tables must be cleaned properly only after the work shift is over.
questions.description: A regular cleaning every 2-4 hours of work station surfaces gets rid of leftover food pieces, fat, dust and other dirt which protects micro-organisms and gives them living space.

questions.question: Mashed potato is an easily perishable food product.
questions.description: Pre-made foods are easily perishable products. Easily perishable foods must be stored in the cold, under 6 degrees Celsius.

questions.question: The orientation of new employees is not part of the own-check plan.
questions.description: The orientation and training of new employee is an important part of the own-check plan.

questions.question: Properly heated food products can not contain bacteria that causes food poisoning.
questions.description: Even properly heated food products can contain food poisoning causing bacteria; the bacteria can spread to the food due to bad handling hygiene or dirty equipment during e.g. chopping or serving.

questions.question: Ice makers do not need to be washed because microbes do not multiply in such a cold environment.
questions.description: Ice makers must be washed regularly. Ice makers and utensils for picking up ice must be kept clean and in good condition, and their lids must be kept closed to prevent dirt from entering the machines. The high number of microbes in ice cubes causes a deterioration in the quality of food products and even food poisoning.

questions.question: If food does not smell bad it can not be spoiled.
questions.description: Many food poisoning causing bacteria can reproduce in food without causing changes that can be noticed with the senses (visually, smell etc.)

questions.question: Instructions for waste disposal are included in the own-check plan.
questions.description: The own-check plan for a food premises always includes instructions for food waste disposal.

questions.question: Cleaning plans include accurate instructions about how and when cleaning is done.
questions.description: A cleaning plan is an essential part of an own-check plan. Cleaning plans include more accurate instructions on the cleaning of all parts of a food production area.

questions.question: When there is packaged meat in a delivery load, it can be safely left at room temperature for a few hours.
questions.description: The cold chain of meat products in a delivery load must not be broken.

questions.question: Raw milk is not suitable for people with a weakened immune system.
questions.description: Because raw milk has not been pasteurized it can contain pathogens (disease-causing bacteria.) The most important bacteria that can cause danger to food safety in raw milk are EHEC, listeria, salmonella and campylo bacteria.

questions.question: Only old cold storage equipment must have a thermometer.
questions.description: All cold storage equipment in food production areas must have a thermometer.

questions.question: Microbes reproduce the fastest in their own optimal temperatures.
questions.description: All microbes have their own optimal temperatures where reproduction is the fastest. In the insides of humans and animals, the temperature range between 20 and 45 degrees Celsius is the best for microbes. Anything hotter or colder than this causes microbes to reproduce slower.

questions.question: Own-check plans must include clear instructions on how to act when food poisoning suspicions are raised.
questions.description: When food is prepared for customers, food poisoning events must be planned for in advance. Own-check plans must include clear instructions for these events. It is important to notify health inspectors about suspicions immediately.

questions.question: Most food poisoning causing microbes will be destroyed when the temperature of food is more than 75 degrees Celsius.
questions.description: Most food poisoning causing microbes can not live in temperatures over 75 degrees Celsius. However, bacteria-spores can live in much higher temperatures.

questions.question: It is not allowed to use useful microbes in baking.
questions.description: Yeast is used in baking to make dough rise.

questions.question: Sliced sourdough bread keeps better than a whole loaf of sourdough bread.
questions.description: Handling food products by chopping or slicing them, for example, impairs their shelf life.

questions.question: The priority of waste laws is to make people working in the food industry responsible for assorting their waste.
questions.description: The priority of waste laws is to lessen the amount of waste and its effects.

questions.question: If canned foods are not sterilized properly, the food can be dangerous for the human health.
questions.description: The cans of canned food can contain spores of clostridium botulinum if the food is not sterilized properly. This spore can create dangerous toxins in the product.

questions.question: If a product or ingredient is suspected to be the cause of food poisoning in a customer, the product or ingredient should be gotten rid of as soon as possible.
questions.description: Suspected causes of food poisoning must not be gotten rid of but must instead be stored so that it can be examined in a laboratory to find the cause of the poisoning.

questions.question: If a member of staff becomes infected with salmonella while abroad, he or she cannot spread the infection in Finland.
questions.description: Most cases of salmonella infection are acquired abroad, and an infection acquired abroad can also spread in Finland.

questions.question: Blanching improves the lastingness of for example vegetables when they are stored in freezing.
questions.description: Blanching, which means quick boiling, stops enzymic activity on the surface of vegetables by destroying microbe activity. This way vegetables do not dry on the surface while freezing them. Blanching can also be used for example to get rid of naturally occuring toxins in morel mushrooms to make them edible. In this case blanching is done many times and the boiling water is changed between boilings.

questions.question: All transport companies can transport food to restaurants provided that their vehicles are spacious enough.
questions.description: Professional transporting of food requires certification from the appropriate authorities as well as an own-check plan.

questions.question: Domestic water pollution is often caused by human faeces.
questions.description: Norovirus and Campylobacter enter the domestic water supply mainly through municipal wastewater, and Campylobacter also through animal faeces. Inadequate dosing of disinfectant chemicals can also cause contamination.

questions.question: Food control authorities must approve a company's own-check plan to allow the company to begin its activites in the industry.
questions.description: Approval from authorities is not required to start activities. The plans are part of the companies' personal documents, which authorities will check and intervene in if problems are noticed.

questions.question: Visual evaluation is enough to check the cleanliness of working areas and equipment.
questions.description: When working the results of cleaning can be evaluated visually, but it is good to occasionally do tests by taking bacteria samples from surfaces and equipment. The microbiological quality of food products that have been treated in some way is a good measure for the effectiveness of cleaning. It is a good idea to name a responsible person to monitor the results of cleaning regularly.

questions.question: Blue cheese contains living mould.
questions.description: Clean, controlled and living moulds are used when producing blue cheese. The moulds create various taste ingredients in the cheese.

questions.question: A cleaning equipment storage room is not needed in a food production area.
questions.description: It's not always necessary to have a separate storage space for cleaning equipment. Food production areas need a separate storage, maintenance and drying space if the food production area requires it for constructional reasons. It's important to make sure that there are no risks for food safety and the hygienic treatment, maintenance and storage of cleaning equipment are done properly. If necessary the working stages and functions has to be separated structually or timely.

questions.question: Self-service sales points need to be protected from droplets that spread into the air when someone coughs.
questions.description: Self-service sales points are protected from droplet transmissions from customers who cough.

questions.question: When receiving frozen goods, their temperature does not need to be measured if the product feels cold.
questions.description: It is recommended that one occasionally measures the temperature of frozen deliveries, especially if there are any doubts about the accuracy of transportation temperature.

questions.question: A food poisoning epidemic is a situation where at least 10 people have become sick with similar symptoms after consuming the same food product or ingredient.
questions.description: A food poisoning epidemic means a situation where at least 2 people have become sick with similar symptoms after consuming the same food or drink.

questions.question: Cleaning equipment must be cleaned always after being used.
questions.description: Dirty and wet cleaning equipment contain lots of microbes. The results of cleaning with this equipment are not good.

questions.question: Health inspectors can not inspect restaurant kitchens.
questions.description: The work of health inspectors requires making inspections in food production areas such as food stores and restaurants.

questions.question: If food does not taste spoiled it can not cause food poisoning.
questions.description: Many food poisoning causing bacteria can reproduce in food without causing changes that can be noticed with the senses (visually, taste etc.)

questions.question: If one's hands are clean, the temperature of food can be checked with the fingers.
questions.description: It is not possible to see how microbiologically clean one's hands are if only using the bare eye. Microbes can spread from the fingers to cooked food; when measuring the temperature of food a thermometer which can be easily cleaned must be used.

questions.question: Mashed potato is an easily perishable food product.
questions.description: Pre-made foods are easily perishable products. Easily perishable foods must be stored in the cold, under 6 degrees Celsius.

questions.question: Potatoes must be washed with water that meets the requirements for domestic water.
questions.description: When preparing food, always use water that meets the requirements for domestic water to ensure that food safety is not compromised.

questions.question: A piece of rotten fruit affects the shelf life of other pieces of fruit that are near it.
questions.description: A piece of rotten fruit also spoils other pieces of fruit kept in the same dish, so it is important to dispose of rotten fruit.

questions.question: Frozen food products are stored in a freezer at a temperature of -15°C or colder.
questions.description: The temperature in a freezer must be -18°C or colder.

questions.question: Staphylococcus aureus is a food poisoning bacteria.
questions.description: The human skin, nose and mucous membranes can contain staphylococcus aureus. Good hand hygiene is important due to this.

questions.question: Beer is produced with the help of beneficial microbes.
questions.description: Beer is produced with yeast fermentation. Yeast is also used when producing wine.

questions.question: In commercial kitchens, it is necessary to nominate the people in charge of the own-check plan.
questions.description: Designated persons who have been trained for the task are responsible for the various areas of the own-check plan.

questions.question: Yoghurt and viili contain live probiotics.
questions.description: Lactic acid bacteria play an important role in the production of dairy products.

questions.question: High salt content prevents harmful microbes from multiplying in a product
questions.description: Strong salting of a product changes the state of its water so that microbes can not reproduce. However, salted products such as mushrooms must still be stored in cool temperatures to prevent microbes on their surface from perishing them.

questions.question: Sterilizing destroys all microbes and bacteria spores.
questions.description: Canned foods are prepared by sterilizing them. This way easily perishable food products are able to last for years in room temperature.

questions.question: Heat and humidity accelerate vegetable spoilage.
questions.description: The correct storage temperatures and moisture affect the shelf life of vegetables.

questions.question: If a fish is dropped on a freshly washed floor, it can still be cooked as long as it is sufficiently well heated.
questions.description: A fish that has fallen onto the floor must never be used for cooking. Food products must never be stored on the floor.

questions.question: Food product employees are required to have good personal hygiene.
questions.description: Good personal hygiene, including regular washing, clean and neat hair, short nails and healthy cuticles are signs of good work hygiene as well.

questions.question: In lunch restaurants a control measurement of the temperature of food served from serving equipment is done once a week.
questions.description: Control measurements on served products are performed daily. Exceptions are always written down and all temperatures are logged in the own-check plan forms once a week.

questions.question: Taking samples from prepared food products is a part of the own-check plan.
questions.description: Samples must be taken of served food products for example from lunch servings so that they can be stored for possible food poisoning cases.

questions.question: Food that is being served while hot must be at least 55 degrees Celsius during the entire serving period.
questions.description: Food that is being served while hot must be kept at over 60 degrees Celsius during the entire serving period. The temperature must be measured and marked down in own-check logs.

questions.question: When handling food products, employees should not touch their skin if possible.
questions.description: The skin and mouth contain large amounts of different bacteria, including food poisoning causing bacteria. Because of this touching the skin should be avoided when working with food products.

questions.question: Protective gloves are used to protect employees' hands from dirt, so that their hands do not need to be washed as often.
questions.description: Gloves are also used to protect food from microbes spread by hands. Gloves are a great way to keep work hygiene good when tasks must be changed quickly. Gloves must be changed regularly enough while working to keep hygiene good. It is also good to properly wash and dry one's hands when changing gloves. Gloves must always be changed immediately after touching door handles or taps.

questions.question: Clostridium perfringens is a bacteria that is often found in earth.
questions.description: Earth contains many microbes, some of which cause food poisoning. To prevent clostridium perfringens food poisonings it is important to properly heat and cool the food and not store it in the dangerous temperature zone of 6 to 60 degrees Celsius.

questions.question: Bacteria toxins can require boiling for 5 hours before they disappear from food.
questions.description: If toxins have appeared in the food, they can cause food poisoning. Only a very long boiling time will get rid of the toxins.

questions.question: You can wear disposable gloves instead of washing your hands when preparing food in a restaurant tent.
questions.description: Washing your hands thoroughly and often enough is the basis for safe food handling and general hygiene, and it is important to also wear disposable gloves, for example.

questions.question: Blue cheese doesn't contain living mould.
questions.description: Clean, controlled and living moulds are used when producing blue cheese. The moulds create various taste ingredients in the cheese. The ready cheese still contain these living moulds.

questions.question: The only mandatory information on food packaging is the ingredients and the name of the food product.
questions.description: In addition to the name of the food product and the ingredients, the packaging must also state the minimum shelf life and the use by date.

questions.question: An entire block of cheese spoils faster than cheese that has been sliced.
questions.description: The spoiling of a product usually starts on the surface. The surface contains a lot of oxygen and some amounts of microbes have always been spread onto the surface during production and packing. Products with lots of surface area always spoil faster than similar products that are still in their original entire form.

questions.question: Listeria can not reproduce in cold fish (e.g. salmon) in vacuum-packages.
questions.description: Listeria and yersinia are rare exceptions of food poisoning causing bacteria, because they can reproduce in refrigerator temperatures.

questions.question: Hepatitis A is never spread in food products.
questions.description: The most important viruses that reproduce in the intestines of humans are the norovirus and hepatitis A. Both viruses last for a long time and are able to spread in the cold and even in frozen foods.

questions.question: An animal can be slaughtered in a restaurant if a special permit has been granted.
questions.description: It is prohibited to slaughter animals in restaurants.

questions.question: Cold-stored root vegetables may contain Yersinia bacteria that cause food poisoning.
questions.description: Root vegetables that are cold stored for a long time may contain Yersinia bacteria that cause food poisoning.

questions.question: If a product or ingredient is suspected to be the cause of food poisoning in a customer, the product or ingredient should be gotten rid of as soon as possible.
questions.description: Suspected causes of food poisoning must not be gotten rid of but must instead be stored so that it can be examined in a laboratory to find the cause of the poisoning.

questions.question: Viruses can not reproduce in food products.
questions.description: Viruses need living host cells to reproduce, which means they can not reproduce or produce toxins in food products. However, food products can still work as spreaders of viruses.

questions.question: Frozen vegetables may contain listeria bacteria.
questions.description: Listeria can be found in unheated food products such as fresh vegetables and products made from these.

questions.question: The fresh fish that has been up for retail sale during the day can, with the decision and permission of the store, be smoked during the evening and then sold.
questions.description: Fish that has been on the sales counter can not be smoked for the next day's sales. This is against the ethics of food product law and deceives consumers. If fish has been up for retail sale during the day, its sales time must not continue by smoking it.

questions.question: All food that is being served needs to be sampled daily.
questions.description: Taken samples must be placed into a container and then placed into a freezer. If food poisonings are suspected, then these samples must be available for research.

questions.question: Taking samples from prepared food products is a part of the own-check plan.
questions.description: Samples must be taken of served food products for example from lunch servings so that they can be stored for possible food poisoning cases.

questions.question: Salt can not contain microbes.
questions.description: Salt is dry, so microbes do not grow in it. However, salt can contain spores of bacteria, moulds or yeast.

questions.question: The use of snus (similar to chewing tobacco) is not allowed during food preparation.
questions.description: When handling food products personal hygiene is important; snus must not be used because of hygienic reasons.

questions.question: When a kitchen floor is washed properly, there cannot be any microbes on it.
questions.description: Microbes are everywhere, even on newly washed kitchen surfaces.

questions.question: Guide dogs are allowed inside food product stores.
questions.description: Guide dogs are always allowed in areas meant for customers. However, no animals can be taken inside food product handling areas or storage areas.

questions.question: The own-check system involves monitoring how quickly food products cool down to storage temperature.
questions.description: Monitoring temperatures is an important part of the own-check system.

questions.question: Unpeeled and peeled carrots will last the same amount of time as long as they are stored in the cold.
questions.description: Earthy and dirty, untreated root vegetables will last long in appropriate cold storage units, but all treatments will worsen their lastingness.

questions.question: High salt content prevents harmful microbes from multiplying in a product
questions.description: Strong salting of a product changes the state of its water so that microbes can not reproduce. However, salted products such as mushrooms must still be stored in cool temperatures to prevent microbes on their surface from perishing them.

questions.question: Properly heated food products can not contain bacteria that causes food poisoning.
questions.description: Even properly heated food products can contain food poisoning causing bacteria; the bacteria can spread to the food due to bad handling hygiene or dirty equipment during e.g. chopping or serving.

questions.question: Food products are allowed to freeze during transport and this does not cause any harm.
questions.description: Food must not be frozen during transport as this will impair the hygienic quality of the food products. Perishable food products that require cold storage are transported in temperatures that do not exceed those set for storing perishable food products.

questions.question: Only old cold storage equipment must have a thermometer.
questions.description: All cold storage equipment in food production areas must have a thermometer.

questions.question: Workers in the food industry, e.g. the owner of a small café, must inform local food control authorities about their activities.
questions.description: All workers in the food industry must inform food control authorities about their activities. The informing must be done before beginning the activities. When founding a food industry workplace, e.g. a sausage factory, the activities must also be approved by the authorities.

questions.question: When a food industry workplace, e.g. a sausage factory, is being founded, the activities of the workplace must be approved in advance by local food control authorities.
questions.description: Workplaces that handle animal-based food products require an approval for their activities. Only informing of the activities is not enough.

questions.question: Raw ingredients containing gluten must be labelled and stored in closed containers in a storage room.
questions.description: Raw ingredients containing allergens and gluten must be labelled and stored separately in closed containers.

questions.question: If the product being handled is fresh and of good quality, the handling hygiene is not as important.
questions.description: Hygienic handling methods and equipment are always important for the lastingness of products. A fresh and good quality good will still perish easily if it is handled unhygienically.

questions.question: If you have just washed your hands carefully with soap, you can taste food with your finger.
questions.description: You can only taste food using clean cutlery, never with your fingers.

questions.question: Bacteria toxins disappear when food is boiled.
questions.description: Some bacteria cause toxins in the food. If toxins have appeared in the food, they weill not disappear during boiling.

questions.question: Wounds on the hands should be covered with both a bandage and a single-use glove.
questions.description: When both a bandage and a single-use glove are used, the wound is protected well enough and is also made more waterproof.
