questions.description: The hygiene of cleaning rags in areas with food products is very important. The rags must be washed and changed regularly so that they will not spread food poisoning bacteria or microbes.

questions.question: Plastic wrappers for food packaging can be stored outdoors, protected from rain.
questions.description: Plastic and paper wrappers for packing food are stored in a clean indoor space. Packaging materials must be stored sufficiently far away from contaminating materials such as waste or food.

questions.question: Chefs can use their work shoes during their travel to and from their workplace.
questions.description: Work shoes must not be worn outside the workplace to prevent microbes from spreading into the food production area.

questions.question: Taking samples from prepared food products is a part of the own-check plan.
questions.description: Samples must be taken of served food products for example from lunch servings so that they can be stored for possible food poisoning cases.

questions.question: Food poisoning symptoms always start within one day of consuming a perished food product.
questions.description: Food poisoning symptoms can already begin in one hour since consuming a perished food product, but they can also begin after many days of no symptoms.

questions.question: Cooked rice is not an easily perishable food product.
questions.description: Dry rice lasts in room temperature. Cooked rice contains moisture and because of this it is an easily perishable product. Cooked rice must be stored under 6 degrees Celsius.

questions.question: Bacteria reproduce very quickly in acidized products.
questions.description: Bacteria that are a threat to food product hygiene reproduce the best when in the neutral zone. Bacteria growth especially can be prevented by increasing the acidity of a product.

questions.question: Own-check plans do not need to include clear instructions on how to act when food poisoning suspicions are raised.
questions.description: When food is prepared for customers, food poisoning events must be planned for in advance. Own-check plans must include clear instructions for these events. It is important to notify health inspectors about suspicions immediately.

questions.question: Temperature measurements are to be made only by the superiors of a workplace.
questions.description: The instructions of own-check plans must be adhered to by all employees. Because of this temperature measurements are also the responsibility of all other employees.

questions.question: Dirty root vegetables can be handled in the same area where desserts are produced.
questions.description: Dirt always contains many microbes. Dirty root vegetables must be handled separately from other products so that the microbes in the dirt do not spread to other food products.

questions.question: The results in Oiva-reports are not allowed to be read by customers.
questions.description: Municipality food control authorities do routine inspections at workplaces. Oiva-reports are published documents about these inspections.

questions.question: Food control authorities must approve a company's own-check plan to allow the company to begin its activites in the industry.
questions.description: Approval from authorities is not required to start activities. The plans are part of the companies' personal documents, which authorities will check and intervene in if problems are noticed.

questions.question: Own-check plans are meant for the leadership of food industry companies.
questions.description: Own-check plans include lots of instructions and lists responsibilities. Because of this it is important that all employees get to know the own-check plan and adhere to it while working.

questions.question: Temperature measurements stated in own-check plans do not have to made when one is busy.
questions.description: Only regularly done measurements can prove that the own-check plan has been adhered to at a workplace.

questions.question: The only mandatory information on food packaging is the ingredients and the name of the food product.
questions.description: In addition to the name of the food product and the ingredients, the packaging must also state the minimum shelf life and the use by date.

questions.question: Listeria bacteria are destroyed when a product is frozen.
questions.description: Freezing does not destroy microbes. Listeria can also reproduce in frozen foods.

questions.question: Some viruses can last and stay reproductive in water.
questions.description: Viruses can not reproduce in water. However, they can remain able to reproduce later on for a long time while in water.

questions.question: Dirt and dust can make microbes spread to food products.
questions.description: Different kinds of impurities, such as dirt and dust, contain microbes. If dirt or dust gets onto a food product then the microbes contained will also spread onto the product.

questions.question: The contents of a bulged can of food can be used for food preparation if the product is properly heated.
questions.description: All causes of food poisoning are not eliminated by heating. The contents of a bulged (ie. faulty) can of food must be discarded.

questions.question: You can touch the inside surfaces of food packaging if you have just washed your hands.
questions.description: You should always try not to touch the inside surfaces of food packaging.

questions.question: Campylo bacteria is naturally found in fowl and poultry.
questions.description: Campylo bacteria and salmonella are found naturally in fowl and poultry. Both bacteria are destroyed when the meat is cooked thoroughly to over 75 degrees Celsius.

questions.question: All cold storage equipment must have a thermometer.
questions.description: Own-check plans require to monitor the temperature of cold storage equipment. If the equipment does not thermometers, the monitoring is impossible to do.

questions.question: Food poisoning is always caused by bacteria.
questions.description: The cause of food poisoning can, in addition to bacteria, also be a virus, mould fungus or protozoan.

questions.question: Food products stored in protective gas do not have to be stored in the cold because the protective gas protects the products from perishing.
questions.description: Food products stored in packages with protective gas must always be stored in the cold according to the instructions on the packaging. Protective gas packages have normal air changed into air that contains little or no oxygen to prevent microbes that use oxygen from reproducing. Protective gas prevents e.g. the surface of meat from darkening and thus keeps the product sensually appealling.

questions.question: Only reproductive microbes are destroyed during sterilization. Bacteria spores are not destroyed.
questions.description: During sterilization (e.g. during canned food production) all microbes and bacteria spores are destroyed. This way easily perishable products will be able to last long in room temperature.

questions.question: Own-check plans must also include e.g. cleaning and waste disposal procedures.
questions.description: Own-check plans must, along with microbiological risks, consider the hygiene of personnel, cleaning, receival of products and actions to be done when pests have been noticed.

questions.question: Wastebins do not need to be cleaned.
questions.description: Wastebins must not be broken, must include a lid and must also be cleaned regularly.

questions.question: Worn down and broken equipment is a hygienic risk.
questions.description: Waste food can get easily stuck in worn or broken equipment. Even small amounts of waste food will give microbes a good growing environment.

questions.question: Own-check plans are meant for the leadership of food industry companies.
questions.description: Own-check plans include lots of instructions and lists responsibilities. Because of this it is important that all employees get to know the own-check plan and adhere to it while working.

questions.question: If a food authority representative wants to see your own-check plan, you must present it to him/her.
questions.description: If a food authority representative wants to see an operator's own-check plan, the operator is obliged to present it.

questions.question: Oiva-reports must be placed at the entrance of the café, restaurant etc. so that customers can read them.
questions.description: Oiva-reports are published documents about routine inspections. These reports are also published online at www.oivahymy.fi

questions.question: Cold storage units should not be filled beyond their set fill limits because the food products might not stay cold enough.
questions.description: The fill limit is an instruction on usage by the producer of the cold storage unit. The limit should not be crossed because food products outside the limit will not stay cold enough.

questions.question: An entire carrot spoils faster than a grated carrot.
questions.description: Treating a carrot and grating it shortens the time it lasts. During grating microbes spread onto the carrot and water inside the carrot becomes available for the microbes to use. Grated products also have more surface area than intact products; microbes, especially ones that require oxygen, are suitable to live on the surface of products.

questions.question: Soup made for the following day can be left to cool overnight on the kitchen counter.
questions.description: The rapid cooling and cold storing of soup prevents or slows down the growth of bacteria.

questions.question: There may be flies in a food premises even if the waste management is well organised.
questions.description: Flies in the premises are always a sign of inadequate cleaning.

questions.question: Campylo bacteria is naturally found in fowl and poultry.
questions.description: Campylo bacteria and salmonella are found naturally in fowl and poultry. Both bacteria are destroyed when the meat is cooked thoroughly to over 75 degrees Celsius.

questions.question: Some viruses can last and stay reproductive in water.
questions.description: Viruses can not reproduce in water. However, they can remain able to reproduce later on for a long time while in water.

questions.question: Dirt and dust can make microbes spread to food products.
questions.description: Different kinds of impurities, such as dirt and dust, contain microbes. If dirt or dust gets onto a food product then the microbes contained will also spread onto the product.

questions.question: Dirty root vegetables and pre-made food products can not be stored in the same cold room.
questions.description: Dirt always contains many microbes. Dirty root vegetables must be handled separately from other products so that the microbes in the dirt do not spread to other food products.

questions.question: The amount of water a product contains does not significantly affect its lastingness.
questions.description: Harmful microbes need water to reproduce. Because of this dry products last well.

questions.question: Salmonella can only get transmitted through feces.
questions.description: Salmonella can get transmitted through feces by way of poor hand hygiene but also via contaminated food products, such as raw meat and eggs.

questions.question: Liquid soap is to be used when washing the hands.
questions.description: Liquid soap is hygienic. The dispenser of the liquid soap should be one which can be pressed with the forearm instead of the hands.

questions.question: Detergents (washing chemicals) can be stored in soda bottles.
questions.description: Only the original packages can be used to make sure that the correct detergent is being used for the situation.

questions.question: Optimal temperature means the temperature where microbes reproduce the slowest.
questions.description: All microbes have their own optimal temperatures where reproduction is the fastest. In the insides of humans and animals, the temperature range between 20 and 45 degrees Celsius is the best for microbes. Anything hotter or colder than this causes microbes to reproduce slower.

questions.question: Contamination means e.g. unwanted microbes and/or chemicals spreading into a product.
questions.description: Contamination can be microbiological, chemical or physical. It is unwanted and can cause perishing of food products or food poisoning.

questions.question: When outside temperatures are very cold, food products can be cooled quickly outside.
questions.description: Food products must not be cooled or stored outside. All equipment and products, e.g. boxes containg baked goods, must be stored inside.

questions.question: Listeria and yersinia can reproduce in refrigerator temperatures.
questions.description: Earth and various bodies of water contain microbes, such as listeria and yersinia, that are able to survive cold conditions well. Listeria and yersinia can reproduce in very cold refrigerator temperatures.

questions.question: The most hygienic way to handle unpacked food products is to use wooden utensils.
questions.description: The most hygienic utensils for handling unpacked food products are made of plastic or steel.

questions.question: Food products must be traceable, i.e. it must be possible, if necessary, to prove from where the raw materials were obtained.
questions.description: Traceability is used to prove from where the raw materials were obtained and to where the finished products have been delivered.

questions.question: The temperature monitoring of cold storages is a part of own-check plans.
questions.description: The temperatures of cold storages must be checked and logged regularly according to the own-check plan. Cold storages must always have thermometers for measurements.

questions.question: A microbiological sample of a food product can be placed in any container.
questions.description: A microbiological sample of a food product must always be placed in a container that is definitely clean.

questions.question: Ice cube machines do not need to be cleaned separately, because their low temperature prevents microbes from multiplying.
questions.description: Ice cube machines must be cleaned just as regularly and carefully as other cooling equipment.

questions.question: Most microbes grow poorly when the pH is close to neutral (pH 7).
questions.description: Most microbes grow best in neutral pH conditions, in the pH range from 6.6 to 7.5.

questions.question: The monitoring logs made for own-check plans, e.g. logs of temperature measurements, must be stored at the workplace for 6 months.
questions.description: Logs must be stored for at least 1 year after selling a product. The information included can be used to trace errors and problems.

questions.question: Dirty root vegetables must have a separate work space.
questions.description: Dirt always contains many microbes. Dirty root vegetables must be handled separately from other products so that the microbes in the dirt do not spread to other food products.

questions.question: Disinfected work surfaces contain no microbes.
questions.description: Correctly done disinfection reduces the amount of microbes excellently on work surfaces and equipment. However, a disinfected work surface is not sterile.

questions.question: The amount of things covered in the waste disposal instructions must be the same for everyone in the food industry.
questions.description: The own-check plan's waste disposal instructions' coverage depends on what the done activities cover.

questions.question: In lunch restaurants a control measurement of the temperature of food served from serving equipment is done once a week.
questions.description: Control measurements on served products are performed daily. Exceptions are always written down and all temperatures are logged in the own-check plan forms once a week.

questions.question: Even thoroughly boiled food contains microbes.
questions.description: Bacteria spores will not be destroyed during boiling. When boiled food cools to less than 60 degrees Celsius the bacteria spores may reproduce again.

questions.question: If worktops look clean, they are definitely clean.
questions.description: Microbes are microorganisms that are invisible to the naked eye.

questions.question: It is not allowed to use useful microbes in baking.
questions.description: Yeast is used in baking to make dough rise.

questions.question: Large central kitchens and small cafés have the same own-check plan.
questions.description: All workplaces must design their own own-check plan that suits their activities. The acitivities, products and customers are different in small cafés and large kitchens. The own-check plans of large kitchens must be more precise and also more broad.

questions.question: After washing dishes must be dry before they can be piled for storing.
questions.description: Harmful microbes multiply in damp conditions, so dishes must be allowed to fully dry before piling.

questions.question: Permitted food additives are marked with E numbers.
questions.description: In addition to the category that indicates the intended use, additives also have a name or numerical code, i.e. an E number.

questions.question: Listeria bacteria are destroyed when a product is frozen.
questions.description: Freezing does not destroy microbes. Listeria can also reproduce in frozen foods.

questions.question: You can touch the inside surfaces of food packaging if you have just washed your hands.
questions.description: You should always try not to touch the inside surfaces of food packaging.

questions.question: Mould that has spread from blue cheese to other cheeses is not hazardous.
questions.description: Mould spreading from blue cheese to other cheeses, which the mould is not supposed to be in, is hazardous and can worsen the quality and also perish the cheeses. However, the spreading of the mould to other cheeses is not always a health risk.

questions.question: Vinegar lowers the pH value of a product and in this way makes the product last better.
questions.description: Especially the growth of bacteria can be prevented by increasing the acidity of a product.

questions.question: A low activity of water in food products means that the products can contain water, but microbes can't use the water to reproduce.
questions.description: The products can contain water, but microbes can not use it. The water activity can be lowered by adding sugar or salt to the products.

questions.question: Foreign raspberries may be used for making food if the product will be kept well refrigerated.
questions.description: Foreign raspberies must always be properly heated by boiling before serving. Using non-heated foreign rasberries creates a risk of listeria.

questions.question: Windows in food premises can be opened for ventilation.
questions.description: Windows and doors in food premises must be kept closed to prevent pests from entering the premises.

questions.question: Food products that contain preservatives can not cause food poisoning.
questions.description: Preservatives prevent and slow down the growth of microbes in food products. However, preservatives do not destroy food poisoning causing bacteria, which makes food poisoning possible.

questions.question: Waste disposal is an essential part of hygienic working in a professional kitchen.
questions.description: Appropriate waste bins and their regular emptying and cleaning, as well as the appropriate assortment and storage areas for waste that is going to be transported away, are all a part of good hygienic working. A professional kitchen's waste disposal is based on waste laws as well as regional waste disposal directives.

questions.question: There are no microbes in dried food products.
questions.description: Dried products last well due to having no water that bacteria could use to reproduce. However, the microbes have not been destroyed in dried products and the products can contain spores of bacteria, moulds or yeast.

questions.question: Milk spoils faster than sour milk.
questions.description: The pH value of milk is 7, which means it is neutral. The pH value of sour milk is lower, which means sour milk is acidized. It is harder for bacteria to reproduce in acidized milk products than in neutral products.

questions.question: An entire carrot spoils faster than a grated carrot.
questions.description: Treating a carrot and grating it shortens the time it lasts. During grating microbes spread onto the carrot and water inside the carrot becomes available for the microbes to use. Grated products also have more surface area than intact products; microbes, especially ones that require oxygen, are suitable to live on the surface of products.

questions.question: Frozen vegetables may contain listeria bacteria.
questions.description: Listeria can be found in unheated food products such as fresh vegetables and products made from these.

questions.question: Minced meat that has been prepared in a store can be sold on the day of preparation and the day after that.
questions.description: Minced meat prepared in a retail store and grounded liver can be sold on the day of preparation and the day after it has been prepared.

questions.question: Biofilm means plastic wrap that is specially made for food products.
questions.description: Biofilm can form onto e.g. the surface of a plate if prewashing is done with too hot water before proper dishwashing. Too hot water can burn albumin spots onto the surface of the dish and create biofilm, which is a suitable growing environment for microbes.

questions.question: Kitchen waste bins are always emptied after a work shift.
questions.description: Kitchen waste bins are emptied into the waste assortment room always when necessary during a work shift. At the same time the emptied waste bins must be washed.

questions.question: Listeria bacteria are not destroyed when a product is frozen.
questions.description: Freezing does not destroy microbes. Listeria can also reproduce in frozen foods.

questions.question: Cleaning plans are not a part of own-check plans.
questions.description: Cleaning plans are an important part of own-check plans. Cleaning plans include instructions and schedules for cleaning.

questions.question: Food products can be used safely after the use-by date if they do not look or smell bad.
questions.description: Perished or contaminated products are not always possible to notice just by using the senses (visually etc.) Easily perishable food products' packages have a use-by date marked on them, and after this date has passed the product must not be used or sold.

questions.question: The waste bins in waste assortment rooms do not need lids if they are emptied regularly times.
questions.description: The waste bins in waste assortment rooms need to have lids and need to be cleaned regularly enough. This way waste rooms do not attract pest insects and the rooms stay cleaner and more hygienic.

questions.question: The ice kept in transport cases for fresh fish must meet the purity requirements.
questions.description: Ice used with food products must only be made of water that meets the requirements for domestic water.

questions.question: Chopping vegetables improves their shelf life.
questions.description: Whole vegetables keep better than chopped vegetables. Handling food products impairs their shelf life.

questions.question: All easily perishable food products must be stored in temperatures under 6 degrees Celsius.
questions.description: This statement is correct, but one must notice that raw mince meat requires a storing temperature of at most 4 degrees Celsius, and fish and shellfish even while vacuum-packed must be stored between 0 and 3 degrees Celsius.

questions.question: All E-numbered additives improve the lastingness of food products.
questions.description: Food products can be made to last longer by adding preservatives to them. In the European Union, allowed preservatives have an E-number: for example, E 200 is sorbic acid and E 296 is malic acid. Preservatives that are allowed can be found, along with other additives, in an E-number list. Some preservatives can be found naturally in berries and fruits, such as in lingonberries and citrus fruit. E-numbers are also used to identify additives other than ones that improve lastingness. For example, color additives do not improve the lastingness of food products.

questions.question: Not all microbes and bacteria-spores in food products can be destroyed using any treatments.
questions.description: Sterilizing or radiating can destroy all bacteria or microbe-spores in food products. Canned food, such as canned tuna and canned baby food is sterilized by heating the packed products. Spices are one example of a product that can be treated by radiation.

questions.question: A delivery load that contains meat and fish products can be safely left at room temperature for three hours pending transfer into cold storage.
questions.description: The cold chain of perishable food products must not be interrupted at any point in the supply chain.

questions.question: Chicken eggs never contain salmonella.
questions.description: Chicken eggs can contain salmonella, although the risk is small in Finland.

questions.question: Norovirus is not spread in water.
questions.description: Norovirus infection can also be acquired from contaminated water.

questions.question: Food products can be used after the last use-by-date if the product does not look spoiled.
questions.description: The last use-by-date must be marked on easily perishable food products. The products can not be used nor sold after this date.

questions.question: It is not required to change single-use gloves worn on the hands if money is handled while wearing them.
questions.description: Only one phase of work can be done while wearing the same single-use gloves. If money is handled then the hands must be washed and the gloves must be changed.

questions.question: When a health inspector inspects a workplace, he or she will also check the workplace's own check plan's monitoring logs.
questions.description: Health inspectors make routine inspections in food production areas. The monitoring logs of the own-check plans are also part of the inspections. The logs must be stored for 1 year in the workplace. Only stored logs can prove that the workplace has followed its own-check plan accordingly.

questions.question: Raw milk is not suitable for small children, elderly people, pregnant women or people who have a severe disease.
questions.description: Because raw milk has not been pasteurized it can contain disease causing bacteria. The most important bacteria that are a threat to food product safety in raw milk are EHEC, campylo, listeria and salmonella bacteria.

questions.question: Food product employees are required to have good personal hygiene.
questions.description: Good personal hygiene, including regular washing, clean and neat hair, short nails and healthy cuticles are signs of good work hygiene as well.

questions.question: Frozen foods can be defrosted on a kitchen table if the liquid from the melting does not pour onto the table.
questions.description: All frozen foods must be defrosted in cold storage units. When defrosting, one must make sure that the defrosting product does not pour liquid onto any other food products placed or stored in the cold storage unit. Defrosted or just partially defrosted products can not be frozen again.

questions.question: Sterilizing only destroys microbes capable of reproducing.
questions.description: Sterilizing destroys reproductive spores as well as bacteria spores. Canned foods are produced with sterilization.

questions.question: Coffee cream and milk may be stored in room temperature, because they will be added to hot coffee.
questions.description: Milk and cream are easily perishable food products, and they must be served cold.

questions.question: Food production employees are allowed to wear colorless nail polish.
questions.description: Hands must not containt anything extra such as watches, jewellery, fake nails, nail polish or hand cream.

questions.question: Spices cannot cause food poisoning.
questions.description: In some cases spices, too, can cause a risk of food poisoning, and therefore they must be used and stored hygienically and with care just like other food products.

questions.question: Sterilizing allows easily perishable food products to be stored in room temperature.
questions.description: Canned foods are prepared by sterilizing them. This way canned meat, fish and baby food that has not been opened can be stored in room temperature.

questions.question: The shelf life of the products in the fruit section of a grocery store is affected by the correct handling of mouldy fruit.
questions.description: Mouldy fruits are not recommended for use and they must be removed and disposed of immediately.

questions.question: Open cartons of long-life (UHT) milk and pasteurised milk are stored in the same way.
questions.description: Open cartons of long-life (UHT) milk and pasteurised milk are kept in cold storage.

questions.question: Easily perishable food products do not require a storage instruction label if it is a commonly known product.
questions.description: Packages of easily perishable food products always require a label indicating the last day of use and storing instructions. The shown date is valid only for unopened products that have been stored in the right temperature.

questions.question: Any water can be used for washing potatoes as they have soil on them.
questions.description: Potatoes must always be washed with water that meets the requirements for domestic water.

questions.question: Ham slices left over from a buffet can be used for lunch the next day.
questions.description: Food products that have been served at a buffet must never be served again. Food starts to perish immediately after cooking. Contamination is slowed down by adhering to the correct temperatures, serving time and hygienic working methods. A buffet, which is visited by a lot of people, offers particularly good conditions for contamination.

questions.question: Eating is allowed while preparing food.
questions.description: Microbes in the mouth spread onto the hands while eating. Eating must be done in a separate area and after eating hands must be washed.

questions.question: All own-check plan related measurements must be recorded in own-check plan forms.
questions.description: Though recording all own-check related measurements is essential, all measurements do not need to be logged. For example, it is good to pay daily attention to the temperatures of cold storage, but only a weekly log entry is sufficient.

questions.question: Packages for non-easily perishable food products must have a label indicating their best-before date.
questions.description: Packaging labels for non-easily perishable food products show the best-before date. The accuracy of the date is determined by the product's shelf life. The product may be used after the date if its sensory qualities, such as smell, taste and look are impeccable.

questions.question: Food served in a lunch buffet must remain at +60 degrees celsius for the entire duration of the serving.
questions.description: If food that has been prepared by heating or cooking is not served immediately, it must be kept at a temperature of at least 60 degrees throughout the entire serving.

questions.question: The shelf life of food products can be extended by irradiating them.
questions.description: Only dried aromatic herbs, spices and vegetable seasonings are allowed to be irradiated. The purpose of irradiation is to eliminate bacteria and insects as well as to prevent the product from sprouting, for example.

questions.question: Botulism, a food poisoning caused by clostridium botulinum, is always a very weak food poisoning.
questions.description: Clostridium botulinum creates a very deadly toxin called botulin. The food poisoning caused by botulin can cause death.

questions.question: Organic food does not cause food poisoning as easily as "normal" food.
questions.description: Organic food is produced without fertilizers or pesticides. This does not affect food poisoning almost at all. The risk for food poisoning is the same between "normal" and organic food.

questions.question: A restaurant can use food products after their best before date has expired provided that the products are sufficiently well heated well.
questions.description: It is prohibited to sell or use food products after their best before date has expired, and they must not be used in the manufacture of food to be sold or served.

questions.question: Sneezing spreads harmful microbes into the surrounding environment in the droplets/spray.
questions.description: There are lots of microbes in the respiratory system and mouth which can spread into the surroundings.

questions.question: When receiving products one must make sure that they are moved into their appropriate, separate storage areas as soon as possible after the receival check.
questions.description: Products should be moved into their own storage areas as soon as possible after the receival check. Easily perishable food products can not be stored in room temperature for longer than 10-15 minutes.

questions.question: If a product or ingredient is suspected to be the cause of food poisoning in a customer, the product or ingredient should be gotten rid of as soon as possible.
questions.description: Suspected causes of food poisoning must not be gotten rid of but must instead be stored so that it can be examined in a laboratory to find the cause of the poisoning.

questions.question: Moulds and yeasts can reproduce in more acidized environments than bacteria.
questions.description: Most bacteria reproduce the best in the neutral zone. Moulds and yeasts can reproduce on a very broad pH zone, including products with acidity.

questions.question: Vegetables stored in a vinegared liquid can be kept in room temperature.
questions.description: Sterilized, can-packed and unopened vinegared products can be stored in room temperature. Vinegared products will last long due to the high acidity, but opened packages must be stored in cool temperatures.

questions.question: Oiva is a system which helps people to self-assess the food product safety of their workplace.
questions.description: Municipality food control authorities make Oiva-reports about the workplaces they inspect. It is not a part of the workplace's self-assessment.

questions.question: Fungi and plants can also cause food poisoning.
questions.description: Causes of food poisoning include microbes, toxins produced by microbes, parasites, poisonous animals, plants and fungi.

questions.question: Jewellery and watches must be removed from one's hands before washing hands.
questions.description: Jewellery and watches must always be removed before washing. They must also not be used while preparing food because they collect microbes which may travel into the prepared food and cause food poisoning risks.

questions.question: Food poisoning is always caused by some kind of bacteria or virus.
questions.description: Food poisoning can also be caused by parasites, protozoa, natural toxins (such as in morel mushrooms), poisonous plants or animals, chemicals or some other disease-causing particle.

questions.question: Foreign frozen raspberries can be served without heating because the freezing destroys any possible disease causers.
questions.description: Foreign frozen raspberries must always be heated properly (boiling for 5 minutes) before serving because they may contain the norovirus. Freezing does not destroy disease causers that have gotten into the food product before freezing, because viruses stay able to spread for a long time in different conditions.

questions.question: EHEC bacteria are not intestinal bacteria.
questions.description: EHEC bacteria is found especially in the intestines of cattle. EHEC bacteria create toxins in the intestines of humans. The toxin often causes bloody diarrhea and very uncomfortable stomache pains.

questions.question: Foreign raspberries may be used for making food if the product will be kept well refrigerated.
questions.description: Foreign raspberies must always be properly heated by boiling before serving. Using non-heated foreign rasberries creates a risk of listeria.

questions.question: Frozen foods can be defrosted on a kitchen table if the liquid from the melting does not pour onto the table.
questions.description: All frozen foods must be defrosted in cold storage units. When defrosting, one must make sure that the defrosting product does not pour liquid onto any other food products placed or stored in the cold storage unit. Defrosted or just partially defrosted products can not be frozen again.

questions.question: The lastingness of food products can also be improved during treatment by using hygienic work methods, clean surfaces and equipment.
questions.description: Ingredients and their handling equipment must be kept separate from cooked products to prevent cross-contamination. For example, differently colored cutting boards and equipment for different food groups, such as vegetables, fish, meat and cooked food helps to prevent cross-contamination.

questions.question: Beer is produced with the help of beneficial microbes.
questions.description: Beer is produced with yeast fermentation. Yeast is also used when producing wine.

questions.question: Cooked rice is not an easily perishable food product.
questions.description: Dry rice lasts in room temperature. Cooked rice contains moisture and because of this it is an easily perishable product. Cooked rice must be stored under 6 degrees Celsius.

questions.question: The incorrect storing temperature of food is a major cause for food poisoning.
questions.description: If food is stored in too warm temperatures, microbes that cause food poisoning will reproduce quickly. Because of this the temperatures of cold storage units and freezers must be monitored regularly using thermometers.

questions.question: A cleaning equipment storage room is not needed in a food production area.
questions.description: It's not always necessary to have a separate storage space for cleaning equipment. Food production areas need a separate storage, maintenance and drying space if the food production area requires it for constructional reasons. It's important to make sure that there are no risks for food safety and the hygienic treatment, maintenance and storage of cleaning equipment are done properly. If necessary the working stages and functions has to be separated structually or timely.

questions.question: Raw milk contains more microbes than pasteurized milk.
questions.description: When milk is pasteurized a large amount of microbes gets destroyed. For example listeria, salmonella and EHEC bacteria are destroyed during pasteurization.

questions.question: Self-service sales points need to be protected from droplets that spread into the air when someone coughs.
questions.description: Self-service sales points are protected from droplet transmissions from customers who cough.

questions.question: The toxins contained in fresh morel mushrooms can not be removed by only roasting the mushrooms.
questions.description: Morel mushrooms must be boiled twice for at least 5 minutes and washed thoroughly between the boilings.

questions.question: If food is cooled too slowly it can lead to food poisoning.
questions.description: Too slow cooling of food is a very common reason for food poisoning. Cooling should happen quickly (in under 4 hours) so that the microbes in the food can not reproduce and grow into large hazardous quantities. During cooling food has a dangerous temperature (between 6 and 60 degrees Celsius) where microbes reproduce very quickly.

questions.question: The amount of things covered in the waste disposal instructions must be the same for everyone in the food industry.
questions.description: The own-check plan's waste disposal instructions' coverage depends on what the done activities cover.

questions.question: The temperatures of cold storage equipment do not need to be measured if they feel cold enough.
questions.description: The temperatures of refrigerating equipment, drawers and cabinets must be measured and logged at the same time each day. Atypical measuring results are logged in the own-check forms and necessary measures are taken to restore the right temperature in that piece of equipment.

questions.question: Minced meat produced in a store can be sold on the day of production and the day after that.
questions.description: Minced meat is an easily perishable food product. Because of this the safety of minced meat produced in a store can not be ensured for a longer period of time. Minced meat should be stored at 4 degrees Celsius.

questions.question: Coffee cream and milk may be stored in room temperature, because they will be added to hot coffee.
questions.description: Milk and cream are easily perishable food products, and they must be served cold.

questions.question: Vegetables and fruit must be washed prior to food preparation with water that meets the requirements of household water.
questions.description: Taps in any food preparation space must provide water that meets the requirements of household water, which is used in preparing and making food as well as by staff to wash their hands.

questions.question: Yoghurt and viili contain live probiotics.
questions.description: Lactic acid bacteria play an important role in the production of dairy products.

questions.question: Hand washing sinks can be used for cleaning root vegetables.
questions.description: Enough hand washing areas must be available, and they must only be used for washing hands.

questions.question: Water is not necessary for microbes to reproduce.
questions.description: Dried products last well due to having no water that bacteria could use to reproduce. Microbes can't reproduce in dried products.

questions.question: The disinfection of working surfaces destroys all harmful microbes and sterilizes the surfaces.
questions.description: Even a thorough cleaning will destroy about 90% of micro-organisms. Disinfectants can be used to destroy nearly all microbes. However, even disinfectants can not sterilize working areas, because not all bacteria-spores die from disinfectants. When cleaning it is not essential to sterilize the environment but instead to regularly and properly clean and wash it.

questions.question: A working and up-to-date collection of recipes is part of the own-check plan.
questions.description: Regularly served food needs to have up-to-date recipes. Recipes can be used to check what different foods contain and how they are prepared during any problematic situations.

questions.question: When handling food products, employees should not touch their nose if possible.
questions.description: The nose contains lots of microbes which will spread onto the hands if the nose is touched.

questions.question: Food product employees are required to have good personal hygiene.
questions.description: Good personal hygiene, including regular washing, clean and neat hair, short nails and healthy cuticles are signs of good work hygiene as well.

questions.question: All food that is being served needs to be sampled daily.
questions.description: Taken samples must be placed into a container and then placed into a freezer. If food poisonings are suspected, then these samples must be available for research.

questions.question: Guide dogs are not allowed inside food product stores.
questions.description: Guide dogs are always allowed in areas meant for customers. However, no animals can be taken inside food product handling areas or storage areas.

questions.question: Bacteria spores are destroyed in freezers.
questions.description: Bacteria do not reproduce in freezers. However, the spores of the bacteria do not get destroyed during freezing.

questions.question: Working areas and surfaces must be cleaned regularly during work shifts and after work is over.
questions.description: Regular cleaning, done every 2-4 hours, of working equipment and surfaces with clean cleaning equipment, substances and water gets rid of leftover pieces of food, dust and other dirt that protects microorganisms and is used as living space by the organisms.

questions.question: Temperature measurements stated in own-check plans do not have to made when one is busy.
questions.description: Only regularly done measurements can prove that the own-check plan has been adhered to at a workplace.

questions.question: Bacteria can reproduce in more dry environments than moulds.
questions.description: Only some moulds can reproduce in very dry products. For example, bread becomes spoiled only due to mould; bacteria and yeasts can not reproduce in the bread.

questions.question: A bar of soap is unhygienic when used by staff in food premises.
questions.description: It is recommended to use liquid soap to wash your hands. A bar of soap is not hygienic enough.

questions.question: Listeriosis should be avoided especially during pregnancy.
questions.description: Listeriosis during pregnancy can cause miscarriages or premature birth.

questions.question: HACCP is a food poisoning causing bacteria.
questions.description: HACCP stands for Hazard Analysis and Critical Control Points, which is a part of own-check plans. When working with an own-check plan these critical points must be identified and constantly monitored carefully.

questions.question: In lunch restaurants a control measurement of the temperature of food served from serving equipment is done once a week.
questions.description: Control measurements on served products are performed daily. Exceptions are always written down and all temperatures are logged in the own-check plan forms once a week.

questions.question: Intestinal bacteria cannot spread from hands to food.
questions.description: Intestinal bacteria can spread to food even from the hands.

questions.question: Appropriate freezing improves the lastingness of a product.
questions.description: Freezing prevents microbe reproduction because frozen water can not be used by microbes for reproduction. Frozen products have recommended storing times, and freezing never improves the microbiological quality of a product. Frozen products should be defrosted slowly in a cold storage unit when they are going to be used. A product that has been defrosted once can not be frozen again.

questions.question: Wastebins do not need to be cleaned.
questions.description: Wastebins must not be broken, must include a lid and must also be cleaned regularly.

questions.question: Self-service sales points need to be protected from droplets that spread into the air when someone coughs.
questions.description: Self-service sales points are protected from droplet transmissions from customers who cough.

questions.question: Salmonella can only get transmitted through feces.
questions.description: Salmonella can get transmitted through feces by way of poor hand hygiene but also via contaminated food products, such as raw meat and eggs.

questions.question: Bacteria can reproduce in more acidized environments than moulds and yeasts.
questions.description: Bacteria that are a threat to food product safety reproduce the best in the neutral zone. Because of this the growth of these bacteria can be prevented by increasing the acidity of a product.

questions.question: Sneezing spreads harmful microbes into the surrounding environment in the droplets/spray.
questions.description: There are lots of microbes in the respiratory system and mouth which can spread into the surroundings.

questions.question: Dried products last well due to having no water that bacteria could use to reproduce.
questions.description: Water is necessary for microbes to reproduce. Dried products last well due to having no water.

questions.question: Oiva is a system which helps to assess the food product safety of different workplaces.
questions.description: Municipality food control authorities do routine inspections at workplaces. Oiva is the publishing system for the results of these inspections, and is co-ordinated by Ruokavirasto.

questions.question: The norovirus is not destroyed when a food product is frozen.
questions.description: The norovirus lasts for long amounts of time and is able to spread even in the cold or in frozen foods.

questions.question: Customers and employees are allowed to use the same toilet.
questions.description: Strict toilet and hand hygiene must be used in food production. This is not possible if toilets are shared with customers. Customers may have diseases, can be drunk or they can be small children; in each case the use of the same toilets is a risk.

questions.question: Protective gloves are used to protect employees' hands from dirt, so that their hands do not need to be washed as often.
questions.description: Gloves are also used to protect food from microbes spread by hands. Gloves are a great way to keep work hygiene good when tasks must be changed quickly. Gloves must be changed regularly enough while working to keep hygiene good. It is also good to properly wash and dry one's hands when changing gloves. Gloves must always be changed immediately after touching door handles or taps.

questions.question: Moulds can reproduce in more dry environments than bacteria.
questions.description: Only some moulds can reproduce in very dry products. For example, bread becomes spoiled only due to mould; bacteria and yeasts can not reproduce in the bread.

questions.question: Workers in the food industry, e.g. the owner of a small café, must inform local food control authorities about their activities.
questions.description: All workers in the food industry must inform food control authorities about their activities. The informing must be done before beginning the activities. When founding a food industry workplace, e.g. a sausage factory, the activities must also be approved by the authorities.

questions.question: Temperature measurements are to be made only by the superiors of a workplace.
questions.description: The instructions of own-check plans must be adhered to by all employees. Because of this temperature measurements are also the responsibility of all other employees.

questions.question: During food preparation one can go wash one's hands in the staff restroom.
questions.description: There must be a separate hand washing spot in immediate proximity to the food preparation area.

questions.question: Earth does not contain food poisoning causing bacteria.
questions.description: Earth can contain e.g. bacillus cereus or clostridum bacteria. Both of these are common causers of food poisoning.

questions.question: Food that has been heated once is always sterile.
questions.description: Heating food does not make it sterile. Heating might not destroy all of the spores of bacteria and moulds. Microbe growth can start again from the spores in the right conditions, which can cause the food to become perished. Ready food can also be contaminated after heating by e.g. hands of employees.

questions.question: The proper washing of hands removes all harmful bacteria from the skin.
questions.description: Even proper washing of hands does not remove all bacteria. Small skin damage and undersides of nails affect the amount of bacteria. Hands must be properly washed between different phases of work.

questions.question: Moulds and yeasts can reproduce in more acidized environments than bacteria.
questions.description: Most bacteria reproduce the best in the neutral zone. Moulds and yeasts can reproduce on a very broad pH zone, including products with acidity.

questions.question: Frozen food products are stored in a freezer at a temperature of -15°C or colder.
questions.description: The temperature in a freezer must be -18°C or colder.

questions.question: The checking of food and the monitoring of temperature when receiving food products is a part of the own-check plan.
questions.description: The correct storing temperatures affect the lastingness and safety of food. The monitoring of temperature by measurements is an important part of the own-check plan when receiving food products.

questions.question: Mould toxins are destroyed when food products are boiled.
questions.description: Mould toxins can not be destroyed by only boiling them.

questions.question: In Finland the milk found in cartons in stores is almost always pasteurized milk.
questions.description: Only raw milk that has been bought directly from a dairy farm is not usually pasteurized.

questions.question: If a product has been cooled once already, heating it again must be done very carefully.
questions.description: Reheating cooled food must be done very carefully to make sure its microbiological quality stays good. Heating the product thoroughly to 70 degrees Celsius should be possible. Because of this a microwave oven is not a good tool for reheating, because different ingredients in the food will heat in different ways.

questions.question: Own-check plans are meant for the leadership of food industry companies.
questions.description: Own-check plans include lots of instructions and lists responsibilities. Because of this it is important that all employees get to know the own-check plan and adhere to it while working.

questions.question: Pasteurized dairy products can be stored unopened in room temperature.
questions.description: Pasteurizing does not make it possible to store dairy products in room temperature. UHT-treated dairy products can be stored in room temperature if they are unopened.

questions.question: Restaurants must have an own-check plan.
questions.description: All workplaces in the food industry need to ensure the safety of their products with an own-check plan. Own-check plans are required in all food industry workplaces.

questions.question: The norovirus is not destroyed when a food product is frozen.
questions.description: The norovirus lasts for long amounts of time and is able to spread even in the cold or in frozen foods.

questions.question: The cleanliness of waste rooms is not essential for hygiene because only waste is stored in those rooms.
questions.description: The cleanliness and hygiene of waste rooms is an essential part of taking care of food product hygiene because employees enter the waste room during the work day while wearing their work clothes, which they wear everywhere else as well. Waste rooms must be kept clean and organised.

questions.question: Transported products and cargo being received do not have to be checked.
questions.description: The quality of arriving products must be checked and the temperatures of easily perishable products must be measured. The results must be written down.

questions.question: Cleaning plans include accurate instructions about how and when cleaning is done.
questions.description: A cleaning plan is an essential part of an own-check plan. Cleaning plans include more accurate instructions on the cleaning of all parts of a food production area.

questions.question: A working and up-to-date collection of recipes is part of the own-check plan.
questions.description: Regularly served food needs to have up-to-date recipes. Recipes can be used to check what different foods contain and how they are prepared during any problematic situations.

questions.question: If an employee has inflamed wounds on their hands, they must not handle easily perishable food products.
questions.description: A person with inflamed wounds or other inflamed areas on their hands or other visible skin must not handle unpacked food products. Small wounds in the hands must be cleaned and protected with a water-proof bandage, and single-use gloves must be used.

questions.question: Sour milk spoils faster than milk.
questions.description: The pH value of milk is 7, which means it is neutral. The pH value of sour milk is lower, which means sour milk is acidized. It is harder for bacteria to reproduce in acidized milk products than in neutral products.

questions.question: Listeriosis should be avoided especially during pregnancy.
questions.description: Listeriosis during pregnancy can cause miscarriages or premature birth.

questions.question: Own-check plans must also include e.g. cleaning and waste disposal procedures.
questions.description: Own-check plans must, along with microbiological risks, consider the hygiene of personnel, cleaning, receival of products and actions to be done when pests have been noticed.

questions.question: If you detect deviations from the limit values, you must take the measurement again the next day.
questions.description: When the limit determined in the own-check plan is exceeded you must record the result, take the relevant corrective measures and record them and then record the new results.

questions.question: Food products are always safe if the best before date has not yet expired.
questions.description: A food product may be contaminated even if there are still several days until the best before date. Contamination may be caused by unhygienic tools or work environment and incorrect temperatures, for example.

questions.question: Kitchens in hospitals should have separate spaces for different work phases such as the treatment of root vegetables, baking and dishwashing.
questions.description: When each work phase is done in its own separate area the work is hygienic and the risk of cross-contamination is smaller.

questions.question: Food poisoning causing bacteria can not be found naturally.
questions.description: Microbes are everywhere: in the air, water, earth, plants, animals and humans. Some of these microbes cause food poisoning.

questions.question: When a new detergent is introduced into a kitchen, the cleaning plan in the own-check plan is updated.
questions.description: It is important that the own-check plan is always up to date. All changes to the own-check plan, e.g. introduction of a new detergent, must be updated in the cleaning plan.

questions.question: Arriving products and cargo must be checked when received.
questions.description: The quality of arriving products must be checked and the temperatures of easily perishable products must be measured. The results must be written down.

questions.question: After washing dishes must be dry before they can be piled for storing.
questions.description: Harmful microbes multiply in damp conditions, so dishes must be allowed to fully dry before piling.

questions.question: Employers have the responsibility to monitor the health of employees and thus make sure that they are capable of working.
questions.description: All employees have the responsibility to tell their superiors about illnesses or any symptoms hazardous to food product safety, such as diarrhea, a sore throat, inflamed wounds or inflamed respiratory ducts. Employees with such symptoms must not handle food products.

questions.question: Raw milk can contain yersinia.
questions.description: Raw milk has not been pasteurized. Yersinia is destroyed when milk is heated to over 70 degrees Celsius; in other words it is destroyed when the milk is pasteurized.

questions.question: In lunch restaurants a control measurement of the temperature of food served from serving equipment is done once a week.
questions.description: Control measurements on served products are performed daily. Exceptions are always written down and all temperatures are logged in the own-check plan forms once a week.

questions.question: A cleaning and washing program must be included in the own-check plan.
questions.description: Areas that need to be cleaned, washing and cleaning methods for each area and specific cleaning equipment and substances (if required) must be listed in the own-check plan. The effectiveness of the cleaning must be checked visually daily and the responsible person has to log results for example once a week or always when abnormalities are noticed.

questions.question: The correct concentration of detergent significantly affects the cleaning result.
questions.description: Detergents and disinfectants must be measured out in accordance with the manufacturer's instructions. A solution that is stronger than recommended does not usually guarantee a better cleaning result, and a solution that is diluted too much may give a worse result.

questions.question: Due to salmonella risks, fowl and poultry meat must always be heated thoroughly to over 75 degrees Celsius.
questions.description: Fowl/poultry can contain salmonella naturally. Salmonella bacteria must be alive to cause an illness. The meat of fowl/poultry is safe if it is heated thoroughly to over 75 degrees Celsius.

questions.question: Listeria is destroyed when a product is heated to over 70 degrees Celsius.
questions.description: Because listeria is destroyed during heating, products that are not heated are risk food products: vacuum-packed and protective gas packed fish, meat and blue cheese and normal cheese produced from non-pasteurized milk.

questions.question: Smoking is allowed at the loading docks of kitchens.
questions.description: Loading docks are a part of food production areas; smoking is not allowed in food production areas.

questions.question: If a member of staff becomes infected with salmonella while abroad, he or she cannot spread the infection in Finland.
questions.description: Most cases of salmonella infection are acquired abroad, and an infection acquired abroad can also spread in Finland.

questions.question: Oiva is a system which helps people to self-assess the food product safety of their workplace.
questions.description: Municipality food control authorities make Oiva-reports about the workplaces they inspect. It is not a part of the workplace's self-assessment.

questions.question: A restaurant can use food products after their best before date has expired provided that the products are sufficiently well heated well.
questions.description: It is prohibited to sell or use food products after their best before date has expired, and they must not be used in the manufacture of food to be sold or served.

questions.question: Ultra-high-temperature processing (UHT) uses higher temperatures than pasteurizing.
questions.description: Ultra-high-temperature processing is done in much higher temperatures than pasteurizing. UHT destroys most bacteria spores and because of this products that have been treated with UHT can be stored in room temperature.

questions.question: Fungi and plants can also cause food poisoning.
questions.description: Causes of food poisoning include microbes, toxins produced by microbes, parasites, poisonous animals, plants and fungi.

questions.question: Oiva-reports must be placed at the entrance of the café, restaurant etc. so that customers can read them.
questions.description: Oiva-reports are published documents about routine inspections. These reports are also published online at www.oivahymy.fi

questions.question: UHT-treated milk products can be stored in room temperature.
questions.description: In UHT (ultra high temperature) -treatment products are rapidly heated to a high temperature and packaged in sterilized packaging. This is why treated products cana be kept in room temperature.

questions.question: A grated carrot spoils faster than an entire carrot.
questions.description: Treating a carrot and grating it shortens the time it lasts. During grating microbes spread onto the carrot and water inside the carrot becomes available for the microbes to use. Grated products also have more surface area than intact products; microbes, especially ones that require oxygen, are suitable to live on the surface of products.

questions.question: Norovirus is not spread in water.
questions.description: Norovirus infection can also be acquired from contaminated water.

questions.question: Washing machines do not need to be washed separately, because the washing temperatures are hot enough to destroy harmful microbes.
questions.description: Washing machines, as well as their dust filters and other removable parts, must be washed and dried regularly. The surfaces of the machines must also be swiped and the lids left open so that the machine's inside dries.

questions.question: The serving dishes of coffee cream or coffee milk can be filled many times during a day.
questions.description: Coffee cream or coffee milk must always be served from a clean dish, and after the dish is empty it should be changed and washed.

questions.question: The disinfection of working surfaces destroys all harmful microbes and sterilizes the surfaces.
questions.description: Even a thorough cleaning will destroy about 90% of micro-organisms. Disinfectants can be used to destroy nearly all microbes. However, even disinfectants can not sterilize working areas, because not all bacteria-spores die from disinfectants. When cleaning it is not essential to sterilize the environment but instead to regularly and properly clean and wash it.

questions.question: Detergents and disinfectants used in food premises can be stored anywhere.
questions.description: Detergents and disinfectants must be stored in such a place that they do not endanger food safety.

questions.question: Old and worn cleaning equipment can spread harmful microbes into food premises.
questions.description: It is important to make sure that cleaning equipment is always clean and in good condition.

questions.question: The cooling of food products should be done by using cooling cabinets (chillers).
questions.description: Only cooling cabinets can ensure sufficiently fast and effective cooling.

questions.question: Temperature measurements stated in the own-check plan must be done according to the own-check plan.
questions.description: Only regularly done measurements can prove that the own-check plan has been adhered to at a workplace.

questions.question: The human skin does not contain microbes.
questions.description: Especially the face, scalp, mouth, nose etc. contain microbes. Food poisoning causing Staphylococcus bacteria can also be found on the skin.

questions.question: When a kitchen floor is washed properly, there cannot be any microbes on it.
questions.description: Microbes are everywhere, even on newly washed kitchen surfaces.

questions.question: Windows in food premises can be opened for ventilation.
questions.description: Windows and doors in food premises must be kept closed to prevent pests from entering the premises.

questions.question: Products that have gone through ultra-high-temperature treatment (UHT) can be stored in room temperature.
questions.description: During UHT products are sterilized with quick heating. Unopened packages can be stored in room temperature because most bacteria spores have been destroyed.

questions.question: Fungi and plants can also cause food poisoning.
questions.description: Causes of food poisoning include microbes, toxins produced by microbes, parasites, poisonous animals, plants and fungi.

questions.question: EHEC bacteria are not intestinal bacteria.
questions.description: EHEC bacteria is found especially in the intestines of cattle. EHEC bacteria create toxins in the intestines of humans. The toxin often causes bloody diarrhea and very uncomfortable stomache pains.

questions.question: Moulds can not create mould toxins.
questions.description: Some moulds can create mould toxins such as mycotoxins and aflatoxins. Because of this mouldy products should not be used.

questions.question: Listeria and yersinia can not reproduce in refrigerator temperatures.
questions.description: Earth and various bodies of water contain microbes, such as listeria and yersinia, that are able to survive cold conditions well. Listeria and yersinia can reproduce in very cold refrigerator temperatures.

questions.question: A cooked meal and the raw ingredients used to prepare it can be stored in the same container during transport.
questions.description: Cooked meals and raw ingredients are always stored separately in their own clean containers.

questions.question: Raw milk can contain yersinia.
questions.description: Raw milk has not been pasteurized. Yersinia is destroyed when milk is heated to over 70 degrees Celsius; in other words it is destroyed when the milk is pasteurized.

questions.question: Dairy products that contain lactose keep well at room temperature.
questions.description: Dairy-based products that are produced by using at least pasteurisation are stored at +8 degrees. Ultra-heat treated milk keeps at room temperature for several months.

questions.question: Washing machines do not need to be washed separately, because the washing temperatures are hot enough to destroy harmful microbes.
questions.description: Washing machines, as well as their dust filters and other removable parts, must be washed and dried regularly. The surfaces of the machines must also be swiped and the lids left open so that the machine's inside dries.

questions.question: Officials benefit from own-check plans the most because a large part of planning the monitoring is given to the food product industry's companies.
questions.description: Own-check plans that are done well make it easier for companies to upkeep food product safety because resources used for monitoring can be focused on things essential for company activities. Knowledge of the quality of the activities will also improve when the activities are planned. In the best case customer satisfaction, profitability and officials' trust will improve.

questions.question: Food tasting must be done with a spoon.
questions.description: Food must never be touched with the fingers if it is not necessary. Spoons should be used for tasting.

questions.question: Frozen fish is thawed on the kitchen counter.
questions.description: Frozen food products are always thawed in a cold room.

questions.question: If a food product includes nuts it must say so on the package.
questions.description: Packaging markings must tell if the product contains ingredients that cause allergic reactions; the EU has a compiled list of these.

questions.question: Self-service sales points need to be protected from droplets that spread into the air when someone coughs.
questions.description: Self-service sales points are protected from droplet transmissions from customers who cough.

questions.question: Products that have gone through ultra-high-temperature treatment (UHT) can not be stored in room temperature.
questions.description: During UHT products are sterilized with quick heating. Unopened packages can be stored in room temperature because most bacteria spores have been destroyed.

questions.question: Even in small cafés the same cleaning equipment can not be used to clean the customer areas and the kitchen.
questions.description: If the same cleaning equipment is used, microbes can easily spread from customers to the kitchen in the equipment.

questions.question: The own-check plan must include cleaning instructions that are up-to-date.
questions.description: Cleaning instructions for equipment and work areas must be available and known to the personnel, so that cleaning procedures will be the same and integrated between everyone, and so that employees will be able to easily disassemble equipment to clean them properly.

questions.question: If the film/foil of a vacuum-package is loose or tensionless the package is damaged.
questions.description: The package has probably been broken and air has entered it. The lastingness of the product can not be estimated after this, because the use-by-date marked on the package is based on the assumption that the package contains no air (oxygen that microbes can use to grow.)

questions.question: Jewellery and watches must be removed from one's hands before washing hands.
questions.description: Jewellery and watches must always be removed before washing. They must also not be used while preparing food because they collect microbes which may travel into the prepared food and cause food poisoning risks.

questions.question: Own-check plans are meant for the leadership of food industry companies.
questions.description: Own-check plans include lots of instructions and lists responsibilities. Because of this it is important that all employees get to know the own-check plan and adhere to it while working.

questions.question: Rings can be used when handling unpacked food products.
questions.description: Rings can not be used when handling unpacked food products, because microbes have optimal growth conditions underneath them.

questions.question: Waste disposal is not a part of the own-check plan.
questions.description: Waste disposal is a part of the own-check plan. Health inspectors also pay attention to how well waste is disposed of in food related premises. The regular emptying and cleaning of waste containers must be looked after.

questions.question: Microbes can not reproduce in food products that are in a protective gas package.
questions.description: Protective gas packages contain little or no oxygen. This prevents microbes that require oxygen from growing. However, the product can also contain microbes that do not need oxygen.

questions.question: Employees are free to decide who is responsible for the own-check plan at the beginning of each shift.
questions.description: Designated persons who have been trained for the task are responsible for the various areas of the own-check plan.

questions.question: Cooked rice is not an easily perishable food product.
questions.description: Dry rice lasts in room temperature. Cooked rice contains moisture and because of this it is an easily perishable product. Cooked rice must be stored under 6 degrees Celsius.

questions.question: Wine is produced with the help of beneficial microbes.
questions.description: The production of wine and beer uses yeast. Yeast is a beneficial microbe.

questions.question: Food control authorities must approve a company's own-check plan to allow the company to begin its activites in the industry.
questions.description: Approval from authorities is not required to start activities. The plans are part of the companies' personal documents, which authorities will check and intervene in if problems are noticed.

questions.question: Pasteurization improves the lastingness of food products.
questions.description: In dairies milk products are pasteurized, which means that they are heated to 72 degrees Celsius for 15 seconds and then afterwards cooled immediately. A large amount of bacteria capable of reproducing is destroyed, but this treatment does not destroy all microbes. Pasteurized milk must be stored under 6 degrees Celsius in a refrigerator. Juices are another example of a product which can gain better lastingness when pasteurized during production.

questions.question: Few bacteria can reproduce in acidized products.
questions.description: Bacteria that are a threat to food product hygiene reproduce the best when in the neutral zone. Bacteria growth especially can be prevented by increasing the acidity of a product.

questions.question: Pasteurisation of milk destroys listeria bacteria.
questions.description: Pasteurisation of milk is a process that destroys listeria bacteria. Milk is pasteurised when heated to 72°C for about 15 seconds.

questions.question: Good cleaning results are verified by taking samples from surfaces.
questions.description: Samples are taken from surfaces in order to verify that cleaning efforts are adequate.

questions.question: Restaurants must have an own-check plan.
questions.description: All workplaces in the food industry need to ensure the safety of their products with an own-check plan. Own-check plans are required in all food industry workplaces.

questions.question: Most food poisoning causing microbes will be destroyed when the temperature of food is more than 75 degrees Celsius.
questions.description: Most food poisoning causing microbes can not live in temperatures over 75 degrees Celsius. However, bacteria-spores can live in much higher temperatures.

questions.question: Food products can be used after the last use-by-date if the product does not look spoiled.
questions.description: The last use-by-date must be marked on easily perishable food products. The products can not be used nor sold after this date.

questions.question: During food preparation one can go wash one's hands in the staff restroom.
questions.description: There must be a separate hand washing spot in immediate proximity to the food preparation area.

questions.question: Chefs are allowed to handle money and prepare food without washing their hands in between.
questions.description: Notes and coins contain a lot of microbes, and you must always wash your hands after handling money before you start cooking.

questions.question: The training of personnel is an important part of own-check plans.
questions.description: The training of personnel is an essential part of own-check plans. In the food industry technology, equipment, ingredients, preparation methods and even risks change, so it is important to update knowledge regularly.

questions.question: The human skin does not contain microbes.
questions.description: Especially the face, scalp, mouth, nose etc. contain microbes. Food poisoning causing Staphylococcus bacteria can also be found on the skin.

questions.question: Vegetables that do not have any visible soil on them do not contain any harmful microbes.
questions.description: There can be microbes on vegetables that do not have any visible soil on them. Microbes enter plants from the environment when they grow and from irrigation water, for example.

questions.question: Ascorbic acid (vitamin C) can be used as a preservative.
questions.description: Ascorbic acid lowers the pH value of food products. The growth of bacteria especially can be slowed down by increasing the acidity of products.

questions.question: Contamination means e.g. unwanted microbes and/or chemicals spreading into a product.
questions.description: Contamination can be microbiological, chemical or physical. It is unwanted and can cause perishing of food products or food poisoning.

questions.question: When a food industry workplace, e.g. a sausage factory, is being founded, the activities of the workplace must be approved in advance by local food control authorities.
questions.description: Workplaces that handle animal-based food products require an approval for their activities. Only informing of the activities is not enough.

questions.question: Food products containing food poisoning bacteria can always be noticed by bad smells and other visual perishing symptoms.
questions.description: Food poisoning bacteria can not be noticed using the senses (visually etc.) in food products. Perished food products might contain food poisoning bacteria, but the bacteria might not cause any changes in the appearance of the food product.

questions.question: Water is not necessary for microbes to reproduce.
questions.description: Dried products last well due to having no water that bacteria could use to reproduce. Microbes can't reproduce in dried products.

questions.question: Bacillus cereus is a food poisoning causing bacteria.
questions.description: Bacillus cereus is a spore bacteria. Risk food products for this are e.g. raw milk and rice.

questions.question: Chopping vegetables improves their shelf life.
questions.description: Whole vegetables keep better than chopped vegetables. Handling food products impairs their shelf life.
