questions.question: Food products are always safe if the best before date has not yet expired.
questions.description: A food product may be contaminated even if there are still several days until the best before date. Contamination may be caused by unhygienic tools or work environment and incorrect temperatures, for example.

questions.question: An entire block of cheese spoils faster than cheese that has been sliced.
questions.description: The spoiling of a product usually starts on the surface. The surface contains a lot of oxygen and some amounts of microbes have always been spread onto the surface during production and packing. Products with lots of surface area always spoil faster than similar products that are still in their original entire form.

questions.question: Women that are pregnant should not eat vacuum-packed salmon due to the higher risk of listeriosis.
questions.description: Risk food products are products that have not been heated and have a long selling time. Vacuum-packed salmon has not been heated and has a long selling time. The vacuum-package does not prevent listeria from reproducing because listeria can grow in conditions without oxygen. Proper cold storage does not prevent the risk either because listeria can reproduce in refrigerator temperatures.

questions.question: Prepared salads can be stored in room temperature without a risk of food poisoning.
questions.description: Prepared salads are easily perishable food products. For example, chopped or grated vegetables and root vegetables, meat, fish and mayonnaise are often ingredients of prepared salads, so they have to be stored in the cold.

questions.question: Bacteria can reproduce in more dry environments than moulds.
questions.description: Only some moulds can reproduce in very dry products. For example, bread becomes spoiled only due to mould; bacteria and yeasts can not reproduce in the bread.

questions.question: Rings can be used when handling unpacked food products.
questions.description: Rings can not be used when handling unpacked food products, because microbes have optimal growth conditions underneath them.

questions.question: Sliced sourdough bread keeps better than a whole loaf of sourdough bread.
questions.description: Handling food products by chopping or slicing them, for example, impairs their shelf life.

questions.question: Pasteurization improves the lastingness of food products.
questions.description: In dairies milk products are pasteurized, which means that they are heated to 72 degrees Celsius for 15 seconds and then afterwards cooled immediately. A large amount of bacteria capable of reproducing is destroyed, but this treatment does not destroy all microbes. Pasteurized milk must be stored under 6 degrees Celsius in a refrigerator. Juices are another example of a product which can gain better lastingness when pasteurized during production.

questions.question: Self-service sales points need to be protected from droplets that spread into the air when someone coughs.
questions.description: Self-service sales points are protected from droplet transmissions from customers who cough.

questions.question: Frozen food products can be thawed outdoors in summer as sunlight protects them from contamination.
questions.description:
Frozen food products are generally thawed in a cold room or
in a similar refrigerated space so that the temperature of the surface of the food product
does not rise above the other parts of the products. Sunlight does not protect food against contamination.

questions.question: Raw milk is not suitable for people with a weakened immune system.
questions.description: Because raw milk has not been pasteurized it can contain pathogens (disease-causing bacteria.) The most important bacteria that can cause danger to food safety in raw milk are EHEC, listeria, salmonella and campylo bacteria.

questions.question: Raw and cooked food products must always have separate cold storage spaces.
questions.description: If only one cold-store is available, raw products are placed on the lower shelves and cooked ones on the top shelves in order to avoid risking contamination.

questions.question: Chefs can use their work shoes during their travel to and from their workplace.
questions.description: Work shoes must not be worn outside the workplace to prevent microbes from spreading into the food production area.

questions.question: Tapeworms are parasites found especially in shellfish.
questions.description: Tapeworms can be found in the roe (eggs) and muscles of lake fish, such as bass, pike, burbot and ruffe.

questions.question: Employees are free to decide who is responsible for the own-check plan at the beginning of each shift.
questions.description: Designated persons who have been trained for the task are responsible for the various areas of the own-check plan.

questions.question: All transport companies can transport food to restaurants provided that their vehicles are spacious enough.
questions.description: Professional transporting of food requires certification from the appropriate authorities as well as an own-check plan.

questions.question: Bacteria toxins disappear when food is boiled.
questions.description: Some bacteria cause toxins in the food. If toxins have appeared in the food, they weill not disappear during boiling.

questions.question: Visually clean work surfaces guarantee their microbiological cleanliness.
questions.description: Microbiological cleanliness can not be guaranteed by using just the bare eye. Correct cleaning methods and equipment, as well as regular and proper cleaning, guarantee the cleanliness much better. Samples can also be taken of the cleanliness of specific surfaces if required.

questions.question: All milk products must always be stored in cold storage, where the temperature is less than 6 degrees Celsius.
questions.description: Ultra-high-temperature processing sterilizes milk products. In UHT processing milk is heated for a few seconds to at least 135 degrees Celsius and packed into disinfected packaging in a clean area.This treatment destroys all reproducing micro-organisms and all unopened packages can be stored in room temperature.

questions.question: Dirty root vegetables can be stored in cardboard boxes above meat products on cold room shelves.
questions.description: Dirt always contains many microbes. Dirty root vegetables must be handled separately from other products so that the microbes in the dirt do not spread to other food products.

questions.question: Kitchen cloths can include lots of microbes even if they are visually clean-looking.
questions.description: Kitchen cloths are often wet and can contain waste food. Microbes can reproduce quickly in these conditions.

questions.question: Working surfaces must be dried properly after cleaning.
questions.description: Harmful microbes multiply in damp conditions, so surfaces must be fully dried after cleaning.

questions.question: The same knife can be used for cutting raw and cooked meat.
questions.description: Heated food must be protected from contamination after being heated. Ingredients and the equipment used to handle those ingredients must be kept separate from cooked products to prevent cross-contamination.

questions.question: Food production areas do not produce hazardous waste which would require special attention.
questions.description: Cleaning and washing substances as well as their packaging, and for example fluorescent lamps, are hazardous waste and must be recycled appropriately.

questions.question: Cleaning equipment must be cleaned always after being used.
questions.description: Dirty and wet cleaning equipment contain lots of microbes. The results of cleaning with this equipment are not good.

questions.question: Mould that has spread from blue cheese to other cheeses is not hazardous.
questions.description: Mould spreading from blue cheese to other cheeses, which the mould is not supposed to be in, is hazardous and can worsen the quality and also perish the cheeses. However, the spreading of the mould to other cheeses is not always a health risk.

questions.question: Salmonella infection can only be acquired from foreign food products.
questions.description: Salmonella can be transmitted through both domestic and foreign food products or water contaminated with animal or human faeces, and it can cause food poisoning.

questions.question: Mashed potato is an easily perishable food product.
questions.description: Pre-made foods are easily perishable products. Easily perishable foods must be stored in the cold, under 6 degrees Celsius.

questions.question: Moulds can produce dangerous toxins in food products.
questions.description: Moulds can grow on food products. While growing, some moulds produce toxins that are hazardous for the human health. Mould toxins will sometimes not get destroyed when heating a food product, even though the mould itself might be destroyed.

questions.question: Equipment used for slicing food products must be cleaned regularly.
questions.description: Equipment used for slicing food products is cleaned regularly by disassembling it and washing the parts with the appropriate washing agent.

questions.question: When unprotected, cooked and uncooked food products must be stored in separate areas.
questions.description: Unprotected cooked and uncooked food products must have separate storage areas to prevent cross-contamination.

questions.question: Most food poisoning causing microbes will be destroyed when the temperature of food is more than 75 degrees Celsius.
questions.description: Most food poisoning causing microbes can not live in temperatures over 75 degrees Celsius. However, bacteria-spores can live in much higher temperatures.

questions.question: EHEC bacteria are intestinal bacteria.
questions.description: EHEC bacteria is found especially in the intestines of cattle. EHEC bacteria create toxins in the intestines of humans. The toxin often causes bloody diarrhea and very uncomfortable stomache pains.

questions.question: Pizza toppings do not need to be cold stored because pizzas are baked in a very hot oven.
questions.description: Perishable food products that require cold storage must always be cold stored.

questions.question: Hepatitis A can spread in food products.
questions.description: The most important viruses that reproduce in the intestines of humans are the norovirus and hepatitis A. Both viruses last for a long time and are able to spread in the cold and even in frozen foods.

questions.question: Only old cold storage equipment must have a thermometer.
questions.description: All cold storage equipment in food production areas must have a thermometer.

questions.question: Staphylococcus aureus is a food poisoning bacteria.
questions.description: The human skin, nose and mucous membranes can contain staphylococcus aureus. Good hand hygiene is important due to this.

questions.question: Fresh fish is an easily perishable food product.
questions.description: Fresh fish is a very easily perishable food product. Fresh fish products must be stored at the temperature of melting ice, max 2 degrees Celsius.

questions.question: The uniform used for food product work can also be used while travelling to work if using one's own car.
questions.description: Using the work uniform outside of work is not allowed. Work uniforms and shoes are meant to protect food products from becoming dirty.

questions.question: A food product can be sold if it is packed in a vacuum pack that has softened only a little.
questions.description: Air has entered a softened vacuum pack, which means that the product is no longer safe.

questions.question: Even thoroughly boiled food contains microbes.
questions.description: Bacteria spores will not be destroyed during boiling. When boiled food cools to less than 60 degrees Celsius the bacteria spores may reproduce again.

questions.question: The Food Act determines how food is stored in food premises.
questions.description: The Food Act determines how food is handled, transported and stored.

questions.question: Salmonella infections can be symptomless.
questions.description: It is possible for salmonella infections to not be noticed. One might not notice the infection at all, but can still spread the salmonella to others. In practice salmonella can only be spread if one's hands are not washed well after going to the toilet.

questions.question: When the best-before-date of a product has passed, the product usually spoils quickly.
questions.description: The best-before-date is found on products sold in room temperature (with the exception of milk products.) The products will not spoil too easily, so the products can be kept for sale and used after the best-before-date.

questions.question: Chefs can use their work shoes only inside the food production area.
questions.description: Work shoes must not be worn outside the workplace to prevent microbes from spreading into the food production area.

questions.question: Some microbes can reproduce even in food products that are in a protective gas package.
questions.description: Protective gas packages contain little or no oxygen. This prevents microbes that require oxygen from growing. However, the product can also contain microbes that do not need oxygen.

questions.question: Biofilm means plastic wrap that is specially made for food products.
questions.description: Biofilm can form onto e.g. the surface of a plate if prewashing is done with too hot water before proper dishwashing. Too hot water can burn albumin spots onto the surface of the dish and create biofilm, which is a suitable growing environment for microbes.

questions.question: Crates can be stored on the loading dock as long as they are protected from the rain.
questions.description: Storing crates on the loading dock is a hygiene hazard as they attract birds and other animals.

questions.question: Bacteria spores are destroyed in freezers.
questions.description: Bacteria do not reproduce in freezers. However, the spores of the bacteria do not get destroyed during freezing.

questions.question: Raw milk can contain yersinia.
questions.description: Raw milk has not been pasteurized. Yersinia is destroyed when milk is heated to over 70 degrees Celsius; in other words it is destroyed when the milk is pasteurized.

questions.question: Spices cannot cause food poisoning.
questions.description: In some cases spices, too, can cause a risk of food poisoning, and therefore they must be used and stored hygienically and with care just like other food products.

questions.question: Ascorbic acid (vitamin C) can not be used as a preservative.
questions.description: Ascorbic acid lowers the pH value of food products. The growth of bacteria especially can be slowed down by increasing the acidity of products.

questions.question: If an employee gets a small wound on his or her hand, it is enough to protect it with a bandage.
questions.description: A bandage alone is not enough. A single-use glove should also be worn on the hand; this prevents water from entering the wound.

questions.question: Beneficial bacteria usually make it harder for harmful bacteria to grow.
questions.description: Harmful bacteria have to compete with beneficial bacteria for living space and nutrition. Beneficial bacteria can change living conditions in food products, e.g. the acidity, such that it becomes worse for harmful bacteria and makes them grow slower or not at all.

questions.question: Some viruses can last and stay reproductive in water.
questions.description: Viruses can not reproduce in water. However, they can remain able to reproduce later on for a long time while in water.

questions.question: Microbes reproduce the fastest in their own optimal temperatures.
questions.description: All microbes have their own optimal temperatures where reproduction is the fastest. In the insides of humans and animals, the temperature range between 20 and 45 degrees Celsius is the best for microbes. Anything hotter or colder than this causes microbes to reproduce slower.

questions.question: Irradiation can be used to destroy microbes in dairy products.
questions.description: Irradiation destroys microbes in dry herbs and spices.

questions.question: If food is cooled too slowly it can lead to food poisoning.
questions.description: Too slow cooling of food is a very common reason for food poisoning. Cooling should happen quickly (in under 4 hours) so that the microbes in the food can not reproduce and grow into large hazardous quantities. During cooling food has a dangerous temperature (between 6 and 60 degrees Celsius) where microbes reproduce very quickly.

questions.question: Monitoring the temperature when taking samples, storing and serving products is an essential part of own-check plans.
questions.description: Taking samples from products to be served and the hygienic state of food preparation areas, as well as monitoring the temperature of storing areas, are important parts of daily activities in food preparation. When measurements have been regularly logged it is easier to begin fixing procedures during possible problematic situations, and to prove that good hygiene is being used.

questions.question: Freezing does not always destroy food poisoning microbes.
questions.description: Freezing does not kill microbes, but prevents them from multiplying.

questions.question: The own-check plan helps to make sure that there are fewer unsafe food products.
questions.description: The most important objective of the own-check plan is to improve food safety.

questions.question: Dirty root vegetables and pre-made food products can be stored in the same cold room.
questions.description: Dirt always contains many microbes. Dirty root vegetables must be handled separately from other products so that the microbes in the dirt do not spread to other food products.

questions.question: Pasteurization improves the lastingness of food products.
questions.description: In dairies milk products are pasteurized, which means that they are heated to 72 degrees Celsius for 15 seconds and then afterwards cooled immediately. A large amount of bacteria capable of reproducing is destroyed, but this treatment does not destroy all microbes. Pasteurized milk must be stored under 6 degrees Celsius in a refrigerator. Juices are another example of a product which can gain better lastingness when pasteurized during production.

questions.question: The more microbes there are in a cleaning cloth, the worse it smells.
questions.description: Microbes are usually odourless microorganisms that are invisible to the naked eye.

questions.question: Ingredients should always be handled with clean equipment instead of hands whenever possible.
questions.description: Even washed hands contain some amounts of microbes. Even some healthy people carry food poisoning causing microbes on their skin. Using clean equipment is more hygienic.

questions.question: Raw ingredients containing gluten must be labelled and stored in closed containers in a storage room.
questions.description: Raw ingredients containing allergens and gluten must be labelled and stored separately in closed containers.

questions.question: Dishes do not need to be pre-washed before being put into a washing machine if the washing temperature is hot enough.
questions.description: Dishes must always be pre-washed before being put into a washing machine. It is important to get rid of protein spots with cool water so that the protein does not stick to the dishes in hot temperatures. The biofilm that the protein creates acts as a living space for microbes.

questions.question: The waste disposal procedures for professional kitchens, such as recycling, are decided upon between the personnel.
questions.description: A professional kitchen's waste disposal is based on waste laws as well as regional waste disposal directives.

questions.question: Food that is being served while cold must have its temperature measured and marked down.
questions.description: Temperature measurements of food that is being served are a part of own-check plans. The results of the measurements must be mark down in the monitoring logs of the own-check plans and then stored at the workplace for 1 year.

questions.question: Frozen food products can be thawed outdoors in summer as sunlight protects them from contamination.
questions.description:
Frozen food products are generally thawed in a cold room or
in a similar refrigerated space so that the temperature of the surface of the food product
does not rise above the other parts of the products. Sunlight does not protect food against contamination.

questions.question: The results of Oiva-reports can be viewed by anyone online.
questions.description: The Oiva system is used to allow consumers to view the results of routine inspections.

questions.question: Food production employees are allowed to wear colorless nail polish.
questions.description: Hands must not containt anything extra such as watches, jewellery, fake nails, nail polish or hand cream.

questions.question: Old and worn cleaning equipment can spread harmful microbes into food premises.
questions.description: It is important to make sure that cleaning equipment is always clean and in good condition.

questions.question: Food products are allowed to freeze during transport and this does not cause any harm.
questions.description: Food must not be frozen during transport as this will impair the hygienic quality of the food products. Perishable food products that require cold storage are transported in temperatures that do not exceed those set for storing perishable food products.

questions.question: Plants can be displayed and sold anywhere in a grocery store as long as adequate ventilation is provided.
questions.description: Plants must be located as far as possible from unpackaged perishable food products. There are lots of microbes on the surface of plants and in the soil, and these may spread to food products.

questions.question: EHEC bacteria are intestinal bacteria of cattle.
questions.description: This intestinal bacteria can only found in food products if the work hygiene is not proper during milking or slaughtering.

questions.question: Food poisoning is always caused by bacteria that has been accidentally let into food.
questions.description: Food poisoning can often be caused by storing food for too long in hazardous temperatures, too slow cooling or ineffective heating. These are situations where bacteria have had time to reproduce and multiply.

questions.question: Food poisoning suspicions must always be informed to health officials.
questions.description: Informing health officials is only required if more than 5 people have become sick. Informing must also be done if the epidemic has spread in a school, hospital or other institution or if the cause is suspected to be in a commercial food product or in a some other way wide-spread product.

questions.question: Prepared salads can be stored in room temperature without a risk of food poisoning.
questions.description: Prepared salads are easily perishable food products. For example, chopped or grated vegetables and root vegetables, meat, fish and mayonnaise are often ingredients of prepared salads, so they have to be stored in the cold.

questions.question: If the temperature of a cold storage unit is too high it must not be marked down on the own-check plan's monitoring logs.
questions.description: Measured temperatures must be marked down in the own-check plan's monitoring logs, even if they are too high or too low. The logs must also contain information on what fixing procedure has been made to correct the incorrect temperature.

questions.question: Chopping vegetables improves their shelf life.
questions.description: Whole vegetables keep better than chopped vegetables. Handling food products impairs their shelf life.

questions.question: Any water can be used for washing potatoes as they have soil on them.
questions.description: Potatoes must always be washed with water that meets the requirements for domestic water.

questions.question: A tool made of wood is a hygiene hazard.
questions.description: Wood is a porous material and can absorb water, dirt and detergents, and it can stay damp for a long time.

questions.question: Food poisoning microbes can only spread through the air.
questions.description: Food poisoning microbes can be transmitted into food in many ways such as via hands, soil, contaminated water or airborne dust particles. Rodents, insects and birds can also spread food poisoning microbes.

questions.question: The use of snus (similar to chewing tobacco) is not allowed during food preparation.
questions.description: When handling food products personal hygiene is important; snus must not be used because of hygienic reasons.

questions.question: Brooms and mops can be stored on the floor in the corner of a cleaning equipment storage room.
questions.description: Brooms and mops will not dry if they are stored on the floor. Microbes can reproduce quickly in wet cleaning equipment.

questions.question: The most hygienic tools are well-washed hands.
questions.description: The handling of food products should be done with clean equipment instead of hands whenever possible. Clean and appropriate equipment is one of the most effective ways to prevent food products from contamination.

questions.question: Pasteurization improves the lastingness of food products.
questions.description: In dairies milk products are pasteurized, which means that they are heated to 72 degrees Celsius for 15 seconds and then afterwards cooled immediately. A large amount of bacteria capable of reproducing is destroyed, but this treatment does not destroy all microbes. Pasteurized milk must be stored under 6 degrees Celsius in a refrigerator. Juices are another example of a product which can gain better lastingness when pasteurized during production.

questions.question: Permitted food additives are marked with E numbers.
questions.description: In addition to the category that indicates the intended use, additives also have a name or numerical code, i.e. an E number.

questions.question: Intestinal bacteria can spread from hands to food.
questions.description: Intestinal bacteria can spread to food even from the hands.

questions.question: Employees are free to decide who is responsible for the own-check plan at the beginning of each shift.
questions.description: Designated persons who have been trained for the task are responsible for the various areas of the own-check plan.

questions.question: Boxes meant for transporting food can be stored outside if there is no space indoors.
questions.description: Food transportation boxes must be stored in an area where they do not get dirty. Restaurant and transportation companies agree on the frequency of collection and cleaning of boxes and trolleys.

questions.question: Cooked and uncooked products should always be handled on different working surfaces and with different equipment.
questions.description: Microbes will spread to cooked products if they are handled with the same equipment or on the same surfaces as raw products.

questions.question: The acidity of food products affects the reproduction of bacteria in the products.
questions.description: Increasing the acidity of a food product makes it harder for many harmful microbes to reproduce. Because of this, lactic acid fermentation is a good traditional way to store e.g. vegetables. The fermentation is based on how lactic acid works. Lactic acid bacteria (LAB) is a good example of beneficial microbes, which has good health benefits. All microbes are thus not harmful for food products.

questions.question: Even thoroughly boiled food contains microbes.
questions.description: Bacteria spores will not be destroyed during boiling. When boiled food cools to less than 60 degrees Celsius the bacteria spores may reproduce again.

questions.question: Norwalk-like viruses (NLV) will be destroyed if they are in temperatures higher than 90 degrees Celsius for 2 minutes.
questions.description: Food poisoning causing NLV will be destroyed using heat treatment. However, it can withstand very high temperatures. 2 minutes in over 90 degrees Celsius temperatures is enough to remove the virus from food products.

questions.question: Food products can be used after the last use-by-date if the product does not look spoiled.
questions.description: The last use-by-date must be marked on easily perishable food products. The products can not be used nor sold after this date.

questions.question: During food preparation one can go wash one's hands in the staff restroom.
questions.description: There must be a separate hand washing spot in immediate proximity to the food preparation area.

questions.question: Microbes are destroyed when meat is minced.
questions.description: When meat is minced, the bacteria on its surface spread throughout the minced meat.

questions.question: Washing machines do not need to be washed separately, because the washing temperatures are hot enough to destroy harmful microbes.
questions.description: Washing machines, as well as their dust filters and other removable parts, must be washed and dried regularly. The surfaces of the machines must also be swiped and the lids left open so that the machine's inside dries.

questions.question: Food that is being served while cold must have its temperature measured and marked down.
questions.description: Temperature measurements of food that is being served are a part of own-check plans. The results of the measurements must be mark down in the monitoring logs of the own-check plans and then stored at the workplace for 1 year.

questions.question: Raw milk can contain yersinia.
questions.description: Raw milk has not been pasteurized. Yersinia is destroyed when milk is heated to over 70 degrees Celsius; in other words it is destroyed when the milk is pasteurized.

questions.question: Food products stored in protective gas do not have to be stored in the cold because the protective gas protects the products from perishing.
questions.description: Food products stored in packages with protective gas must always be stored in the cold according to the instructions on the packaging. Protective gas packages have normal air changed into air that contains little or no oxygen to prevent microbes that use oxygen from reproducing. Protective gas prevents e.g. the surface of meat from darkening and thus keeps the product sensually appealling.

questions.question: If one's hands have been carefully washed then food products can be handled with hands.
questions.description: Clean equipment should always be used instead of hands, no matter how well washed, whenever possible.

questions.question: The same knife can be used for cutting raw and cooked meat.
questions.description: Heated food must be protected from contamination after being heated. Ingredients and the equipment used to handle those ingredients must be kept separate from cooked products to prevent cross-contamination.

questions.question: Microbiological samples of served food are taken only if there is suspicion of there being something wrong with the product.
questions.description: Microbiological samples of served food are taken daily. Samples are kept for 2 weeks, so that potential food poisoning cases can be solved if need be.

questions.question: HACCP is a food poisoning causing bacteria.
questions.description: HACCP stands for Hazard Analysis and Critical Control Points, which is a part of own-check plans. When working with an own-check plan these critical points must be identified and constantly monitored carefully.

questions.question: Coffee cream and milk may be stored in room temperature, because they will be added to hot coffee.
questions.description: Milk and cream are easily perishable food products, and they must be served cold.

questions.question: A wound that has been cleaned must also be carefully covered with a bandage.
questions.description: A cleaned wound may spread harmful microbes to food products.

questions.question: Cleaning equipment must be cleaned once a week.
questions.description: Cleaning equipment must be cleaned after each use and must then be left to dry.

questions.question: Food products can not be stored on the floor of dry storage rooms.
questions.description: Storing food products on the floor is not a hygienic way to store food. Floors always contain more microbes than shelves.

questions.question: Cleaning equipment that is old and in bad condition can spread harmful microbes to a food production area.
questions.description: Cleaning equipment wears down and becomes dirty during use. They often contain microbes even though they are washed regularly. Cleaning equipment should be renewed regularly.

questions.question: Tap water does not contain microbes.
questions.description: Even tap water can contain microbes. Tap water cleanliness must be monitored using the senses. Water samples can also be regularly sent for chemical and microbiological inspections.

questions.question: All E-numbered additives improve the lastingness of food products.
questions.description: Food products can be made to last longer by adding preservatives to them. In the European Union, allowed preservatives have an E-number: for example, E 200 is sorbic acid and E 296 is malic acid. Preservatives that are allowed can be found, along with other additives, in an E-number list. Some preservatives can be found naturally in berries and fruits, such as in lingonberries and citrus fruit. E-numbers are also used to identify additives other than ones that improve lastingness. For example, color additives do not improve the lastingness of food products.

questions.question: Beer is not produced with the help of beneficial microbes.
questions.description: Beer is produced with yeast fermentation. Yeast is a beneficial microbe.

questions.question: The shelf life of food products can be extended by irradiating them.
questions.description: Only dried aromatic herbs, spices and vegetable seasonings are allowed to be irradiated. The purpose of irradiation is to eliminate bacteria and insects as well as to prevent the product from sprouting, for example.

questions.question: Bacteria are always harmful on human skin or in the intestines.
questions.description: Beneficial bacteria exist on the skin and in the intestines that protect humans from harmful bacteria and strengthen the immune system.

questions.question: There may be flies in a food premises even if the waste management is well organised.
questions.description: Flies in the premises are always a sign of inadequate cleaning.

questions.question: The toxins contained in fresh morel mushrooms can not be removed by only roasting the mushrooms.
questions.description: Morel mushrooms must be boiled twice for at least 5 minutes and washed thoroughly between the boilings.

questions.question: Taking samples from prepared food products is a part of the own-check plan.
questions.description: Samples must be taken of served food products for example from lunch servings so that they can be stored for possible food poisoning cases.

questions.question: Products in protective gas packages do not have any microbes.
questions.description: Products in protective gas packages always contain some microbes. The protective gas is used to prevent microbes that require oxygen from growing.

questions.question: Vegetables that do not have any visible soil on them do not contain any harmful microbes.
questions.description: There can be microbes on vegetables that do not have any visible soil on them. Microbes enter plants from the environment when they grow and from irrigation water, for example.

questions.question: Tap water can cause food poisoning.
questions.description: Tap water cleanliness must be monitored using the senses. Water samples can also be regularly sent for chemical and microbiological inspections. For example the food poisoning causing norovirus lasts well in water.

questions.question: Disinfected work surfaces contain no microbes.
questions.description: Correctly done disinfection reduces the amount of microbes excellently on work surfaces and equipment. However, a disinfected work surface is not sterile.

questions.question: Smoking is not allowed at the loading docks of kitchens.
questions.description: Loading docks are a part of food production areas; smoking is not allowed in food production areas.

questions.question: Few bacteria can reproduce in acidized products.
questions.description: Bacteria that are a threat to food product hygiene reproduce the best when in the neutral zone. Bacteria growth especially can be prevented by increasing the acidity of a product.

questions.question: After handling waste it is important to check the cleanliness of one's work clothes and keep care of hand hygiene.
questions.description: If work clothes get badly dirty when handling waste they should be changed before continuing working. Hand hygiene is also important to give specific attention to after handling waste.

questions.question: Microbes reproduce in dry products.
questions.description: Microbes need water to reproduce. Microbes will not reproduce in dried products but dried products can contain spores of bacteria, moulds or yeast.

questions.question: The post-contamination of a cooked product can be prevented by using appropriate and clean storing containers.
questions.description: Good hand hygiene, clean working equipment and hygienic storing containers protect cooked products from post-contamination due to hazards that affect the safety of the product after heating it.

questions.question: Raw milk contains less microbes than pasteurized milk.
questions.description: When milk is pasteurized a large amount of microbes gets destroyed. For example listeria, salmonella and EHEC bacteria are destroyed during pasteurization. The bacteria in raw milk have not been destroyed with heat treatment.

questions.question: An animal can be slaughtered in a restaurant if a special permit has been granted.
questions.description: It is prohibited to slaughter animals in restaurants.

questions.question: If food does not smell bad it can not be spoiled.
questions.description: Many food poisoning causing bacteria can reproduce in food without causing changes that can be noticed with the senses (visually, smell etc.)

questions.question: Self-service sales points need to be protected from droplets that spread into the air when someone coughs.
questions.description: Self-service sales points are protected from droplet transmissions from customers who cough.

questions.question: Chefs are required to have a hygiene proficiency passport even if their employment is not permanent.
questions.description: Chefs handle easily perishable food products in their work. This means that chefs must pass a hygiene proficiency test at least 3 months after starting their work.

questions.question: The waste disposal procedures for professional kitchens, such as recycling, are decided upon between the personnel.
questions.description: A professional kitchen's waste disposal is based on waste laws as well as regional waste disposal directives.

questions.question: Bacteria spores will stay alive even when a product is dried.
questions.description: Spores are the form of bacteria that will last. Spores are able to endure dryness, boiling, salting and the cold. Bacteria can not reproduce in dry products but they will survive as spores.

questions.question: Cleaning plans are not a part of own-check plans.
questions.description: Cleaning plans are an important part of own-check plans. Cleaning plans include instructions and schedules for cleaning.

questions.question: Samples taken from batches of food prepared in large kitchens must be stored for 1-2 months.
questions.description: Samples are taken from large kitchens' food batches to trace possible food poisoning causes easier. Samples must be taken daily from all batches being somehow served or sold and the samples must be stored appropriately marked in a freezer for 1-2 weeks. During this time a majority of food poisoning symptoms start to appear.

questions.question: When a food industry workplace, e.g. a sausage factory, is being founded, the activities of the workplace must be approved in advance by local food control authorities.
questions.description: Workplaces that handle animal-based food products require an approval for their activities. Only informing of the activities is not enough.

questions.question: Ultra-high-temperature processing (UHT) uses higher temperatures than pasteurizing.
questions.description: Ultra-high-temperature processing is done in much higher temperatures than pasteurizing. UHT destroys most bacteria spores and because of this products that have been treated with UHT can be stored in room temperature.

questions.question: It is important to visually monitor cleanliness on a daily basis in addition to regular cleaning.
questions.description: Everyone working in a food premises must constantly monitor its cleanliness.

questions.question: Monitoring the temperature when taking samples, storing and serving products is an essential part of own-check plans.
questions.description: Taking samples from products to be served and the hygienic state of food preparation areas, as well as monitoring the temperature of storing areas, are important parts of daily activities in food preparation. When measurements have been regularly logged it is easier to begin fixing procedures during possible problematic situations, and to prove that good hygiene is being used.

questions.question: Production of cheese uses beneficial microbes.
questions.description: Clean, controlled and beneficial microbes are used in cheeses. During storage these microbes will create taste ingredients in the cheese.

questions.question: When receiving products one must make sure that they are moved into their appropriate, separate storage areas as soon as possible after the receival check.
questions.description: Products should be moved into their own storage areas as soon as possible after the receival check. Easily perishable food products can not be stored in room temperature for longer than 10-15 minutes.

questions.question: Food products must never be cooled or stored outside.
questions.description: Food products must not be cooled or stored outside. All equipment and products, e.g. boxes containg baked goods, must be stored inside.

questions.question: Harmful microbes can multiply at a refrigerator's temperature.
questions.description: Harmful microbes can multiply at a refrigerator's temperature and even at 0°C. Listeria and yersinia are pathogens that are tolerant to cold.

questions.question: Cold storage units should not be filled beyond their set fill limits because the food products might not stay cold enough.
questions.description: The fill limit is an instruction on usage by the producer of the cold storage unit. The limit should not be crossed because food products outside the limit will not stay cold enough.

questions.question: Raw ingredients containing gluten must be labelled and stored in closed containers in a storage room.
questions.description: Raw ingredients containing allergens and gluten must be labelled and stored separately in closed containers.

questions.question: Unpeeled and peeled carrots will last the same amount of time as long as they are stored in the cold.
questions.description: Earthy and dirty, untreated root vegetables will last long in appropriate cold storage units, but all treatments will worsen their lastingness.

questions.question: Visually clean work surfaces guarantee their microbiological cleanliness.
questions.description: Microbiological cleanliness can not be guaranteed by using just the bare eye. Correct cleaning methods and equipment, as well as regular and proper cleaning, guarantee the cleanliness much better. Samples can also be taken of the cleanliness of specific surfaces if required.

questions.question: Cleaning rags must be changed regularly.
questions.description: The hygiene of cleaning rags in areas with food products is very important. The rags must be washed and changed regularly so that they will not spread food poisoning bacteria or microbes.

questions.question: An entire block of cheese spoils faster than cheese that has been sliced.
questions.description: The spoiling of a product usually starts on the surface. The surface contains a lot of oxygen and some amounts of microbes have always been spread onto the surface during production and packing. Products with lots of surface area always spoil faster than similar products that are still in their original entire form.

questions.question: When unprotected, cooked and uncooked food products must be stored in separate areas.
questions.description: Unprotected cooked and uncooked food products must have separate storage areas to prevent cross-contamination.

questions.question: During the cooling of food microbes are able to reproduce in the food.
questions.description: The danger zone for food temperatures is between 6 and 60 degrees Celsius. Microbes can reproduce in food when the temperature is within this danger zone. During the cooling of food the food is within this danger zone.

questions.question: Some viruses can last and stay reproductive in water.
questions.description: Viruses can not reproduce in water. However, they can remain able to reproduce later on for a long time while in water.

questions.question: Dirty root vegetables and pre-made food products can not be stored in the same cold room.
questions.description: Dirt always contains many microbes. Dirty root vegetables must be handled separately from other products so that the microbes in the dirt do not spread to other food products.

questions.question: The safety data sheets of detergents (washing chemicals) must always be kept close to their storage location.
questions.description: Safety data sheets must be kept near detergents so that the user of the detergent can read e.g. the first aid instructions.

questions.question: Cleaning plans are a part of own-check plans.
questions.description: Cleaning plans are an important part of own-check plans. Cleaning plans include instructions and schedules for cleaning.

questions.question: Officials benefit from own-check plans the most because a large part of planning the monitoring is given to the food product industry's companies.
questions.description: Own-check plans that are done well make it easier for companies to upkeep food product safety because resources used for monitoring can be focused on things essential for company activities. Knowledge of the quality of the activities will also improve when the activities are planned. In the best case customer satisfaction, profitability and officials' trust will improve.

questions.question: Raw fish cannot contain listeria bacteria
questions.description: Raw fish may also contain listeria bacteria.

questions.question: A microbiological sample of a food product can be placed in any container.
questions.description: A microbiological sample of a food product must always be placed in a container that is definitely clean.

questions.question: Food production areas' waste bins must be cleaned regularly.
questions.description: The cleanliness and hygiene of waste bins must be taken care of regularly. Waste bins in kitchens should be cleaned always after they are emptied.

questions.question: Food poisoning symptoms always start within one day of consuming a perished food product.
questions.description: Food poisoning symptoms can already begin in one hour since consuming a perished food product, but they can also begin after many days of no symptoms.

questions.question: A cleaning equipment storage room must be included in a food production area.
questions.description: It's not always necessary to have a separate storage space for cleaning equipment. Food production areas need a separate storage, maintenance and drying space if the food production area requires it for constructional reasons. It's important to make sure that there are no risks for food safety and the hygienic treatment, maintenance and storage of cleaning equipment are done properly. If necessary the working stages and functions has to be separated structually or timely.

questions.question: Cleaning equipment that is old and in bad condition can spread harmful microbes to a food production area.
questions.description: Cleaning equipment wears down and becomes dirty during use. They often contain microbes even though they are washed regularly. Cleaning equipment should be renewed regularly.

questions.question: Bacteria spores can not be destroyed by boiling.
questions.description: Bacteria do not reproduce in boiling hot food. However, the spores of the bacteria do not get destroyed during boiling.

questions.question: If food is cooled too slowly it can lead to food poisoning.
questions.description: Too slow cooling of food is a very common reason for food poisoning. Cooling should happen quickly (in under 4 hours) so that the microbes in the food can not reproduce and grow into large hazardous quantities. During cooling food has a dangerous temperature (between 6 and 60 degrees Celsius) where microbes reproduce very quickly.

questions.question: Using own-check plans takes a lot of time and resources.
questions.description: Well-planned own-check plans saves time and resources. Resources used for monitoring can be focused on the most important areas, activities and control points. Resources can also be focused on the most effective preventive actions. In problematic situations correct procedures will be known and mistakes can be fixed quickly.

questions.question: Customer feedback is a part of the own-check plan.
questions.description: It is useful to pay attention to appropriate customer feedback when carrying out the own-check plan. Customer feedback can be viewed as a way to enhance quality of service. Feedback should be written down, discussed with the staff and utilized in developing procedures and protocols.

questions.question: You are allowed to use snus (nuuska in Finnish) while preparing food.
questions.description: The use of snus (nuuska in Finnish) is prohibited while preparing food.

questions.question: The own-check system involves monitoring how quickly food products cool down to storage temperature.
questions.description: Monitoring temperatures is an important part of the own-check system.

questions.question: Lactic acid bacteria (LAB) are used when producing yoghurt.
questions.description: Yoghurt and other fermented milk products use LAB in their production. LAB create lactic acid, which cause acidity in the products.

questions.question: Washed, clean dishes can only be handled with clean hands.
questions.description: If clean dishes are handled with dirty hands, microbes and dirt will spread from the hands onto the dishes.

questions.question: Chefs are required to have a hygiene proficiency passport even if their employment is not permanent.
questions.description: Chefs handle easily perishable food products in their work. This means that chefs must pass a hygiene proficiency test at least 3 months after starting their work.

questions.question: A food product can be sold if it is packed in a vacuum pack that has softened only a little.
questions.description: Air has entered a softened vacuum pack, which means that the product is no longer safe.

questions.question: Milk can be stored at room temperature during the breakfast service.
questions.description: Milk and cream are perishable food products and they must be served cold.

questions.question: You must remove all rings before washing your hands to make sure that no dirt remains under the rings.
questions.description: A lot of dirt and microbes live under rings, which means that rings must be removed before washing your hands.

questions.question: A piece of rotten fruit affects the shelf life of other pieces of fruit that are near it.
questions.description: A piece of rotten fruit also spoils other pieces of fruit kept in the same dish, so it is important to dispose of rotten fruit.

questions.question: Freezing in a sufficiently cold temperature improves the lastingness of products.
questions.description: Products can be stored by freezing them, but one must notice that freezing affects the quality of different food products. For example, fish, meat and baked goods dry up easily during freezing, so the quality of products stored in freezing must be checked regularly.

questions.question: It is important to use cleaning methods that remove dust efficiently when cleaning food premises.
questions.description: Cleaning methods that remove dust efficiently are used for cleaning food premises. Surface dust can be effectively removed by vacuuming and wiping surfaces with a microfibre cloth or a damp towel.

questions.question: Marinating prevents meat from spoiling.
questions.description: Meat can contain harmful microbes even if it is marinated.

questions.question: All monitoring logs made for own-check plans must be stored for at least a year at the workplace.
questions.description: Only stored monitoring logs can prove that the own-check plan has been adhered to.

questions.question: High salt content prevents harmful microbes from multiplying in a product
questions.description: Strong salting of a product changes the state of its water so that microbes can not reproduce. However, salted products such as mushrooms must still be stored in cool temperatures to prevent microbes on their surface from perishing them.

questions.question: Food products can be cooled in the same freezer where frozen products are stored.
questions.description: Food products must first be cooled with separate cooling equipment and moved afterwards into a freezer for storage.

questions.question: A waiter must be able to tell customers the ingredients of a food product that has not been packed.
questions.description: A waiter must be able to provide customers with information about food products verbally and, if necessary, also in writing.

questions.question: Tapeworms can be found in the roe (eggs) and muscles of some lake fish.
questions.description: Tapeworms can be found in the roe (eggs) and muscles of lake fish, such as bass, pike, burbot and ruffe. Proper cooking or freezing (2 days minimum) will destroy the tapeworm.

questions.question: Waste bins in food premises may contain microbes that are a health hazard.
questions.description: It is important to make sure that waste bins are regularly emptied and that they are clean by washing them with appropriate detergents.

questions.question: Waste disposal is not a part of the own-check plan.
questions.description: The own-check plan always includes instructions for waste disposal. How much the instructions cover always depends on the activities and what the activities cover. It is important to set daily assignments and responsibility areas.

questions.question: The priority of waste laws is to make people working in the food industry responsible for assorting their waste.
questions.description: The priority of waste laws is to lessen the amount of waste and its effects.

questions.question: Workers in the food industry can be found responsible for a customer becoming sick.
questions.description: Product liability laws also cover food products. If a customer is able to provide sufficient evidence, a worker in the food industry can be found responsible for causing a sickness in the customer.

questions.question: Cleaning plans include accurate instructions about how and when cleaning is done.
questions.description: A cleaning plan is an essential part of an own-check plan. Cleaning plans include more accurate instructions on the cleaning of all parts of a food production area.

questions.question: Listeria is destroyed when a product is heated to over 70 degrees Celsius.
questions.description: Because listeria is destroyed during heating, products that are not heated are risk food products: vacuum-packed and protective gas packed fish, meat and blue cheese and normal cheese produced from non-pasteurized milk.

questions.question: Food products can be sold after the last use-by-date if it is sold at a discount price.
questions.description: The last use-by-date must be marked on easily perishable food products. The products can not be used nor sold after this date.

questions.question: Carrots covered with soil do not contain harmful microbes because soil is a pure natural product.
questions.description: Many microbes are part of the normal microbial growth in soil, which means that carrots covered in soil contain microbes.

questions.question: Brooms and mops can be stored on the floor in the corner of a cleaning equipment storage room.
questions.description: Brooms and mops will not dry if they are stored on the floor. Microbes can reproduce quickly in wet cleaning equipment.

questions.question: The temperature monitoring of cold storages is a part of own-check plans.
questions.description: The temperatures of cold storages must be checked and logged regularly according to the own-check plan. Cold storages must always have thermometers for measurements.

questions.question: When a food industry workplace, e.g. a sausage factory, is being founded, the workplace must only inform local food control authorities about the activities.
questions.description: When a food industry workplace, e.g. a sausage factory, is being founded, an approval for the activities by local food control authorities is required.

questions.question: Products sold at a fish stall must have a marking if they have been defrosted for sale.
questions.description: Customers must know if they are buying products that have already been defrosted. A product that has been frozen and defrosted once can not be frozen again.

questions.question: The norovirus is not destroyed when a food product is frozen.
questions.description: The norovirus lasts for long amounts of time and is able to spread even in the cold or in frozen foods.

questions.question: Norwalk-like viruses (NLV) will be destroyed if they are in temperatures higher than 90 degrees Celsius for 2 minutes.
questions.description: Food poisoning causing NLV will be destroyed using heat treatment. However, it can withstand very high temperatures. 2 minutes in over 90 degrees Celsius temperatures is enough to remove the virus from food products.

questions.question: Ultra-high-temperature processing (UHT) uses higher temperatures than pasteurizing.
questions.description: Ultra-high-temperature processing is done in much higher temperatures than pasteurizing. UHT destroys most bacteria spores and because of this products that have been treated with UHT can be stored in room temperature.

questions.question: Bacteria reproduce very quickly in products that have high acidity.
questions.description: Bacteria that are a threat to food product safety reproduce the best in the neutral zone. Because of this the growth of these bacteria can be prevented by increasing the acidity of a product.

questions.question: Food poisoning bacteria cannot multiply in vacuum packaged food products.
questions.description: A vacuum package does not prevent bacteria from multiplying. Anaerobs, ie. food poisoning bacteria that multiply in spaces free from oxygen can also multiply in vacuum packages.

questions.question: Salmonella bacteria can not be found in fowl or poultry.
questions.description: Salmonella can be found in fowl or poultry. Due to the risk of salmonella, the meat of fowl/poultry must always be cooked to at least 75 degrees Celsius.

questions.question: Own-check plans must include clear instructions on how to act when food poisoning suspicions are raised.
questions.description: When food is prepared for customers, food poisoning events must be planned for in advance. Own-check plans must include clear instructions for these events. It is important to notify health inspectors about suspicions immediately.

questions.question: One of the reasons for the existence of own-check plans is to make the work of food product industry companies easier.
questions.description: Own-check plans that are done well make it easier for companies to upkeep food product safety because resources used for monitoring can be focused on things essential for company activities. Knowledge of the quality of the activities will also improve when the activities are planned. In the best case customer satisfaction, profitability and officials' trust will improve.

questions.question: Permitted food additives are marked with E numbers.
questions.description: In addition to the category that indicates the intended use, additives also have a name or numerical code, i.e. an E number.

questions.question: A low activity of water in food products means that the products can contain water, but microbes can't use the water to reproduce.
questions.description: The products can contain water, but microbes can not use it. The water activity can be lowered by adding sugar or salt to the products.

questions.question: Minced meat lasts as long as unprepared meat if it is packaged in a vacuum container or vacuum bag.
questions.description: Minced meat requires that it be stored in a maximum temperature of +4 degrees celsius, whereas whole meat can be stored in +6 degrees celsius.

questions.question: If the temperature of food that is to be served while warm is too low it must not be marked down on the own-check plan's monitoring logs.
questions.description: Measured temperatures must be marked down in the own-check plan's monitoring logs, even if they are too high or too low. The logs must also contain information on what fixing procedure has been made to correct the incorrect temperature.

questions.question: Even in small cafés the same cleaning equipment can not be used to clean the customer areas and the kitchen.
questions.description: If the same cleaning equipment is used, microbes can easily spread from customers to the kitchen in the equipment.

questions.question: People do not have any microbes on their skin if they shower regularly.
questions.description: There are microbes everywhere in soil, water, dust and also on human and animal skin.

questions.question: Cooked rice is an easily perishable food product.
questions.description: Dry rice lasts in room temperature. Cooked rice contains moisture and because of this it is an easily perishable product.

questions.question: Food poisoning causing bacteria reproduce quickly in food kept in room temperature.
questions.description: The temperature of food products left in room temperature becomes suitable for bacteria reproduction, which causes the reproduction to become much quicker in the food product.

questions.question: Vegetables stored in a vinegared liquid can be kept in room temperature.
questions.description: Sterilized, can-packed and unopened vinegared products can be stored in room temperature. Vinegared products will last long due to the high acidity, but opened packages must be stored in cool temperatures.

questions.question: Cleaning equipment must be cleaned once a week.
questions.description: Cleaning equipment must be cleaned after each use and must then be left to dry.

questions.question: Blue cheese contains living mould.
questions.description: Clean, controlled and living moulds are used when producing blue cheese. The moulds create various taste ingredients in the cheese.

questions.question: Fresh fish is not an easily perishable food product.
questions.description: Fresh fish is a very easily perishable food product. Fresh fish products must be stored at the temperature of melting ice, max 2 degrees Celsius.

questions.question: A bar of soap is unhygienic when used by staff in food premises.
questions.description: It is recommended to use liquid soap to wash your hands. A bar of soap is not hygienic enough.

questions.question: Own-check plans are meant for the leadership of food industry companies.
questions.description: Own-check plans include lots of instructions and lists responsibilities. Because of this it is important that all employees get to know the own-check plan and adhere to it while working.

questions.question: Food served in a lunch buffet must remain at +60 degrees celsius for the entire duration of the serving.
questions.description: If food that has been prepared by heating or cooking is not served immediately, it must be kept at a temperature of at least 60 degrees throughout the entire serving.

questions.question: Hepatitis A can spread in food products.
questions.description: The most important viruses that reproduce in the intestines of humans are the norovirus and hepatitis A. Both viruses last for a long time and are able to spread in the cold and even in frozen foods.

questions.question: Officials benefit from own-check plans the most because a large part of planning the monitoring is given to the food product industry's companies.
questions.description: Own-check plans that are done well make it easier for companies to upkeep food product safety because resources used for monitoring can be focused on things essential for company activities. Knowledge of the quality of the activities will also improve when the activities are planned. In the best case customer satisfaction, profitability and officials' trust will improve.

questions.question: Actions made after noticing mistakes or abnormalities in the packaging or quality of food products during receival checks must be logged in the own-check plan.
questions.description: Mistakes or abnormalities noticed in the quality or packaging of food products must be logged into the own-check plan. It is also required to detailedly log what actions are made after noticing a mistake or abnormality and who is responsible for informing for example the supplier of the products about it.

questions.question: Vibrio bacteria are found in sea waters at warm geographical locations.
questions.description: Vibrio bacteria have been found in salty coast seawater at warm geographical locations. Seafood that has been heated badly or stored in too warm temperatures are risk food products.

questions.question: A restaurant can use food products after their best before date has expired provided that the products are sufficiently well heated well.
questions.description: It is prohibited to sell or use food products after their best before date has expired, and they must not be used in the manufacture of food to be sold or served.

questions.question: Packages of easily perishable food products must have a label indicating their best-before date.
questions.description: Packages of easily perishable food products always require a label indicating the last day of use and storing instructions. The shown date is valid only for unopened products that have been stored in the right temperature.

questions.question: Campylo bacteria is naturally found in fowl and poultry.
questions.description: Campylo bacteria and salmonella are found naturally in fowl and poultry. Both bacteria are destroyed when the meat is cooked thoroughly to over 75 degrees Celsius.

questions.question: When you clean a refrigerator, you only need to wipe away visible dirt as microbes do not multiply in such a cold place.
questions.description: Refrigerators must be cleaned regularly with appropriate detergents. Some microbes thrive and even grow at the refrigerator temperature.

questions.question: Food product stores do not require an own-check plan.
questions.description: All workplaces in the food industry need to ensure the safety of their products with an own-check plan. Own-check plans are required in all food industry workplaces.

questions.question: The gas in protective gas packaging completely prevents harmful microbes from growing.
questions.description: The amount of oxygen in protective gas is changed to make it harder for most microbes to grow. Some harmful microbes can withstand exceptional conditions and will be able to reproduce even in protective gas packages. Additionally, the protective gas in the packages will try to equalize with the air around it, so the amount of gas can change.

questions.question: It is enough to visually monitor the results of cleaning and washing.
questions.description: The results of cleaning and washing and the need for cleaning needs to be monitored regularly. It is required to name a responsible person for this task in the own-check plan and to form a monitoring plan to use. As well as doing visual inspections, the monitoring can also be done by taking microbiological samples from work surfaces and equipment by for example using Hygicult sample strips.

questions.question: The most hygienic tools are well-washed hands.
questions.description: The handling of food products should be done with clean equipment instead of hands whenever possible. Clean and appropriate equipment is one of the most effective ways to prevent food products from contamination.

questions.question: Customer feedback is a part of the own-check plan.
questions.description: It is useful to pay attention to appropriate customer feedback when carrying out the own-check plan. Customer feedback can be viewed as a way to enhance quality of service. Feedback should be written down, discussed with the staff and utilized in developing procedures and protocols.

questions.question: Raw and cooked food products must always have separate cold storage spaces.
questions.description: If only one cold-store is available, raw products are placed on the lower shelves and cooked ones on the top shelves in order to avoid risking contamination.

questions.question: BSE, also called mad cow's disease, is not a food poisoning causing bacteria.
questions.description: BSE is caused by changes in the central nervous system of cows. Humans can get the disease only by eating meat that is contaminated with BSE.

questions.question: If you have just washed your hands carefully with soap, you can taste food with your finger.
questions.description: You can only taste food using clean cutlery, never with your fingers.

questions.question: Dirty root vegetables must have a separate work space.
questions.description: Dirt always contains many microbes. Dirty root vegetables must be handled separately from other products so that the microbes in the dirt do not spread to other food products.

questions.question: The same cleaning equipment can be used in both dining areas and food preparation areas.
questions.description: Kitchen facilities and customer areas must have separate cleaning equipment in order to avoid possible disease agents from transferring from one space to the other via cleaning supplies, such as table wiping rags.

questions.question: Mould and bacterial spores can also be found in dry food products.
questions.description: Spores are more resistant than bacteria to their surrounding conditions, especially heat, drought and chemical agents.

questions.question: The temperature checks for received food products that need hot or cold storage are part of the own-check plan.
questions.description: Temperature monitoring of hot or cold storage food products when receiving is an important part of the own-check plan. If the temperatures do not meet set requirements they can be returned to the supplier as faulty products.

questions.question: Pet dogs can be taken inside a café with the permission of the owner of the café.
questions.description: If the owner gives permission, a pet dog can be taken inside the customer areas of a café.

questions.question: An employee handling unpacked, easily perishable food products can not have nail polish while working.
questions.description: Nail polish can not be worn when handling easily perishable food products because the polish can break off into the products. Microbes also have good growth environments to reproduce under nails and nail polish. Nails and hands must be kept in good condition when working with food products.

questions.question: UHT-treated milk products can be stored in room temperature.
questions.description: In UHT (ultra high temperature) -treatment products are rapidly heated to a high temperature and packaged in sterilized packaging. This is why treated products cana be kept in room temperature.

questions.question: Good cleaning results are verified by taking samples from surfaces.
questions.description: Samples are taken from surfaces in order to verify that cleaning efforts are adequate.

questions.question: Baker's yeast contains living microbes.
questions.description: Baker's yeast itself is living yeast microbes. These yeast microbes will die if the temperature goes over 42 degrees Celsius. Because of this baker's yeast can not be added to a liquid that is too hot.

questions.question: Dirty and clean work clothes must be stored in separate places.
questions.description: There should be a separate place for storing dirty work clothes. Work clothes should also be clean, neat and suitable for food related work.

questions.question: Windows in food premises can be opened for ventilation.
questions.description: Windows and doors in food premises must be kept closed to prevent pests from entering the premises.

questions.question: Salmonella bacteria can be found in fowl or poultry.
questions.description: Salmonella can be found in fowl or poultry. Due to the risk of salmonella, the meat of fowl/poultry must always be cooked to at least 75 degrees Celsius.

questions.question: If a can of canned food has bloated and become larger, the contents inside the can must not be tasted.
questions.description: Bloated, enlargened cans can contain a dangerous toxin called botulin. Even a very small amount of botulin can be lethal.

questions.question: Oiva is a system which helps to assess the food product safety of different workplaces.
questions.description: Municipality food control authorities do routine inspections at workplaces. Oiva is the publishing system for the results of these inspections, and is co-ordinated by Ruokavirasto.

questions.question: Bacteria spores can not be destroyed by boiling.
questions.description: Bacteria do not reproduce in boiling hot food. However, the spores of the bacteria do not get destroyed during boiling.

questions.question: If the temperature of food that is to be served while warm is too low it must not be marked down on the own-check plan's monitoring logs.
questions.description: Measured temperatures must be marked down in the own-check plan's monitoring logs, even if they are too high or too low. The logs must also contain information on what fixing procedure has been made to correct the incorrect temperature.

questions.question: The Food Act determines how food is stored in food premises.
questions.description: The Food Act determines how food is handled, transported and stored.

questions.question: If the product being handled is fresh and of good quality, the handling hygiene is not as important.
questions.description: Hygienic handling methods and equipment are always important for the lastingness of products. A fresh and good quality good will still perish easily if it is handled unhygienically.

questions.question: Samples taken from batches of food prepared in large kitchens must be stored for 1-2 months.
questions.description: Samples are taken from large kitchens' food batches to trace possible food poisoning causes easier. Samples must be taken daily from all batches being somehow served or sold and the samples must be stored appropriately marked in a freezer for 1-2 weeks. During this time a majority of food poisoning symptoms start to appear.

questions.question: Sour milk spoils faster than milk.
questions.description: The pH value of milk is 7, which means it is neutral. The pH value of sour milk is lower, which means sour milk is acidized. It is harder for bacteria to reproduce in acidized milk products than in neutral products.

questions.question: Berry kisels can be stored in room temperature because the sugar prevents the growth of harmful bacteria.
questions.description: Berry kisels must be stored in cool temperatures because they can perish due to the large quantity of water in them. The sugar in kisels does not prevent harmful bacteria from growing because the sugar density is much lower than in e.g. jams or marmelade.

questions.question: Health inspectors can not inspect restaurant kitchens.
questions.description: The work of health inspectors requires making inspections in food production areas such as food stores and restaurants.

questions.question: Food poisoning symptoms always start within one day of consuming a perished food product.
questions.description: Food poisoning symptoms can already begin in one hour since consuming a perished food product, but they can also begin after many days of no symptoms.

questions.question: Heating food to 75 degrees Celsius or more is enough to destroy salmonella.
questions.description: Salmonella will be destroyed in heat treatment when food is heated to at least 75 degrees Celsius.

questions.question: Own-check plans must include clear instructions on how to act when food poisoning suspicions are raised.
questions.description: When food is prepared for customers, food poisoning events must be planned for in advance. Own-check plans must include clear instructions for these events. It is important to notify health inspectors about suspicions immediately.

questions.question: Food poisoning is always caused by bacteria.
questions.description: The cause of food poisoning can, in addition to bacteria, also be a virus, mould fungus or protozoan.

questions.question: Dried products can spoil quickly if they become wet.
questions.description: Dried products last long if they are stored dry. If the products become wet the microbes in them will start to reproduce.

questions.question: When serving or distributing food products for free, the rules and requirements for handling food products must be followed.
questions.description: Food product handling rules are still required to be followed when serving for free.

questions.question: Eating is not allowed while preparing food.
questions.description: Microbes in the mouth spread onto the hands while eating. Eating must be done in a separate area and after eating hands must be washed.

questions.question: Earth does not contain food poisoning causing bacteria.
questions.description: Earth can contain e.g. bacillus cereus or clostridum bacteria. Both of these are common causers of food poisoning.

questions.question: Microbes reproduce the fastest in their own optimal temperatures.
questions.description: All microbes have their own optimal temperatures where reproduction is the fastest. In the insides of humans and animals, the temperature range between 20 and 45 degrees Celsius is the best for microbes. Anything hotter or colder than this causes microbes to reproduce slower.

questions.question: Food poisoning causing bacteria are found naturally.
questions.description: Microbes are everywhere: in the air, water, earth, plants, animals and humans. Some of these microbes cause food poisoning.

questions.question: A microbiological sample of a food product can be placed in any container.
questions.description: A microbiological sample of a food product must always be placed in a container that is definitely clean.

questions.question: EHEC bacteria are intestinal bacteria.
