questions.description: EHEC bacteria is found especially in the intestines of cattle. EHEC bacteria create toxins in the intestines of humans. The toxin often causes bloody diarrhea and very uncomfortable stomache pains.

questions.question: When handling food products, employees should not touch their skin if possible.
questions.description: The skin and mouth contain large amounts of different bacteria, including food poisoning causing bacteria. Because of this touching the skin should be avoided when working with food products.

questions.question: BSE is also called mad cow's disease.
questions.description: Mad cow's disease is sometimes found in old cows. During slaughtering the carcasses must be checked so that contaminated meat is not used.

questions.question: Food poisoning suspicions must always be informed to health officials.
questions.description: Informing health officials is only required if more than 5 people have become sick. Informing must also be done if the epidemic has spread in a school, hospital or other institution or if the cause is suspected to be in a commercial food product or in a some other way wide-spread product.

questions.question: If an employee has infected wounds on his or her hands, he or she can still work with food products if single-use protective gloves are used.
questions.description: Infected wounds contain large amounts of food poisoning causing Staphylococcus aureus bacteria. It is impossible to constantly prevent the bacteria from spreading to food products.

questions.question: The training of personnel is an important part of own-check plans.
questions.description: The training of personnel is an essential part of own-check plans. In the food industry technology, equipment, ingredients, preparation methods and even risks change, so it is important to update knowledge regularly.

questions.question: A grated carrot spoils faster than an entire carrot.
questions.description: Treating a carrot and grating it shortens the time it lasts. During grating microbes spread onto the carrot and water inside the carrot becomes available for the microbes to use. Grated products also have more surface area than intact products; microbes, especially ones that require oxygen, are suitable to live on the surface of products.

questions.question: Washed, clean dishes can only be handled with clean hands.
questions.description: If clean dishes are handled with dirty hands, microbes and dirt will spread from the hands onto the dishes.

questions.question: If worktops look clean, they are definitely clean.
questions.description: Microbes are microorganisms that are invisible to the naked eye.

questions.question: Yeasts often cause spoilage in acidic food products.
questions.description: Bacteria grow in a more restricted pH range than yeast and mould. Yeasts grow best in food products with a pH of 5.

questions.question: The safety data sheets of detergents (washing chemicals) must always be kept close to their storage location.
questions.description: Safety data sheets must be kept near detergents so that the user of the detergent can read e.g. the first aid instructions.

questions.question: When frozen vegetables are thawed at room temperature, the number of harmful microbes in them increases rapidly.
questions.description: When food products are thawed at room temperature, the risk of microbial growth on the surface of the product increases even before the inner part is thawed.

questions.question: Intestinal bacteria cannot spread from hands to food.
questions.description: Intestinal bacteria can spread to food even from the hands.

questions.question: When a new detergent is introduced into a kitchen, the cleaning plan in the own-check plan is updated.
questions.description: It is important that the own-check plan is always up to date. All changes to the own-check plan, e.g. introduction of a new detergent, must be updated in the cleaning plan.

questions.question: Visual evaluation is enough to check the cleanliness of working areas and equipment.
questions.description: When working the results of cleaning can be evaluated visually, but it is good to occasionally do tests by taking bacteria samples from surfaces and equipment. The microbiological quality of food products that have been treated in some way is a good measure for the effectiveness of cleaning. It is a good idea to name a responsible person to monitor the results of cleaning regularly.

questions.question: Dirty root vegetables can be handled in the same area where desserts are produced.
questions.description: Dirt always contains many microbes. Dirty root vegetables must be handled separately from other products so that the microbes in the dirt do not spread to other food products.

questions.question: Milk can be stored at room temperature during the breakfast service.
questions.description: Milk and cream are perishable food products and they must be served cold.

questions.question: Contamination means e.g. unwanted microbes and/or chemicals spreading into a product.
questions.description: Contamination can be microbiological, chemical or physical. It is unwanted and can cause perishing of food products or food poisoning.

questions.question: Not all microbes and bacteria-spores in food products can be destroyed using any treatments.
questions.description: Sterilizing or radiating can destroy all bacteria or microbe-spores in food products. Canned food, such as canned tuna and canned baby food is sterilized by heating the packed products. Spices are one example of a product that can be treated by radiation.

questions.question: When a kitchen floor is washed properly, there cannot be any microbes on it.
questions.description: Microbes are everywhere, even on newly washed kitchen surfaces.

questions.question: Food poisoning causing bacteria reproduce very quickly in biowaste bins kept in room temperature.
questions.description: Bacteria have good growing conditions in biowaste bins kept in room temperature: the temperature is good and there is plenty of nutrition and moisture. The amount of oxygen is different for different parts of the waste, so bacteria that live well in both oxygen-containing and non-oxygenic environments can reproduce in biowaste bins.

questions.question: Own-check plans are meant for the leadership of food industry companies.
questions.description: Own-check plans include lots of instructions and lists responsibilities. Because of this it is important that all employees get to know the own-check plan and adhere to it while working.

questions.question: Trichinella spiralis is a parasite of salmon.
questions.description: Trichinella spiralis is found in the non-inspected meat of pigs, boar, horses and bears.

questions.question: All food that is being served needs to be sampled daily.
questions.description: Taken samples must be placed into a container and then placed into a freezer. If food poisonings are suspected, then these samples must be available for research.

questions.question: It is not allowed to use useful microbes in baking.
questions.description: Yeast is used in baking to make dough rise.

questions.question: Fresh morel mushrooms must be roasted thoroughly before they can be eaten.
questions.description: Fresh morel mushrooms contain natural toxins which can not be removed by only roasting the mushrooms.

questions.question: Food poisoning can be caused by careless hand washing.
questions.description: Dirty hands may contain microbes that cause food poisoning.

questions.question: Ham slices left over from a buffet can be used for lunch the next day.
questions.description: Food products that have been served at a buffet must never be served again. Food starts to perish immediately after cooking. Contamination is slowed down by adhering to the correct temperatures, serving time and hygienic working methods. A buffet, which is visited by a lot of people, offers particularly good conditions for contamination.

questions.question: Spices cannot cause food poisoning.
questions.description: In some cases spices, too, can cause a risk of food poisoning, and therefore they must be used and stored hygienically and with care just like other food products.

questions.question: The waste disposal procedures for professional kitchens, such as recycling, are decided upon between the personnel.
questions.description: A professional kitchen's waste disposal is based on waste laws as well as regional waste disposal directives.

questions.question: If an employee has inflamed wounds on their hands, they must not handle easily perishable food products.
questions.description: A person with inflamed wounds or other inflamed areas on their hands or other visible skin must not handle unpacked food products. Small wounds in the hands must be cleaned and protected with a water-proof bandage, and single-use gloves must be used.

questions.question: Cold storage units should not be filled beyond their set fill limits because the food products might not stay cold enough.
questions.description: The fill limit is an instruction on usage by the producer of the cold storage unit. The limit should not be crossed because food products outside the limit will not stay cold enough.

questions.question: A tool made of wood is a hygiene hazard.
questions.description: Wood is a porous material and can absorb water, dirt and detergents, and it can stay damp for a long time.

questions.question: EHEC bacteria are not intestinal bacteria.
questions.description: EHEC bacteria is found especially in the intestines of cattle. EHEC bacteria create toxins in the intestines of humans. The toxin often causes bloody diarrhea and very uncomfortable stomache pains.

questions.question: Bacillus cereus is a food poisoning causing bacteria.
questions.description: Bacillus cereus is a spore bacteria. Risk food products for this are e.g. raw milk and rice.

questions.question: Food poisoning bacteria cannot multiply in vacuum packaged food products.
questions.description: A vacuum package does not prevent bacteria from multiplying. Anaerobs, ie. food poisoning bacteria that multiply in spaces free from oxygen can also multiply in vacuum packages.

questions.question: Biofilm means plastic wrap that is specially made for food products.
questions.description: Biofilm can form onto e.g. the surface of a plate if prewashing is done with too hot water before proper dishwashing. Too hot water can burn albumin spots onto the surface of the dish and create biofilm, which is a suitable growing environment for microbes.

questions.question: A best-before-date must be marked on easily perishable products.
questions.description: Easily perishable products must have a use-by-date.

questions.question: Lactic acid bacteria (LAB) are used when producing yoghurt.
questions.description: Yoghurt and other fermented milk products use LAB in their production. LAB create lactic acid, which cause acidity in the products.

questions.question: Freezing in a sufficiently cold temperature improves the lastingness of products.
questions.description: Products can be stored by freezing them, but one must notice that freezing affects the quality of different food products. For example, fish, meat and baked goods dry up easily during freezing, so the quality of products stored in freezing must be checked regularly.

questions.question: Own-check plans do not need to include clear instructions on how to act when food poisoning suspicions are raised.
questions.description: When food is prepared for customers, food poisoning events must be planned for in advance. Own-check plans must include clear instructions for these events. It is important to notify health inspectors about suspicions immediately.

questions.question: Brooms and mops can be stored on the floor in the corner of a cleaning equipment storage room.
questions.description: Brooms and mops will not dry if they are stored on the floor. Microbes can reproduce quickly in wet cleaning equipment.

questions.question: The temperatures of cold storage equipment do not need to be measured if they feel cold enough.
questions.description: The temperatures of refrigerating equipment, drawers and cabinets must be measured and logged at the same time each day. Atypical measuring results are logged in the own-check forms and necessary measures are taken to restore the right temperature in that piece of equipment.

questions.question: Officials benefit from own-check plans the most because a large part of planning the monitoring is given to the food product industry's companies.
questions.description: Own-check plans that are done well make it easier for companies to upkeep food product safety because resources used for monitoring can be focused on things essential for company activities. Knowledge of the quality of the activities will also improve when the activities are planned. In the best case customer satisfaction, profitability and officials' trust will improve.

questions.question: Food that is being served while hot must be at least 60 degrees Celsius during the entire serving period.
questions.description: The temperature must also be measured and marked down in own-check logs. The food can be kept in service while hot for a maximum of 4 hours.

questions.question: When unprotected, cooked and uncooked food products must be stored in separate areas.
questions.description: Unprotected cooked and uncooked food products must have separate storage areas to prevent cross-contamination.

questions.question: All milk products must always be stored in cold storage, where the temperature is less than 6 degrees Celsius.
questions.description: Ultra-high-temperature processing sterilizes milk products. In UHT processing milk is heated for a few seconds to at least 135 degrees Celsius and packed into disinfected packaging in a clean area.This treatment destroys all reproducing micro-organisms and all unopened packages can be stored in room temperature.

questions.question: Some microbes can reproduce even in food products that are in a protective gas package.
questions.description: Protective gas packages contain little or no oxygen. This prevents microbes that require oxygen from growing. However, the product can also contain microbes that do not need oxygen.

questions.question: Frozen foods can be defrosted on a kitchen table if the liquid from the melting does not pour onto the table.
questions.description: All frozen foods must be defrosted in cold storage units. When defrosting, one must make sure that the defrosting product does not pour liquid onto any other food products placed or stored in the cold storage unit. Defrosted or just partially defrosted products can not be frozen again.

questions.question: Salmonella bacteria can be found in fowl or poultry.
questions.description: Salmonella can be found in fowl or poultry. Due to the risk of salmonella, the meat of fowl/poultry must always be cooked to at least 75 degrees Celsius.

questions.question: If a product has been cooled once already, heating it again must be done very carefully.
questions.description: Reheating cooled food must be done very carefully to make sure its microbiological quality stays good. Heating the product thoroughly to 70 degrees Celsius should be possible. Because of this a microwave oven is not a good tool for reheating, because different ingredients in the food will heat in different ways.

questions.question: Raw milk can contain yersinia.
questions.description: Raw milk has not been pasteurized. Yersinia is destroyed when milk is heated to over 70 degrees Celsius; in other words it is destroyed when the milk is pasteurized.

questions.question: Workers in the food industry can be found responsible for a customer becoming sick.
questions.description: Product liability laws also cover food products. If a customer is able to provide sufficient evidence, a worker in the food industry can be found responsible for causing a sickness in the customer.

questions.question: Food poisoning bacteria cannot multiply in vacuum packaged food products.
questions.description: A vacuum package does not prevent bacteria from multiplying. Anaerobs, ie. food poisoning bacteria that multiply in spaces free from oxygen can also multiply in vacuum packages.

questions.question: Waste disposal is not a part of the own-check plan.
questions.description: Waste disposal is a part of the own-check plan. Health inspectors also pay attention to how well waste is disposed of in food related premises. The regular emptying and cleaning of waste containers must be looked after.

questions.question: When a kitchen floor is washed properly, there cannot be any microbes on it.
questions.description: Microbes are everywhere, even on newly washed kitchen surfaces.

questions.question: Disinfectants only work if the concentration is correct and they are left to work for the correct period of time.
questions.description: The effectiveness of a disinfectant depends on issues such as the concentration, how long it is left to work and the temperature of the solution.

questions.question: When you clean a refrigerator, you only need to wipe away visible dirt as microbes do not multiply in such a cold place.
questions.description: Refrigerators must be cleaned regularly with appropriate detergents. Some microbes thrive and even grow at the refrigerator temperature.

questions.question: Oiva is a system which helps people to self-assess the food product safety of their workplace.
questions.description: Municipality food control authorities make Oiva-reports about the workplaces they inspect. It is not a part of the workplace's self-assessment.

questions.question: A best-before-date must be marked on easily perishable products.
questions.description: Easily perishable products must have a use-by-date.

questions.question: Oiva-reports must be placed at the entrance of the café, restaurant etc. so that customers can read them.
questions.description: Oiva-reports are published documents about routine inspections. These reports are also published online at www.oivahymy.fi

questions.question: Any water can be used for washing potatoes as they have soil on them.
questions.description: Potatoes must always be washed with water that meets the requirements for domestic water.

questions.question: Old and worn cleaning equipment can spread harmful microbes into food premises.
questions.description: It is important to make sure that cleaning equipment is always clean and in good condition.

questions.question: If food does not taste spoiled it can not cause food poisoning.
questions.description: Many food poisoning causing bacteria can reproduce in food without causing changes that can be noticed with the senses (visually, taste etc.)

questions.question: If the temperature of a cold storage unit is too high it must not be marked down on the own-check plan's monitoring logs.
questions.description: Measured temperatures must be marked down in the own-check plan's monitoring logs, even if they are too high or too low. The logs must also contain information on what fixing procedure has been made to correct the incorrect temperature.

questions.question: Customers and employees are allowed to use the same toilet.
questions.description: Strict toilet and hand hygiene must be used in food production. This is not possible if toilets are shared with customers. Customers may have diseases, can be drunk or they can be small children; in each case the use of the same toilets is a risk.

questions.question: Waste disposal is an essential part of hygienic working in a professional kitchen.
questions.description: Appropriate waste bins and their regular emptying and cleaning, as well as the appropriate assortment and storage areas for waste that is going to be transported away, are all a part of good hygienic working. A professional kitchen's waste disposal is based on waste laws as well as regional waste disposal directives.

questions.question: Microbes reproduce the fastest in their own optimal temperatures.
questions.description: All microbes have their own optimal temperatures where reproduction is the fastest. In the insides of humans and animals, the temperature range between 20 and 45 degrees Celsius is the best for microbes. Anything hotter or colder than this causes microbes to reproduce slower.

questions.question: Mashed potato is not an easily perishable food product.
questions.description: Pre-made foods are easily perishable products. Easily perishable foods must be stored in the cold, under 6 degrees Celsius.

questions.question: Beer is produced with the help of beneficial microbes.
questions.description: Beer is produced with yeast fermentation. Yeast is also used when producing wine.

questions.question: Organic food does not cause food poisoning as easily as "normal" food.
questions.description: Organic food is produced without fertilizers or pesticides. This does not affect food poisoning almost at all. The risk for food poisoning is the same between "normal" and organic food.

questions.question: The gutting and proper washing of fish is enough to prevent tapeworm infections.
questions.description: Infectious tapeworm larvas can be inside the muscles or roe of the fish. Tapeworm infections can be prevented by cooking or freezing the fish or roe.

questions.question: All monitoring logs made for own-check plans must be stored for at least a year at the workplace.
questions.description: Only stored monitoring logs can prove that the own-check plan has been adhered to.

questions.question: Wooden utensils are well suited for professional kitchens if they are washed in a washing machine on a sufficiently hot program.
questions.description: Wooden utensils should not be used in professional kitchens, as they do not withstand repeated washes in a washing machine. Materials must very durable in order to cope with repeated washes, like for example plastic and steel utensils that are meant for food product related use.

questions.question: Cooling cabinets may also be used for storing food.
questions.description: Food should be cooled to less than 6 degrees Celsius within only 4 hours. When the products have been cooled they should be moved into another cold storage unit. Cooling cabinets are only used for cooling food (not storing.)

questions.question: When receiving products one must make sure that they are moved into their appropriate, separate storage areas as soon as possible after the receival check.
questions.description: Products should be moved into their own storage areas as soon as possible after the receival check. Easily perishable food products can not be stored in room temperature for longer than 10-15 minutes.

questions.question: When a food industry workplace, e.g. a sausage factory, is being founded, the activities of the workplace must be approved in advance by local food control authorities.
questions.description: Workplaces that handle animal-based food products require an approval for their activities. Only informing of the activities is not enough.

questions.question: The most hygienic way to handle unpacked food products is to use wooden utensils.
questions.description: The most hygienic utensils for handling unpacked food products are made of plastic or steel.

questions.question: Coffee cream and milk may be stored in room temperature, because they will be added to hot coffee.
questions.description: Milk and cream are easily perishable food products, and they must be served cold.

questions.question: Mould that has spread from blue cheese to other cheeses is not hazardous.
questions.description: Mould spreading from blue cheese to other cheeses, which the mould is not supposed to be in, is hazardous and can worsen the quality and also perish the cheeses. However, the spreading of the mould to other cheeses is not always a health risk.

questions.question: Bacteria spores are destroyed when products are boiled (+100 degrees Celsius).
questions.description: Bacteria spores are destroyed only during sterilization. In excess pressure the temperature is raised to about 145 degrees Celsius and this way bacteria spores are also destroyed.

questions.question: Hand washing areas must be cleaned regularly.
questions.description: A dirty hand washing area is a risk for hand hygiene.

questions.question: Cooling cabinets may also be used for storing food.
questions.description: Food should be cooled to less than 6 degrees Celsius within only 4 hours. When the products have been cooled they should be moved into another cold storage unit. Cooling cabinets are only used for cooling food (not storing.)

questions.question: Transported products and cargo being received do not have to be checked.
questions.description: The quality of arriving products must be checked and the temperatures of easily perishable products must be measured. The results must be written down.

questions.question: There must be an appropriate washing place for large machines and dishes in the food premises.
questions.description: A cleaning plan is made for every machine and device to specify an appropriate place for washing each one of them.

questions.question: Products that have gone through ultra-high-temperature treatment (UHT) can not be stored in room temperature.
questions.description: During UHT products are sterilized with quick heating. Unopened packages can be stored in room temperature because most bacteria spores have been destroyed.

questions.question: Crates can be stored on the loading dock as long as they are protected from the rain.
questions.description: Storing crates on the loading dock is a hygiene hazard as they attract birds and other animals.

questions.question: Disinfectants only work if the concentration is correct and they are left to work for the correct period of time.
questions.description: The effectiveness of a disinfectant depends on issues such as the concentration, how long it is left to work and the temperature of the solution.

questions.question: The purpose of own-check plans is to prevent mistakes and problematic situations from occurring during food preparation and serving.
questions.description: Good own-check plans as well as good knowledge of the own-check plan's contents by the personnel prevents problematic situations and makes it easier to identify the causes of any noticed problems.

questions.question: Most food poisoning causing microbes will be destroyed when the temperature of food is more than 75 degrees Celsius.
questions.description: Most food poisoning causing microbes can not live in temperatures over 75 degrees Celsius. However, bacteria-spores can live in much higher temperatures.

questions.question: Dirty root vegetables and pre-made food products can be stored in the same cold room.
questions.description: Dirt always contains many microbes. Dirty root vegetables must be handled separately from other products so that the microbes in the dirt do not spread to other food products.

questions.question: When washing dishes, the prewashing must not be done with hot water.
questions.description: Prewashing must be done with cool-temperatured water. Too hot water can burn albumin spots onto the surface of the dish and create biofilm, which is a suitable growing environment for microbes.

questions.question: Employees are free to decide who is responsible for the own-check plan at the beginning of each shift.
questions.description: Designated persons who have been trained for the task are responsible for the various areas of the own-check plan.

questions.question: You can wear disposable gloves instead of washing your hands when preparing food in a restaurant tent.
questions.description: Washing your hands thoroughly and often enough is the basis for safe food handling and general hygiene, and it is important to also wear disposable gloves, for example.

questions.question: The same broom can be used for cleaning the floor and work surfaces.
questions.description: Floors contain a lot more microbes than work surfaces. If floor brooms are used for work surfaces, the microbes on the floor will spread to the work surface from the broom.

questions.question: All microbes in earth and the ground are beneficial decomposing microbes which do not cause harm to consumers when they spread to food products.
questions.description: There are many harmful microbes in earth and the ground that can cause food poisoning if they spread to food products.

questions.question: The temperature checks for received food products that need hot or cold storage are part of the own-check plan.
questions.description: Temperature monitoring of hot or cold storage food products when receiving is an important part of the own-check plan. If the temperatures do not meet set requirements they can be returned to the supplier as faulty products.

questions.question: The cooling of food products should be done by using cooling cabinets (chillers).
questions.description: Only cooling cabinets can ensure sufficiently fast and effective cooling.

questions.question: When the best-before-date of a product has passed, the product usually spoils quickly.
questions.description: The best-before-date is found on products sold in room temperature (with the exception of milk products.) The products will not spoil too easily, so the products can be kept for sale and used after the best-before-date.

questions.question: If you forget to take the measurements related to the own-check plan, you can estimate the measurements later.
questions.description: The monitoring of temperatures and recording of the results must always be based on actual measurements.

questions.question: Working areas and equipment must always be cleaned by using plenty of water.
questions.description: Water is an important part of cleaning and washing. Water acts as a solvent and substance that transports dirt away. However it is also important to dry the surfaces and equipment properly, because microbes grow and reproduce easily in moist environments.

questions.question: Organic food does not cause food poisoning as easily as "normal" food.
questions.description: Organic food is produced without fertilizers or pesticides. This does not affect food poisoning almost at all. The risk for food poisoning is the same between "normal" and organic food.

questions.question: Production of cheese uses beneficial microbes.
questions.description: Clean, controlled and beneficial microbes are used in cheeses. During storage these microbes will create taste ingredients in the cheese.

questions.question: Temperature does not affect the reproduction speed of microbes.
questions.description: Temperatures are very important for the reproduction abilities of microbes. The insides of humans and animals often contain the optimal temperature for microbes, between 20 and 45 degrees Celsius.

questions.question: Temperature measurements stated in own-check plans do not have to made when one is busy.
questions.description: Only regularly done measurements can prove that the own-check plan has been adhered to at a workplace.

questions.question: Thoroughly boiled food does not contain any microbes.
questions.description: Bacteria spores will not be destroyed during boiling. When boiled food cools to less than 60 degrees Celsius the bacteria spores may reproduce again.

questions.question: The amount of water a product contains does not significantly affect its lastingness.
questions.description: Harmful microbes need water to reproduce. Because of this dry products last well.

questions.question: Vegetables and fruit must be washed prior to food preparation with water that meets the requirements of household water.
questions.description: Taps in any food preparation space must provide water that meets the requirements of household water, which is used in preparing and making food as well as by staff to wash their hands.

questions.question: Cleaning plans include accurate instructions about how and when cleaning is done.
questions.description: A cleaning plan is an essential part of an own-check plan. Cleaning plans include more accurate instructions on the cleaning of all parts of a food production area.

questions.question: Sneezing spreads harmful microbes into the surrounding environment in the droplets/spray.
questions.description: There are lots of microbes in the respiratory system and mouth which can spread into the surroundings.

questions.question: Only reproductive microbes are destroyed during sterilization. Bacteria spores are not destroyed.
questions.description: During sterilization (e.g. during canned food production) all microbes and bacteria spores are destroyed. This way easily perishable products will be able to last long in room temperature.

questions.question: Cooked rice is an easily perishable food product.
questions.description: Dry rice lasts in room temperature. Cooked rice contains moisture and because of this it is an easily perishable product.

questions.question: Food products that contain preservatives can not cause food poisoning.
questions.description: Preservatives prevent and slow down the growth of microbes in food products. However, preservatives do not destroy food poisoning causing bacteria, which makes food poisoning possible.

questions.question: Hands must be washed after sneezing and blowing one's nose.
questions.description: Microbes spread onto the hands when sneezing and blowing one's nose. If the hands are not washed, these bacteria will easily spread onto food products.

questions.question: Oiva is a system which helps to assess the food product safety of different workplaces.
questions.description: Municipality food control authorities do routine inspections at workplaces. Oiva is the publishing system for the results of these inspections, and is co-ordinated by Ruokavirasto.

questions.question: During the cooling of food microbes are not able to reproduce in the food.
questions.description: The danger zone for food temperatures is between 6 and 60 degrees Celsius. Microbes can reproduce in food when the temperature is within this danger zone. During the cooling of food the food is within this danger zone.

questions.question: UHT-treated milk products can be stored in room temperature.
questions.description: In UHT (ultra high temperature) -treatment products are rapidly heated to a high temperature and packaged in sterilized packaging. This is why treated products cana be kept in room temperature.

questions.question: Campylo bacteria is destroyed when a product is heated properly.
questions.description: Campylo bacteria and salmonella are found naturally in fowl and poultry. Both bacteria are destroyed when the meat is cooked thoroughly to over 75 degrees Celsius.

questions.question: Ascorbic acid (vitamin C) can not be used as a preservative.
questions.description: Ascorbic acid lowers the pH value of food products. The growth of bacteria especially can be slowed down by increasing the acidity of products.

questions.question: If a summer restaurant is located next to a lake with clean water, the water in the lake can be used for washing fruits.
questions.description: All food preparation requires the use of water that is tap water quality.

questions.question: The waste disposal instructions for a food production area need to tell who is responsible for emptying the area's waste into the waste room's recycling bins.
questions.description: The waste disposal instructions need to tell which waste disposal company takes care of transporting waste away from the waste room, but the waste in the food production area needs to always be moved into the waste room at least after the work shift is over.

questions.question: Cold-stored root vegetables may contain Yersinia bacteria that cause food poisoning.
questions.description: Root vegetables that are cold stored for a long time may contain Yersinia bacteria that cause food poisoning.

questions.question: Old and worn cleaning equipment can spread harmful microbes into food premises.
questions.description: It is important to make sure that cleaning equipment is always clean and in good condition.

questions.question: EHEC bacteria are intestinal bacteria.
questions.description: EHEC bacteria is found especially in the intestines of cattle. EHEC bacteria create toxins in the intestines of humans. The toxin often causes bloody diarrhea and very uncomfortable stomache pains.

questions.question: Handling money can transfer harmful microbes into food products.
questions.description: Money and easily perishable unpackaged food products should not be handled simultanously, as money can have microbes in it that jeopardize food hygiene.

questions.question: BSE is also called mad cow's disease.
questions.description: Mad cow's disease is sometimes found in old cows. During slaughtering the carcasses must be checked so that contaminated meat is not used.

questions.question: All microbes in earth and the ground are beneficial decomposing microbes which do not cause harm to consumers when they spread to food products.
questions.description: There are many harmful microbes in earth and the ground that can cause food poisoning if they spread to food products.

questions.question: When a kitchen floor is washed properly, there cannot be any microbes on it.
questions.description: Microbes are everywhere, even on newly washed kitchen surfaces.

questions.question: Food production employees are allowed to wear their work outfit when going outside of the food production area during e.g. their lunch break.
questions.description: The work outfit can only be worn inside the food production area; this prevents microbes from spreading into the area from the clothes.

questions.question: Vibrio bacteria are found in sea waters at warm geographical locations.
questions.description: Vibrio bacteria have been found in salty coast seawater at warm geographical locations. Seafood that has been heated badly or stored in too warm temperatures are risk food products.

questions.question: Salmonella infection can only be acquired from foreign food products.
questions.description: Salmonella can be transmitted through both domestic and foreign food products or water contaminated with animal or human faeces, and it can cause food poisoning.

questions.question: When hot food being served is kept at over 60 degrees Celsius the microbes in the food can not reproduce.
questions.description: If the food is not eaten or cooled immediately after production it must be kept at over 60 degrees Celsius when being served to prevent microbes from reproducing. The serving time is 4 hours at maximum.

questions.question: Vinegar lowers the pH value of a product and in this way makes the product last for a shorter amount of time.
questions.description: Especially the growth of bacteria can be prevented by increasing the acidity of a product.

questions.question: Raw ingredients containing gluten must be labelled and stored in closed containers in a storage room.
questions.description: Raw ingredients containing allergens and gluten must be labelled and stored separately in closed containers.

questions.question: Waste disposal is an essential part of hygienic working in a professional kitchen.
questions.description: Appropriate waste bins and their regular emptying and cleaning, as well as the appropriate assortment and storage areas for waste that is going to be transported away, are all a part of good hygienic working. A professional kitchen's waste disposal is based on waste laws as well as regional waste disposal directives.

questions.question: Food that is being served only requires temperature measurements if it is being served hot.
questions.description: Temperature measurements must also be done for food that is being served cold.

questions.question: Unprepared root vegetables can temporarily be stored in a cleaning supply closet or another spacious place.
questions.description: Food products cannot be stored in places that are not meant for that purpose.

questions.question: A tool made of wood is a hygiene hazard.
questions.description: Wood is a porous material and can absorb water, dirt and detergents, and it can stay damp for a long time.

questions.question: Salmonella bacteria can not be found in fowl or poultry.
questions.description: Salmonella can be found in fowl or poultry. Due to the risk of salmonella, the meat of fowl/poultry must always be cooked to at least 75 degrees Celsius.

questions.question: Hepatitis A is never spread in food products.
questions.description: The most important viruses that reproduce in the intestines of humans are the norovirus and hepatitis A. Both viruses last for a long time and are able to spread in the cold and even in frozen foods.

questions.question: Unpeeled and peeled carrots will last the same amount of time as long as they are stored in the cold.
questions.description: Earthy and dirty, untreated root vegetables will last long in appropriate cold storage units, but all treatments will worsen their lastingness.

questions.question: The surfaces of work station tables must be cleaned properly only after the work shift is over.
questions.description: A regular cleaning every 2-4 hours of work station surfaces gets rid of leftover food pieces, fat, dust and other dirt which protects micro-organisms and gives them living space.

questions.question: Permitted food additives are marked with E numbers.
questions.description: In addition to the category that indicates the intended use, additives also have a name or numerical code, i.e. an E number.

questions.question: All work phases, such as dishwashing, baking and treatment of root vegetables, can be done in the same area in hospital kitchens.
questions.description: When each work phase is done in its own separate area the work is hygienic and the risk of cross-contamination is smaller.

questions.question: Frozen products can be thawed in room temperature to make the thawing fast enough.
questions.description: If food products are thawed in room temperature, the products' surfaces will melt quicker than the insides. The surfaces will start to spoil even though the insides can still be frozen.

questions.question: The use of snus (similar to chewing tobacco) is not allowed during food preparation.
questions.description: When handling food products personal hygiene is important; snus must not be used because of hygienic reasons.

questions.question: Additives may be used in all food products.
questions.description: Only approved additives can be used in the preparation of food products. Additives must undergo a thorough safety assessment before they are approved for use.

questions.question: Sneezing spreads harmful microbes into the surrounding environment in the droplets/spray.
questions.description: There are lots of microbes in the respiratory system and mouth which can spread into the surroundings.

questions.question: Food poisonings can be prevented by using single-use protective gloves.
questions.description: Single-use protective gloves must be used when handling very easily perishable food products. Protective gloves make it easier to work when employees must change tasks quickly.

questions.question: Dry flour contains microbes.
questions.description: Dry products can contain spores of bacteria, moulds and yeast. However, they do not reproduce in dry products.

questions.question: The most hygienic tools are well-washed hands.
questions.description: The handling of food products should be done with clean equipment instead of hands whenever possible. Clean and appropriate equipment is one of the most effective ways to prevent food products from contamination.

questions.question: Plastic wrappers for food packaging can be stored outdoors, protected from rain.
questions.description: Plastic and paper wrappers for packing food are stored in a clean indoor space. Packaging materials must be stored sufficiently far away from contaminating materials such as waste or food.

questions.question: Dirty root vegetables and pre-made food products can be stored in the same cold room.
questions.description: Dirt always contains many microbes. Dirty root vegetables must be handled separately from other products so that the microbes in the dirt do not spread to other food products.

questions.question: Worn down and broken equipment is a hygienic risk.
questions.description: Waste food can get easily stuck in worn or broken equipment. Even small amounts of waste food will give microbes a good growing environment.

questions.question: If a fish is dropped on a freshly washed floor, it can still be cooked as long as it is sufficiently well heated.
questions.description: A fish that has fallen onto the floor must never be used for cooking. Food products must never be stored on the floor.

questions.question: Pet dog hair cannot spread microbes into food products.
questions.description: Pet hair can spread microbes into food products.

questions.question: When food products are stored in the correct temperatures, the microbes in the products will not be able to reproduce and grow into dangerous quantities too quickly.
questions.description: Microbes can not be fully prevented from getting into food products. However, correct temperatures will slow down or prevent the microbes in food from reproducing and growing in hazardous amounts.

questions.question: A food poisoning epidemic is a situation where at least 10 people have become sick with similar symptoms after consuming the same food product or ingredient.
questions.description: A food poisoning epidemic means a situation where at least 2 people have become sick with similar symptoms after consuming the same food or drink.

questions.question: Hard rye bread (crisp bread) is not an easily perishable food product.
questions.description: Hard rye bread is a dry food product, and because of this microbes can not reproduce in it. Hard rye bread can be stored in room temperature.

questions.question: The proper washing of hands removes all harmful bacteria from the skin.
questions.description: Even proper washing of hands does not remove all bacteria. Small skin damage and undersides of nails affect the amount of bacteria. Hands must be properly washed between different phases of work.

questions.question: Food products can not be sold nor used after the last use-by-date.
questions.description: The last use-by-date must be marked on easily perishable food products. The marking must be based upon research results of lastingness.

questions.question: A microbiological sample of a food product can be placed in any container.
questions.description: A microbiological sample of a food product must always be placed in a container that is definitely clean.

questions.question: A food manufacturer is responsible for date labelling (best before date or use by date).
questions.description: A food manufacturer or packer is responsible for correct date labelling.

questions.question: A frozen product may be defrosted in room temperature if the product is needed quickly.
questions.description: Frozen products are always to be defrosted in coolers. If defrosting must be sped up, one can use the defrosting option on a microwave or the product can be kept in its packaging under cold running water.

questions.question: Pizza toppings do not need to be cold stored because pizzas are baked in a very hot oven.
questions.description: Perishable food products that require cold storage must always be cold stored.

questions.question: Listeria bacteria are destroyed when a product is frozen.
questions.description: Freezing does not destroy microbes. Listeria can also reproduce in frozen foods.

questions.question: Minced meat produced in a store can be sold on the day of production and the day after that.
questions.description: Minced meat is an easily perishable food product. Because of this the safety of minced meat produced in a store can not be ensured for a longer period of time. Minced meat should be stored at 4 degrees Celsius.

questions.question: Biofilm means plastic wrap that is specially made for food products.
questions.description: Biofilm can form onto e.g. the surface of a plate if prewashing is done with too hot water before proper dishwashing. Too hot water can burn albumin spots onto the surface of the dish and create biofilm, which is a suitable growing environment for microbes.

questions.question: A food poisoning epidemic is a situation where at least 10 people have become sick with similar symptoms after consuming the same food product or ingredient.
questions.description: A food poisoning epidemic means a situation where at least 2 people have become sick with similar symptoms after consuming the same food or drink.

questions.question: Most food poisoning causing microbes will be destroyed when the temperature of food is more than 75 degrees Celsius.
questions.description: Most food poisoning causing microbes can not live in temperatures over 75 degrees Celsius. However, bacteria-spores can live in much higher temperatures.

questions.question: Arriving products and cargo must be checked when received.
questions.description: The quality of arriving products must be checked and the temperatures of easily perishable products must be measured. The results must be written down.

questions.question: Single-use gloves are used to protect the food preparer from microbes on the food products.
questions.description: The first priority of using single-use gloves is to protect the food products from microbes on the hands.

questions.question: Wastebins do not need to be cleaned.
questions.description: Wastebins must not be broken, must include a lid and must also be cleaned regularly.

questions.question: Coffee cream and milk may be stored in room temperature, because they will be added to hot coffee.
questions.description: Milk and cream are easily perishable food products, and they must be served cold.

questions.question: Whipping is one way to improve the shelf life of cream.
questions.description: If you whip cream, you process an unpackaged perishable food product, which shortens its shelf life.

questions.question: Equipment used for slicing food products must be cleaned regularly.
questions.description: Equipment used for slicing food products is cleaned regularly by disassembling it and washing the parts with the appropriate washing agent.

questions.question: Officials will prepare an own-check plan for new companies in the food product industry.
questions.description: Companies in the food product industry must prepare their own own-check plan when starting their activities. The plan must be followed and updated when needed.

questions.question: Berry kisels can be stored in room temperature because the sugar prevents the growth of harmful bacteria.
questions.description: Berry kisels must be stored in cool temperatures because they can perish due to the large quantity of water in them. The sugar in kisels does not prevent harmful bacteria from growing because the sugar density is much lower than in e.g. jams or marmelade.

questions.question: Milk spoils faster than sour milk.
questions.description: The pH value of milk is 7, which means it is neutral. The pH value of sour milk is lower, which means sour milk is acidized. It is harder for bacteria to reproduce in acidized milk products than in neutral products.

questions.question: Disinfecting reduces the amount of microbes from work surfaces and equipment.
questions.description: Correctly done disinfection reduces the amount of microbes excellently on work surfaces and equipment.

questions.question: When there is packaged meat in a delivery load, it can be safely left at room temperature for a few hours.
questions.description: The cold chain of meat products in a delivery load must not be broken.

questions.question: Optimal temperature means the temperature where microbes reproduce the slowest.
questions.description: All microbes have their own optimal temperatures where reproduction is the fastest. In the insides of humans and animals, the temperature range between 20 and 45 degrees Celsius is the best for microbes. Anything hotter or colder than this causes microbes to reproduce slower.

questions.question: Listeria can not reproduce in cold fish (e.g. salmon) in vacuum-packages.
questions.description: Listeria and yersinia are rare exceptions of food poisoning causing bacteria, because they can reproduce in refrigerator temperatures.

questions.question: Easily perishable food products do not require a storage instruction label if it is a commonly known product.
questions.description: Packages of easily perishable food products always require a label indicating the last day of use and storing instructions. The shown date is valid only for unopened products that have been stored in the right temperature.

questions.question: The own-check plan has been created to make it easier for health officials to do their job.
questions.description: Own-check plans and measurement charts are the establishment's own documents that are supposed to emphasize the actor's own responsibility in controlling risks. If there are any problems, it is afterwords easier to find out what caused them. Officials check plans and interfere with defects if necessary.

questions.question: If one's hands are clean, the temperature of food can be checked with the fingers.
questions.description: It is not possible to see how microbiologically clean one's hands are if only using the bare eye. Microbes can spread from the fingers to cooked food; when measuring the temperature of food a thermometer which can be easily cleaned must be used.

questions.question: Minced meat that has been prepared in a store can be sold on the day of preparation and the day after that.
questions.description: Minced meat prepared in a retail store and grounded liver can be sold on the day of preparation and the day after it has been prepared.

questions.question: Food poisoning causing microbes can spread only by hands.
questions.description: Working areas and surfaces must be cleaned regularly during work shifts and after work is over.

questions.question: Tap water can cause food poisoning.
questions.description: Tap water cleanliness must be monitored using the senses. Water samples can also be regularly sent for chemical and microbiological inspections. For example the food poisoning causing norovirus lasts well in water.

questions.question: Food tasting must be done with a spoon.
questions.description: Food must never be touched with the fingers if it is not necessary. Spoons should be used for tasting.

questions.question: Vegetables and fruit must be washed prior to food preparation with water that meets the requirements of household water.
questions.description: Taps in any food preparation space must provide water that meets the requirements of household water, which is used in preparing and making food as well as by staff to wash their hands.

questions.question: Pasteurized dairy products can be stored unopened in room temperature.
questions.description: Pasteurizing does not make it possible to store dairy products in room temperature. UHT-treated dairy products can be stored in room temperature if they are unopened.

questions.question: Soup made for the following day can be left to cool overnight on the kitchen counter.
questions.description: The rapid cooling and cold storing of soup prevents or slows down the growth of bacteria.

questions.question: Pet dog hair cannot spread microbes into food products.
questions.description: Pet hair can spread microbes into food products.

questions.question: During the cooling of food microbes are not able to reproduce in the food.
questions.description: The danger zone for food temperatures is between 6 and 60 degrees Celsius. Microbes can reproduce in food when the temperature is within this danger zone. During the cooling of food the food is within this danger zone.

questions.question: If your protective clothing gets dirty when you take out the rubbish, you must change into clean ones before you continue cooking.
questions.description: Staff must make sure that their work clothes are always clean when they handle and prepare food.

questions.question: Easily perishable food products that require cold storage must be served at a temperature below +8 degrees celsius.
questions.description: During serving easily perishable food products that require cold storage may be +12 degrees celsius at most. The maximum serving time is 12 hours, after which the products must be discarded.

questions.question: Dirty root vegetables can be stored in cardboard boxes above meat products on cold room shelves.
questions.description: Dirt always contains many microbes. Dirty root vegetables must be handled separately from other products so that the microbes in the dirt do not spread to other food products.

questions.question: Raw ingredients containing gluten must be labelled and stored in closed containers in a storage room.
questions.description: Raw ingredients containing allergens and gluten must be labelled and stored separately in closed containers.

questions.question: Food products must be cooled first by using separate cooling equipment and only then moved into a freezer for storage.
questions.description: Products that are not frozen and are placed into a freezer will raise the temperature of the freezer; this weakens the lastingness of the products in the freezer.

questions.question: Food products must never be cooled or stored outside.
questions.description: Food products must not be cooled or stored outside. All equipment and products, e.g. boxes containg baked goods, must be stored inside.

questions.question: There are no microbes in dried food products.
questions.description: Dried products last well due to having no water that bacteria could use to reproduce. However, the microbes have not been destroyed in dried products and the products can contain spores of bacteria, moulds or yeast.

questions.question: The purity of the air in the food packaging area has no effect on the shelf life of food products.
questions.description: Food products are packed in an area with clean air, as it affects their shelf life.

questions.question: Bacillus cereus is a food poisoning causing bacteria.
questions.description: Bacillus cereus is a spore bacteria. Risk food products for this are e.g. raw milk and rice.

questions.question: Salmonella infections can be symptomless.
questions.description: It is possible for salmonella infections to not be noticed. One might not notice the infection at all, but can still spread the salmonella to others. In practice salmonella can only be spread if one's hands are not washed well after going to the toilet.

questions.question: Dried products last well due to having no water that bacteria could use to reproduce.
questions.description: Water is necessary for microbes to reproduce. Dried products last well due to having no water.

questions.question: Temperature measurements stated in own-check plans do not have to made when one is busy.
questions.description: Only regularly done measurements can prove that the own-check plan has been adhered to at a workplace.

questions.question: Dry flour contains no microbes.
questions.description: The microbes in dry products have not been destroyed. Dry products can contain spores of bacteria, moulds and yeast.

questions.question: There may be flies in a food premises even if the waste management is well organised.
questions.description: Flies in the premises are always a sign of inadequate cleaning.

questions.question: Microbes reproduce the fastest in their own optimal temperatures.
questions.description: All microbes have their own optimal temperatures where reproduction is the fastest. In the insides of humans and animals, the temperature range between 20 and 45 degrees Celsius is the best for microbes. Anything hotter or colder than this causes microbes to reproduce slower.

questions.question: Sterilizing only destroys microbes capable of reproducing.
questions.description: Sterilizing destroys reproductive spores as well as bacteria spores. Canned foods are produced with sterilization.

questions.question: Pet dog hair cannot spread microbes into food products.
questions.description: Pet hair can spread microbes into food products.

questions.question: Food poisoning only spreads by contaminated food products or drinking water.
questions.description: Food poisoning can also spread due to bad work or hand hygiene. Food poisoning bacteria such as salmonella can spread human-to-human without any intermediate due to bad hand hygiene. Disease carriers without symptoms can also spread salmonella to other people.

questions.question: The HACCP system is used to help own-check plans and the planning of them.
questions.description: HACCP, meaning the Hazard Analysis and Critical Control Points system, helps to think of critical points during transportation of food products from preparation to consumers. Explaining these critical points in the own-check plan helps upkeeping good work hygiene.

questions.question: If there are other companies working in the same estate, then the food production area needs a waste disposal area separate from the other companies' areas.
questions.description: Waste disposal areas can be the same with other companies but the own-check plan's waste disposal instructions must show if the waste disposal and its contract only cover the food production area or the entire estate.

questions.question: Some microbes can reproduce even in food products that are in a protective gas package.
questions.description: Protective gas packages contain little or no oxygen. This prevents microbes that require oxygen from growing. However, the product can also contain microbes that do not need oxygen.

questions.question: Food products containing preservatives never spoil.
questions.description: Preservatives only slow down the spoiling done by microbes.

questions.question: Food products must be cooled first by using separate cooling equipment and only then moved into a freezer for storage.
questions.description: Products that are not frozen and are placed into a freezer will raise the temperature of the freezer; this weakens the lastingness of the products in the freezer.

questions.question: If your protective clothing gets dirty when you take out the rubbish, you must change into clean ones before you continue cooking.
questions.description: Staff must make sure that their work clothes are always clean when they handle and prepare food.

questions.question: The slow cooling of food is one of the main causes of food poisoning.
questions.description: The slower food is cooled to under 8 degrees Celsius, the longer food poisoning causing microbes have time to reproduce quickly in optimal conditions. Food should be cooled to under 8 degrees in under 4 hours. When preparing large amounts of food at the same time, the cooling can take too long.

questions.question: All dangerous food poisoning microbes need oxygen to grow.
questions.description: Most of the bacteria that cause food poisoning are facultative anaerobic bacteria, which means that they can grow in either the presence or absence of oxygen.

questions.question: Norwalk-like viruses (NLV) will be destroyed if they are in temperatures higher than 90 degrees Celsius for 2 minutes.
questions.description: Food poisoning causing NLV will be destroyed using heat treatment. However, it can withstand very high temperatures. 2 minutes in over 90 degrees Celsius temperatures is enough to remove the virus from food products.

questions.question: The training of personnel is an important part of own-check plans.
questions.description: The training of personnel is an essential part of own-check plans. In the food industry technology, equipment, ingredients, preparation methods and even risks change, so it is important to update knowledge regularly.

questions.question: In commercial kitchens, it is necessary to nominate the people in charge of the own-check plan.
questions.description: Designated persons who have been trained for the task are responsible for the various areas of the own-check plan.

questions.question: Food products are allowed to freeze during transport and this does not cause any harm.
questions.description: Food must not be frozen during transport as this will impair the hygienic quality of the food products. Perishable food products that require cold storage are transported in temperatures that do not exceed those set for storing perishable food products.

questions.question: The activity of water contained in food products can be lowered by adding salt or sugar to the product.
questions.description: The activity of water shows how easily the water in a product can be used by microbes. Salt and sugar change the state of water so that the microbes can not use it.

questions.question: Listeria bacteria are not destroyed when a product is frozen.
questions.description: Freezing does not destroy microbes. Listeria can also reproduce in frozen foods.

questions.question: Moulds can produce dangerous toxins in food products.
questions.description: Moulds can grow on food products. While growing, some moulds produce toxins that are hazardous for the human health. Mould toxins will sometimes not get destroyed when heating a food product, even though the mould itself might be destroyed.

questions.question: If a can of canned food has bloated and become larger, the contents inside the can must not be tasted.
questions.description: Bloated, enlargened cans can contain a dangerous toxin called botulin. Even a very small amount of botulin can be lethal.

questions.question: Tapeworms can be found in the roe (eggs) and muscles of some lake fish.
questions.description: Tapeworms can be found in the roe (eggs) and muscles of lake fish, such as bass, pike, burbot and ruffe. Proper cooking or freezing (2 days minimum) will destroy the tapeworm.

questions.question: If you have just washed your hands carefully with soap, you can taste food with your finger.
questions.description: You can only taste food using clean cutlery, never with your fingers.

questions.question: Heat and humidity accelerate vegetable spoilage.
questions.description: The correct storage temperatures and moisture affect the shelf life of vegetables.

questions.question: Food poisoning microbes can only spread through the air.
questions.description: Food poisoning microbes can be transmitted into food in many ways such as via hands, soil, contaminated water or airborne dust particles. Rodents, insects and birds can also spread food poisoning microbes.

questions.question: Smoking is allowed in the food premises storeroom if the employer allows it.
questions.description: Smoking is prohibited in the food premises in those areas where food is prepared, sold, processed or stored.

questions.question: Own-check plans must include clear instructions on how to act when food poisoning suspicions are raised.
questions.description: When food is prepared for customers, food poisoning events must be planned for in advance. Own-check plans must include clear instructions for these events. It is important to notify health inspectors about suspicions immediately.

questions.question: Ice cube machines do not need to be cleaned separately, because their low temperature prevents microbes from multiplying.
questions.description: Ice cube machines must be cleaned just as regularly and carefully as other cooling equipment.

questions.question: Disinfected work surfaces contain no microbes.
questions.description: Correctly done disinfection reduces the amount of microbes excellently on work surfaces and equipment. However, a disinfected work surface is not sterile.

questions.question: Contamination means e.g. unwanted microbes and/or chemicals spreading into a product.
questions.description: Contamination can be microbiological, chemical or physical. It is unwanted and can cause perishing of food products or food poisoning.

questions.question: The gas in protective gas packaging completely prevents harmful microbes from growing.
questions.description: The amount of oxygen in protective gas is changed to make it harder for most microbes to grow. Some harmful microbes can withstand exceptional conditions and will be able to reproduce even in protective gas packages. Additionally, the protective gas in the packages will try to equalize with the air around it, so the amount of gas can change.

questions.question: EHEC bacteria can be found in milk is the work hygiene during milking is not proper.
questions.description: This intestinal bacteria can only found in food products if the work hygiene is not proper during milking or slaughtering. Pasteurization destroys EHEC in milk.

questions.question: All E-numbered additives improve the lastingness of food products.
questions.description: Food products can be made to last longer by adding preservatives to them. In the European Union, allowed preservatives have an E-number: for example, E 200 is sorbic acid and E 296 is malic acid. Preservatives that are allowed can be found, along with other additives, in an E-number list. Some preservatives can be found naturally in berries and fruits, such as in lingonberries and citrus fruit. E-numbers are also used to identify additives other than ones that improve lastingness. For example, color additives do not improve the lastingness of food products.

questions.question: Intestinal bacteria can spread from hands to food.
questions.description: Intestinal bacteria can spread to food even from the hands.

questions.question: Vinegar lowers the pH value of a product and in this way makes the product last better.
questions.description: Especially the growth of bacteria can be prevented by increasing the acidity of a product.

questions.question: Bacteria spores are destroyed in freezers.
questions.description: Bacteria do not reproduce in freezers. However, the spores of the bacteria do not get destroyed during freezing.

questions.question: Suspicions of food poisoning are not a part of own-check plans because health officials will investigate the cause of disease if necessary.
questions.description: Own-check plans must have clear instructions for dealing with food poisoning cases and suspicions. Responsible people and methods of informing should be explained in the own-check plan.

questions.question: Washed, clean dishes can only be handled with clean hands.
questions.description: If clean dishes are handled with dirty hands, microbes and dirt will spread from the hands onto the dishes.

questions.question: Cold-stored root vegetables may contain Yersinia bacteria that cause food poisoning.
questions.description: Root vegetables that are cold stored for a long time may contain Yersinia bacteria that cause food poisoning.

questions.question: If you have just washed your hands carefully with soap, you can taste food with your finger.
questions.description: You can only taste food using clean cutlery, never with your fingers.

questions.question: HACCP is not a food poisoning causing bacteria.
questions.description: HACCP stands for Hazard Analysis and Critical Control Points, which is a part of own-check plans. When working with an own-check plan these critical points must be identified and constantly monitored carefully.

questions.question: Reheated products must be heated to +75 degrees celsius before serving.
questions.description: Reheated food products, such as appropriately cooled food that has been prepared the previous day, must be thoroughly heated to +75 degrees before serving.

questions.question: Listeria and yersinia can reproduce in refrigerator temperatures.
questions.description: Earth and various bodies of water contain microbes, such as listeria and yersinia, that are able to survive cold conditions well. Listeria and yersinia can reproduce in very cold refrigerator temperatures.

questions.question: The post-contamination of a cooked product can be prevented by using appropriate and clean storing containers.
questions.description: Good hand hygiene, clean working equipment and hygienic storing containers protect cooked products from post-contamination due to hazards that affect the safety of the product after heating it.

questions.question: Any water can be used for washing potatoes as they have soil on them.
questions.description: Potatoes must always be washed with water that meets the requirements for domestic water.

questions.question: The same knife can be used for cutting raw and cooked meat.
questions.description: Heated food must be protected from contamination after being heated. Ingredients and the equipment used to handle those ingredients must be kept separate from cooked products to prevent cross-contamination.

questions.question: Viruses can not reproduce in food products.
questions.description: Viruses need living host cells to reproduce, which means they can not reproduce or produce toxins in food products. However, food products can still work as spreaders of viruses.

questions.question: All transport companies can transport food to restaurants provided that their vehicles are spacious enough.
questions.description: Professional transporting of food requires certification from the appropriate authorities as well as an own-check plan.

questions.question: Health inspectors inspect restaurant kitchens.
questions.description: The work of health inspectors requires making inspections in food production areas such as food stores and restaurants.

questions.question: All work phases, such as dishwashing, baking and treatment of root vegetables, can be done in the same area in hospital kitchens.
questions.description: When each work phase is done in its own separate area the work is hygienic and the risk of cross-contamination is smaller.

questions.question: In lunch restaurants a control measurement of the temperature of food served from serving equipment is done once a week.
questions.description: Control measurements on served products are performed daily. Exceptions are always written down and all temperatures are logged in the own-check plan forms once a week.

questions.question: Smoking is not allowed at the loading docks of kitchens.
questions.description: Loading docks are a part of food production areas; smoking is not allowed in food production areas.

questions.question: The only mandatory information on food packaging is the ingredients and the name of the food product.
questions.description: In addition to the name of the food product and the ingredients, the packaging must also state the minimum shelf life and the use by date.

questions.question: When receiving food products it is enough to check their temperature.
questions.description: When receiving food products it is also required to check the products' appearance, the quality of the packaging and the packaging markings with the senses (visually etc.).

questions.question: The temperature monitoring of cold storages is a part of own-check plans.
questions.description: The temperatures of cold storages must be checked and logged regularly according to the own-check plan. Cold storages must always have thermometers for measurements.

questions.question: Old and worn cleaning equipment can spread harmful microbes into food premises.
questions.description: It is important to make sure that cleaning equipment is always clean and in good condition.

questions.question: Plants can be displayed and sold anywhere in a grocery store as long as adequate ventilation is provided.
questions.description: Plants must be located as far as possible from unpackaged perishable food products. There are lots of microbes on the surface of plants and in the soil, and these may spread to food products.

questions.question: Temperatures measured under the own-check plan do not need to be recorded if you learn them by heart.
questions.description: It is important to measure and record temperatures.

questions.question: Samples taken from batches of food prepared in large kitchens must be stored for 1-2 months.
questions.description: Samples are taken from large kitchens' food batches to trace possible food poisoning causes easier. Samples must be taken daily from all batches being somehow served or sold and the samples must be stored appropriately marked in a freezer for 1-2 weeks. During this time a majority of food poisoning symptoms start to appear.

questions.question: When a new detergent is introduced into a kitchen, the cleaning plan in the own-check plan is updated.
questions.description: It is important that the own-check plan is always up to date. All changes to the own-check plan, e.g. introduction of a new detergent, must be updated in the cleaning plan.

questions.question: Tap water can cause food poisoning.
questions.description: Tap water cleanliness must be monitored using the senses. Water samples can also be regularly sent for chemical and microbiological inspections. For example the food poisoning causing norovirus lasts well in water.

questions.question: A food poisoning epidemic is a situation where at least 10 people have become sick with similar symptoms after consuming the same food product or ingredient.
questions.description: A food poisoning epidemic means a situation where at least 2 people have become sick with similar symptoms after consuming the same food or drink.

questions.question: The transportation company is responsible for the approproate storing temperature of food during transportation.
questions.description: Drivers ensure that food is being stored in the right temperature, and that packages do not get damaged. The person receiving the delivery inspects the delivery and makes sure products quickly get placed in the appropriate storing place.

questions.question: Earth does not contain food poisoning causing bacteria.
questions.description: Earth can contain e.g. bacillus cereus or clostridum bacteria. Both of these are common causers of food poisoning.

questions.question: Waiters and servers are not required to have headwear.
questions.description: Waiters and servers are allowed to work without headwear.

questions.question: Temperature measurements stated in the own-check plan must be done according to the own-check plan.
questions.description: Only regularly done measurements can prove that the own-check plan has been adhered to at a workplace.

questions.question: Windows in food premises can be opened for ventilation.
questions.description: Windows and doors in food premises must be kept closed to prevent pests from entering the premises.

questions.question: It is important to change disposable gloves often enough.
questions.description: When working with food, you must change disposable gloves whenever you start a new work phase.

questions.question: Cooked rice left at room temperature is a good breeding ground for various microbes.
questions.description: Bacillus cereus is one of the bacteria that causes food poisoning; it cannot be completely stopped from spreading to food products. Bacillus cereus is found in almost all food products. It is most commonly spread through rice dishes and vegetables.

questions.question: Fermented milk products are produced with the help of lactic acid bacteria.
questions.description: Lactic acid bacteria (LAB) are used when producing fermented milk products. LAB create lactic acid in the product, which causes the product to become acidized. Most bacteria are unable to reproduce in acidized products and because of this fermenting milk products makes them last longer.
