questions.question: Food control authorities are responsible for monitoring companies' own-check plans.
questions.description: The responsibility of own-check plans is the company's. Officials have a possibility to get to know companies' own-check plans and data while doing checks. However, own-check plan documents are companies' personal documents and the companies have the responsibility of storing them and training any personnel to act according to the own-check plan.

questions.question: Ice makers do not need to be washed because microbes do not multiply in such a cold environment.
questions.description: Ice makers must be washed regularly. Ice makers and utensils for picking up ice must be kept clean and in good condition, and their lids must be kept closed to prevent dirt from entering the machines. The high number of microbes in ice cubes causes a deterioration in the quality of food products and even food poisoning.

questions.question: Food that is being served while hot must be at least 55 degrees Celsius during the entire serving period.
questions.description: Food that is being served while hot must be kept at over 60 degrees Celsius during the entire serving period. The temperature must be measured and marked down in own-check logs.

questions.question: Soup made for the following day can be left to cool overnight on the kitchen counter.
questions.description: The rapid cooling and cold storing of soup prevents or slows down the growth of bacteria.

questions.question: The human skin naturally contains microbes.
questions.description: Especially the face, scalp, mouth, nose etc. contain microbes. Food poisoning causing Staphylococcus bacteria can also be found on the skin.

questions.question: Food that is being served while hot must be at least 60 degrees Celsius during the entire serving period.
questions.description: The temperature must also be measured and marked down in own-check logs. The food can be kept in service while hot for a maximum of 4 hours.

questions.question: BSE is also called mad cow's disease.
questions.description: Mad cow's disease is sometimes found in old cows. During slaughtering the carcasses must be checked so that contaminated meat is not used.

questions.question: The own-check plan helps to make sure that there are fewer unsafe food products.
questions.description: The most important objective of the own-check plan is to improve food safety.

questions.question: Fresh morel mushrooms must be roasted thoroughly before they can be eaten.
questions.description: Fresh morel mushrooms contain natural toxins which can not be removed by only roasting the mushrooms.

questions.question: Food poisoning can be caused by careless hand washing.
questions.description: Dirty hands may contain microbes that cause food poisoning.

questions.question: Unpeeled and peeled carrots will last the same amount of time as long as they are stored in the cold.
questions.description: Earthy and dirty, untreated root vegetables will last long in appropriate cold storage units, but all treatments will worsen their lastingness.

questions.question: All cold storage units in food production areas must contain a thermometer.
questions.description: The monitoring and logging of temperatures is an important part of the . Thermometers are a vital tool for this and must be used.

questions.question: Disinfectants should be changed regularly.
questions.description: Microbes can become immune to specific disinfectants, and so the disinfectants should be changed from time to time.

questions.question: After washing one's hands the tap must be closed using a hand towel, otherwise the hands can become dirty again.
questions.description: After washing the hands they must be dried using a single-use hand towel and the tap must be closed using the towel. This way any possible microbes on the tap do not spread onto the clean hands.

questions.question: Cleaning equipment do not need a separate storage area.
questions.description: It's not always necessary to have a separate storage space for cleaning equipment. Food production areas need a separate storage, maintenance and drying space if the food production area requires it for constructional reasons. It's important to make sure that there are no risks for food safety and the hygienic treatment, maintenance and storage of cleaning equipment are done properly. If necessary the working stages and functions has to be separated structually or timely.

questions.question: Mashed potato is an easily perishable food product.
questions.description: Pre-made foods are easily perishable products. Easily perishable foods must be stored in the cold, under 6 degrees Celsius.

questions.question: Bacteria are always harmful on human skin or in the intestines.
questions.description: Beneficial bacteria exist on the skin and in the intestines that protect humans from harmful bacteria and strengthen the immune system.

questions.question: A best-before-date must be marked on easily perishable products.
questions.description: Easily perishable products must have a use-by-date.

questions.question: Additives may be used in all food products.
questions.description: Only approved additives can be used in the preparation of food products. Additives must undergo a thorough safety assessment before they are approved for use.

questions.question: A piece of rotten fruit affects the shelf life of other pieces of fruit that are near it.
questions.description: A piece of rotten fruit also spoils other pieces of fruit kept in the same dish, so it is important to dispose of rotten fruit.

questions.question: Moulds can not create mould toxins.
questions.description: Some moulds can create mould toxins such as mycotoxins and aflatoxins. Because of this mouldy products should not be used.

questions.question: Acidity in a food product prevents the reproduction of bacteria.
questions.description: Bacteria that are a threat to food product safety reproduce the best in the neutral zone. Because of this the growth of these bacteria can be prevented by increasing the acidity of a product.

questions.question: Only supervisors carry out the activities described in the own-check plan.
questions.description: Everyone working in a food premises is responsible for carrying out the activities described in the own-check plan.

questions.question: High salt content prevents harmful microbes from multiplying in a product
questions.description: Strong salting of a product changes the state of its water so that microbes can not reproduce. However, salted products such as mushrooms must still be stored in cool temperatures to prevent microbes on their surface from perishing them.

questions.question: Organic food does not cause food poisoning as easily as "normal" food.
questions.description: Organic food is produced without fertilizers or pesticides. This does not affect food poisoning almost at all. The risk for food poisoning is the same between "normal" and organic food.

questions.question: Hand washing sinks can be used for cleaning root vegetables.
questions.description: Enough hand washing areas must be available, and they must only be used for washing hands.

questions.question: A cleaning and washing program must be included in the own-check plan.
questions.description: Areas that need to be cleaned, washing and cleaning methods for each area and specific cleaning equipment and substances (if required) must be listed in the own-check plan. The effectiveness of the cleaning must be checked visually daily and the responsible person has to log results for example once a week or always when abnormalities are noticed.

questions.question: All easily perishable food products must be stored in temperatures under 6 degrees Celsius.
questions.description: This statement is correct, but one must notice that raw mince meat requires a storing temperature of at most 4 degrees Celsius, and fish and shellfish even while vacuum-packed must be stored between 0 and 3 degrees Celsius.

questions.question: It is not required to change single-use gloves worn on the hands if a phone is answered while wearing them.
questions.description: Only one phase of work can be done while wearing the same single-use gloves. If a phone is answered then the hands must be washed and the gloves must be changed.

questions.question: Milk can be stored at room temperature during the breakfast service.
questions.description: Milk and cream are perishable food products and they must be served cold.

questions.question: All E-numbered additives improve the lastingness of food products.
questions.description: Food products can be made to last longer by adding preservatives to them. In the European Union, allowed preservatives have an E-number: for example, E 200 is sorbic acid and E 296 is malic acid. Preservatives that are allowed can be found, along with other additives, in an E-number list. Some preservatives can be found naturally in berries and fruits, such as in lingonberries and citrus fruit. E-numbers are also used to identify additives other than ones that improve lastingness. For example, color additives do not improve the lastingness of food products.

questions.question: Ice makers do not need to be washed because microbes do not multiply in such a cold environment.
questions.description: Ice makers must be washed regularly. Ice makers and utensils for picking up ice must be kept clean and in good condition, and their lids must be kept closed to prevent dirt from entering the machines. The high number of microbes in ice cubes causes a deterioration in the quality of food products and even food poisoning.

questions.question: Freezing improves the lastingness of food products because microbes are destroyed in the cold.
questions.description: Cold does not destroy microbes. If a product being freezed is microbiologically bad quality, it will be even worse quality after defrosting. However, freezing a good quality product will make it last longer as long as the freezing temperature is cold enough (-18 degrees Celsius or lower) and defrosting happens sufficiently slowly in cold areas.

questions.question: It is not allowed to use useful microbes in baking.
questions.description: Yeast is used in baking to make dough rise.

questions.question: Any mould can be used in the production of mould-ripened cheese.
questions.description: Only certain moulds are suitable for making mould-ripened cheeses.

questions.question: Food products that have been thawed only once can be refrozen as long as they are packed in hygienic packaging.
questions.description: You must never refreeze food products that have already been thawed.

questions.question: Raw ingredients containing gluten must be labelled and stored in closed containers in a storage room.
questions.description: Raw ingredients containing allergens and gluten must be labelled and stored separately in closed containers.

questions.question: Disinfectants only work if the concentration is correct and they are left to work for the correct period of time.
questions.description: The effectiveness of a disinfectant depends on issues such as the concentration, how long it is left to work and the temperature of the solution.

questions.question: Guide dogs are allowed inside food product stores.
questions.description: Guide dogs are always allowed in areas meant for customers. However, no animals can be taken inside food product handling areas or storage areas.

questions.question: If one's hands are clean, the temperature of food can be checked with the fingers.
questions.description: It is not possible to see how microbiologically clean one's hands are if only using the bare eye. Microbes can spread from the fingers to cooked food; when measuring the temperature of food a thermometer which can be easily cleaned must be used.

questions.question: The cleanliness of waste rooms is not essential for hygiene because only waste is stored in those rooms.
questions.description: The cleanliness and hygiene of waste rooms is an essential part of taking care of food product hygiene because employees enter the waste room during the work day while wearing their work clothes, which they wear everywhere else as well. Waste rooms must be kept clean and organised.

questions.question: When a food industry workplace, e.g. a sausage factory, is being founded, the workplace must only inform local food control authorities about the activities.
questions.description: When a food industry workplace, e.g. a sausage factory, is being founded, an approval for the activities by local food control authorities is required.

questions.question: If a fish is dropped on a freshly washed floor, it can still be cooked as long as it is sufficiently well heated.
questions.description: A fish that has fallen onto the floor must never be used for cooking. Food products must never be stored on the floor.

questions.question: Oiva-reports must be placed at the entrance of the café, restaurant etc. so that customers can read them.
questions.description: Oiva-reports are published documents about routine inspections. These reports are also published online at www.oivahymy.fi

questions.question: Products that have gone through ultra-high-temperature treatment (UHT) can be stored in room temperature.
questions.description: During UHT products are sterilized with quick heating. Unopened packages can be stored in room temperature because most bacteria spores have been destroyed.

questions.question: Food packaging materials can be stored on a clean floor.
questions.description: Food packaging materials must never be stored directly on the floor but they must be placed on clean racks or other hygienic surfaces.

questions.question: Campylo bacteria is naturally found in fowl and poultry.
questions.description: Campylo bacteria and salmonella are found naturally in fowl and poultry. Both bacteria are destroyed when the meat is cooked thoroughly to over 75 degrees Celsius.

questions.question: Microbes can not reproduce in dry products.
questions.description: Microbes need water to reproduce. Microbes will not reproduce in dried products but dried products can contain spores of bacteria, moulds or yeast.

questions.question: Easily perishable food products do not require a storage instruction label if it is a commonly known product.
questions.description: Packages of easily perishable food products always require a label indicating the last day of use and storing instructions. The shown date is valid only for unopened products that have been stored in the right temperature.

questions.question: Food poisonings can be prevented by using single-use protective gloves.
questions.description: Single-use protective gloves must be used when handling very easily perishable food products. Protective gloves make it easier to work when employees must change tasks quickly.

questions.question: The creation and following requirements of own-check plans include all companies that handle food products.
questions.description: The creation and use of an own-check plan is a requirement by law, which has included all companies handling food products since 1995. All employees in a company are responsible for the implementation of own-check plans.

questions.question: Food product employees can use wedding and engagement rings while handling easily perishable goods.
questions.description: Jewellery can not be used when working with food products. No matter how well hands are washed, a large amount of harmful microbes can stay under rings and can later contaminate food products being handled.

questions.question: Mould that has spread from blue cheese to other cheeses is not hazardous.
questions.description: Mould spreading from blue cheese to other cheeses, which the mould is not supposed to be in, is hazardous and can worsen the quality and also perish the cheeses. However, the spreading of the mould to other cheeses is not always a health risk.

questions.question: Contamination means e.g. unwanted microbes and/or chemicals spreading into a product.
questions.description: Contamination can be microbiological, chemical or physical. It is unwanted and can cause perishing of food products or food poisoning.

questions.question: In a cramped or nearly full storage facility, food products that can easily perish can be stored on the floor if it has just been washed.
questions.description: Easily perishable food products must always have shelves or a platform in storage facilities. Food products can never be stored on the floor.

questions.question: The norovirus is not destroyed when a food product is frozen.
questions.description: The norovirus lasts for long amounts of time and is able to spread even in the cold or in frozen foods.

questions.question: Food that is being served only requires temperature measurements if it is being served hot.
questions.description: Temperature measurements must also be done for food that is being served cold.

questions.question: Only supervisors carry out the activities described in the own-check plan.
questions.description: Everyone working in a food premises is responsible for carrying out the activities described in the own-check plan.

questions.question: Using food, that has been served at a buffet table, as an ingredient for preparing new foods increases food poisoning risks.
questions.description: Food that is at a buffet table is often in room temperature and available to be taken by customers themselves. This means that food poisoning causing bacteria spread to these foods easier and reproduce quicker in them. The risk of food poisoning increases when the same foods are used to make new ones. Food from buffet tables must not be used again in food preparation.

questions.question: The activity of water contained in food products can be lowered by adding salt or sugar to the product.
questions.description: The activity of water shows how easily the water in a product can be used by microbes. Salt and sugar change the state of water so that the microbes can not use it.

questions.question: Employees are free to decide who is responsible for the own-check plan at the beginning of each shift.
questions.description: Designated persons who have been trained for the task are responsible for the various areas of the own-check plan.

questions.question: Pet dog hair cannot spread microbes into food products.
questions.description: Pet hair can spread microbes into food products.

questions.question: Food products can be used after the last use-by-date if the product does not look spoiled.
questions.description: The last use-by-date must be marked on easily perishable food products. The products can not be used nor sold after this date.

questions.question: All plastic containers are suitable for storing food.
questions.description: Materials that come into contact with food must be meant for food use.

questions.question: Dirt and dust can make microbes spread to food products.
questions.description: Different kinds of impurities, such as dirt and dust, contain microbes. If dirt or dust gets onto a food product then the microbes contained will also spread onto the product.

questions.question: If a summer restaurant is located next to a lake with clean water, the water in the lake can be used for washing fruits.
questions.description: All food preparation requires the use of water that is tap water quality.

questions.question: If a salmonella infection is asymptomatic, it cannot spread into handled food products via an employee.
questions.description: A salmonella infection can spread even if the person who carries it has no symptoms. This is why it is important to have a salmonella test before the employment starts.

questions.question: Own-check plans must not be changed.
questions.description: Own-check plans must be updated when changes happen in the workplace.

questions.question: If the film/foil of a vacuum-package is loose or tensionless the package is damaged.
questions.description: The package has probably been broken and air has entered it. The lastingness of the product can not be estimated after this, because the use-by-date marked on the package is based on the assumption that the package contains no air (oxygen that microbes can use to grow.)

questions.question: The results in Oiva-reports are not allowed to be read by customers.
questions.description: Municipality food control authorities do routine inspections at workplaces. Oiva-reports are published documents about these inspections.

questions.question: The monitoring logs made for own-check plans, e.g. logs of temperature measurements, must be stored at the workplace for 6 months.
questions.description: Logs must be stored for at least 1 year after selling a product. The information included can be used to trace errors and problems.

questions.question: If food does not taste spoiled it can not cause food poisoning.
questions.description: Many food poisoning causing bacteria can reproduce in food without causing changes that can be noticed with the senses (visually, taste etc.)

questions.question: Norovirus is not spread in water.
questions.description: Norovirus infection can also be acquired from contaminated water.

questions.question: Food poisoning causing bacteria are found naturally.
questions.description: Microbes are everywhere: in the air, water, earth, plants, animals and humans. Some of these microbes cause food poisoning.

questions.question: All easily perishable food products must be stored in temperatures under 6 degrees Celsius.
questions.description: This statement is correct, but one must notice that raw mince meat requires a storing temperature of at most 4 degrees Celsius, and fish and shellfish even while vacuum-packed must be stored between 0 and 3 degrees Celsius.

questions.question: BSE, also called mad cow's disease, is not a food poisoning causing bacteria.
questions.description: BSE is caused by changes in the central nervous system of cows. Humans can get the disease only by eating meat that is contaminated with BSE.

questions.question: Dirty root vegetables can be stored in cardboard boxes above meat products on cold room shelves.
questions.description: Dirt always contains many microbes. Dirty root vegetables must be handled separately from other products so that the microbes in the dirt do not spread to other food products.

questions.question: Beneficial microbes cannot be used in the production of cream cheese.
questions.description: Cream cheese is made using beneficial microbes.

questions.question: If the temperature of a cold storage unit is too high it must not be marked down on the own-check plan's monitoring logs.
questions.description: Measured temperatures must be marked down in the own-check plan's monitoring logs, even if they are too high or too low. The logs must also contain information on what fixing procedure has been made to correct the incorrect temperature.

questions.question: A delivery load that contains meat and fish products can be safely left at room temperature for three hours pending transfer into cold storage.
questions.description: The cold chain of perishable food products must not be interrupted at any point in the supply chain.

questions.question: During food preparation one can go wash one's hands in the staff restroom.
questions.description: There must be a separate hand washing spot in immediate proximity to the food preparation area.

questions.question: The own-check plan must include cleaning instructions that are up-to-date.
questions.description: Cleaning instructions for equipment and work areas must be available and known to the personnel, so that cleaning procedures will be the same and integrated between everyone, and so that employees will be able to easily disassemble equipment to clean them properly.

questions.question: Raw milk can contain yersinia.
questions.description: Raw milk has not been pasteurized. Yersinia is destroyed when milk is heated to over 70 degrees Celsius; in other words it is destroyed when the milk is pasteurized.

questions.question: Mashed potato is not an easily perishable food product.
questions.description: Pre-made foods are easily perishable products. Easily perishable foods must be stored in the cold, under 6 degrees Celsius.

questions.question: A product can not be used for food preparation after the product's best-before date.
questions.description: Best before dates tell that the product's main attributes and characteristics will remain the same up to the marked date, as long as it is stored correctly. The product can be used and sold after the best before date. The usability and quality of the product can be checked using the senses (visually etc.) after the best before date.

questions.question: Food production employees are not allowed to wear colorless nail polish.
questions.description: Hands must not containt anything extra such as watches, jewellery, fake nails, nail polish or hand cream.

questions.question: Raw milk is not suitable for small children, elderly people, pregnant women or people who have a severe disease.
questions.description: Because raw milk has not been pasteurized it can contain disease causing bacteria. The most important bacteria that are a threat to food product safety in raw milk are EHEC, campylo, listeria and salmonella bacteria.

questions.question: Temperature does not affect the speed of microbe reproduction.
questions.description: Temperatures are very important for the reproduction abilities of microbes. All microbes have their own optimal temperatures where reproduction is the fastest.

questions.question: Oiva is a system which helps people to self-assess the food product safety of their workplace.
questions.description: Municipality food control authorities make Oiva-reports about the workplaces they inspect. It is not a part of the workplace's self-assessment.

questions.question: Cooked rice can be cooled in room temperature.
questions.description: Cooked rice is an easily perishable food product. In room temperature the microbes in the rice can reproduce very quickly and cause food poisoning.

questions.question: Any water can be used for washing potatoes as they have soil on them.
questions.description: Potatoes must always be washed with water that meets the requirements for domestic water.

questions.question: Indoor plants can spread harmful microbes to food products.
questions.description: Indoor plants must not be kept in food product preparation areas because microbes live on their surface and in their earth.

questions.question: Intestinal bacteria cannot spread from hands to food.
questions.description: Intestinal bacteria can spread to food even from the hands.

questions.question: Useful microbes are used in baking.
questions.description: Yeast is used in baking to make dough rise.

questions.question: Thawing frozen food products in a sealed container at room temperature does not increase the risk of food poisoning.
questions.description: Food must be thawed in such a way as to minimise the increase of pathogens as much as possible. A frozen food product is defrosted in a cold room so that the temperature of the food product's surface does not rise above the other parts of the product.

questions.question: A cleaning and washing program must be included in the own-check plan.
questions.description: Areas that need to be cleaned, washing and cleaning methods for each area and specific cleaning equipment and substances (if required) must be listed in the own-check plan. The effectiveness of the cleaning must be checked visually daily and the responsible person has to log results for example once a week or always when abnormalities are noticed.

questions.question: The slime that appears on the surface of meat products is caused by harmful microbes.
questions.description: Some harmful microbes produce slime. For example, slime appearing on the surface of a sausage is a sign of it perishing. Slime-producing microbes reproduce quickly in food products e.g. when the product is stored or served in too high temperatures.

questions.question: A grated carrot spoils faster than an entire carrot.
questions.description: Treating a carrot and grating it shortens the time it lasts. During grating microbes spread onto the carrot and water inside the carrot becomes available for the microbes to use. Grated products also have more surface area than intact products; microbes, especially ones that require oxygen, are suitable to live on the surface of products.

questions.question: The results of Oiva-reports can be viewed by anyone online.
questions.description: The Oiva system is used to allow consumers to view the results of routine inspections.

questions.question: Sliced sourdough bread keeps better than a whole loaf of sourdough bread.
questions.description: Handling food products by chopping or slicing them, for example, impairs their shelf life.

questions.question: Food that is being served while cold must have its temperature measured and marked down.
questions.description: Temperature measurements of food that is being served are a part of own-check plans. The results of the measurements must be mark down in the monitoring logs of the own-check plans and then stored at the workplace for 1 year.

questions.question: The gas in protective gas packaging completely prevents harmful microbes from growing.
questions.description: The amount of oxygen in protective gas is changed to make it harder for most microbes to grow. Some harmful microbes can withstand exceptional conditions and will be able to reproduce even in protective gas packages. Additionally, the protective gas in the packages will try to equalize with the air around it, so the amount of gas can change.

questions.question: The amount of water a product contains does not significantly affect its lastingness.
questions.description: Harmful microbes need water to reproduce. Because of this dry products last well.

questions.question: Smoking is allowed at the loading docks of kitchens.
questions.description: Loading docks are a part of food production areas; smoking is not allowed in food production areas.

questions.question: Customer feedback is not a part of the own-check plan.
questions.description: Customer feedback is part of a company's own-check plan. The own-check plan should also explain how feedback is used.

questions.question: You can touch the inside surfaces of food packaging if you have just washed your hands.
questions.description: You should always try not to touch the inside surfaces of food packaging.

questions.question: Health inspectors can not inspect a workplace's own-check plan's monitoring logs.
questions.description: Health inspectors make routine inspections in food production areas. The monitoring logs of the own-check plans are also part of the inspections. The logs must be stored for 1 year in the workplace. Only stored logs can prove that the workplace has followed its own-check plan accordingly.

questions.question: A cheese roll packed in a tight plastic wrap is protected from microbes.
questions.description: A cheese roll is a perishable food product that is stored and served cold. In addition to being wrapped in plastic film, make sure that it is kept in the correct storage and serving temperatures.

questions.question: The amount of things covered in the waste disposal instructions must be the same for everyone in the food industry.
questions.description: The own-check plan's waste disposal instructions' coverage depends on what the done activities cover.

questions.question: Staphylococcus aureus is a food poisoning bacteria.
questions.description: The human skin, nose and mucous membranes can contain staphylococcus aureus. Good hand hygiene is important due to this.

questions.question: Mould and bacterial spores can also be found in dry food products.
questions.description: Spores are more resistant than bacteria to their surrounding conditions, especially heat, drought and chemical agents.

questions.question: Salmonella bacteria that can be contained in milk products or eggs can be destroyed by pasteurization.
questions.description: Pasteurizing milk, meaning heating to 72 degrees Celsius for 15 seconds, destroys salmonella bacteria. Pasteurization can also be used to treat industrially used batches made from eggs.

questions.question: Listeria can not reproduce in cold fish (e.g. salmon) in vacuum-packages.
questions.description: Listeria and yersinia are rare exceptions of food poisoning causing bacteria, because they can reproduce in refrigerator temperatures.

questions.question: All cold storage units in food production areas must contain a thermometer.
questions.description: The monitoring and logging of temperatures is an important part of the . Thermometers are a vital tool for this and must be used.

questions.question: Rings can be used when handling unpacked food products.
questions.description: Rings can not be used when handling unpacked food products, because microbes have optimal growth conditions underneath them.

questions.question: Yersinia bacteria has been found on fields and in fresh vegetables that have been spoiled during storage.
questions.description: Yersinia is destroyed when heating a product to over 70 degrees Celsius. Fresh vegetables are often served non-heated, so possible yersinia is not destroyed. Yersinia can also reproduce during storage in refrigerator temperatures.

questions.question: Cleaning equipment must be cleaned always after being used.
questions.description: Dirty and wet cleaning equipment contain lots of microbes. The results of cleaning with this equipment are not good.

questions.question: Temperature measurements are to be made only by the superiors of a workplace.
questions.description: The instructions of own-check plans must be adhered to by all employees. Because of this temperature measurements are also the responsibility of all other employees.

questions.question: Bacteria spores are always found inside the cans of canned food.
questions.description: Canned foods are produced with sterilization which destroys all bacteria spores. The sterilization has failed bacteria spores are found inside the can.

questions.question: Chefs can use their work shoes during their travel to and from their workplace.
questions.description: Work shoes must not be worn outside the workplace to prevent microbes from spreading into the food production area.

questions.question: A waiter must be able to tell customers the ingredients of a food product that has not been packed.
questions.description: A waiter must be able to provide customers with information about food products verbally and, if necessary, also in writing.

questions.question: Most harmful microbes reproduce the easiest in temperatures between 6 and 60 degrees Celsius.
questions.description: 6-60 degrees Celsius is a hazardous temperature region where food products should not be stored for long periods of time. Food served from a counter should be kept colder or hotter than this for the entire length of serving, and food to be served later after cooking should be cooled to colder than 6 degrees Celsius quickly (sooner than 4 hours.)

questions.question: Cleaning plans include accurate instructions about how and when cleaning is done.
questions.description: A cleaning plan is an essential part of an own-check plan. Cleaning plans include more accurate instructions on the cleaning of all parts of a food production area.

questions.question: A food product can be sold if it is packed in a vacuum pack that has softened only a little.
questions.description: Air has entered a softened vacuum pack, which means that the product is no longer safe.

questions.question: In lunch restaurants a control measurement of the temperature of food served from serving equipment is done once a week.
questions.description: Control measurements on served products are performed daily. Exceptions are always written down and all temperatures are logged in the own-check plan forms once a week.

questions.question: When a food industry workplace, e.g. a sausage factory, is being founded, the activities of the workplace must be approved in advance by local food control authorities.
questions.description: Workplaces that handle animal-based food products require an approval for their activities. Only informing of the activities is not enough.

questions.question: Disinfecting reduces the amount of microbes from work surfaces and equipment.
questions.description: Correctly done disinfection reduces the amount of microbes excellently on work surfaces and equipment.

questions.question: Intestinal bacteria cannot spread from hands to food.
questions.description: Intestinal bacteria can spread to food even from the hands.

questions.question: All plastic containers are suitable for storing food.
questions.description: Materials that come into contact with food must be meant for food use.

questions.question: Mashed potato is an easily perishable food product.
questions.description: Pre-made foods are easily perishable products. Easily perishable foods must be stored in the cold, under 6 degrees Celsius.

questions.question: Wounds on the hands should be covered with both a bandage and a single-use glove.
questions.description: When both a bandage and a single-use glove are used, the wound is protected well enough and is also made more waterproof.

questions.question: Cold storage units should not be filled beyond their set fill limits because the food products might not stay cold enough.
questions.description: The fill limit is an instruction on usage by the producer of the cold storage unit. The limit should not be crossed because food products outside the limit will not stay cold enough.

questions.question: Customers and employees are allowed to use the same toilet.
questions.description: Strict toilet and hand hygiene must be used in food production. This is not possible if toilets are shared with customers. Customers may have diseases, can be drunk or they can be small children; in each case the use of the same toilets is a risk.

questions.question: Bacteria reproduce very quickly in products that have high acidity.
questions.description: Bacteria that are a threat to food product safety reproduce the best in the neutral zone. Because of this the growth of these bacteria can be prevented by increasing the acidity of a product.

questions.question: Bars of soap are to be used when washing the hands.
questions.description: Microbes on the hands will spread onto bar soap. Because of this bar soap is not hygienic enough.

questions.question: Indoor plants can spread harmful microbes to food products.
questions.description: Indoor plants must not be kept in food product preparation areas because microbes live on their surface and in their earth.

questions.question: Potatoes must be washed with water that meets the requirements for domestic water.
questions.description: When preparing food, always use water that meets the requirements for domestic water to ensure that food safety is not compromised.

questions.question: Health inspectors can not inspect a workplace's own-check plan's monitoring logs.
questions.description: Health inspectors make routine inspections in food production areas. The monitoring logs of the own-check plans are also part of the inspections. The logs must be stored for 1 year in the workplace. Only stored logs can prove that the workplace has followed its own-check plan accordingly.

questions.question: Chefs are allowed to handle money and prepare food without washing their hands in between.
questions.description: Notes and coins contain a lot of microbes, and you must always wash your hands after handling money before you start cooking.

questions.question: During food preparation one can go wash one's hands in the staff restroom.
questions.description: There must be a separate hand washing spot in immediate proximity to the food preparation area.

questions.question: Food products can be used safely after the use-by date if they do not look or smell bad.
questions.description: Perished or contaminated products are not always possible to notice just by using the senses (visually etc.) Easily perishable food products' packages have a use-by date marked on them, and after this date has passed the product must not be used or sold.

questions.question: Sterilizing only destroys microbes capable of reproducing.
questions.description: Sterilizing destroys reproductive spores as well as bacteria spores. Canned foods are produced with sterilization.

questions.question: Listeriosis should be avoided especially during pregnancy.
questions.description: Listeriosis during pregnancy can cause miscarriages or premature birth.

questions.question: Food products containing preservatives will also spoil.
questions.description: Preservatives only slow down the spoiling done by microbes. In the European Union all allowed preservatives have an E-code.

questions.question: Dried products can spoil quickly if they become wet.
questions.description: Dried products last long if they are stored dry. If the products become wet the microbes in them will start to reproduce.

questions.question: There must be an appropriate washing place for large machines and dishes in the food premises.
questions.description: A cleaning plan is made for every machine and device to specify an appropriate place for washing each one of them.

questions.question: The results in Oiva-reports are not allowed to be read by customers.
questions.description: Municipality food control authorities do routine inspections at workplaces. Oiva-reports are published documents about these inspections.

questions.question: If upon delivery there are any problems in regards to the transportation temperature of easily perishable food products, one should report it to Finnish Food Safety Authority.
questions.description: If there are any problems with the quality of delivered products, they should be returned to the supplier and reported to the driver.

questions.question: The same knife can be used for cutting raw and cooked meat.
questions.description: Heated food must be protected from contamination after being heated. Ingredients and the equipment used to handle those ingredients must be kept separate from cooked products to prevent cross-contamination.

questions.question: Cleaning plans include accurate instructions about how and when cleaning is done.
questions.description: A cleaning plan is an essential part of an own-check plan. Cleaning plans include more accurate instructions on the cleaning of all parts of a food production area.

questions.question: Cooked and uncooked products should always be handled on different working surfaces and with different equipment.
questions.description: Microbes will spread to cooked products if they are handled with the same equipment or on the same surfaces as raw products.

questions.question: Campylo bacteria is naturally found in fowl and poultry.
questions.description: Campylo bacteria and salmonella are found naturally in fowl and poultry. Both bacteria are destroyed when the meat is cooked thoroughly to over 75 degrees Celsius.

questions.question: Health inspectors can not inspect restaurant kitchens.
questions.description: The work of health inspectors requires making inspections in food production areas such as food stores and restaurants.

questions.question: Guide dogs are not allowed inside food product stores.
questions.description: Guide dogs are always allowed in areas meant for customers. However, no animals can be taken inside food product handling areas or storage areas.

questions.question: Frozen food products are stored in a freezer at a temperature of -15°C or colder.
questions.description: The temperature in a freezer must be -18°C or colder.

questions.question: Easily perishable food products do not require a storage instruction label if it is a commonly known product.
questions.description: Packages of easily perishable food products always require a label indicating the last day of use and storing instructions. The shown date is valid only for unopened products that have been stored in the right temperature.

questions.question: In commercial kitchens, it is necessary to nominate the people in charge of the own-check plan.
questions.description: Designated persons who have been trained for the task are responsible for the various areas of the own-check plan.

questions.question: HACCP is a food poisoning causing bacteria.
questions.description: HACCP stands for Hazard Analysis and Critical Control Points, which is a part of own-check plans. When working with an own-check plan these critical points must be identified and constantly monitored carefully.

questions.question: Salmonella bacteria can not be found in fowl or poultry.
questions.description: Salmonella can be found in fowl or poultry. Due to the risk of salmonella, the meat of fowl/poultry must always be cooked to at least 75 degrees Celsius.

questions.question: Salmonella can only get transmitted through feces.
questions.description: Salmonella can get transmitted through feces by way of poor hand hygiene but also via contaminated food products, such as raw meat and eggs.

questions.question: Waste disposal is an essential part of hygienic working in a professional kitchen.
questions.description: Appropriate waste bins and their regular emptying and cleaning, as well as the appropriate assortment and storage areas for waste that is going to be transported away, are all a part of good hygienic working. A professional kitchen's waste disposal is based on waste laws as well as regional waste disposal directives.

questions.question: Food products can be sold after the last use-by-date if it is sold at a discount price.
questions.description: The last use-by-date must be marked on easily perishable food products. The products can not be used nor sold after this date.

questions.question: Dirt and dust can make microbes spread to food products.
questions.description: Different kinds of impurities, such as dirt and dust, contain microbes. If dirt or dust gets onto a food product then the microbes contained will also spread onto the product.

questions.question: Pet dogs can be taken inside a café with the permission of the owner of the café.
questions.description: If the owner gives permission, a pet dog can be taken inside the customer areas of a café.

questions.question: Food production areas do not produce hazardous waste which would require special attention.
questions.description: Cleaning and washing substances as well as their packaging, and for example fluorescent lamps, are hazardous waste and must be recycled appropriately.

questions.question: Kitchens in hospitals should have separate spaces for different work phases such as the treatment of root vegetables, baking and dishwashing.
questions.description: When each work phase is done in its own separate area the work is hygienic and the risk of cross-contamination is smaller.

questions.question: Some toxins produced by moulds in food will withstand heating and cause food poisoning even though the mould itself can get destroyed.
questions.description: Mould toxins can withstand much higher temperatures than the mould itself.

questions.question: Packages for non-easily perishable food products must have a label indicating their best-before date.
questions.description: Packaging labels for non-easily perishable food products show the best-before date. The accuracy of the date is determined by the product's shelf life. The product may be used after the date if its sensory qualities, such as smell, taste and look are impeccable.

questions.question: Pasteurizing destroys all bacteria from a food product.
questions.description: During pasteurization the food product is heated to +degrees celsius. This temperature destroys a large percentage of microbes, but the product still requires cold storage. For example pasteurized milk must be kept at a temperature of +6 degrees or less.

questions.question: Due to salmonella risks, fowl and poultry meat must always be heated thoroughly to over 75 degrees Celsius.
questions.description: Fowl/poultry can contain salmonella naturally. Salmonella bacteria must be alive to cause an illness. The meat of fowl/poultry is safe if it is heated thoroughly to over 75 degrees Celsius.

questions.question: Chefs do not require a hygiene proficiency passport if their employment is not permanent.
questions.description: Chefs handle easily perishable food products in their work. This means that chefs must pass a hygiene proficiency test at least 3 months after starting their work.

questions.question: Handling money can transfer harmful microbes into food products.
questions.description: Money and easily perishable unpackaged food products should not be handled simultanously, as money can have microbes in it that jeopardize food hygiene.

questions.question: All E-numbered additives improve the lastingness of food products.
questions.description: Food products can be made to last longer by adding preservatives to them. In the European Union, allowed preservatives have an E-number: for example, E 200 is sorbic acid and E 296 is malic acid. Preservatives that are allowed can be found, along with other additives, in an E-number list. Some preservatives can be found naturally in berries and fruits, such as in lingonberries and citrus fruit. E-numbers are also used to identify additives other than ones that improve lastingness. For example, color additives do not improve the lastingness of food products.

questions.question: The slow cooling of food is one of the main causes of food poisoning.
questions.description: The slower food is cooled to under 8 degrees Celsius, the longer food poisoning causing microbes have time to reproduce quickly in optimal conditions. Food should be cooled to under 8 degrees in under 4 hours. When preparing large amounts of food at the same time, the cooling can take too long.

questions.question: Disinfectants should be changed regularly.
questions.description: Microbes can become immune to specific disinfectants, and so the disinfectants should be changed from time to time.

questions.question: Trichinella spiralis is a parasite of salmon.
questions.description: Trichinella spiralis is found in the non-inspected meat of pigs, boar, horses and bears.

questions.question: HACCP is not a food poisoning causing bacteria.
questions.description: HACCP stands for Hazard Analysis and Critical Control Points, which is a part of own-check plans. When working with an own-check plan these critical points must be identified and constantly monitored carefully.

questions.question: Food production areas' waste bins must be cleaned regularly.
questions.description: The cleanliness and hygiene of waste bins must be taken care of regularly. Waste bins in kitchens should be cleaned always after they are emptied.

questions.question: Frozen products can be thawed in room temperature to make the thawing fast enough.
questions.description: If food products are thawed in room temperature, the products' surfaces will melt quicker than the insides. The surfaces will start to spoil even though the insides can still be frozen.

questions.question: Pet animals can carry food poisoning causing parasites and protozoa.
questions.description: Pet animals can carry different disease causers in their fur, paws and feces. Pet animals can not be allowed inside food preparation areas. Pet animals are allowed in dining areas if the merchant allows it.

questions.question: Every employee shares in the responsibility of carrying out the own-check plan.
questions.description: Sharing responsibility is an essential part of a own-check plan. Every task of the plan requires a person who is in charge of that particular task, logs measurements and verifies them with his or her signture. Own-check plans also require continuing staff training and familiarization with relevant tasks.

questions.question: A cleaning equipment storage room must be included in a food production area.
questions.description: It's not always necessary to have a separate storage space for cleaning equipment. Food production areas need a separate storage, maintenance and drying space if the food production area requires it for constructional reasons. It's important to make sure that there are no risks for food safety and the hygienic treatment, maintenance and storage of cleaning equipment are done properly. If necessary the working stages and functions has to be separated structually or timely.

questions.question: Earth does not contain food poisoning causing bacteria.
questions.description: Earth can contain e.g. bacillus cereus or clostridum bacteria. Both of these are common causers of food poisoning.

questions.question: Bacterial spores are more resistant than bacteria.
questions.description: When bacteria are in an environment where they cannot grow as easily, they turn into spores. Spores are more resistant than bacteria to heat and drought, for example.

questions.question: The own-check plan only refers to measuring and recording temperatures.
questions.description: The purpose of the own-check plan is to help operators to manage the risks associated with food hygiene. Measuring and recording temperatures is an important part of the own-check system. Other areas of the own-check system include cleaning and tidiness as well as hygienic skills of the staff.

questions.question: Intestinal bacteria can spread from hands to food.
questions.description: Intestinal bacteria can spread to food even from the hands.

questions.question: Bacteria toxins disappear when food is boiled.
questions.description: Some bacteria cause toxins in the food. If toxins have appeared in the food, they weill not disappear during boiling.

questions.question: The purpose of the own-check plan is to make sure that operators manage the risks associated with food hygiene in their operations.
questions.description: Drawing up and following an own-check plan helps operators to manage the risks associated with food hygiene.

questions.question: Rings and other hand jewellery as well as watches must be removed when working with easily perishable food products.
questions.description: Jewellery and watches are not part of a food product employee's work uniform. Microbes, dirt and chemicals can easily stay underneath them even after washing one's hands, and these can later spread while working. Earrings and piercings on one's face can also be a hazard to hygienic working.

questions.question: Food poisoning is always caused by some kind of bacteria or virus.
questions.description: Food poisoning can also be caused by parasites, protozoa, natural toxins (such as in morel mushrooms), poisonous plants or animals, chemicals or some other disease-causing particle.

questions.question: Restaurants must have an own-check plan.
questions.description: All workplaces in the food industry need to ensure the safety of their products with an own-check plan. Own-check plans are required in all food industry workplaces.

questions.question: Food packaging materials can be stored on a clean floor.
questions.description: Food packaging materials must never be stored directly on the floor but they must be placed on clean racks or other hygienic surfaces.

questions.question: Salmonella bacteria that can be contained in milk products or eggs can be destroyed by pasteurization.
questions.description: Pasteurizing milk, meaning heating to 72 degrees Celsius for 15 seconds, destroys salmonella bacteria. Pasteurization can also be used to treat industrially used batches made from eggs.

questions.question: Microbes can not reproduce in food products that are in a protective gas package.
questions.description: Protective gas packages contain little or no oxygen. This prevents microbes that require oxygen from growing. However, the product can also contain microbes that do not need oxygen.

questions.question: Dirty root vegetables can be stored in cardboard boxes above meat products on cold room shelves.
questions.description: Dirt always contains many microbes. Dirty root vegetables must be handled separately from other products so that the microbes in the dirt do not spread to other food products.

questions.question: Large central kitchens and small cafés have the same own-check plan.
questions.description: All workplaces must design their own own-check plan that suits their activities. The acitivities, products and customers are different in small cafés and large kitchens. The own-check plans of large kitchens must be more precise and also more broad.

questions.question: When frozen vegetables are thawed at room temperature, the number of harmful microbes in them increases rapidly.
questions.description: When food products are thawed at room temperature, the risk of microbial growth on the surface of the product increases even before the inner part is thawed.

questions.question: Dirty root vegetables and pre-made food products can not be stored in the same cold room.
questions.description: Dirt always contains many microbes. Dirty root vegetables must be handled separately from other products so that the microbes in the dirt do not spread to other food products.

questions.question: Transported products and cargo being received do not have to be checked.
questions.description: The quality of arriving products must be checked and the temperatures of easily perishable products must be measured. The results must be written down.

questions.question: Microbes reproduce the fastest in their own optimal temperatures.
questions.description: All microbes have their own optimal temperatures where reproduction is the fastest. In the insides of humans and animals, the temperature range between 20 and 45 degrees Celsius is the best for microbes. Anything hotter or colder than this causes microbes to reproduce slower.

questions.question: The toxins contained in fresh morel mushrooms can not be removed by only roasting the mushrooms.
questions.description: Morel mushrooms must be boiled twice for at least 5 minutes and washed thoroughly between the boilings.

questions.question: If there are any problems in temperature or sensory quality of delivered food products, a spoken report to one's supervisor is sufficient.
questions.description: Mistakes or abnormalities in temperature or sensory quality of delivered easily perishable products must always be logged in the own-check plan forms.

questions.question: If upon delivery there are any problems in regards to the transportation temperature of easily perishable food products, one should report it to Finnish Food Safety Authority.
questions.description: If there are any problems with the quality of delivered products, they should be returned to the supplier and reported to the driver.

questions.question: A food product can only be a health hazard if it has a contaminated area that is visible to the naked eye.
questions.description: Growth on the surfaces of food products caused by moulds and yeasts are visible to the naked eye, but microbes are usually microorganisms that are not visible to the naked eye.

questions.question: Bacteria toxins can require boiling for 5 hours before they disappear from food.
questions.description: If toxins have appeared in the food, they can cause food poisoning. Only a very long boiling time will get rid of the toxins.

questions.question: Microbes are destroyed when meat is minced.
questions.description: When meat is minced, the bacteria on its surface spread throughout the minced meat.

questions.question: Food products can not be sold nor used after the last use-by-date.
questions.description: The last use-by-date must be marked on easily perishable food products. The marking must be based upon research results of lastingness.

questions.question: Cleaning equipment must be cleaned once a week.
questions.description: Cleaning equipment must be cleaned after each use and must then be left to dry.

questions.question: The use of snus (similar to chewing tobacco) is not allowed during food preparation.
questions.description: When handling food products personal hygiene is important; snus must not be used because of hygienic reasons.

questions.question: The placement of biowaste bins outside a restaurant does not matter as long as they are not close to an entrance.
questions.description: A waste room's  or recycling area's biowaste bins must be covered from the sun and placed such that pests do not get to them.

questions.question: If there are any problems in temperature or sensory quality of delivered food products, a spoken report to one's supervisor is sufficient.
questions.description: Mistakes or abnormalities in temperature or sensory quality of delivered easily perishable products must always be logged in the own-check plan forms.

questions.question: A meat mincer is washed every week.
questions.description: A meat mincer must always be checked for cleanliness before it is used. A meat mincer is washed after every use. The appliance is disassembled and washed with an appropriate cleaning agent.

questions.question: Fresh fish is an easily perishable food product.
questions.description: Fresh fish is a very easily perishable food product. Fresh fish products must be stored at the temperature of melting ice, max 2 degrees Celsius.

questions.question: You can wear disposable gloves instead of washing your hands when preparing food in a restaurant tent.
questions.description: Washing your hands thoroughly and often enough is the basis for safe food handling and general hygiene, and it is important to also wear disposable gloves, for example.

questions.question: Products in protective gas packages contain microbes.
questions.description: Products in protective gas packages always contain some microbes. The protective gas is used to prevent microbes that require oxygen from growing.

questions.question: The contents of a bulged can of food can be used for food preparation if the product is properly heated.
questions.description: All causes of food poisoning are not eliminated by heating. The contents of a bulged (ie. faulty) can of food must be discarded.

questions.question: Chefs can use their work shoes during their travel to and from their workplace.
questions.description: Work shoes must not be worn outside the workplace to prevent microbes from spreading into the food production area.

questions.question: A cheese roll packed in a tight plastic wrap is protected from microbes.
questions.description: A cheese roll is a perishable food product that is stored and served cold. In addition to being wrapped in plastic film, make sure that it is kept in the correct storage and serving temperatures.

questions.question: All work phases, such as dishwashing, baking and treatment of root vegetables, can be done in the same area in hospital kitchens.
questions.description: When each work phase is done in its own separate area the work is hygienic and the risk of cross-contamination is smaller.

questions.question: Salmonella infections always cause severe symptoms. In other words it is impossible for the person carrying the salmonella to not know about it.
questions.description: It is possible for salmonella infections to not be noticed. One might not notice the infection at all, but can still spread the salmonella to others. In practice salmonella can only be spread if one's hands are not washed well after going to the toilet.

questions.question: Own-check plans are meant for the leadership of food industry companies.
questions.description: Own-check plans include lots of instructions and lists responsibilities. Because of this it is important that all employees get to know the own-check plan and adhere to it while working.

questions.question: The slow cooling of food is one of the main causes of food poisoning.
questions.description: The slower food is cooled to under 8 degrees Celsius, the longer food poisoning causing microbes have time to reproduce quickly in optimal conditions. Food should be cooled to under 8 degrees in under 4 hours. When preparing large amounts of food at the same time, the cooling can take too long.

questions.question: Marinating prevents meat from spoiling.
questions.description: Meat can contain harmful microbes even if it is marinated.

questions.question: The most hygienic way to dry your hands is to use a cloth towel.
questions.description: The most hygienic way to dry your hands is to use disposable hand towels.

questions.question: EHEC bacteria are intestinal bacteria.
questions.description: EHEC bacteria is found especially in the intestines of cattle. EHEC bacteria create toxins in the intestines of humans. The toxin often causes bloody diarrhea and very uncomfortable stomache pains.

questions.question: Cleaning equipment must be cleaned always after being used.
questions.description: Dirty and wet cleaning equipment contain lots of microbes. The results of cleaning with this equipment are not good.

questions.question: Salmonella bacteria can be found in fowl or poultry.
questions.description: Salmonella can be found in fowl or poultry. Due to the risk of salmonella, the meat of fowl/poultry must always be cooked to at least 75 degrees Celsius.

questions.question: BSE, also called mad cow's disease, is not a food poisoning causing bacteria.
questions.description: BSE is caused by changes in the central nervous system of cows. Humans can get the disease only by eating meat that is contaminated with BSE.

questions.question: If an easily perishable food product has been stored in too warm conditions, the product can still be stored until the use-by-date.
questions.description: The use-by-date is reliable only if the product has been stored correctly. Storing products in too warm conditions always makes the products last for shorter periods of times.

questions.question: Bear meat must be checked for trichinella spiralis.
questions.description: Bear meat can contain trichinella spiralis. All carcasses that are going to be sold must be checked for trichinella spiralis. Proper heating will destroy the parasite.

questions.question: The maximum storage temperature for cooked shellfish is +6°C.
questions.description: Cooked molluscs and shellfish are stored at the temperature of melting ice (maximum +2°C).

questions.question: Unpacked raw fish must always be stored separate from other food products.
questions.description: Raw fish must be stored separately from other food products to prevent the risk of cross-contamination.

questions.question: During food preparation one can sometimes go wash one's hands in the staff restroom.
questions.description: There must be a separate hand washing spot in immediate proximity to the food preparation area.

questions.question: Boxes meant for transporting food can be stored outside if there is no space indoors.
questions.description: Food transportation boxes must be stored in an area where they do not get dirty. Restaurant and transportation companies agree on the frequency of collection and cleaning of boxes and trolleys.

questions.question: A food poisoning epidemic is a situation where at least 10 people have become sick with similar symptoms after consuming the same food product or ingredient.
questions.description: A food poisoning epidemic means a situation where at least 2 people have become sick with similar symptoms after consuming the same food or drink.

questions.question: There is no need to measure the temperature in the freezer because the food products are frozen.
questions.description: Regular monitoring of the freezer temperature is an important part of the own-check plan. The most important aspect of storage management is the regular monitoring and recording of storage room temperatures. Freezers must have a thermometer and a system for recording temperatures regularly.

questions.question: Guide dogs are not allowed inside food product stores.
questions.description: Guide dogs are always allowed in areas meant for customers. However, no animals can be taken inside food product handling areas or storage areas.

questions.question: The temperature checks for received food products that need hot or cold storage are part of the own-check plan.
questions.description: Temperature monitoring of hot or cold storage food products when receiving is an important part of the own-check plan. If the temperatures do not meet set requirements they can be returned to the supplier as faulty products.

questions.question: Clostridium perfringens is a bacteria that is often found in earth.
questions.description: Earth contains many microbes, some of which cause food poisoning. To prevent clostridium perfringens food poisonings it is important to properly heat and cool the food and not store it in the dangerous temperature zone of 6 to 60 degrees Celsius.

questions.question: Oiva is a system which helps people to self-assess the food product safety of their workplace.
questions.description: Municipality food control authorities make Oiva-reports about the workplaces they inspect. It is not a part of the workplace's self-assessment.

questions.question: If upon delivery there are any problems in regards to the transportation temperature of easily perishable food products, one should report it to Finnish Food Safety Authority.
questions.description: If there are any problems with the quality of delivered products, they should be returned to the supplier and reported to the driver.

questions.question: If you detect deviations from the limit values, you must take the measurement again the next day.
questions.description: When the limit determined in the own-check plan is exceeded you must record the result, take the relevant corrective measures and record them and then record the new results.

questions.question: Vacuum-packed meat is deaerated and hermetically sealed.
questions.description: A vacuum pack does not contain any air and prevents the growth of microbes that need oxygen.

questions.question: Lactic acid bacteria often cause food poisoning.
questions.description: Lactic acid bacteria do not cause food poisoning. Lactic acid bacteria are not harmful if used in the treatment of food poisoning, but they have not been scientifically proven to be of any use either.

questions.question: Clostridium perfringens is a bacteria that is often found in earth.
questions.description: Earth contains many microbes, some of which cause food poisoning. To prevent clostridium perfringens food poisonings it is important to properly heat and cool the food and not store it in the dangerous temperature zone of 6 to 60 degrees Celsius.

questions.question: The cleanliness of waste rooms is not essential for hygiene because only waste is stored in those rooms.
questions.description: The cleanliness and hygiene of waste rooms is an essential part of taking care of food product hygiene because employees enter the waste room during the work day while wearing their work clothes, which they wear everywhere else as well. Waste rooms must be kept clean and organised.

questions.question: Single-use gloves are used to protect the food preparer from microbes on the food products.
questions.description: The first priority of using single-use gloves is to protect the food products from microbes on the hands.

questions.question: Raw and cooked produce should not be handled at the same time or with the same utensils.
questions.description: Raw and cooked produce should be stored and handled separately. Surfaces should be properly cleaned in between handling raw and cooked produce. Unhygienic cleaning equipment can also contaminate the kitchen surfaces and cause microbes to spread. This type of spreading of microbes is called cross contamination.

questions.question: Guide dogs are allowed inside food product stores.
questions.description: Guide dogs are always allowed in areas meant for customers. However, no animals can be taken inside food product handling areas or storage areas.

questions.question: Food served in a lunch buffet must remain at +60 degrees celsius for the entire duration of the serving.
questions.description: If food that has been prepared by heating or cooking is not served immediately, it must be kept at a temperature of at least 60 degrees throughout the entire serving.

questions.question: Blue cheese doesn't contain living mould.
questions.description: Clean, controlled and living moulds are used when producing blue cheese. The moulds create various taste ingredients in the cheese. The ready cheese still contain these living moulds.

questions.question: During food preparation one can sometimes go wash one's hands in the staff restroom.
questions.description: There must be a separate hand washing spot in immediate proximity to the food preparation area.

questions.question: If an easily perishable food product has been stored in too warm conditions, the product can still be stored until the use-by-date.
questions.description: The use-by-date is reliable only if the product has been stored correctly. Storing products in too warm conditions always makes the products last for shorter periods of times.

questions.question: Packages for non-easily perishable food products must have a label indicating their best-before date.
questions.description: Packaging labels for non-easily perishable food products show the best-before date. The accuracy of the date is determined by the product's shelf life. The product may be used after the date if its sensory qualities, such as smell, taste and look are impeccable.

questions.question: Spices cannot cause food poisoning.
questions.description: In some cases spices, too, can cause a risk of food poisoning, and therefore they must be used and stored hygienically and with care just like other food products.

questions.question: If a food premises changes owners, this must always be reported to the local food authority.
questions.description: When a food premises changes owners, this must always be reported to the local food authority.

questions.question: Health inspectors can not inspect a workplace's own-check plan's monitoring logs.
questions.description: Health inspectors make routine inspections in food production areas. The monitoring logs of the own-check plans are also part of the inspections. The logs must be stored for 1 year in the workplace. Only stored logs can prove that the workplace has followed its own-check plan accordingly.

questions.question: When receiving products one must make sure that they are moved into their appropriate, separate storage areas as soon as possible after the receival check.
questions.description: Products should be moved into their own storage areas as soon as possible after the receival check. Easily perishable food products can not be stored in room temperature for longer than 10-15 minutes.

questions.question: The purity of the air in the food packaging area has no effect on the shelf life of food products.
questions.description: Food products are packed in an area with clean air, as it affects their shelf life.

questions.question: All easily perishable food products must be stored in temperatures under 6 degrees Celsius.
questions.description: This statement is correct, but one must notice that raw mince meat requires a storing temperature of at most 4 degrees Celsius, and fish and shellfish even while vacuum-packed must be stored between 0 and 3 degrees Celsius.

questions.question: Dirty root vegetables can be handled in the same area where desserts are produced.
questions.description: Dirt always contains many microbes. Dirty root vegetables must be handled separately from other products so that the microbes in the dirt do not spread to other food products.

questions.question: Microbes can not reproduce in dry products.
questions.description: Microbes need water to reproduce. Microbes will not reproduce in dried products but dried products can contain spores of bacteria, moulds or yeast.

questions.question: Products that have gone through ultra-high-temperature treatment (UHT) can not be stored in room temperature.
questions.description: During UHT products are sterilized with quick heating. Unopened packages can be stored in room temperature because most bacteria spores have been destroyed.

questions.question: Food products stored in protective gas do not have to be stored in the cold.
questions.description: Protective gas protects a food product's surface from drying up and enzymic darkening, but the products must still be stored in the cold just like similar products with no protective gas.

questions.question: Bacteria reproduce very quickly in acidized products.
questions.description: Bacteria that are a threat to food product hygiene reproduce the best when in the neutral zone. Bacteria growth especially can be prevented by increasing the acidity of a product.

questions.question: Ice cubes cannot contain harmful microbes, because their temperature is so low.
questions.description: Ice cubes can contain harmful microbes if the ice cube machine or the ice cube container hasn't been properly cleaned. The water used for producing the ice cubes has to meet the standards for clean drinking water.

questions.question: Food that is being served while cold must have its temperature measured and marked down.
questions.description: Temperature measurements of food that is being served are a part of own-check plans. The results of the measurements must be mark down in the monitoring logs of the own-check plans and then stored at the workplace for 1 year.

questions.question: Microbes can not reproduce in food products that are in a protective gas package.
questions.description: Protective gas packages contain little or no oxygen. This prevents microbes that require oxygen from growing. However, the product can also contain microbes that do not need oxygen.

questions.question: Mould toxins are destroyed when food products are boiled.
questions.description: Mould toxins can not be destroyed by only boiling them.

questions.question: Any water can be used for washing potatoes as they have soil on them.
questions.description: Potatoes must always be washed with water that meets the requirements for domestic water.

questions.question: Ripened cheese is prepared by using beneficial microbes.
questions.description: Ripened cheese is prepared by using extensively studied and monitored microbe populations. They help to make the cheese last longer and also affect its composition and taste.

questions.question: Hands must be washed after sneezing and blowing one's nose.
questions.description: Microbes spread onto the hands when sneezing and blowing one's nose. If the hands are not washed, these bacteria will easily spread onto food products.

questions.question: Mashed potato is not an easily perishable food product.
questions.description: Pre-made foods are easily perishable products. Easily perishable foods must be stored in the cold, under 6 degrees Celsius.

questions.question: Chefs are allowed to handle money and prepare food without washing their hands in between.
questions.description: Notes and coins contain a lot of microbes, and you must always wash your hands after handling money before you start cooking.

questions.question: HACCP is a food poisoning causing bacteria.
questions.description: HACCP stands for Hazard Analysis and Critical Control Points, which is a part of own-check plans. When working with an own-check plan these critical points must be identified and constantly monitored carefully.
