questions.question: All plastic containers are suitable for storing food.
questions.description: Materials that come into contact with food must be meant for food use.

questions.question: A microbiological sample of a food product can be placed in any container.
questions.description: A microbiological sample of a food product must always be placed in a container that is definitely clean.

questions.question: When raw frozen chicken is thawed it releases liquid that can contain salmonella.
questions.description: Raw fowl/poultry meat can always contain salmonella, which will not be destroyed in a freezer. If the meat contains salmonella it will also certainly be in the liquid.

questions.question: Contamination means e.g. unwanted microbes and/or chemicals spreading into a product.
questions.description: Contamination can be microbiological, chemical or physical. It is unwanted and can cause perishing of food products or food poisoning.

questions.question: Cold fish products (e.g. salmon) in vacuum-packages has sometimes been found to contain listeria.
questions.description: Cold fish products in vacuum-packages have a risk to cause listeriosis because the fish has not been heated and the storing time is long.

questions.question: Own-check plans must include clear instructions on how to act when food poisoning suspicions are raised.
questions.description: When food is prepared for customers, food poisoning events must be planned for in advance. Own-check plans must include clear instructions for these events. It is important to notify health inspectors about suspicions immediately.

questions.question: Food production employees are allowed to wear their work outfit when going outside of the food production area during e.g. their lunch break.
questions.description: The work outfit can only be worn inside the food production area; this prevents microbes from spreading into the area from the clothes.

questions.question: Taking samples from prepared food products is a part of the own-check plan.
questions.description: Samples must be taken of served food products for example from lunch servings so that they can be stored for possible food poisoning cases.

questions.question: EHEC bacteria are intestinal bacteria of cattle.
questions.description: This intestinal bacteria can only found in food products if the work hygiene is not proper during milking or slaughtering.

questions.question: Pasteurizing and ultra-high-temperature processing (UHT) mean the same thing.
questions.description: Ultra-high-temperature processing is done in much higher temperatures than pasteurizing. UHT destroys most bacteria spores and because of this products that have been treated with UHT can be stored in room temperature.

questions.question: Bacteria toxins can require boiling for 5 hours before they disappear from food.
questions.description: If toxins have appeared in the food, they can cause food poisoning. Only a very long boiling time will get rid of the toxins.

questions.question: When a new detergent is introduced into a kitchen, the cleaning plan in the own-check plan is updated.
questions.description: It is important that the own-check plan is always up to date. All changes to the own-check plan, e.g. introduction of a new detergent, must be updated in the cleaning plan.

questions.question: The creation and following requirements of own-check plans include all companies that handle food products.
questions.description: The creation and use of an own-check plan is a requirement by law, which has included all companies handling food products since 1995. All employees in a company are responsible for the implementation of own-check plans.

questions.question: The sampling plan is not part of the own-check plan.
questions.description: The sampling plan is an important part of own-check operations.

questions.question: Cooling cabinets are used only for cooling food.
questions.description: Food should be cooled to less than 6 degrees Celsius within only 4 hours. When the products have been cooled they should be moved into another cold storage unit. Cooling cabinets are only used for cooling food (not storing.)

questions.question: Microbes can not reproduce in food products that are in a protective gas package.
questions.description: Protective gas packages contain little or no oxygen. This prevents microbes that require oxygen from growing. However, the product can also contain microbes that do not need oxygen.

questions.question: Ultra-high-temperature processing (UHT) uses higher temperatures than pasteurizing.
questions.description: Ultra-high-temperature processing is done in much higher temperatures than pasteurizing. UHT destroys most bacteria spores and because of this products that have been treated with UHT can be stored in room temperature.

questions.question: When preparing a own-check plan, all essential food product risk monitoring must be explained.
questions.description: It is essential for the plan to think which parts of done activities are ones where microbes can reproduce and how risks will be monitored, as well as what actions must be taken to fix risk situations.

questions.question: Tapeworms can be found in the roe (eggs) and muscles of some lake fish.
questions.description: Tapeworms can be found in the roe (eggs) and muscles of lake fish, such as bass, pike, burbot and ruffe. Proper cooking or freezing (2 days minimum) will destroy the tapeworm.

questions.question: Jewellery and watches must be removed from one's hands before washing hands.
questions.description: Jewellery and watches must always be removed before washing. They must also not be used while preparing food because they collect microbes which may travel into the prepared food and cause food poisoning risks.

questions.question: When frozen vegetables are thawed at room temperature, the number of harmful microbes in them increases rapidly.
questions.description: When food products are thawed at room temperature, the risk of microbial growth on the surface of the product increases even before the inner part is thawed.

questions.question: Frozen foods can be defrosted on a kitchen table if the liquid from the melting does not pour onto the table.
questions.description: All frozen foods must be defrosted in cold storage units. When defrosting, one must make sure that the defrosting product does not pour liquid onto any other food products placed or stored in the cold storage unit. Defrosted or just partially defrosted products can not be frozen again.

questions.question: Food products can be used safely after the use-by date if they do not look or smell bad.
questions.description: Perished or contaminated products are not always possible to notice just by using the senses (visually etc.) Easily perishable food products' packages have a use-by date marked on them, and after this date has passed the product must not be used or sold.

questions.question: A best-before-date must be marked on easily perishable products.
questions.description: Easily perishable products must have a use-by-date.

questions.question: It is important to visually monitor cleanliness on a daily basis in addition to regular cleaning.
questions.description: Everyone working in a food premises must constantly monitor its cleanliness.

questions.question: Kitchens in hospitals should have separate spaces for different work phases such as the treatment of root vegetables, baking and dishwashing.
questions.description: When each work phase is done in its own separate area the work is hygienic and the risk of cross-contamination is smaller.

questions.question: Bacteria reproduce very quickly in products that have high acidity.
questions.description: Bacteria that are a threat to food product safety reproduce the best in the neutral zone. Because of this the growth of these bacteria can be prevented by increasing the acidity of a product.

questions.question: Cooling cabinets may also be used for storing food.
questions.description: Food should be cooled to less than 6 degrees Celsius within only 4 hours. When the products have been cooled they should be moved into another cold storage unit. Cooling cabinets are only used for cooling food (not storing.)

questions.question: Hepatitis A is never spread in food products.
questions.description: The most important viruses that reproduce in the intestines of humans are the norovirus and hepatitis A. Both viruses last for a long time and are able to spread in the cold and even in frozen foods.

questions.question: After washing one's hands the tap must be closed using a hand towel, otherwise the hands can become dirty again.
questions.description: After washing the hands they must be dried using a single-use hand towel and the tap must be closed using the towel. This way any possible microbes on the tap do not spread onto the clean hands.

questions.question: You can touch the inside surfaces of food packaging if you have just washed your hands.
questions.description: You should always try not to touch the inside surfaces of food packaging.

questions.question: Any mould can be used in the production of mould-ripened cheese.
questions.description: Only certain moulds are suitable for making mould-ripened cheeses.

questions.question: Taking samples from prepared food products is a part of the own-check plan.
questions.description: Samples must be taken of served food products for example from lunch servings so that they can be stored for possible food poisoning cases.

questions.question: A restaurant can use food products after their best before date has expired provided that the products are sufficiently well heated well.
questions.description: It is prohibited to sell or use food products after their best before date has expired, and they must not be used in the manufacture of food to be sold or served.

questions.question: Frozen products can be thawed in room temperature to make the thawing fast enough.
questions.description: If food products are thawed in room temperature, the products' surfaces will melt quicker than the insides. The surfaces will start to spoil even though the insides can still be frozen.

questions.question: All microbes are harmful to humans.
questions.description: Many food products also have in them naturally beneficial microbes, and with many food manufacturing processes microbes have an essential role, like for example making beer and fermented vegetables.

questions.question: Own-check plans must not be changed.
questions.description: Own-check plans must be updated when changes happen in the workplace.

questions.question: Chicken eggs never contain salmonella.
questions.description: Chicken eggs can contain salmonella, although the risk is small in Finland.

questions.question: Food products containing preservatives never spoil.
questions.description: Preservatives only slow down the spoiling done by microbes.

questions.question: When outside temperatures are very cold, food products can be cooled quickly outside.
questions.description: Food products must not be cooled or stored outside. All equipment and products, e.g. boxes containg baked goods, must be stored inside.

questions.question: Appropriate freezing improves the lastingness of a product.
questions.description: Freezing prevents microbe reproduction because frozen water can not be used by microbes for reproduction. Frozen products have recommended storing times, and freezing never improves the microbiological quality of a product. Frozen products should be defrosted slowly in a cold storage unit when they are going to be used. A product that has been defrosted once can not be frozen again.

questions.question: Temperature affects the speed of microbe reproduction.
questions.description: Temperatures are very important for the reproduction abilities of microbes. All microbes have their own optimal temperatures where reproduction is the fastest.

questions.question: It is not required to change single-use gloves worn on the hands if money is handled while wearing them.
questions.description: Only one phase of work can be done while wearing the same single-use gloves. If money is handled then the hands must be washed and the gloves must be changed.

questions.question: A working and up-to-date collection of recipes is part of the own-check plan.
questions.description: Regularly served food needs to have up-to-date recipes. Recipes can be used to check what different foods contain and how they are prepared during any problematic situations.

questions.question: All work phases, such as dishwashing, baking and treatment of root vegetables, can be done in the same area in hospital kitchens.
questions.description: When each work phase is done in its own separate area the work is hygienic and the risk of cross-contamination is smaller.

questions.question: If a product or ingredient is suspected to be the cause of food poisoning in a customer, the product or ingredient should be gotten rid of as soon as possible.
questions.description: Suspected causes of food poisoning must not be gotten rid of but must instead be stored so that it can be examined in a laboratory to find the cause of the poisoning.

questions.question: All cold storage units in food production areas must contain a thermometer.
questions.description: The monitoring and logging of temperatures is an important part of the . Thermometers are a vital tool for this and must be used.

questions.question: Pet dogs can be taken inside a café with the permission of the owner of the café.
questions.description: If the owner gives permission, a pet dog can be taken inside the customer areas of a café.

questions.question: Received food products must be stored where there is the most space for them in the storage facility.
questions.description: Received food products are stored based on the FIFO method (First In, First Out) which means that products already stored in the storage facility are moved to the front to be used or taken first, and any new products are placed behind or after any prior ones. This way the products are taken out of storage in the order they arrived in and the amount of wastage is reduced.

questions.question: Cooling cabinets are used only for cooling food.
questions.description: Food should be cooled to less than 6 degrees Celsius within only 4 hours. When the products have been cooled they should be moved into another cold storage unit. Cooling cabinets are only used for cooling food (not storing.)

questions.question: Kitchens in hospitals should have separate spaces for different work phases such as the treatment of root vegetables, baking and dishwashing.
questions.description: When each work phase is done in its own separate area the work is hygienic and the risk of cross-contamination is smaller.

questions.question: One of the reasons for the existence of own-check plans is to make the work of food product industry companies easier.
questions.description: Own-check plans that are done well make it easier for companies to upkeep food product safety because resources used for monitoring can be focused on things essential for company activities. Knowledge of the quality of the activities will also improve when the activities are planned. In the best case customer satisfaction, profitability and officials' trust will improve.

questions.question: Bacteria in our environment can not be seen with the bare eye.
questions.description: Single bacteria can not be seen without using a microscope.

questions.question: Washing machines do not need to be washed separately, because the washing temperatures are hot enough to destroy harmful microbes.
questions.description: Washing machines, as well as their dust filters and other removable parts, must be washed and dried regularly. The surfaces of the machines must also be swiped and the lids left open so that the machine's inside dries.

questions.question: Temperature does not affect the speed of microbe reproduction.
questions.description: Temperatures are very important for the reproduction abilities of microbes. All microbes have their own optimal temperatures where reproduction is the fastest.

questions.question: Food poisoning microbes can only spread through the air.
questions.description: Food poisoning microbes can be transmitted into food in many ways such as via hands, soil, contaminated water or airborne dust particles. Rodents, insects and birds can also spread food poisoning microbes.

questions.question: Own-check plans do not need to include clear instructions on how to act when food poisoning suspicions are raised.
questions.description: When food is prepared for customers, food poisoning events must be planned for in advance. Own-check plans must include clear instructions for these events. It is important to notify health inspectors about suspicions immediately.

questions.question: Dirty root vegetables and pre-made food products can not be stored in the same cold room.
questions.description: Dirt always contains many microbes. Dirty root vegetables must be handled separately from other products so that the microbes in the dirt do not spread to other food products.

questions.question: Smoking is allowed at the loading docks of kitchens.
questions.description: Loading docks are a part of food production areas; smoking is not allowed in food production areas.

questions.question: Officials benefit from own-check plans the most because a large part of planning the monitoring is given to the food product industry's companies.
questions.description: Own-check plans that are done well make it easier for companies to upkeep food product safety because resources used for monitoring can be focused on things essential for company activities. Knowledge of the quality of the activities will also improve when the activities are planned. In the best case customer satisfaction, profitability and officials' trust will improve.

questions.question: If an easily perishable food product has been stored in too warm conditions, the use-by-date marked on the package is no longer reliable.
questions.description: The use-by-date is reliable only if the product has been stored correctly. Storing products in too warm conditions always makes the products last for shorter periods of times.

questions.question: Water is necessary for microbes to reproduce.
questions.description: Dried products last well due to having no water that bacteria could use to reproduce. Microbes can't reproduce in dried products.

questions.question: Any water can be used for washing potatoes as they have soil on them.
questions.description: Potatoes must always be washed with water that meets the requirements for domestic water.

questions.question: Customer feedback is a part of the own-check plan.
questions.description: It is useful to pay attention to appropriate customer feedback when carrying out the own-check plan. Customer feedback can be viewed as a way to enhance quality of service. Feedback should be written down, discussed with the staff and utilized in developing procedures and protocols.

questions.question: Salmonella bacteria can be found in fowl or poultry.
questions.description: Salmonella can be found in fowl or poultry. Due to the risk of salmonella, the meat of fowl/poultry must always be cooked to at least 75 degrees Celsius.

questions.question: Dirty root vegetables can be stored in cardboard boxes above meat products on cold room shelves.
questions.description: Dirt always contains many microbes. Dirty root vegetables must be handled separately from other products so that the microbes in the dirt do not spread to other food products.

questions.question: Headwear is used in kitchens to protect the employee's hair from getting dirty.
questions.description: Headwear is used to prevent the employee's hair from getting into the prepared food.

questions.question: Wounds on the hands should be covered with both a bandage and a single-use glove.
questions.description: When both a bandage and a single-use glove are used, the wound is protected well enough and is also made more waterproof.

questions.question: Rings can be used when handling unpacked food products.
questions.description: Rings can not be used when handling unpacked food products, because microbes have optimal growth conditions underneath them.

questions.question: Norwalk-like viruses (NLV) will be destroyed if they are in temperatures higher than 90 degrees Celsius for 2 minutes.
questions.description: Food poisoning causing NLV will be destroyed using heat treatment. However, it can withstand very high temperatures. 2 minutes in over 90 degrees Celsius temperatures is enough to remove the virus from food products.

questions.question: Food products must never be cooled or stored outside.
questions.description: Food products must not be cooled or stored outside. All equipment and products, e.g. boxes containg baked goods, must be stored inside.

questions.question: Coffee cream and milk may be stored in room temperature, because they will be added to hot coffee.
questions.description: Milk and cream are easily perishable food products, and they must be served cold.

questions.question: Raw milk is not suitable for small children, elderly people, pregnant women or people who have a severe disease.
questions.description: Because raw milk has not been pasteurized it can contain disease causing bacteria. The most important bacteria that are a threat to food product safety in raw milk are EHEC, campylo, listeria and salmonella bacteria.

questions.question: Cold fish products (e.g. salmon) in vacuum-packages has sometimes been found to contain listeria.
questions.description: Cold fish products in vacuum-packages have a risk to cause listeriosis because the fish has not been heated and the storing time is long.

questions.question: Ascorbic acid (vitamin C) can not be used as a preservative.
questions.description: Ascorbic acid lowers the pH value of food products. The growth of bacteria especially can be slowed down by increasing the acidity of products.

questions.question: Dried products last well due to having no water that bacteria could use to reproduce.
questions.description: Water is necessary for microbes to reproduce. Dried products last well due to having no water.

questions.question: After washing one's hands the tap must be closed using a hand towel, otherwise the hands can become dirty again.
questions.description: After washing the hands they must be dried using a single-use hand towel and the tap must be closed using the towel. This way any possible microbes on the tap do not spread onto the clean hands.

questions.question: If a food product includes nuts it does not have to say so on the package.
questions.description: Packaging markings must tell if the product contains ingredients that cause allergic reactions; the EU has a compiled list of these.

questions.question: The creation and following requirements of own-check plans include all companies that handle food products.
questions.description: The creation and use of an own-check plan is a requirement by law, which has included all companies handling food products since 1995. All employees in a company are responsible for the implementation of own-check plans.

questions.question: Ultra-high-temperature processing (UHT) uses higher temperatures than pasteurizing.
questions.description: Ultra-high-temperature processing is done in much higher temperatures than pasteurizing. UHT destroys most bacteria spores and because of this products that have been treated with UHT can be stored in room temperature.

questions.question: Biowaste bins do not have to be emptied daily if the bin has not become full.
questions.description: Biowaste bins must be emptied at least once a day because biowaste contains perishing materials.

questions.question: Pizza toppings do not need to be cold stored because pizzas are baked in a very hot oven.
questions.description: Perishable food products that require cold storage must always be cold stored.

questions.question: Some microbes can reproduce even in food products that are in a protective gas package.
questions.description: Protective gas packages contain little or no oxygen. This prevents microbes that require oxygen from growing. However, the product can also contain microbes that do not need oxygen.

questions.question: Even thoroughly boiled food contains microbes.
questions.description: Bacteria spores will not be destroyed during boiling. When boiled food cools to less than 60 degrees Celsius the bacteria spores may reproduce again.

questions.question: Kitchen waste bins are always emptied after a work shift.
questions.description: Kitchen waste bins are emptied into the waste assortment room always when necessary during a work shift. At the same time the emptied waste bins must be washed.

questions.question: All cold storage units in food production areas must contain a thermometer.
questions.description: The monitoring and logging of temperatures is an important part of the . Thermometers are a vital tool for this and must be used.

questions.question: Frozen fish is thawed on the kitchen counter.
questions.description: Frozen food products are always thawed in a cold room.

questions.question: Microbes can not reproduce in food products that are in a protective gas package.
questions.description: Protective gas packages contain little or no oxygen. This prevents microbes that require oxygen from growing. However, the product can also contain microbes that do not need oxygen.

questions.question: The shelf life of the products in the fruit section of a grocery store is affected by the correct handling of mouldy fruit.
questions.description: Mouldy fruits are not recommended for use and they must be removed and disposed of immediately.

questions.question: Received food products must be stored where there is the most space for them in the storage facility.
questions.description: Received food products are stored based on the FIFO method (First In, First Out) which means that products already stored in the storage facility are moved to the front to be used or taken first, and any new products are placed behind or after any prior ones. This way the products are taken out of storage in the order they arrived in and the amount of wastage is reduced.

questions.question: BSE is also called mad cow's disease.
questions.description: Mad cow's disease is sometimes found in old cows. During slaughtering the carcasses must be checked so that contaminated meat is not used.

questions.question: Dirty root vegetables can be stored in cardboard boxes above meat products on cold room shelves.
questions.description: Dirt always contains many microbes. Dirty root vegetables must be handled separately from other products so that the microbes in the dirt do not spread to other food products.

questions.question: Customers and employees are allowed to use the same toilet.
questions.description: Strict toilet and hand hygiene must be used in food production. This is not possible if toilets are shared with customers. Customers may have diseases, can be drunk or they can be small children; in each case the use of the same toilets is a risk.

questions.question: There must be an appropriate washing place for large machines and dishes in the food premises.
questions.description: A cleaning plan is made for every machine and device to specify an appropriate place for washing each one of them.

questions.question: A product can not be used for food preparation after the product's best-before date.
questions.description: Best before dates tell that the product's main attributes and characteristics will remain the same up to the marked date, as long as it is stored correctly. The product can be used and sold after the best before date. The usability and quality of the product can be checked using the senses (visually etc.) after the best before date.

questions.question: Sterilizing only destroys microbes capable of reproducing.
questions.description: Sterilizing destroys reproductive spores as well as bacteria spores. Canned foods are produced with sterilization.

questions.question: Dried products can spoil quickly if they become wet.
questions.description: Dried products last long if they are stored dry. If the products become wet the microbes in them will start to reproduce.

questions.question: Food must not be served heated for over 2 hours.
questions.description: Food served / sold hot may be kept in a temperature-controlled bath (min +60 degrees) for a maximum of four hours, after which the food must be replaced.

questions.question: An animal can be slaughtered in a restaurant if a special permit has been granted.
questions.description: It is prohibited to slaughter animals in restaurants.

questions.question: Heat and humidity accelerate vegetable spoilage.
questions.description: The correct storage temperatures and moisture affect the shelf life of vegetables.

questions.question: People who have been infected with salmonella always have diarrhoea.
questions.description: The symptoms of salmonella infection include nausea, diarrhoea, high temperature and headache. Not everyone with the infection has symptoms.

questions.question: Worn down and broken equipment is a hygienic risk.
questions.description: Waste food can get easily stuck in worn or broken equipment. Even small amounts of waste food will give microbes a good growing environment.

questions.question: If the dry storage rooms has no space elsewhere, food products can be stored on the floor of the room for a short time.
questions.description: Food products can not be stored on the floor even for a short time.

questions.question: Food products that have been thawed only once can be refrozen as long as they are packed in hygienic packaging.
questions.description: You must never refreeze food products that have already been thawed.

questions.question: You can leave your rings on your fingers while you wash your hands.
questions.description: A lot of dirt and microbes live under rings, which means that rings must be removed before washing your hands.

questions.question: Good cleaning results are verified by taking samples from surfaces.
questions.description: Samples are taken from surfaces in order to verify that cleaning efforts are adequate.

questions.question: You can touch the inside surfaces of food packaging if you have just washed your hands.
questions.description: You should always try not to touch the inside surfaces of food packaging.

questions.question: You are allowed to use snus (nuuska in Finnish) while preparing food.
questions.description: The use of snus (nuuska in Finnish) is prohibited while preparing food.

questions.question: HACCP is not a food poisoning causing bacteria.
questions.description: HACCP stands for Hazard Analysis and Critical Control Points, which is a part of own-check plans. When working with an own-check plan these critical points must be identified and constantly monitored carefully.

questions.question: BSE, also called mad cow's disease, is not a food poisoning causing bacteria.
questions.description: BSE is caused by changes in the central nervous system of cows. Humans can get the disease only by eating meat that is contaminated with BSE.

questions.question: Equipment used for slicing food products must be cleaned regularly.
questions.description: Equipment used for slicing food products is cleaned regularly by disassembling it and washing the parts with the appropriate washing agent.

questions.question: Wastebins must be cleaned regularly.
questions.description: Wastebins must not be broken, must include a lid and must also be cleaned regularly.

questions.question: Food production employees are only allowed to wear their work outfit at their workplace, the food production area.
questions.description: The work outfit can only be worn inside the food production area; this prevents microbes from spreading into the area from the clothes.

questions.question: Even in small cafés the same cleaning equipment can not be used to clean the customer areas and the kitchen.
questions.description: If the same cleaning equipment is used, microbes can easily spread from customers to the kitchen in the equipment.

questions.question: An employee handling unpacked, easily perishable food products can not have nail polish while working.
questions.description: Nail polish can not be worn when handling easily perishable food products because the polish can break off into the products. Microbes also have good growth environments to reproduce under nails and nail polish. Nails and hands must be kept in good condition when working with food products.

questions.question: Plastic wrappers for food packaging can be stored outdoors, protected from rain.
questions.description: Plastic and paper wrappers for packing food are stored in a clean indoor space. Packaging materials must be stored sufficiently far away from contaminating materials such as waste or food.

questions.question: Workers in the food industry, e.g. the owner of a small café, must inform local food control authorities about their activities.
questions.description: All workers in the food industry must inform food control authorities about their activities. The informing must be done before beginning the activities. When founding a food industry workplace, e.g. a sausage factory, the activities must also be approved by the authorities.

questions.question: Actions made after noticing mistakes or abnormalities in the packaging or quality of food products during receival checks must be logged in the own-check plan.
questions.description: Mistakes or abnormalities noticed in the quality or packaging of food products must be logged into the own-check plan. It is also required to detailedly log what actions are made after noticing a mistake or abnormality and who is responsible for informing for example the supplier of the products about it.

questions.question: The acidity of food products affects the reproduction of bacteria in the products.
questions.description: Increasing the acidity of a food product makes it harder for many harmful microbes to reproduce. Because of this, lactic acid fermentation is a good traditional way to store e.g. vegetables. The fermentation is based on how lactic acid works. Lactic acid bacteria (LAB) is a good example of beneficial microbes, which has good health benefits. All microbes are thus not harmful for food products.

questions.question: Temperature measurements stated in the own-check plan must be done according to the own-check plan.
questions.description: Only regularly done measurements can prove that the own-check plan has been adhered to at a workplace.

questions.question: During the cooling of food microbes are able to reproduce in the food.
questions.description: The danger zone for food temperatures is between 6 and 60 degrees Celsius. Microbes can reproduce in food when the temperature is within this danger zone. During the cooling of food the food is within this danger zone.

questions.question: Most harmful microbes reproduce the easiest in temperatures between 6 and 60 degrees Celsius.
questions.description: 6-60 degrees Celsius is a hazardous temperature region where food products should not be stored for long periods of time. Food served from a counter should be kept colder or hotter than this for the entire length of serving, and food to be served later after cooking should be cooled to colder than 6 degrees Celsius quickly (sooner than 4 hours.)

questions.question: Dirty and clean work clothes must be stored in separate places.
questions.description: There should be a separate place for storing dirty work clothes. Work clothes should also be clean, neat and suitable for food related work.

questions.question: Safety data sheets are the same thing as the instruction manual of a device.
questions.description: Safety data sheets include the most important information about detergents (washing chemicals) and also include first aid instructions.

questions.question: Cooling cabinets are used only for cooling food.
questions.description: Food should be cooled to less than 6 degrees Celsius within only 4 hours. When the products have been cooled they should be moved into another cold storage unit. Cooling cabinets are only used for cooling food (not storing.)

questions.question: Drying makes an easily perishable food product a long-lasting one.
questions.description: Microbes need water to reproduce. Getting rid of water in any ingredients is a very effective way of stopping perishing. Drying is one of the oldest known preserving methods. Dry products last long when they are stored dry during all transportation and storing phases. As long as the products stay dry, microbes in them can not reproduce.

questions.question: Food products can be used safely after the use-by date if they do not look or smell bad.
questions.description: Perished or contaminated products are not always possible to notice just by using the senses (visually etc.) Easily perishable food products' packages have a use-by date marked on them, and after this date has passed the product must not be used or sold.

questions.question: Crates can be stored on the loading dock as long as they are protected from the rain.
questions.description: Storing crates on the loading dock is a hygiene hazard as they attract birds and other animals.

questions.question: Wooden utensils are well suited for professional kitchens if they are washed in a washing machine on a sufficiently hot program.
questions.description: Wooden utensils should not be used in professional kitchens, as they do not withstand repeated washes in a washing machine. Materials must very durable in order to cope with repeated washes, like for example plastic and steel utensils that are meant for food product related use.

questions.question: Trichinella spiralis is a parasite of salmon.
questions.description: Trichinella spiralis is found in the non-inspected meat of pigs, boar, horses and bears.

questions.question: Hepatitis A is never spread in food products.
questions.description: The most important viruses that reproduce in the intestines of humans are the norovirus and hepatitis A. Both viruses last for a long time and are able to spread in the cold and even in frozen foods.

questions.question: Cooked rice can be cooled in room temperature.
questions.description: Cooked rice is an easily perishable food product. In room temperature the microbes in the rice can reproduce very quickly and cause food poisoning.

questions.question: Dirty root vegetables and pre-made food products can be stored in the same cold room.
questions.description: Dirt always contains many microbes. Dirty root vegetables must be handled separately from other products so that the microbes in the dirt do not spread to other food products.

questions.question: Transported products and cargo being received do not have to be checked.
questions.description: The quality of arriving products must be checked and the temperatures of easily perishable products must be measured. The results must be written down.

questions.question: Freezing improves the lastingness of food products because microbes are destroyed in the cold.
questions.description: Cold does not destroy microbes. If a product being freezed is microbiologically bad quality, it will be even worse quality after defrosting. However, freezing a good quality product will make it last longer as long as the freezing temperature is cold enough (-18 degrees Celsius or lower) and defrosting happens sufficiently slowly in cold areas.

questions.question: Milk spoils faster than sour milk.
questions.description: The pH value of milk is 7, which means it is neutral. The pH value of sour milk is lower, which means sour milk is acidized. It is harder for bacteria to reproduce in acidized milk products than in neutral products.

questions.question: The slime that appears on the surface of meat products is caused by harmful microbes.
questions.description: Some harmful microbes produce slime. For example, slime appearing on the surface of a sausage is a sign of it perishing. Slime-producing microbes reproduce quickly in food products e.g. when the product is stored or served in too high temperatures.

questions.question: Bacteria spores are destroyed when products are boiled (+100 degrees Celsius).
questions.description: Bacteria spores are destroyed only during sterilization. In excess pressure the temperature is raised to about 145 degrees Celsius and this way bacteria spores are also destroyed.

questions.question: Working surfaces must be dried properly after cleaning.
questions.description: Harmful microbes multiply in damp conditions, so surfaces must be fully dried after cleaning.

questions.question: BSE, also called mad cow's disease, is not a food poisoning causing bacteria.
questions.description: BSE is caused by changes in the central nervous system of cows. Humans can get the disease only by eating meat that is contaminated with BSE.

questions.question: Equipment used for slicing food products must be cleaned regularly.
questions.description: Equipment used for slicing food products is cleaned regularly by disassembling it and washing the parts with the appropriate washing agent.

questions.question: When outside temperatures are very cold, food products can be cooled quickly outside.
questions.description: Food products must not be cooled or stored outside. All equipment and products, e.g. boxes containg baked goods, must be stored inside.

questions.question: Eating is not allowed while preparing food.
questions.description: Microbes in the mouth spread onto the hands while eating. Eating must be done in a separate area and after eating hands must be washed.

questions.question: The smaller the pieces of chopped vegetables, the longer their shelf life.
questions.description: The more you handle and chop food products, the shorter their shelf life is.

questions.question: Spices cannot cause food poisoning.
questions.description: In some cases spices, too, can cause a risk of food poisoning, and therefore they must be used and stored hygienically and with care just like other food products.

questions.question: Ascorbic acid (vitamin C) can be used as a preservative.
questions.description: Ascorbic acid lowers the pH value of food products. The growth of bacteria especially can be slowed down by increasing the acidity of products.

questions.question: Food poisoning causing bacteria reproduce quickly in Karelian pasties kept in room temperature.
questions.description: Karelian pasties are usually filled with rice porridge boiled in milk. Easily perishable food products, such as Karelian pasties, must be kept in cool temperatures. In room temperature the bacteria in pasties will reproduce quicker.

questions.question: Hands must be washed after sneezing and blowing one's nose.
questions.description: Microbes spread onto the hands when sneezing and blowing one's nose. If the hands are not washed, these bacteria will easily spread onto food products.

questions.question: Wine is produced with the help of beneficial microbes.
questions.description: The production of wine and beer uses yeast. Yeast is a beneficial microbe.

questions.question: A cheese roll packed in a tight plastic wrap is protected from microbes.
questions.description: A cheese roll is a perishable food product that is stored and served cold. In addition to being wrapped in plastic film, make sure that it is kept in the correct storage and serving temperatures.

questions.question: An employee handling unpacked, easily perishable food products can not have nail polish while working.
questions.description: Nail polish can not be worn when handling easily perishable food products because the polish can break off into the products. Microbes also have good growth environments to reproduce under nails and nail polish. Nails and hands must be kept in good condition when working with food products.

questions.question: Thoroughly boiled food does not contain any microbes.
questions.description: Bacteria spores will not be destroyed during boiling. When boiled food cools to less than 60 degrees Celsius the bacteria spores may reproduce again.

questions.question: EHEC bacteria are intestinal bacteria.
questions.description: EHEC bacteria is found especially in the intestines of cattle. EHEC bacteria create toxins in the intestines of humans. The toxin often causes bloody diarrhea and very uncomfortable stomache pains.

questions.question: If food is prepared to be served later, the finished products must be cooled as soon as possible for storage.
questions.description: Hot, cooked food must be cooled to under 6 degrees Celsius in under 4 hours. Cooling large amounts of products requires the use of actual cooling devices, from which the cooled products must be moved to their appropriate cold storage units.

questions.question: Temperature does not affect the speed of microbe reproduction.
questions.description: Temperatures are very important for the reproduction abilities of microbes. All microbes have their own optimal temperatures where reproduction is the fastest.

questions.question: Packages for non-easily perishable food products must have a label indicating their best-before date.
questions.description: Packaging labels for non-easily perishable food products show the best-before date. The accuracy of the date is determined by the product's shelf life. The product may be used after the date if its sensory qualities, such as smell, taste and look are impeccable.

questions.question: Waste bins in food premises may contain microbes that are a health hazard.
questions.description: It is important to make sure that waste bins are regularly emptied and that they are clean by washing them with appropriate detergents.

questions.question: All milk products must always be stored in cold storage, where the temperature is less than 6 degrees Celsius.
questions.description: Ultra-high-temperature processing sterilizes milk products. In UHT processing milk is heated for a few seconds to at least 135 degrees Celsius and packed into disinfected packaging in a clean area.This treatment destroys all reproducing micro-organisms and all unopened packages can be stored in room temperature.

questions.question: Food that is being served while hot must be at least 60 degrees Celsius during the entire serving period.
questions.description: The temperature must also be measured and marked down in own-check logs. The food can be kept in service while hot for a maximum of 4 hours.

questions.question: If the temperature of a cold storage unit is too high it must not be marked down on the own-check plan's monitoring logs.
questions.description: Measured temperatures must be marked down in the own-check plan's monitoring logs, even if they are too high or too low. The logs must also contain information on what fixing procedure has been made to correct the incorrect temperature.

questions.question: A biowaste container that is kept closed can be stored in the kitchen's storage area at room temperature for a few days.
questions.description: Waste must be stored in a designated area that is sufficiently separated from other operations and food products.

questions.question: Sour milk spoils faster than milk.
questions.description: The pH value of milk is 7, which means it is neutral. The pH value of sour milk is lower, which means sour milk is acidized. It is harder for bacteria to reproduce in acidized milk products than in neutral products.

questions.question: Kitchen waste bins are always emptied after a work shift.
questions.description: Kitchen waste bins are emptied into the waste assortment room always when necessary during a work shift. At the same time the emptied waste bins must be washed.

questions.question: Disinfecting work surfaces does not compensate for regular, careful washing.
questions.description: Work surfaces must be cleaned and washed regularly after each phase of work, and disinfecting can improve the overall cleaning result.

questions.question: The purpose of the own-check plan is to make sure that operators manage the risks associated with food hygiene in their operations.
questions.description: Drawing up and following an own-check plan helps operators to manage the risks associated with food hygiene.

questions.question: Temperature affects the speed of microbe reproduction.
questions.description: Temperatures are very important for the reproduction abilities of microbes. All microbes have their own optimal temperatures where reproduction is the fastest.

questions.question: Microbes reproduce the fastest in their own optimal temperatures.
questions.description: All microbes have their own optimal temperatures where reproduction is the fastest. In the insides of humans and animals, the temperature range between 20 and 45 degrees Celsius is the best for microbes. Anything hotter or colder than this causes microbes to reproduce slower.

questions.question: The sampling plan is not part of the own-check plan.
questions.description: The sampling plan is an important part of own-check operations.

questions.question: If an employee has infected wounds on his or her hands, he or she must not handle food products.
questions.description: Infected wounds contain large amounts of food poisoning causing Staphylococcus aureus bacteria. It is impossible to constantly prevent the bacteria from spreading to food products.

questions.question: Food poisoning causing microbes can spread only by hands.
questions.description: Working areas and surfaces must be cleaned regularly during work shifts and after work is over.

questions.question: Vegetables stored in a vinegared liquid can be kept in room temperature.
questions.description: Sterilized, can-packed and unopened vinegared products can be stored in room temperature. Vinegared products will last long due to the high acidity, but opened packages must be stored in cool temperatures.

questions.question: An employee on antibiotics can not spread food poisoning causing microbes.
questions.description: An employee using antibiotics is not free from all food poisoning causing bacteria which can be on the skin, mucosas or in the intestines. The antibiotics might not affect all harmful microbes and so the person could spread microbes even during the use of the antibiotics.

questions.question: Hands must be washed after sneezing and blowing one's nose.
questions.description: Microbes spread onto the hands when sneezing and blowing one's nose. If the hands are not washed, these bacteria will easily spread onto food products.

questions.question: The lastingness of food products can also be improved during treatment by using hygienic work methods, clean surfaces and equipment.
questions.description: Ingredients and their handling equipment must be kept separate from cooked products to prevent cross-contamination. For example, differently colored cutting boards and equipment for different food groups, such as vegetables, fish, meat and cooked food helps to prevent cross-contamination.

questions.question: Guide dogs are allowed inside food product stores.
questions.description: Guide dogs are always allowed in areas meant for customers. However, no animals can be taken inside food product handling areas or storage areas.

questions.question: Cooked rice left at room temperature is a good breeding ground for various microbes.
questions.description: Bacillus cereus is one of the bacteria that causes food poisoning; it cannot be completely stopped from spreading to food products. Bacillus cereus is found in almost all food products. It is most commonly spread through rice dishes and vegetables.

questions.question: Campylo bacteria is naturally found in fowl and poultry.
questions.description: Campylo bacteria and salmonella are found naturally in fowl and poultry. Both bacteria are destroyed when the meat is cooked thoroughly to over 75 degrees Celsius.

questions.question: Listeria and yersinia can not reproduce in refrigerator temperatures.
questions.description: Earth and various bodies of water contain microbes, such as listeria and yersinia, that are able to survive cold conditions well. Listeria and yersinia can reproduce in very cold refrigerator temperatures.

questions.question: Arriving products and cargo must be checked when received.
questions.description: The quality of arriving products must be checked and the temperatures of easily perishable products must be measured. The results must be written down.

questions.question: Fresh fish and roe must be stored between 0 and 2 degrees Celsius.
questions.description: Fresh fish and roe are very easily perishable food products which must be stored close to the temperature of melting ice, between 0 and 2 degrees Celsius. Certain food perishing causing bacteria, which make fish and roe be considered a risk food product, are able to reproduce even in temperatures as low as 3 degrees Celsius.

questions.question: Drying makes an easily perishable food product a long-lasting one.
questions.description: Microbes need water to reproduce. Getting rid of water in any ingredients is a very effective way of stopping perishing. Drying is one of the oldest known preserving methods. Dry products last long when they are stored dry during all transportation and storing phases. As long as the products stay dry, microbes in them can not reproduce.

questions.question: The amount of sugar a product contains does not affect its lastingness.
questions.description: Highly sugared products, such as jams, marmelades and sweets do not perish easily because sugar changes the state of water so that microbes can not reproduce.

questions.question: Food products can be used safely after the use-by date if they do not look or smell bad.
questions.description: Perished or contaminated products are not always possible to notice just by using the senses (visually etc.) Easily perishable food products' packages have a use-by date marked on them, and after this date has passed the product must not be used or sold.

questions.question: Minced meat produced in a store can be sold on the day of production and the day after that.
questions.description: Minced meat is an easily perishable food product. Because of this the safety of minced meat produced in a store can not be ensured for a longer period of time. Minced meat should be stored at 4 degrees Celsius.

questions.question: The sampling plan is not part of the own-check plan.
questions.description: The sampling plan is an important part of own-check operations.

questions.question: The own-check plan has been created to make it easier for health officials to do their job.
questions.description: Own-check plans and measurement charts are the establishment's own documents that are supposed to emphasize the actor's own responsibility in controlling risks. If there are any problems, it is afterwords easier to find out what caused them. Officials check plans and interfere with defects if necessary.

questions.question: Fever and the flu are good reasons for a food product employee to not go to work.
questions.description: Food products should not be handled when one has a fever or the flu because causes of the disease spread easily by coughing or sneezing.

questions.question: Sugar can contain microbes.
questions.description: Sugar is dry, so microbes do not grow in it. However, salt can contain spores of bacteria, moulds or yeast.

questions.question: Frozen food products are stored in a freezer at a temperature of -15°C or colder.
questions.description: The temperature in a freezer must be -18°C or colder.

questions.question: Dried products last well due to having no water that bacteria could use to reproduce.
questions.description: Water is necessary for microbes to reproduce. Dried products last well due to having no water.

questions.question: It is recommended to use a hand dryer for drying your hands because the air they produce is so hot.
questions.description: Dry your hands with a clean disposable paper towel or a cloth towel.

questions.question: A cooked meal and the raw ingredients used to prepare it can be stored in the same container during transport.
questions.description: Cooked meals and raw ingredients are always stored separately in their own clean containers.

questions.question: When you clean a refrigerator, you only need to wipe away visible dirt as microbes do not multiply in such a cold place.
questions.description: Refrigerators must be cleaned regularly with appropriate detergents. Some microbes thrive and even grow at the refrigerator temperature.

questions.question: Not all microbes and bacteria-spores in food products can be destroyed using any treatments.
questions.description: Sterilizing or radiating can destroy all bacteria or microbe-spores in food products. Canned food, such as canned tuna and canned baby food is sterilized by heating the packed products. Spices are one example of a product that can be treated by radiation.

questions.question: Restaurants must have an own-check plan.
questions.description: All workplaces in the food industry need to ensure the safety of their products with an own-check plan. Own-check plans are required in all food industry workplaces.

questions.question: An employee handling unpacked, easily perishable food products can not have nail polish while working.
questions.description: Nail polish can not be worn when handling easily perishable food products because the polish can break off into the products. Microbes also have good growth environments to reproduce under nails and nail polish. Nails and hands must be kept in good condition when working with food products.

questions.question: Food production areas do not need a written cleaning plan if the procedures have been discussed carefully with the personnel and everyone knows their tasks.
questions.description: The cleaning and washing program always needs to be part of the food production area's own-check plan. The own-check plan is produced on paper before starting activities in the food production area.

questions.question: The HACCP system is used to help own-check plans and the planning of them.
questions.description: HACCP, meaning the Hazard Analysis and Critical Control Points system, helps to think of critical points during transportation of food products from preparation to consumers. Explaining these critical points in the own-check plan helps upkeeping good work hygiene.

questions.question: Listeria and yersinia can reproduce in refrigerator temperatures.
questions.description: Earth and various bodies of water contain microbes, such as listeria and yersinia, that are able to survive cold conditions well. Listeria and yersinia can reproduce in very cold refrigerator temperatures.

questions.question: Disinfecting work surfaces does not compensate for regular, careful washing.
questions.description: Work surfaces must be cleaned and washed regularly after each phase of work, and disinfecting can improve the overall cleaning result.

questions.question: Microbes reproduce in dry products.
questions.description: Microbes need water to reproduce. Microbes will not reproduce in dried products but dried products can contain spores of bacteria, moulds or yeast.

questions.question: Packages for non-easily perishable food products must have a label indicating their best-before date.
questions.description: Packaging labels for non-easily perishable food products show the best-before date. The accuracy of the date is determined by the product's shelf life. The product may be used after the date if its sensory qualities, such as smell, taste and look are impeccable.

questions.question: Hepatitis A can spread in food products.
questions.description: The most important viruses that reproduce in the intestines of humans are the norovirus and hepatitis A. Both viruses last for a long time and are able to spread in the cold and even in frozen foods.

questions.question: Tapeworms can be found in the roe (eggs) and muscles of some lake fish.
questions.description: Tapeworms can be found in the roe (eggs) and muscles of lake fish, such as bass, pike, burbot and ruffe. Proper cooking or freezing (2 days minimum) will destroy the tapeworm.

questions.question: Pasteurization improves the lastingness of food products.
questions.description: In dairies milk products are pasteurized, which means that they are heated to 72 degrees Celsius for 15 seconds and then afterwards cooled immediately. A large amount of bacteria capable of reproducing is destroyed, but this treatment does not destroy all microbes. Pasteurized milk must be stored under 6 degrees Celsius in a refrigerator. Juices are another example of a product which can gain better lastingness when pasteurized during production.

questions.question: Dry flour contains microbes.
questions.description: Dry products can contain spores of bacteria, moulds and yeast. However, they do not reproduce in dry products.

questions.question: Vegetables that do not have any visible soil on them do not contain any harmful microbes.
questions.description: There can be microbes on vegetables that do not have any visible soil on them. Microbes enter plants from the environment when they grow and from irrigation water, for example.

questions.question: Mashed potato is an easily perishable food product.
questions.description: Pre-made foods are easily perishable products. Easily perishable foods must be stored in the cold, under 6 degrees Celsius.

questions.question: Permitted food additives are marked with E numbers.
questions.description: In addition to the category that indicates the intended use, additives also have a name or numerical code, i.e. an E number.

questions.question: All own-check plan related measurements must be recorded in own-check plan forms.
questions.description: Though recording all own-check related measurements is essential, all measurements do not need to be logged. For example, it is good to pay daily attention to the temperatures of cold storage, but only a weekly log entry is sufficient.

questions.question: Any water can be used for washing potatoes as they have soil on them.
questions.description: Potatoes must always be washed with water that meets the requirements for domestic water.

questions.question: Vibrio bacteria are found in sea waters at warm geographical locations.
questions.description: Vibrio bacteria have been found in salty coast seawater at warm geographical locations. Seafood that has been heated badly or stored in too warm temperatures are risk food products.

questions.question: BSE, also called mad cow's disease, is not a food poisoning causing bacteria.
questions.description: BSE is caused by changes in the central nervous system of cows. Humans can get the disease only by eating meat that is contaminated with BSE.

questions.question: Visually clean work surfaces guarantee their microbiological cleanliness.
questions.description: Microbiological cleanliness can not be guaranteed by using just the bare eye. Correct cleaning methods and equipment, as well as regular and proper cleaning, guarantee the cleanliness much better. Samples can also be taken of the cleanliness of specific surfaces if required.

questions.question: Lactic acid bacteria (LAB) are used when producing yoghurt.
questions.description: Yoghurt and other fermented milk products use LAB in their production. LAB create lactic acid, which cause acidity in the products.

questions.question: A biowaste container that is kept closed can be stored in the kitchen's storage area at room temperature for a few days.
questions.description: Waste must be stored in a designated area that is sufficiently separated from other operations and food products.

questions.question: Defrosting frozen foods in room temperature increases the risk of food poisoning.
questions.description: Frozen foods' surfaces will defrost faster than the insides. In room temperature the surfaces will become warm enough for microbes to grow even though the insides might still be frozen.

questions.question: The serving dishes of coffee cream or coffee milk can be filled many times during a day.
questions.description: Coffee cream or coffee milk must always be served from a clean dish, and after the dish is empty it should be changed and washed.

questions.question: The results of Oiva-reports can be viewed by anyone online.
questions.description: The Oiva system is used to allow consumers to view the results of routine inspections.

questions.question: Microbes are destroyed when meat is minced.
questions.description: When meat is minced, the bacteria on its surface spread throughout the minced meat.

questions.question: Food that is being served while cold must have its temperature measured and marked down.
questions.description: Temperature measurements of food that is being served are a part of own-check plans. The results of the measurements must be mark down in the monitoring logs of the own-check plans and then stored at the workplace for 1 year.

questions.question: The fresh fish that has been up for retail sale during the day can, with the decision and permission of the store, be smoked during the evening and then sold.
questions.description: Fish that has been on the sales counter can not be smoked for the next day's sales. This is against the ethics of food product law and deceives consumers. If fish has been up for retail sale during the day, its sales time must not continue by smoking it.

questions.question: Reheated products must be heated to +75 degrees celsius before serving.
questions.description: Reheated food products, such as appropriately cooled food that has been prepared the previous day, must be thoroughly heated to +75 degrees before serving.

questions.question: Food poisonings can be prevented by using single-use protective gloves.
questions.description: Single-use protective gloves must be used when handling very easily perishable food products. Protective gloves make it easier to work when employees must change tasks quickly.

questions.question: Water is not necessary for microbes to reproduce.
questions.description: Dried products last well due to having no water that bacteria could use to reproduce. Microbes can't reproduce in dried products.

questions.question: The gas in protective gas packaging completely prevents harmful microbes from growing.
questions.description: The amount of oxygen in protective gas is changed to make it harder for most microbes to grow. Some harmful microbes can withstand exceptional conditions and will be able to reproduce even in protective gas packages. Additionally, the protective gas in the packages will try to equalize with the air around it, so the amount of gas can change.

questions.question: A disinfectant detergent never needs to be replaced.
questions.description: It is possible for a disinfectant detergent to become ineffective against certain bacteria, and it is therefore important to change the detergent regularly.

questions.question: In Finland the milk found in cartons in stores is rarely pasteurized.
questions.description: In Finland the milk found in cartons in stores is almost always pasteurized milk. Only raw milk that has been bought directly from a dairy farm is not usually pasteurized.

questions.question: Packages for non-easily perishable food products must have a label indicating their best-before date.
questions.description: Packaging labels for non-easily perishable food products show the best-before date. The accuracy of the date is determined by the product's shelf life. The product may be used after the date if its sensory qualities, such as smell, taste and look are impeccable.

questions.question: Bacteria spores can not be destroyed by boiling.
questions.description: Bacteria do not reproduce in boiling hot food. However, the spores of the bacteria do not get destroyed during boiling.

questions.question: Norwalk-like viruses (NLV) will be destroyed if they are in temperatures higher than 90 degrees Celsius for 2 minutes.
questions.description: Food poisoning causing NLV will be destroyed using heat treatment. However, it can withstand very high temperatures. 2 minutes in over 90 degrees Celsius temperatures is enough to remove the virus from food products.

questions.question: Production of cheese uses beneficial microbes.
questions.description: Clean, controlled and beneficial microbes are used in cheeses. During storage these microbes will create taste ingredients in the cheese.

questions.question: Restaurants must have an own-check plan.
questions.description: All workplaces in the food industry need to ensure the safety of their products with an own-check plan. Own-check plans are required in all food industry workplaces.

questions.question: Cleaning equipment storage rooms must be cleaned regularly.
questions.description: All parts of a food production area must be cleaned regularly according to the cleaning plan.

questions.question: Raw milk can contain yersinia.
questions.description: Raw milk has not been pasteurized. Yersinia is destroyed when milk is heated to over 70 degrees Celsius; in other words it is destroyed when the milk is pasteurized.

questions.question: Cooked rice left at room temperature is a good breeding ground for various microbes.
questions.description: Bacillus cereus is one of the bacteria that causes food poisoning; it cannot be completely stopped from spreading to food products. Bacillus cereus is found in almost all food products. It is most commonly spread through rice dishes and vegetables.

questions.question: Smoking is allowed at the loading docks of kitchens.
questions.description: Loading docks are a part of food production areas; smoking is not allowed in food production areas.

questions.question: Thawing frozen products in cold rooms or refrigerators is a hygienic risk because the thawing happens too slowly.
questions.description: If food products are thawed in room temperature, the products' surfaces will melt quicker than the insides. The surfaces will start to spoil even though the insides can still be frozen. Thawing in cold rooms takes a longer amount of time but the cold room's temperature will allow very few microbes to reproduce.

questions.question: If an easily perishable food product has been stored in too warm conditions, the product can still be stored until the use-by-date.
questions.description: The use-by-date is reliable only if the product has been stored correctly. Storing products in too warm conditions always makes the products last for shorter periods of times.

questions.question: Lactic acid bacteria often cause food poisoning.
questions.description: Lactic acid bacteria do not cause food poisoning. Lactic acid bacteria are not harmful if used in the treatment of food poisoning, but they have not been scientifically proven to be of any use either.

questions.question: Microbes are only found in places which are visibly dirty.
questions.description: Microbes are everywhere, not only in dirty locations. However it is probable that dirty spots contain more microbes than clean ones.

questions.question: Only reproductive microbes are destroyed during sterilization. Bacteria spores are not destroyed.
questions.description: During sterilization (e.g. during canned food production) all microbes and bacteria spores are destroyed. This way easily perishable products will be able to last long in room temperature.

questions.question: The same broom can be used for cleaning the floor and work surfaces.
questions.description: Floors contain a lot more microbes than work surfaces. If floor brooms are used for work surfaces, the microbes on the floor will spread to the work surface from the broom.

questions.question: The cooling of food products should be done by using cooling cabinets (chillers).
questions.description: Only cooling cabinets can ensure sufficiently fast and effective cooling.

questions.question: Milk spoils faster than sour milk.
questions.description: The pH value of milk is 7, which means it is neutral. The pH value of sour milk is lower, which means sour milk is acidized. It is harder for bacteria to reproduce in acidized milk products than in neutral products.

questions.question: Frozen products can be thawed in room temperature to make the thawing fast enough.
questions.description: If food products are thawed in room temperature, the products' surfaces will melt quicker than the insides. The surfaces will start to spoil even though the insides can still be frozen.

questions.question: Hands must be washed after sneezing and blowing one's nose.
questions.description: Microbes spread onto the hands when sneezing and blowing one's nose. If the hands are not washed, these bacteria will easily spread onto food products.

questions.question: If one's hands have been carefully washed then food products can be handled with hands.
questions.description: Clean equipment should always be used instead of hands, no matter how well washed, whenever possible.

questions.question: If a can of canned food has bloated and become larger, the contents inside the can must not be tasted.
questions.description: Bloated, enlargened cans can contain a dangerous toxin called botulin. Even a very small amount of botulin can be lethal.

questions.question: Frozen food products can be thawed outdoors in summer as sunlight protects them from contamination.
questions.description:
Frozen food products are generally thawed in a cold room or
in a similar refrigerated space so that the temperature of the surface of the food product
does not rise above the other parts of the products. Sunlight does not protect food against contamination.

questions.question: Detergents (washing chemicals) can be stored in soda bottles.
questions.description: Only the original packages can be used to make sure that the correct detergent is being used for the situation.

questions.question: Salmonella bacteria can be found in fowl or poultry.
questions.description: Salmonella can be found in fowl or poultry. Due to the risk of salmonella, the meat of fowl/poultry must always be cooked to at least 75 degrees Celsius.

questions.question: The sale time for minced meat produced in a store is 10 days.
questions.description: The minced meat produced in a store can be sold on the day of production and the day after that.

questions.question: Food products stored in protective gas do not have to be stored in the cold because the protective gas protects the products from perishing.
questions.description: Food products stored in packages with protective gas must always be stored in the cold according to the instructions on the packaging. Protective gas packages have normal air changed into air that contains little or no oxygen to prevent microbes that use oxygen from reproducing. Protective gas prevents e.g. the surface of meat from darkening and thus keeps the product sensually appealling.

questions.question: Disinfecting work surfaces does not compensate for regular, careful washing.
questions.description: Work surfaces must be cleaned and washed regularly after each phase of work, and disinfecting can improve the overall cleaning result.

questions.question: Mashed potato is not an easily perishable food product.
questions.description: Pre-made foods are easily perishable products. Easily perishable foods must be stored in the cold, under 6 degrees Celsius.

questions.question: The waste disposal procedures for professional kitchens, such as recycling, are decided upon between the personnel.
questions.description: A professional kitchen's waste disposal is based on waste laws as well as regional waste disposal directives.

questions.question: A cleaning equipment storage room is not needed in a food production area.
questions.description: It's not always necessary to have a separate storage space for cleaning equipment. Food production areas need a separate storage, maintenance and drying space if the food production area requires it for constructional reasons. It's important to make sure that there are no risks for food safety and the hygienic treatment, maintenance and storage of cleaning equipment are done properly. If necessary the working stages and functions has to be separated structually or timely.

questions.question: The same knife can be used for cutting raw and cooked meat.
questions.description: Heated food must be protected from contamination after being heated. Ingredients and the equipment used to handle those ingredients must be kept separate from cooked products to prevent cross-contamination.

questions.question: Raw and cooked produce should not be handled at the same time or with the same utensils.
questions.description: Raw and cooked produce should be stored and handled separately. Surfaces should be properly cleaned in between handling raw and cooked produce. Unhygienic cleaning equipment can also contaminate the kitchen surfaces and cause microbes to spread. This type of spreading of microbes is called cross contamination.

questions.question: Products that have gone through ultra-high-temperature treatment (UHT) can be stored in room temperature.
questions.description: During UHT products are sterilized with quick heating. Unopened packages can be stored in room temperature because most bacteria spores have been destroyed.

questions.question: Ingredients should always be handled with clean equipment instead of hands whenever possible.
questions.description: Even washed hands contain some amounts of microbes. Even some healthy people carry food poisoning causing microbes on their skin. Using clean equipment is more hygienic.

questions.question: A meat mincer is washed every week.
questions.description: A meat mincer must always be checked for cleanliness before it is used. A meat mincer is washed after every use. The appliance is disassembled and washed with an appropriate cleaning agent.

questions.question: When receiving products one must make sure that they are moved into their appropriate, separate storage areas as soon as possible after the receival check.
questions.description: Products should be moved into their own storage areas as soon as possible after the receival check. Easily perishable food products can not be stored in room temperature for longer than 10-15 minutes.

questions.question: One of the reasons for the existence of own-check plans is to make the work of food product industry companies easier.
questions.description: Own-check plans that are done well make it easier for companies to upkeep food product safety because resources used for monitoring can be focused on things essential for company activities. Knowledge of the quality of the activities will also improve when the activities are planned. In the best case customer satisfaction, profitability and officials' trust will improve.

questions.question: The proper washing of hands removes all harmful bacteria from the skin.
questions.description: Even proper washing of hands does not remove all bacteria. Small skin damage and undersides of nails affect the amount of bacteria. Hands must be properly washed between different phases of work.

questions.question: Waste bins to be used in kitchens must be water-proof and easily cleanable.
questions.description: Waste bins to be used in kitchens must be water-proof so that waste liquids do not pour onto the floor. They must also be easy to clean so that the cleaning process during emptying is as easy as possible.
