questions.question: All work phases, such as dishwashing, baking and treatment of root vegetables, can be done in the same area in hospital kitchens.
questions.description: When each work phase is done in its own separate area the work is hygienic and the risk of cross-contamination is smaller.

questions.question: The washing and treatment of vegetables worsens their lastingness.
questions.description: For example, carrots that have not been treated will last for weeks when properly stored, but when they have been washed, peeled and grated they become an easily perishable product.

questions.question: The temperature checks for received food products that need hot or cold storage are part of the own-check plan.
questions.description: Temperature monitoring of hot or cold storage food products when receiving is an important part of the own-check plan. If the temperatures do not meet set requirements they can be returned to the supplier as faulty products.

questions.question: Hard rye bread (crisp bread) is an easily perishable food product.
questions.description: Hard rye bread is a dry food product, and because of this microbes can not reproduce in it. Hard rye bread can be stored in room temperature.

questions.question: Vegetables stored in a vinegared liquid can be kept in room temperature.
questions.description: Sterilized, can-packed and unopened vinegared products can be stored in room temperature. Vinegared products will last long due to the high acidity, but opened packages must be stored in cool temperatures.

questions.question: All food that is being served needs to be sampled daily.
questions.description: Taken samples must be placed into a container and then placed into a freezer. If food poisonings are suspected, then these samples must be available for research.

questions.question: In commercial kitchens, it is necessary to nominate the people in charge of the own-check plan.
questions.description: Designated persons who have been trained for the task are responsible for the various areas of the own-check plan.

questions.question: Freezing in a sufficiently cold temperature improves the lastingness of products.
questions.description: Products can be stored by freezing them, but one must notice that freezing affects the quality of different food products. For example, fish, meat and baked goods dry up easily during freezing, so the quality of products stored in freezing must be checked regularly.

questions.question: Temperatures measured under the own-check plan do not need to be recorded if you learn them by heart.
questions.description: It is important to measure and record temperatures.

questions.question: The own-check system involves monitoring how quickly food products cool down to storage temperature.
questions.description: Monitoring temperatures is an important part of the own-check system.

questions.question: Pet dog hair cannot spread microbes into food products.
questions.description: Pet hair can spread microbes into food products.

questions.question: HACCP is a food poisoning causing bacteria.
questions.description: HACCP stands for Hazard Analysis and Critical Control Points, which is a part of own-check plans. When working with an own-check plan these critical points must be identified and constantly monitored carefully.

questions.question: Food products can be cooled in the same freezer where frozen products are stored.
questions.description: Food products must first be cooled with separate cooling equipment and moved afterwards into a freezer for storage.

questions.question: The purpose of own-check plans is to prevent mistakes and problematic situations from occurring during food preparation and serving.
questions.description: Good own-check plans as well as good knowledge of the own-check plan's contents by the personnel prevents problematic situations and makes it easier to identify the causes of any noticed problems.

questions.question: Campylo bacteria is naturally found in fowl and poultry.
questions.description: Campylo bacteria and salmonella are found naturally in fowl and poultry. Both bacteria are destroyed when the meat is cooked thoroughly to over 75 degrees Celsius.

questions.question: Intestinal bacteria can spread from hands to food.
questions.description: Intestinal bacteria can spread to food even from the hands.

questions.question: Wine is produced with the help of beneficial microbes.
questions.description: The production of wine and beer uses yeast. Yeast is a beneficial microbe.

questions.question: Wooden utensils are well suited for professional kitchens if they are washed in a washing machine on a sufficiently hot program.
questions.description: Wooden utensils should not be used in professional kitchens, as they do not withstand repeated washes in a washing machine. Materials must very durable in order to cope with repeated washes, like for example plastic and steel utensils that are meant for food product related use.

questions.question: Vacuum-packed smoked fish does not contain microbes.
questions.description: Vacuum-packages do not include any air and prevent microbes that require oxygen from reproducing. However, the products can still contain microbes that can survive without oxygen.

questions.question: If a fish is dropped on a freshly washed floor, it can still be cooked as long as it is sufficiently well heated.
questions.description: A fish that has fallen onto the floor must never be used for cooking. Food products must never be stored on the floor.

questions.question: If a can of canned food has bloated and become larger, the contents inside the can must be tasted to make sure if the food is spoiled or not.
questions.description: Bloated, enlargened cans can contain a dangerous toxin called botulin. Even a very small amount of botulin can be lethal.

questions.question: A porcelain plate that is chipped is a hygiene hazard.
questions.description: Only use dishes that have an undamaged surface.

questions.question: If you drop a steak onto the floor, you can use it as long as you fry it.
questions.description: A steak that has fallen onto the floor must never be used for cooking. Food products must never be stored on the floor.

questions.question: You are allowed to use snus (nuuska in Finnish) while preparing food.
questions.description: The use of snus (nuuska in Finnish) is prohibited while preparing food.

questions.question: If the temperature of a cold storage unit is too high it must not be marked down on the own-check plan's monitoring logs.
questions.description: Measured temperatures must be marked down in the own-check plan's monitoring logs, even if they are too high or too low. The logs must also contain information on what fixing procedure has been made to correct the incorrect temperature.

questions.question: The priority of waste laws is to make people working in the food industry responsible for assorting their waste.
questions.description: The priority of waste laws is to lessen the amount of waste and its effects.

questions.question: Employees are free to decide who is responsible for the own-check plan at the beginning of each shift.
questions.description: Designated persons who have been trained for the task are responsible for the various areas of the own-check plan.

questions.question: Beer is not produced with the help of beneficial microbes.
questions.description: Beer is produced with yeast fermentation. Yeast is a beneficial microbe.

questions.question: Coffee cream and milk may be stored in room temperature, because they will be added to hot coffee.
questions.description: Milk and cream are easily perishable food products, and they must be served cold.

questions.question: Listeria bacteria are not destroyed when a product is frozen.
questions.description: Freezing does not destroy microbes. Listeria can also reproduce in frozen foods.

questions.question: When a health inspector inspects a workplace, he or she will also check the workplace's own check plan's monitoring logs.
questions.description: Health inspectors make routine inspections in food production areas. The monitoring logs of the own-check plans are also part of the inspections. The logs must be stored for 1 year in the workplace. Only stored logs can prove that the workplace has followed its own-check plan accordingly.

questions.question: Temperature does not affect the speed of microbe reproduction.
questions.description: Temperatures are very important for the reproduction abilities of microbes. All microbes have their own optimal temperatures where reproduction is the fastest.

questions.question: Disinfectants should be changed regularly.
questions.description: Microbes can become immune to specific disinfectants, and so the disinfectants should be changed from time to time.

questions.question: The same cleaning equipment can be used in both dining areas and food preparation areas.
questions.description: Kitchen facilities and customer areas must have separate cleaning equipment in order to avoid possible disease agents from transferring from one space to the other via cleaning supplies, such as table wiping rags.

questions.question: Customer feedback is not a part of the own-check plan.
questions.description: Customer feedback is part of a company's own-check plan. The own-check plan should also explain how feedback is used.

questions.question: Food poisoning can be caused by careless hand washing.
questions.description: Dirty hands may contain microbes that cause food poisoning.

questions.question: The amount of sugar a product contains does not affect its lastingness.
questions.description: Highly sugared products, such as jams, marmelades and sweets do not perish easily because sugar changes the state of water so that microbes can not reproduce.

questions.question: Food products that contain preservatives can not cause food poisoning.
questions.description: Preservatives prevent and slow down the growth of microbes in food products. However, preservatives do not destroy food poisoning causing bacteria, which makes food poisoning possible.

questions.question: Food tasting must be done with a spoon.
questions.description: Food must never be touched with the fingers if it is not necessary. Spoons should be used for tasting.

questions.question: Dishes do not need to be pre-washed before being put into a washing machine.
questions.description: Before being put into a washing machine, dishes must be pre-washed using cool water to get rid of loose dirt and also to get rid of protein spots so that they will not stick to the surface of the dishes and form biofilm.

questions.question: Food products that have been thawed only once can be refrozen as long as they are packed in hygienic packaging.
questions.description: You must never refreeze food products that have already been thawed.

questions.question: When raw frozen chicken is thawed it releases liquid that can contain salmonella.
questions.description: Raw fowl/poultry meat can always contain salmonella, which will not be destroyed in a freezer. If the meat contains salmonella it will also certainly be in the liquid.

questions.question: The correct concentration of detergent significantly affects the cleaning result.
questions.description: Detergents and disinfectants must be measured out in accordance with the manufacturer's instructions. A solution that is stronger than recommended does not usually guarantee a better cleaning result, and a solution that is diluted too much may give a worse result.

questions.question: If the dish washer is not cleaned regularly, harmful microbes can multiply inside the machine and cause a health risk.
questions.description: Dish washers must also be cleaned regularly according to their instructions and allowed to dry afterwards.

questions.question: Dried products last well due to having no water that bacteria could use to reproduce.
questions.description: Water is necessary for microbes to reproduce. Dried products last well due to having no water.

questions.question: Restaurants must have an own-check plan.
questions.description: All workplaces in the food industry need to ensure the safety of their products with an own-check plan. Own-check plans are required in all food industry workplaces.

questions.question: If an easily perishable food product has been stored in too warm conditions, the use-by-date marked on the package is no longer reliable.
questions.description: The use-by-date is reliable only if the product has been stored correctly. Storing products in too warm conditions always makes the products last for shorter periods of times.

questions.question: Waiters and servers are not required to have headwear.
questions.description: Waiters and servers are allowed to work without headwear.

questions.question: If you have just washed your hands carefully with soap, you can taste food with your finger.
questions.description: You can only taste food using clean cutlery, never with your fingers.

questions.question: Appropriate freezing improves the lastingness of a product.
questions.description: Freezing prevents microbe reproduction because frozen water can not be used by microbes for reproduction. Frozen products have recommended storing times, and freezing never improves the microbiological quality of a product. Frozen products should be defrosted slowly in a cold storage unit when they are going to be used. A product that has been defrosted once can not be frozen again.

questions.question: The serving dishes of coffee cream or coffee milk can be filled many times during a day.
questions.description: Coffee cream or coffee milk must always be served from a clean dish, and after the dish is empty it should be changed and washed.

questions.question: Campylo bacteria is destroyed when a product is heated properly.
questions.description: Campylo bacteria and salmonella are found naturally in fowl and poultry. Both bacteria are destroyed when the meat is cooked thoroughly to over 75 degrees Celsius.

questions.question: All transport companies can transport food to restaurants provided that their vehicles are spacious enough.
questions.description: Professional transporting of food requires certification from the appropriate authorities as well as an own-check plan.

questions.question: Intestinal bacteria cannot spread from hands to food.
questions.description: Intestinal bacteria can spread to food even from the hands.

questions.question: The temperatures of cold storage equipment do not need to be measured if they feel cold enough.
questions.description: The temperatures of refrigerating equipment, drawers and cabinets must be measured and logged at the same time each day. Atypical measuring results are logged in the own-check forms and necessary measures are taken to restore the right temperature in that piece of equipment.

questions.question: When washing dishes, the prewashing should be done with water that is as hot as possible.
questions.description: Prewashing must be done with cool-temperatured water. Too hot water can burn albumin spots onto the surface of the dish and create biofilm, which is a suitable growing environment for microbes.

questions.question: Health inspectors can not inspect a workplace's own-check plan's monitoring logs.
questions.description: Health inspectors make routine inspections in food production areas. The monitoring logs of the own-check plans are also part of the inspections. The logs must be stored for 1 year in the workplace. Only stored logs can prove that the workplace has followed its own-check plan accordingly.

questions.question: Food production areas need to have a changing room.
questions.description: Employees need a changing room which has a separate storage space for clean work clothes.

questions.question: EHEC bacteria are intestinal bacteria.
questions.description: EHEC bacteria is found especially in the intestines of cattle. EHEC bacteria create toxins in the intestines of humans. The toxin often causes bloody diarrhea and very uncomfortable stomache pains.

questions.question: The norovirus is destroyed when a food product is frozen.
questions.description: The norovirus lasts for long amounts of time and is able to spread even in the cold or in frozen foods.

questions.question: Food production areas' food waste must be stored in cool temperatures if possible.
questions.description: Food waste should be stored in cold areas specifically meant for the waste if it is possible. However, it is rare to have so many cold areas that they can also be used separately for waste.

questions.question: In a cramped or nearly full storage facility, food products that can easily perish can be stored on the floor if it has just been washed.
questions.description: Easily perishable food products must always have shelves or a platform in storage facilities. Food products can never be stored on the floor.

questions.question: If canned foods are not sterilized properly, the food can be dangerous for the human health.
questions.description: The cans of canned food can contain spores of clostridium botulinum if the food is not sterilized properly. This spore can create dangerous toxins in the product.

questions.question: Dried products can spoil quickly if they become wet.
questions.description: Dried products last long if they are stored dry. If the products become wet the microbes in them will start to reproduce.

questions.question: Food products must be traceable, i.e. it must be possible, if necessary, to prove from where the raw materials were obtained.
questions.description: Traceability is used to prove from where the raw materials were obtained and to where the finished products have been delivered.

questions.question: Food control authorities must approve a company's own-check plan to allow the company to begin its activites in the industry.
questions.description: Approval from authorities is not required to start activities. The plans are part of the companies' personal documents, which authorities will check and intervene in if problems are noticed.

questions.question: Packages for non-easily perishable food products must have a label indicating their best-before date.
questions.description: Packaging labels for non-easily perishable food products show the best-before date. The accuracy of the date is determined by the product's shelf life. The product may be used after the date if its sensory qualities, such as smell, taste and look are impeccable.

questions.question: Berry kisels can be stored in room temperature because the sugar prevents the growth of harmful bacteria.
questions.description: Berry kisels must be stored in cool temperatures because they can perish due to the large quantity of water in them. The sugar in kisels does not prevent harmful bacteria from growing because the sugar density is much lower than in e.g. jams or marmelade.

questions.question: Thawing frozen food products in a sealed container at room temperature does not increase the risk of food poisoning.
questions.description: Food must be thawed in such a way as to minimise the increase of pathogens as much as possible. A frozen food product is defrosted in a cold room so that the temperature of the food product's surface does not rise above the other parts of the product.

questions.question: Soup made for the following day can be left to cool overnight on the kitchen counter.
questions.description: The rapid cooling and cold storing of soup prevents or slows down the growth of bacteria.

questions.question: The purpose of the own-check plan is to make sure that operators manage the risks associated with food hygiene in their operations.
questions.description: Drawing up and following an own-check plan helps operators to manage the risks associated with food hygiene.

questions.question: Frozen vegetables may contain listeria bacteria.
questions.description: Listeria can be found in unheated food products such as fresh vegetables and products made from these.

questions.question: Oiva-reports must be placed at the entrance of the café, restaurant etc. so that customers can read them.
questions.description: Oiva-reports are published documents about routine inspections. These reports are also published online at www.oivahymy.fi

questions.question: Bacteria spores are destroyed during sterilization.
questions.description: During sterilization (e.g. during canned food production) all microbes and bacteria spores are destroyed. This way easily perishable products will be able to last long in room temperature.

questions.question: Wine is produced with the help of beneficial microbes.
questions.description: The production of wine and beer uses yeast. Yeast is a beneficial microbe.

questions.question: Listeriosis should be avoided especially during pregnancy.
questions.description: Listeriosis during pregnancy can cause miscarriages or premature birth.

questions.question: One of the reasons for the existence of own-check plans is to make the work of food product industry companies easier.
questions.description: Own-check plans that are done well make it easier for companies to upkeep food product safety because resources used for monitoring can be focused on things essential for company activities. Knowledge of the quality of the activities will also improve when the activities are planned. In the best case customer satisfaction, profitability and officials' trust will improve.

questions.question: Minced meat produced in a store can be sold on the day of production and the day after that.
questions.description: Minced meat is an easily perishable food product. Because of this the safety of minced meat produced in a store can not be ensured for a longer period of time. Minced meat should be stored at 4 degrees Celsius.

questions.question: Only reproductive microbes are destroyed during sterilization. Bacteria spores are not destroyed.
questions.description: During sterilization (e.g. during canned food production) all microbes and bacteria spores are destroyed. This way easily perishable products will be able to last long in room temperature.

questions.question: Norwalk-like viruses (NLV) will be destroyed if they are in temperatures higher than 90 degrees Celsius for 2 minutes.
questions.description: Food poisoning causing NLV will be destroyed using heat treatment. However, it can withstand very high temperatures. 2 minutes in over 90 degrees Celsius temperatures is enough to remove the virus from food products.

questions.question: Food products are always safe if the best before date has not yet expired.
questions.description: A food product may be contaminated even if there are still several days until the best before date. Contamination may be caused by unhygienic tools or work environment and incorrect temperatures, for example.

questions.question: The incorrect storing temperature of food is a major cause for food poisoning.
questions.description: If food is stored in too warm temperatures, microbes that cause food poisoning will reproduce quickly. Because of this the temperatures of cold storage units and freezers must be monitored regularly using thermometers.

questions.question: Acidity in a food product prevents the reproduction of bacteria.
questions.description: Bacteria that are a threat to food product safety reproduce the best in the neutral zone. Because of this the growth of these bacteria can be prevented by increasing the acidity of a product.

questions.question: Salmonella bacteria can be found in fowl or poultry.
questions.description: Salmonella can be found in fowl or poultry. Due to the risk of salmonella, the meat of fowl/poultry must always be cooked to at least 75 degrees Celsius.

questions.question: Contamination means e.g. unwanted microbes and/or chemicals spreading into a product.
questions.description: Contamination can be microbiological, chemical or physical. It is unwanted and can cause perishing of food products or food poisoning.

questions.question: Yersinia bacteria has been found on fields and in fresh vegetables that have been spoiled during storage.
questions.description: Yersinia is destroyed when heating a product to over 70 degrees Celsius. Fresh vegetables are often served non-heated, so possible yersinia is not destroyed. Yersinia can also reproduce during storage in refrigerator temperatures.

questions.question: Food poisoning causing bacteria reproduce quickly in Karelian pasties kept in room temperature.
questions.description: Karelian pasties are usually filled with rice porridge boiled in milk. Easily perishable food products, such as Karelian pasties, must be kept in cool temperatures. In room temperature the bacteria in pasties will reproduce quicker.

questions.question: Beer is not produced with the help of beneficial microbes.
questions.description: Beer is produced with yeast fermentation. Yeast is a beneficial microbe.

questions.question: Ice makers do not need to be washed because microbes do not multiply in such a cold environment.
questions.description: Ice makers must be washed regularly. Ice makers and utensils for picking up ice must be kept clean and in good condition, and their lids must be kept closed to prevent dirt from entering the machines. The high number of microbes in ice cubes causes a deterioration in the quality of food products and even food poisoning.

questions.question: When roasting or cooking insects, there is no need to be especially careful.
questions.description: When insects are processed, they must be handled in the same way as other perishable food products.

questions.question: When receiving products one must make sure that they are moved into their appropriate, separate storage areas as soon as possible after the receival check.
questions.description: Products should be moved into their own storage areas as soon as possible after the receival check. Easily perishable food products can not be stored in room temperature for longer than 10-15 minutes.

questions.question: If an employee has infected wounds on his or her hands, he or she can still work with food products if single-use protective gloves are used.
questions.description: Infected wounds contain large amounts of food poisoning causing Staphylococcus aureus bacteria. It is impossible to constantly prevent the bacteria from spreading to food products.

questions.question: Microbes are found everywhere in our environment.
questions.description: Microbes are everywhere, but they can not be seen with the naked eye. Most microbes are not dangerous for food hygiene.

questions.question: Restaurants must have an own-check plan.
questions.description: All workplaces in the food industry need to ensure the safety of their products with an own-check plan. Own-check plans are required in all food industry workplaces.

questions.question: Bacteria reproduce very quickly in products that have high acidity.
questions.description: Bacteria that are a threat to food product safety reproduce the best in the neutral zone. Because of this the growth of these bacteria can be prevented by increasing the acidity of a product.

questions.question: Some toxins produced by moulds in food will withstand heating and cause food poisoning even though the mould itself can get destroyed.
questions.description: Mould toxins can withstand much higher temperatures than the mould itself.

questions.question: Waste bins to be used in kitchens must be water-proof and easily cleanable.
questions.description: Waste bins to be used in kitchens must be water-proof so that waste liquids do not pour onto the floor. They must also be easy to clean so that the cleaning process during emptying is as easy as possible.

questions.question: Biowaste bins do not have to be emptied daily if the bin has not become full.
questions.description: Biowaste bins must be emptied at least once a day because biowaste contains perishing materials.

questions.question: Bacteria spores are destroyed in freezers.
questions.description: Bacteria do not reproduce in freezers. However, the spores of the bacteria do not get destroyed during freezing.

questions.question: Old and worn cleaning equipment can spread harmful microbes into food premises.
questions.description: It is important to make sure that cleaning equipment is always clean and in good condition.

questions.question: Packages of easily perishable food products must have a label indicating their best-before date.
questions.description: Packages of easily perishable food products always require a label indicating the last day of use and storing instructions. The shown date is valid only for unopened products that have been stored in the right temperature.

questions.question: Only old cold storage equipment must have a thermometer.
questions.description: All cold storage equipment in food production areas must have a thermometer.

questions.question: Smoking is allowed at the loading docks of kitchens.
questions.description: Loading docks are a part of food production areas; smoking is not allowed in food production areas.

questions.question: Bacteria toxins can require boiling for 5 hours before they disappear from food.
questions.description: If toxins have appeared in the food, they can cause food poisoning. Only a very long boiling time will get rid of the toxins.

questions.question: Raw fish cannot contain listeria bacteria
questions.description: Raw fish may also contain listeria bacteria.

questions.question: The activity of water contained in food products can be lowered by adding salt or sugar to the product.
questions.description: The activity of water shows how easily the water in a product can be used by microbes. Salt and sugar change the state of water so that the microbes can not use it.

questions.question: Health inspectors can not inspect a workplace's own-check plan's monitoring logs.
questions.description: Health inspectors make routine inspections in food production areas. The monitoring logs of the own-check plans are also part of the inspections. The logs must be stored for 1 year in the workplace. Only stored logs can prove that the workplace has followed its own-check plan accordingly.

questions.question: Temperature measurements are to be made only by the superiors of a workplace.
questions.description: The instructions of own-check plans must be adhered to by all employees. Because of this temperature measurements are also the responsibility of all other employees.

questions.question: Food that is being served only requires temperature measurements if it is being served hot.
questions.description: Temperature measurements must also be done for food that is being served cold.

questions.question: The shelf life of spices can be prolonged by radiation.
questions.description: UV, infra red and gamma radiation can be used to destroy microbes from for example spices and pastries that are made to last for long periods of storage.

questions.question: Thawing frozen products in cold rooms or refrigerators is a hygienic risk because the thawing happens too slowly.
questions.description: If food products are thawed in room temperature, the products' surfaces will melt quicker than the insides. The surfaces will start to spoil even though the insides can still be frozen. Thawing in cold rooms takes a longer amount of time but the cold room's temperature will allow very few microbes to reproduce.

questions.question: Own-check plans must include clear instructions on how to act when food poisoning suspicions are raised.
questions.description: When food is prepared for customers, food poisoning events must be planned for in advance. Own-check plans must include clear instructions for these events. It is important to notify health inspectors about suspicions immediately.

questions.question: The waste disposal instructions for a food production area need to tell who is responsible for emptying the area's waste into the waste room's recycling bins.
questions.description: The waste disposal instructions need to tell which waste disposal company takes care of transporting waste away from the waste room, but the waste in the food production area needs to always be moved into the waste room at least after the work shift is over.

questions.question: Few bacteria can reproduce in acidized products.
questions.description: Bacteria that are a threat to food product hygiene reproduce the best when in the neutral zone. Bacteria growth especially can be prevented by increasing the acidity of a product.

questions.question: Dirty root vegetables and pre-made food products can not be stored in the same cold room.
questions.description: Dirt always contains many microbes. Dirty root vegetables must be handled separately from other products so that the microbes in the dirt do not spread to other food products.

questions.question: The use of snus (similar to chewing tobacco) is not allowed during food preparation.
questions.description: When handling food products personal hygiene is important; snus must not be used because of hygienic reasons.

questions.question: Waste disposal is not a part of the own-check plan.
questions.description: Waste disposal is a part of the own-check plan. Health inspectors also pay attention to how well waste is disposed of in food related premises. The regular emptying and cleaning of waste containers must be looked after.

questions.question: Raw milk can contain yersinia.
questions.description: Raw milk has not been pasteurized. Yersinia is destroyed when milk is heated to over 70 degrees Celsius; in other words it is destroyed when the milk is pasteurized.

questions.question: If a food premises changes owners, this must always be reported to the local food authority.
questions.description: When a food premises changes owners, this must always be reported to the local food authority.

questions.question: If the product being handled is fresh and of good quality, the handling hygiene is not as important.
questions.description: Hygienic handling methods and equipment are always important for the lastingness of products. A fresh and good quality good will still perish easily if it is handled unhygienically.

questions.question: Ice makers do not need to be washed because microbes do not multiply in such a cold environment.
questions.description: Ice makers must be washed regularly. Ice makers and utensils for picking up ice must be kept clean and in good condition, and their lids must be kept closed to prevent dirt from entering the machines. The high number of microbes in ice cubes causes a deterioration in the quality of food products and even food poisoning.

questions.question: If food does not smell bad it can not be spoiled.
questions.description: Many food poisoning causing bacteria can reproduce in food without causing changes that can be noticed with the senses (visually, smell etc.)

questions.question: Bacteria spores are destroyed when products are boiled (+100 degrees Celsius).
questions.description: Bacteria spores are destroyed only during sterilization. In excess pressure the temperature is raised to about 145 degrees Celsius and this way bacteria spores are also destroyed.

questions.question: Dried products last well due to having no water that bacteria could use to reproduce.
questions.description: Water is necessary for microbes to reproduce. Dried products last well due to having no water.

questions.question: Food products containing food poisoning bacteria can always be noticed by bad smells and other visual perishing symptoms.
questions.description: Food poisoning bacteria can not be noticed using the senses (visually etc.) in food products. Perished food products might contain food poisoning bacteria, but the bacteria might not cause any changes in the appearance of the food product.

questions.question: The results of Oiva-reports can be viewed by anyone online.
questions.description: The Oiva system is used to allow consumers to view the results of routine inspections.

questions.question: Workers in the food industry can be found responsible for a customer becoming sick.
questions.description: Product liability laws also cover food products. If a customer is able to provide sufficient evidence, a worker in the food industry can be found responsible for causing a sickness in the customer.

questions.question: Mashed potato is not an easily perishable food product.
questions.description: Pre-made foods are easily perishable products. Easily perishable foods must be stored in the cold, under 6 degrees Celsius.

questions.question: In Finland the milk found in cartons in stores is almost always pasteurized milk.
questions.description: Only raw milk that has been bought directly from a dairy farm is not usually pasteurized.

questions.question: Own-check plans do not need to include clear instructions on how to act when food poisoning suspicions are raised.
questions.description: When food is prepared for customers, food poisoning events must be planned for in advance. Own-check plans must include clear instructions for these events. It is important to notify health inspectors about suspicions immediately.

questions.question: Pasteurizing and ultra-high-temperature processing (UHT) mean the same thing.
questions.description: Ultra-high-temperature processing is done in much higher temperatures than pasteurizing. UHT destroys most bacteria spores and because of this products that have been treated with UHT can be stored in room temperature.

questions.question: A waiter must be able to tell customers the ingredients of a food product that has not been packed.
questions.description: A waiter must be able to provide customers with information about food products verbally and, if necessary, also in writing.

questions.question: During food preparation one can sometimes go wash one's hands in the staff restroom.
questions.description: There must be a separate hand washing spot in immediate proximity to the food preparation area.

questions.question: Officials will prepare an own-check plan for new companies in the food product industry.
questions.description: Companies in the food product industry must prepare their own own-check plan when starting their activities. The plan must be followed and updated when needed.

questions.question: All food that is being served needs to be sampled daily.
questions.description: Taken samples must be placed into a container and then placed into a freezer. If food poisonings are suspected, then these samples must be available for research.

questions.question: Food poisoning causing bacteria reproduce quickly in Karelian pasties kept in room temperature.
questions.description: Karelian pasties are usually filled with rice porridge boiled in milk. Easily perishable food products, such as Karelian pasties, must be kept in cool temperatures. In room temperature the bacteria in pasties will reproduce quicker.

questions.question: Food can be tasted with the fingers.
questions.description: Food must never be touched with the fingers if it is not necessary. Spoons should be used for tasting.

questions.question: The training of personnel is an important part of own-check plans.
questions.description: The training of personnel is an essential part of own-check plans. In the food industry technology, equipment, ingredients, preparation methods and even risks change, so it is important to update knowledge regularly.

questions.question: Temperature does not affect the reproduction speed of microbes.
questions.description: Temperatures are very important for the reproduction abilities of microbes. The insides of humans and animals often contain the optimal temperature for microbes, between 20 and 45 degrees Celsius.

questions.question: Rings and other hand jewellery as well as watches must be removed when working with easily perishable food products.
questions.description: Jewellery and watches are not part of a food product employee's work uniform. Microbes, dirt and chemicals can easily stay underneath them even after washing one's hands, and these can later spread while working. Earrings and piercings on one's face can also be a hazard to hygienic working.

questions.question: Hand washing areas must be used only for washing hands.
questions.description: Hand washing areas can not be used for other washing purposes; this helps to prevent microbes from spreading in food production areas.

questions.question: Waste disposal is not a part of the own-check plan.
questions.description: Waste disposal is a part of the own-check plan. Health inspectors also pay attention to how well waste is disposed of in food related premises. The regular emptying and cleaning of waste containers must be looked after.

questions.question: Cooked rice is not an easily perishable food product.
questions.description: Dry rice lasts in room temperature. Cooked rice contains moisture and because of this it is an easily perishable product. Cooked rice must be stored under 6 degrees Celsius.

questions.question: Blanching improves the lastingness of for example vegetables when they are stored in freezing.
questions.description: Blanching, which means quick boiling, stops enzymic activity on the surface of vegetables by destroying microbe activity. This way vegetables do not dry on the surface while freezing them. Blanching can also be used for example to get rid of naturally occuring toxins in morel mushrooms to make them edible. In this case blanching is done many times and the boiling water is changed between boilings.

questions.question: The monitoring logs made for own-check plans, e.g. logs of temperature measurements, must be stored at the workplace for 6 months.
questions.description: Logs must be stored for at least 1 year after selling a product. The information included can be used to trace errors and problems.

questions.question: Washed, clean dishes can only be handled with clean hands.
questions.description: If clean dishes are handled with dirty hands, microbes and dirt will spread from the hands onto the dishes.

questions.question: Raw ingredients containing gluten must be labelled and stored in closed containers in a storage room.
questions.description: Raw ingredients containing allergens and gluten must be labelled and stored separately in closed containers.

questions.question: Food products containing food poisoning bacteria can always be noticed by bad smells and other visual perishing symptoms.
questions.description: Food poisoning bacteria can not be noticed using the senses (visually etc.) in food products. Perished food products might contain food poisoning bacteria, but the bacteria might not cause any changes in the appearance of the food product.

questions.question: Food products can be sold after the last use-by-date if it is sold at a discount price.
questions.description: The last use-by-date must be marked on easily perishable food products. The products can not be used nor sold after this date.

questions.question: All cold storage equipment must have a thermometer.
questions.description: Own-check plans require to monitor the temperature of cold storage equipment. If the equipment does not thermometers, the monitoring is impossible to do.

questions.question: All microbes are harmful to humans.
questions.description: Many food products also have in them naturally beneficial microbes, and with many food manufacturing processes microbes have an essential role, like for example making beer and fermented vegetables.

questions.question: A food poisoning epidemic is a situation where at least 10 people have become sick with similar symptoms after consuming the same food product or ingredient.
questions.description: A food poisoning epidemic means a situation where at least 2 people have become sick with similar symptoms after consuming the same food or drink.

questions.question: A wound that has been cleaned must also be carefully covered with a bandage.
questions.description: A cleaned wound may spread harmful microbes to food products.

questions.question: Plants can be displayed and sold anywhere in a grocery store as long as adequate ventilation is provided.
questions.description: Plants must be located as far as possible from unpackaged perishable food products. There are lots of microbes on the surface of plants and in the soil, and these may spread to food products.

questions.question: Bear meat must be checked for trichinella spiralis.
questions.description: Bear meat can contain trichinella spiralis. All carcasses that are going to be sold must be checked for trichinella spiralis. Proper heating will destroy the parasite.

questions.question: A tool made of wood is a hygiene hazard.
questions.description: Wood is a porous material and can absorb water, dirt and detergents, and it can stay damp for a long time.

questions.question: The cleanliness of waste rooms is not essential for hygiene because only waste is stored in those rooms.
questions.description: The cleanliness and hygiene of waste rooms is an essential part of taking care of food product hygiene because employees enter the waste room during the work day while wearing their work clothes, which they wear everywhere else as well. Waste rooms must be kept clean and organised.

questions.question: Visually clean work surfaces guarantee their microbiological cleanliness.
questions.description: Microbiological cleanliness can not be guaranteed by using just the bare eye. Correct cleaning methods and equipment, as well as regular and proper cleaning, guarantee the cleanliness much better. Samples can also be taken of the cleanliness of specific surfaces if required.

questions.question: Unpeeled and peeled carrots will last the same amount of time as long as they are stored in the cold.
questions.description: Earthy and dirty, untreated root vegetables will last long in appropriate cold storage units, but all treatments will worsen their lastingness.

questions.question: The purpose of the own-check plan is to make sure that operators manage the risks associated with food hygiene in their operations.
questions.description: Drawing up and following an own-check plan helps operators to manage the risks associated with food hygiene.

questions.question: Staphylococcus bacteria, which cause food poisoning, are part of the normal flora on the hands and mucous membranes.
questions.description: The skin is a good environment for many bacteria, and the skin usually has a lot of different bacteria as part of its normal flora.

questions.question: If a food premises changes owners, this must always be reported to the local food authority.
questions.description: When a food premises changes owners, this must always be reported to the local food authority.

questions.question: A food production area means an area in which food is prepared.
questions.description: A food production area is any building, room, part of a room or some other indoor or outdoor space where food meant to be sold or otherwise handed onwards is prepared, stored, transported, kept on sale, served or treated in some other way.

questions.question: Working areas and surfaces must be cleaned regularly during work shifts and after work is over.
questions.description: Regular cleaning, done every 2-4 hours, of working equipment and surfaces with clean cleaning equipment, substances and water gets rid of leftover pieces of food, dust and other dirt that protects microorganisms and is used as living space by the organisms.

questions.question: All food that is being served needs to be sampled daily.
questions.description: Taken samples must be placed into a container and then placed into a freezer. If food poisonings are suspected, then these samples must be available for research.

questions.question: Salmonella infection can only be acquired from foreign food products.
questions.description: Salmonella can be transmitted through both domestic and foreign food products or water contaminated with animal or human faeces, and it can cause food poisoning.

questions.question: Vegetables and fruit must be washed prior to food preparation with water that meets the requirements of household water.
questions.description: Taps in any food preparation space must provide water that meets the requirements of household water, which is used in preparing and making food as well as by staff to wash their hands.

questions.question: If the temperature of a cold storage unit is too high it must not be marked down on the own-check plan's monitoring logs.
questions.description: Measured temperatures must be marked down in the own-check plan's monitoring logs, even if they are too high or too low. The logs must also contain information on what fixing procedure has been made to correct the incorrect temperature.

questions.question: Waste bins can be placed in the dry food storage room if there is no other place for them.
questions.description: The waste management of food premises must be arranged so that waste and food products do not come into contact with each other.

questions.question: Food poisoning is always caused by bacteria.
questions.description: The cause of food poisoning can, in addition to bacteria, also be a virus, mould fungus or protozoan.

questions.question: Cleaning equipment that is old and in bad condition can spread harmful microbes to a food production area.
questions.description: Cleaning equipment wears down and becomes dirty during use. They often contain microbes even though they are washed regularly. Cleaning equipment should be renewed regularly.

questions.question: The surfaces of work station tables must be cleaned properly only after the work shift is over.
questions.description: A regular cleaning every 2-4 hours of work station surfaces gets rid of leftover food pieces, fat, dust and other dirt which protects micro-organisms and gives them living space.

questions.question: Dirty root vegetables must have a separate work space.
questions.description: Dirt always contains many microbes. Dirty root vegetables must be handled separately from other products so that the microbes in the dirt do not spread to other food products.

questions.question: Wooden utensils are well suited for professional kitchens if they are washed in a washing machine on a sufficiently hot program.
questions.description: Wooden utensils should not be used in professional kitchens, as they do not withstand repeated washes in a washing machine. Materials must very durable in order to cope with repeated washes, like for example plastic and steel utensils that are meant for food product related use.

questions.question: The purpose of own-check plans is to prevent mistakes and problematic situations from occurring during food preparation and serving.
questions.description: Good own-check plans as well as good knowledge of the own-check plan's contents by the personnel prevents problematic situations and makes it easier to identify the causes of any noticed problems.

questions.question: Actions made after noticing mistakes or abnormalities in the packaging or quality of food products during receival checks must be logged in the own-check plan.
questions.description: Mistakes or abnormalities noticed in the quality or packaging of food products must be logged into the own-check plan. It is also required to detailedly log what actions are made after noticing a mistake or abnormality and who is responsible for informing for example the supplier of the products about it.

questions.question: The state and cleanliness of the waste management room does not affect the kitchen's hygienic quality.
questions.description: The waste management room must also be kept organised and clean. A dirty waste management room and badly cleaned waste bins can collect pests and spread microbes that are harmful for food products.

questions.question: A restaurant can use food products after their best before date has expired provided that the products are sufficiently well heated well.
questions.description: It is prohibited to sell or use food products after their best before date has expired, and they must not be used in the manufacture of food to be sold or served.

questions.question: If the film/foil of a vacuum-package is loose or tensionless the package is damaged.
questions.description: The package has probably been broken and air has entered it. The lastingness of the product can not be estimated after this, because the use-by-date marked on the package is based on the assumption that the package contains no air (oxygen that microbes can use to grow.)

questions.question: Food poisoning symptoms always start within one day of consuming a perished food product.
questions.description: Food poisoning symptoms can already begin in one hour since consuming a perished food product, but they can also begin after many days of no symptoms.

questions.question: Dried products last well due to having no water that bacteria could use to reproduce.
questions.description: Water is necessary for microbes to reproduce. Dried products last well due to having no water.

questions.question: Hands must be washed after sneezing and blowing one's nose.
questions.description: Microbes spread onto the hands when sneezing and blowing one's nose. If the hands are not washed, these bacteria will easily spread onto food products.

questions.question: A food production area means an area in which food is prepared.
questions.description: A food production area is any building, room, part of a room or some other indoor or outdoor space where food meant to be sold or otherwise handed onwards is prepared, stored, transported, kept on sale, served or treated in some other way.

questions.question: Intestinal bacteria cannot spread from hands to food.
questions.description: Intestinal bacteria can spread to food even from the hands.

questions.question: Chefs are allowed to handle money and prepare food without washing their hands in between.
questions.description: Notes and coins contain a lot of microbes, and you must always wash your hands after handling money before you start cooking.

questions.question: Bacteria spores are not destroyed during boiling.
questions.description: Bacteria spores are destroyed only during sterilization. In excess pressure the temperature is raised to about 145 degrees Celsius and this way bacteria spores are also destroyed.

questions.question: A food product can only be a health hazard if it has a contaminated area that is visible to the naked eye.
questions.description: Growth on the surfaces of food products caused by moulds and yeasts are visible to the naked eye, but microbes are usually microorganisms that are not visible to the naked eye.

questions.question: Pet animals can carry food poisoning causing parasites and protozoa.
questions.description: Pet animals can carry different disease causers in their fur, paws and feces. Pet animals can not be allowed inside food preparation areas. Pet animals are allowed in dining areas if the merchant allows it.

questions.question: Moulds and yeasts can reproduce in more acidized environments than bacteria.
questions.description: Most bacteria reproduce the best in the neutral zone. Moulds and yeasts can reproduce on a very broad pH zone, including products with acidity.

questions.question: Campylo bacteria is destroyed when a product is heated properly.
questions.description: Campylo bacteria and salmonella are found naturally in fowl and poultry. Both bacteria are destroyed when the meat is cooked thoroughly to over 75 degrees Celsius.

questions.question: Water is not necessary for microbes to reproduce.
questions.description: Dried products last well due to having no water that bacteria could use to reproduce. Microbes can't reproduce in dried products.

questions.question: It is enough to visually monitor the results of cleaning and washing.
questions.description: The results of cleaning and washing and the need for cleaning needs to be monitored regularly. It is required to name a responsible person for this task in the own-check plan and to form a monitoring plan to use. As well as doing visual inspections, the monitoring can also be done by taking microbiological samples from work surfaces and equipment by for example using Hygicult sample strips.

questions.question: The own-check plan has been created to make it easier for health officials to do their job.
questions.description: Own-check plans and measurement charts are the establishment's own documents that are supposed to emphasize the actor's own responsibility in controlling risks. If there are any problems, it is afterwords easier to find out what caused them. Officials check plans and interfere with defects if necessary.

questions.question: Listeria bacteria are not destroyed when a product is frozen.
questions.description: Freezing does not destroy microbes. Listeria can also reproduce in frozen foods.

questions.question: Carrots covered with soil do not contain harmful microbes because soil is a pure natural product.
questions.description: Many microbes are part of the normal microbial growth in soil, which means that carrots covered in soil contain microbes.

questions.question: The fresh fish that has been up for retail sale during the day can, with the decision and permission of the store, be smoked during the evening and then sold.
questions.description: Fish that has been on the sales counter can not be smoked for the next day's sales. This is against the ethics of food product law and deceives consumers. If fish has been up for retail sale during the day, its sales time must not continue by smoking it.

questions.question: A microbiological sample of a food product can be placed in any container.
questions.description: A microbiological sample of a food product must always be placed in a container that is definitely clean.

questions.question: Dirty root vegetables must have a separate work space.
questions.description: Dirt always contains many microbes. Dirty root vegetables must be handled separately from other products so that the microbes in the dirt do not spread to other food products.

questions.question: Disinfecting reduces the amount of microbes from work surfaces and equipment.
questions.description: Correctly done disinfection reduces the amount of microbes excellently on work surfaces and equipment.

questions.question: People do not have any microbes on their skin if they shower regularly.
questions.description: There are microbes everywhere in soil, water, dust and also on human and animal skin.

questions.question: A restaurant can use food products after their best before date has expired provided that the products are sufficiently well heated well.
questions.description: It is prohibited to sell or use food products after their best before date has expired, and they must not be used in the manufacture of food to be sold or served.

questions.question: Cleaning plans are not a part of own-check plans.
questions.description: Cleaning plans are an important part of own-check plans. Cleaning plans include instructions and schedules for cleaning.

questions.question: A delivery load that contains meat and fish products can be safely left at room temperature for three hours pending transfer into cold storage.
questions.description: The cold chain of perishable food products must not be interrupted at any point in the supply chain.

questions.question: The shelf life of spices can be prolonged by radiation.
questions.description: UV, infra red and gamma radiation can be used to destroy microbes from for example spices and pastries that are made to last for long periods of storage.

questions.question: Single-use gloves are used to protect the food preparer from microbes on the food products.
questions.description: The first priority of using single-use gloves is to protect the food products from microbes on the hands.

questions.question: Only old cold storage equipment must have a thermometer.
questions.description: All cold storage equipment in food production areas must have a thermometer.

questions.question: Hand washing areas must be used only for washing hands.
questions.description: Hand washing areas can not be used for other washing purposes; this helps to prevent microbes from spreading in food production areas.

questions.question: A working and up-to-date collection of recipes is part of the own-check plan.
questions.description: Regularly served food needs to have up-to-date recipes. Recipes can be used to check what different foods contain and how they are prepared during any problematic situations.

questions.question: Waste disposal is not a part of the own-check plan.
questions.description: The own-check plan always includes instructions for waste disposal. How much the instructions cover always depends on the activities and what the activities cover. It is important to set daily assignments and responsibility areas.

questions.question: Biowaste bins do not have to be emptied daily if the bin has not become full.
questions.description: Biowaste bins must be emptied at least once a day because biowaste contains perishing materials.

questions.question: New products that are to be moved into cold storage are placed where there is enough room for them.
questions.description: In cold storage older products are placed in front and newer ones in the back. Older products are always to be used first. This is called the first in-first out principle.

questions.question: Listeria and yersinia can reproduce in refrigerator temperatures.
questions.description: Earth and various bodies of water contain microbes, such as listeria and yersinia, that are able to survive cold conditions well. Listeria and yersinia can reproduce in very cold refrigerator temperatures.

questions.question: An establishment's own-check plan is in effect for 10 years at a time.
questions.description: The own-check plan must be updated if need arises. It is useful to go over the plan regularly and to assess whether or not there have been changes in the establishment's functioning or protocols that require changes to made in the plan as well. Changes in the regulations of the food industry may necessitate changes in own-check plans as well.

questions.question: The mould used to make mould-ripened cheese cannot grow anywhere else.
questions.description: The mould used to make mould-ripened cheese can grow on other food products. It causes mould to grow on the surfaces of food products that spoils them.

questions.question: Pet dog hair cannot spread microbes into food products.
questions.description: Pet hair can spread microbes into food products.

questions.question: The activity of water contained in food products can be lowered by adding salt or sugar to the product.
questions.description: The activity of water shows how easily the water in a product can be used by microbes. Salt and sugar change the state of water so that the microbes can not use it.

questions.question: Chopping vegetables improves their shelf life.
questions.description: Whole vegetables keep better than chopped vegetables. Handling food products impairs their shelf life.

questions.question: If the product being handled is fresh and of good quality, the handling hygiene is not as important.
questions.description: Hygienic handling methods and equipment are always important for the lastingness of products. A fresh and good quality good will still perish easily if it is handled unhygienically.

questions.question: Staphylococcus aureus is a food poisoning bacteria.
questions.description: The human skin, nose and mucous membranes can contain staphylococcus aureus. Good hand hygiene is important due to this.

questions.question: Bacteria are always harmful on human skin or in the intestines.
questions.description: Beneficial bacteria exist on the skin and in the intestines that protect humans from harmful bacteria and strengthen the immune system.

questions.question: If a product or ingredient is suspected to be the cause of food poisoning in a customer, the product or ingredient should be gotten rid of as soon as possible.
questions.description: Suspected causes of food poisoning must not be gotten rid of but must instead be stored so that it can be examined in a laboratory to find the cause of the poisoning.

questions.question: It is important to change disposable gloves often enough.
questions.description: When working with food, you must change disposable gloves whenever you start a new work phase.

questions.question: Food control authorities must approve a company's own-check plan to allow the company to begin its activites in the industry.
questions.description: Approval from authorities is not required to start activities. The plans are part of the companies' personal documents, which authorities will check and intervene in if problems are noticed.

questions.question: The shelf life of food products can be extended by irradiating them.
questions.description: Only dried aromatic herbs, spices and vegetable seasonings are allowed to be irradiated. The purpose of irradiation is to eliminate bacteria and insects as well as to prevent the product from sprouting, for example.

questions.question: If you drop a steak onto the floor, you can use it as long as you fry it.
questions.description: A steak that has fallen onto the floor must never be used for cooking. Food products must never be stored on the floor.

questions.question: Working areas and equipment must always be cleaned by using plenty of water.
questions.description: Water is an important part of cleaning and washing. Water acts as a solvent and substance that transports dirt away. However it is also important to dry the surfaces and equipment properly, because microbes grow and reproduce easily in moist environments.

questions.question: Eating is not allowed while preparing food.
questions.description: Microbes in the mouth spread onto the hands while eating. Eating must be done in a separate area and after eating hands must be washed.

questions.question: Salmonella can only get transmitted through feces.
questions.description: Salmonella can get transmitted through feces by way of poor hand hygiene but also via contaminated food products, such as raw meat and eggs.

questions.question: Plants can be displayed and sold anywhere in a grocery store as long as adequate ventilation is provided.
questions.description: Plants must be located as far as possible from unpackaged perishable food products. There are lots of microbes on the surface of plants and in the soil, and these may spread to food products.

questions.question: In commercial kitchens, it is necessary to nominate the people in charge of the own-check plan.
questions.description: Designated persons who have been trained for the task are responsible for the various areas of the own-check plan.

questions.question: Tap water does not contain microbes.
questions.description: Even tap water can contain microbes. Tap water cleanliness must be monitored using the senses. Water samples can also be regularly sent for chemical and microbiological inspections.

questions.question: Yersinia bacteria has been found on fields and in fresh vegetables that have been spoiled during storage.
questions.description: Yersinia is destroyed when heating a product to over 70 degrees Celsius. Fresh vegetables are often served non-heated, so possible yersinia is not destroyed. Yersinia can also reproduce during storage in refrigerator temperatures.

questions.question: Dirty root vegetables can be handled in the same area where desserts are produced.
questions.description: Dirt always contains many microbes. Dirty root vegetables must be handled separately from other products so that the microbes in the dirt do not spread to other food products.

questions.question: Campylo bacteria is destroyed when a product is heated properly.
questions.description: Campylo bacteria and salmonella are found naturally in fowl and poultry. Both bacteria are destroyed when the meat is cooked thoroughly to over 75 degrees Celsius.

questions.question: Customers and employees are allowed to use the same toilet.
questions.description: Strict toilet and hand hygiene must be used in food production. This is not possible if toilets are shared with customers. Customers may have diseases, can be drunk or they can be small children; in each case the use of the same toilets is a risk.

questions.question: The amount of sugar a product contains does not affect its lastingness.
questions.description: Highly sugared products, such as jams, marmelades and sweets do not perish easily because sugar changes the state of water so that microbes can not reproduce.

questions.question: Dirty root vegetables must have a separate work space.
questions.description: Dirt always contains many microbes. Dirty root vegetables must be handled separately from other products so that the microbes in the dirt do not spread to other food products.

questions.question: The results of Oiva-reports can be viewed by anyone online.
questions.description: The Oiva system is used to allow consumers to view the results of routine inspections.

questions.question: Foreign raspberries may be used for making food if the product will be kept well refrigerated.
questions.description: Foreign raspberies must always be properly heated by boiling before serving. Using non-heated foreign rasberries creates a risk of listeria.

questions.question: Food poisoning can be caused by careless hand washing.
questions.description: Dirty hands may contain microbes that cause food poisoning.

questions.question: Raw milk is not suitable for people with a weakened immune system.
questions.description: Because raw milk has not been pasteurized it can contain pathogens (disease-causing bacteria.) The most important bacteria that can cause danger to food safety in raw milk are EHEC, listeria, salmonella and campylo bacteria.

questions.question: Disinfected work surfaces contain no microbes.
questions.description: Correctly done disinfection reduces the amount of microbes excellently on work surfaces and equipment. However, a disinfected work surface is not sterile.

questions.question: Optimal temperature means the temperature where microbes reproduce the slowest.
questions.description: All microbes have their own optimal temperatures where reproduction is the fastest. In the insides of humans and animals, the temperature range between 20 and 45 degrees Celsius is the best for microbes. Anything hotter or colder than this causes microbes to reproduce slower.

questions.question: Customers and employees must have their own, separate toilets.
questions.description: Strict toilet and hand hygiene must be used in food production. This is not possible if toilets are shared with customers.

questions.question: Cleaning equipment do not need a separate storage area.
questions.description: It's not always necessary to have a separate storage space for cleaning equipment. Food production areas need a separate storage, maintenance and drying space if the food production area requires it for constructional reasons. It's important to make sure that there are no risks for food safety and the hygienic treatment, maintenance and storage of cleaning equipment are done properly. If necessary the working stages and functions has to be separated structually or timely.

questions.question: Easily perishable food products do not require a storage instruction label if it is a commonly known product.
questions.description: Packages of easily perishable food products always require a label indicating the last day of use and storing instructions. The shown date is valid only for unopened products that have been stored in the right temperature.

questions.question: Vinegar lowers the pH value of a product and in this way makes the product last for a shorter amount of time.
questions.description: Especially the growth of bacteria can be prevented by increasing the acidity of a product.

questions.question: All monitoring logs made for own-check plans must be stored for at least a year at the workplace.
questions.description: Only stored monitoring logs can prove that the own-check plan has been adhered to.

questions.question: Suspicions of food poisoning are not a part of own-check plans because health officials will investigate the cause of disease if necessary.
questions.description: Own-check plans must have clear instructions for dealing with food poisoning cases and suspicions. Responsible people and methods of informing should be explained in the own-check plan.

questions.question: The own-check plan has been created to make it easier for health officials to do their job.
questions.description: Own-check plans and measurement charts are the establishment's own documents that are supposed to emphasize the actor's own responsibility in controlling risks. If there are any problems, it is afterwords easier to find out what caused them. Officials check plans and interfere with defects if necessary.

questions.question: During the cooling of food microbes are not able to reproduce in the food.
questions.description: The danger zone for food temperatures is between 6 and 60 degrees Celsius. Microbes can reproduce in food when the temperature is within this danger zone. During the cooling of food the food is within this danger zone.

questions.question: When receiving food products it is enough to check their temperature.
questions.description: When receiving food products it is also required to check the products' appearance, the quality of the packaging and the packaging markings with the senses (visually etc.).

questions.question: Cleaning equipment storage rooms must be cleaned regularly.
questions.description: All parts of a food production area must be cleaned regularly according to the cleaning plan.

questions.question: Lactic acid bacteria (LAB) are used when producing yoghurt.
questions.description: Yoghurt and other fermented milk products use LAB in their production. LAB create lactic acid, which cause acidity in the products.

questions.question: A food manufacturer is responsible for date labelling (best before date or use by date).
questions.description: A food manufacturer or packer is responsible for correct date labelling.

questions.question: Norovirus is not spread in water.
questions.description: Norovirus infection can also be acquired from contaminated water.

questions.question: Own-check plans do not need to include clear instructions on how to act when food poisoning suspicions are raised.
questions.description: When food is prepared for customers, food poisoning events must be planned for in advance. Own-check plans must include clear instructions for these events. It is important to notify health inspectors about suspicions immediately.

questions.question: Washing machines do not need to be washed separately, because the washing temperatures are hot enough to destroy harmful microbes.
questions.description: Washing machines, as well as their dust filters and other removable parts, must be washed and dried regularly. The surfaces of the machines must also be swiped and the lids left open so that the machine's inside dries.

questions.question: A food poisoning epidemic is a situation where at least 10 people have become sick with similar symptoms after consuming the same food product or ingredient.
questions.description: A food poisoning epidemic means a situation where at least 2 people have become sick with similar symptoms after consuming the same food or drink.

questions.question: Food production areas need to have a changing room.
questions.description: Employees need a changing room which has a separate storage space for clean work clothes.

questions.question: Ultra-high-temperature processing (UHT) uses higher temperatures than pasteurizing.
questions.description: Ultra-high-temperature processing is done in much higher temperatures than pasteurizing. UHT destroys most bacteria spores and because of this products that have been treated with UHT can be stored in room temperature.

questions.question: Pet dogs can not be taken inside a café even with the permission of the owner of the café.
questions.description: If the owner gives permission, a pet dog can be taken inside the customer areas of a café. Guide dogs are always allowed inside customer areas, even without asking for permission.

questions.question: Biowaste bins do not have to be emptied daily if the bin has not become full.
questions.description: Biowaste bins must be emptied at least once a day because biowaste contains perishing materials.

questions.question: Raw milk contains less microbes than pasteurized milk.
questions.description: When milk is pasteurized a large amount of microbes gets destroyed. For example listeria, salmonella and EHEC bacteria are destroyed during pasteurization. The bacteria in raw milk have not been destroyed with heat treatment.

questions.question: Dishes do not need to be pre-washed before being put into a washing machine.
questions.description: Before being put into a washing machine, dishes must be pre-washed using cool water to get rid of loose dirt and also to get rid of protein spots so that they will not stick to the surface of the dishes and form biofilm.

questions.question: A microbiological sample of a food product can be placed in any container.
questions.description: A microbiological sample of a food product must always be placed in a container that is definitely clean.

questions.question: If canned foods are not sterilized properly, the food can be dangerous for the human health.
questions.description: The cans of canned food can contain spores of clostridium botulinum if the food is not sterilized properly. This spore can create dangerous toxins in the product.

questions.question: Protective gloves are used to protect employees' hands from dirt, so that their hands do not need to be washed as often.
questions.description: Gloves are also used to protect food from microbes spread by hands. Gloves are a great way to keep work hygiene good when tasks must be changed quickly. Gloves must be changed regularly enough while working to keep hygiene good. It is also good to properly wash and dry one's hands when changing gloves. Gloves must always be changed immediately after touching door handles or taps.

questions.question: Water is not necessary for microbes to reproduce.
questions.description: Dried products last well due to having no water that bacteria could use to reproduce. Microbes can't reproduce in dried products.

questions.question: Listeria bacteria are destroyed when a product is frozen.
questions.description: Freezing does not destroy microbes. Listeria can also reproduce in frozen foods.

questions.question: Employers have the responsibility to monitor the health of employees and thus make sure that they are capable of working.
questions.description: All employees have the responsibility to tell their superiors about illnesses or any symptoms hazardous to food product safety, such as diarrhea, a sore throat, inflamed wounds or inflamed respiratory ducts. Employees with such symptoms must not handle food products.

questions.question: Cleaning plans are not a part of own-check plans.
questions.description: Cleaning plans are an important part of own-check plans. Cleaning plans include instructions and schedules for cleaning.

questions.question: Any mould can be used in the production of mould-ripened cheese.
questions.description: Only certain moulds are suitable for making mould-ripened cheeses.

questions.question: The slow cooling of food is one of the main causes of food poisoning.
