questions.description: The slower food is cooled to under 8 degrees Celsius, the longer food poisoning causing microbes have time to reproduce quickly in optimal conditions. Food should be cooled to under 8 degrees in under 4 hours. When preparing large amounts of food at the same time, the cooling can take too long.

questions.question: Instructions for waste disposal are included in the own-check plan.
questions.description: The own-check plan for a food premises always includes instructions for food waste disposal.

questions.question: Salmonella infection can only be acquired from foreign food products.
questions.description: Salmonella can be transmitted through both domestic and foreign food products or water contaminated with animal or human faeces, and it can cause food poisoning.

questions.question: Thawing frozen products in cold rooms or refrigerators is a hygienic risk because the thawing happens too slowly.
questions.description: If food products are thawed in room temperature, the products' surfaces will melt quicker than the insides. The surfaces will start to spoil even though the insides can still be frozen. Thawing in cold rooms takes a longer amount of time but the cold room's temperature will allow very few microbes to reproduce.

questions.question: Food must not be served heated for over 2 hours.
questions.description: Food served / sold hot may be kept in a temperature-controlled bath (min +60 degrees) for a maximum of four hours, after which the food must be replaced.

questions.question: The own-check plan has been created to make it easier for health officials to do their job.
questions.description: Own-check plans and measurement charts are the establishment's own documents that are supposed to emphasize the actor's own responsibility in controlling risks. If there are any problems, it is afterwords easier to find out what caused them. Officials check plans and interfere with defects if necessary.

questions.question: It is not essential for hygiene whether hands are washed using liquid soap or soap blocks.
questions.description: Soap used for hand washing must be mild so that it will not damage the skin of the hands. The soap must be liquid and the soap dispenser must also be hygienic. Warm water is used for washing, and it is also important to properly dry one's hands after washing them.

questions.question: Samples taken from batches of food prepared in large kitchens must be stored for 1-2 months.
questions.description: Samples are taken from large kitchens' food batches to trace possible food poisoning causes easier. Samples must be taken daily from all batches being somehow served or sold and the samples must be stored appropriately marked in a freezer for 1-2 weeks. During this time a majority of food poisoning symptoms start to appear.

questions.question: Minced meat lasts as long as unprepared meat if it is packaged in a vacuum container or vacuum bag.
questions.description: Minced meat requires that it be stored in a maximum temperature of +4 degrees celsius, whereas whole meat can be stored in +6 degrees celsius.

questions.question: Bacteria can reproduce in more acidized environments than moulds and yeasts.
questions.description: Bacteria that are a threat to food product safety reproduce the best in the neutral zone. Because of this the growth of these bacteria can be prevented by increasing the acidity of a product.

questions.question: Crates can be stored on the loading dock as long as they are protected from the rain.
questions.description: Storing crates on the loading dock is a hygiene hazard as they attract birds and other animals.

questions.question: Products sold at a fish stall must have a marking if they have been defrosted for sale.
questions.description: Customers must know if they are buying products that have already been defrosted. A product that has been frozen and defrosted once can not be frozen again.

questions.question: Cooked rice left at room temperature is a good breeding ground for various microbes.
questions.description: Bacillus cereus is one of the bacteria that causes food poisoning; it cannot be completely stopped from spreading to food products. Bacillus cereus is found in almost all food products. It is most commonly spread through rice dishes and vegetables.

questions.question: Food product stores do not require an own-check plan.
questions.description: All workplaces in the food industry need to ensure the safety of their products with an own-check plan. Own-check plans are required in all food industry workplaces.

questions.question: Fermented milk products are produced with the help of lactic acid bacteria.
questions.description: Lactic acid bacteria (LAB) are used when producing fermented milk products. LAB create lactic acid in the product, which causes the product to become acidized. Most bacteria are unable to reproduce in acidized products and because of this fermenting milk products makes them last longer.

questions.question: If one's hands are clean, the temperature of food can be checked with the fingers.
questions.description: It is not possible to see how microbiologically clean one's hands are if only using the bare eye. Microbes can spread from the fingers to cooked food; when measuring the temperature of food a thermometer which can be easily cleaned must be used.

questions.question: Pasteurisation of milk destroys listeria bacteria.
questions.description: Pasteurisation of milk is a process that destroys listeria bacteria. Milk is pasteurised when heated to 72°C for about 15 seconds.

questions.question: In Finland the milk found in cartons in stores is almost always pasteurized milk.
questions.description: Only raw milk that has been bought directly from a dairy farm is not usually pasteurized.

questions.question: The creation and following requirements of own-check plans include all companies that handle food products.
questions.description: The creation and use of an own-check plan is a requirement by law, which has included all companies handling food products since 1995. All employees in a company are responsible for the implementation of own-check plans.

questions.question: Headwear is used in kitchens to protect the employee's hair from getting dirty.
questions.description: Headwear is used to prevent the employee's hair from getting into the prepared food.

questions.question: Hand washing sinks can be used for cleaning root vegetables.
questions.description: Enough hand washing areas must be available, and they must only be used for washing hands.

questions.question: Listeria can not reproduce in cold fish (e.g. salmon) in vacuum-packages.
questions.description: Listeria and yersinia are rare exceptions of food poisoning causing bacteria, because they can reproduce in refrigerator temperatures.

questions.question: Most food poisoning causing microbes will be destroyed when the temperature of food is more than 75 degrees Celsius.
questions.description: Most food poisoning causing microbes can not live in temperatures over 75 degrees Celsius. However, bacteria-spores can live in much higher temperatures.

questions.question: Temperature measurements stated in own-check plans do not have to made when one is busy.
questions.description: Only regularly done measurements can prove that the own-check plan has been adhered to at a workplace.

questions.question: The slime that appears on the surface of meat products is caused by harmful microbes.
questions.description: Some harmful microbes produce slime. For example, slime appearing on the surface of a sausage is a sign of it perishing. Slime-producing microbes reproduce quickly in food products e.g. when the product is stored or served in too high temperatures.

questions.question: Staphylococcus aureus is not a food poisoning bacteria.
questions.description: Staphylococcus aureus is a food poisoning bacteria. The human skin, nose and mucous membranes can contain staphylococcus aureus.

questions.question: There is no need to measure the temperature in the freezer because the food products are frozen.
questions.description: Regular monitoring of the freezer temperature is an important part of the own-check plan. The most important aspect of storage management is the regular monitoring and recording of storage room temperatures. Freezers must have a thermometer and a system for recording temperatures regularly.

questions.question: An entire block of cheese spoils faster than cheese that has been sliced.
questions.description: The spoiling of a product usually starts on the surface. The surface contains a lot of oxygen and some amounts of microbes have always been spread onto the surface during production and packing. Products with lots of surface area always spoil faster than similar products that are still in their original entire form.

questions.question: When a kitchen floor is washed properly, there cannot be any microbes on it.
questions.description: Microbes are everywhere, even on newly washed kitchen surfaces.

questions.question: Guide dogs are not allowed inside food product stores.
questions.description: Guide dogs are always allowed in areas meant for customers. However, no animals can be taken inside food product handling areas or storage areas.

questions.question: Restaurants must have an own-check plan.
questions.description: All workplaces in the food industry need to ensure the safety of their products with an own-check plan. Own-check plans are required in all food industry workplaces.

questions.question: Workers in the food industry can be found responsible for a customer becoming sick.
questions.description: Product liability laws also cover food products. If a customer is able to provide sufficient evidence, a worker in the food industry can be found responsible for causing a sickness in the customer.

questions.question: Hand washing sinks can be used for cleaning root vegetables.
questions.description: Enough hand washing areas must be available, and they must only be used for washing hands.

questions.question: If food is cooled too slowly it can lead to food poisoning.
questions.description: Too slow cooling of food is a very common reason for food poisoning. Cooling should happen quickly (in under 4 hours) so that the microbes in the food can not reproduce and grow into large hazardous quantities. During cooling food has a dangerous temperature (between 6 and 60 degrees Celsius) where microbes reproduce very quickly.

questions.question: Sugar can contain microbes.
questions.description: Sugar is dry, so microbes do not grow in it. However, salt can contain spores of bacteria, moulds or yeast.

questions.question: Pasteurizing destroys all bacteria from a food product.
questions.description: During pasteurization the food product is heated to +degrees celsius. This temperature destroys a large percentage of microbes, but the product still requires cold storage. For example pasteurized milk must be kept at a temperature of +6 degrees or less.

questions.question: The most hygienic tools are well-washed hands.
questions.description: The handling of food products should be done with clean equipment instead of hands whenever possible. Clean and appropriate equipment is one of the most effective ways to prevent food products from contamination.

questions.question: Food products can not be stored on the floor of dry storage rooms.
questions.description: Storing food products on the floor is not a hygienic way to store food. Floors always contain more microbes than shelves.

questions.question: Beneficial microbes cannot be used in the production of cream cheese.
questions.description: Cream cheese is made using beneficial microbes.

questions.question: You can leave your rings on your fingers while you wash your hands.
questions.description: A lot of dirt and microbes live under rings, which means that rings must be removed before washing your hands.

questions.question: If you detect deviations from the limit values, you must take the measurement again the next day.
questions.description: When the limit determined in the own-check plan is exceeded you must record the result, take the relevant corrective measures and record them and then record the new results.

questions.question: Products in protective gas packages contain microbes.
questions.description: Products in protective gas packages always contain some microbes. The protective gas is used to prevent microbes that require oxygen from growing.

questions.question: Minced meat lasts as long as unprepared meat if it is packaged in a vacuum container or vacuum bag.
questions.description: Minced meat requires that it be stored in a maximum temperature of +4 degrees celsius, whereas whole meat can be stored in +6 degrees celsius.

questions.question: Customer feedback is not a part of the own-check plan.
questions.description: Customer feedback is part of a company's own-check plan. The own-check plan should also explain how feedback is used.

questions.question: Bacillus cereus is not a food poisoning causing bacteria.
questions.description: Bacillus cereus is a food poisoning causing bacteria. Risk food products for this are e.g. raw milk and rice.

questions.question: The own-check plan helps to make sure that there are fewer unsafe food products.
questions.description: The most important objective of the own-check plan is to improve food safety.

questions.question: Workers in the food industry, e.g. the owner of a small café, must inform local food control authorities about their activities.
questions.description: All workers in the food industry must inform food control authorities about their activities. The informing must be done before beginning the activities. When founding a food industry workplace, e.g. a sausage factory, the activities must also be approved by the authorities.

questions.question: The temperature checks for received food products that need hot or cold storage are part of the own-check plan.
questions.description: Temperature monitoring of hot or cold storage food products when receiving is an important part of the own-check plan. If the temperatures do not meet set requirements they can be returned to the supplier as faulty products.

questions.question: The same knife can be used for cutting raw and cooked meat.
questions.description: Heated food must be protected from contamination after being heated. Ingredients and the equipment used to handle those ingredients must be kept separate from cooked products to prevent cross-contamination.

questions.question: Working areas and surfaces must be cleaned regularly during work shifts and after work is over.
questions.description: Regular cleaning, done every 2-4 hours, of working equipment and surfaces with clean cleaning equipment, substances and water gets rid of leftover pieces of food, dust and other dirt that protects microorganisms and is used as living space by the organisms.

questions.question: Blanching can be used to improve the lastingness of chopped vegetables during freezing.
questions.description: Blanching, which means rapid boiling, stops frozen vegetables' enzymic activity by destroying microbes on their surface.

questions.question: When a food industry workplace, e.g. a sausage factory, is being founded, the workplace must only inform local food control authorities about the activities.
questions.description: When a food industry workplace, e.g. a sausage factory, is being founded, an approval for the activities by local food control authorities is required.

questions.question: A food manufacturer is responsible for date labelling (best before date or use by date).
questions.description: A food manufacturer or packer is responsible for correct date labelling.

questions.question: Intestinal bacteria cannot spread from hands to food.
questions.description: Intestinal bacteria can spread to food even from the hands.

questions.question: Kitchen staff do not need to remove jewellery made of precious metal because precious metal is not a hygiene hazard.
questions.description: Wearing jewellery is always a hygiene hazard. Dirt can accumulate under a ring, and a piece of jewellery or part of it can also come off and end up in food.

questions.question: Raw milk can contain yersinia.
questions.description: Raw milk has not been pasteurized. Yersinia is destroyed when milk is heated to over 70 degrees Celsius; in other words it is destroyed when the milk is pasteurized.

questions.question: Officials benefit from own-check plans the most because a large part of planning the monitoring is given to the food product industry's companies.
questions.description: Own-check plans that are done well make it easier for companies to upkeep food product safety because resources used for monitoring can be focused on things essential for company activities. Knowledge of the quality of the activities will also improve when the activities are planned. In the best case customer satisfaction, profitability and officials' trust will improve.

questions.question: Water is not necessary for microbes to reproduce.
questions.description: Dried products last well due to having no water that bacteria could use to reproduce. Microbes can't reproduce in dried products.

questions.question: Food products are always safe if the best before date has not yet expired.
questions.description: A food product may be contaminated even if there are still several days until the best before date. Contamination may be caused by unhygienic tools or work environment and incorrect temperatures, for example.

questions.question: Mashed potato is not an easily perishable food product.
questions.description: Pre-made foods are easily perishable products. Easily perishable foods must be stored in the cold, under 6 degrees Celsius.

questions.question: The correct concentration of detergent significantly affects the cleaning result.
questions.description: Detergents and disinfectants must be measured out in accordance with the manufacturer's instructions. A solution that is stronger than recommended does not usually guarantee a better cleaning result, and a solution that is diluted too much may give a worse result.

questions.question: Salmonella infections can be symptomless.
questions.description: It is possible for salmonella infections to not be noticed. One might not notice the infection at all, but can still spread the salmonella to others. In practice salmonella can only be spread if one's hands are not washed well after going to the toilet.

questions.question: The waste disposal procedures for professional kitchens, such as recycling, are decided upon between the personnel.
questions.description: A professional kitchen's waste disposal is based on waste laws as well as regional waste disposal directives.

questions.question: Yersinia bacteria has been found on fields and in fresh vegetables that have been spoiled during storage.
questions.description: Yersinia is destroyed when heating a product to over 70 degrees Celsius. Fresh vegetables are often served non-heated, so possible yersinia is not destroyed. Yersinia can also reproduce during storage in refrigerator temperatures.

questions.question: The shelf life of spices can be prolonged by radiation.
questions.description: UV, infra red and gamma radiation can be used to destroy microbes from for example spices and pastries that are made to last for long periods of storage.

questions.question: Dishes do not need to be pre-washed before being put into a washing machine if the washing temperature is hot enough.
questions.description: Dishes must always be pre-washed before being put into a washing machine. It is important to get rid of protein spots with cool water so that the protein does not stick to the dishes in hot temperatures. The biofilm that the protein creates acts as a living space for microbes.

questions.question: The sampling plan is not part of the own-check plan.
questions.description: The sampling plan is an important part of own-check operations.

questions.question: High salt content prevents harmful microbes from multiplying in a product
questions.description: Strong salting of a product changes the state of its water so that microbes can not reproduce. However, salted products such as mushrooms must still be stored in cool temperatures to prevent microbes on their surface from perishing them.

questions.question: The temperature checks for received food products that need hot or cold storage are part of the own-check plan.
questions.description: Temperature monitoring of hot or cold storage food products when receiving is an important part of the own-check plan. If the temperatures do not meet set requirements they can be returned to the supplier as faulty products.

questions.question: Food products must never be cooled or stored outside.
questions.description: Food products must not be cooled or stored outside. All equipment and products, e.g. boxes containg baked goods, must be stored inside.

questions.question: A biowaste container that is kept closed can be stored in the kitchen's storage area at room temperature for a few days.
questions.description: Waste must be stored in a designated area that is sufficiently separated from other operations and food products.

questions.question: A grated carrot spoils faster than an entire carrot.
questions.description: Treating a carrot and grating it shortens the time it lasts. During grating microbes spread onto the carrot and water inside the carrot becomes available for the microbes to use. Grated products also have more surface area than intact products; microbes, especially ones that require oxygen, are suitable to live on the surface of products.

questions.question: Chefs are required to have a hygiene proficiency passport even if their employment is not permanent.
questions.description: Chefs handle easily perishable food products in their work. This means that chefs must pass a hygiene proficiency test at least 3 months after starting their work.

questions.question: A delivery load that contains meat and fish products can be safely left at room temperature for three hours pending transfer into cold storage.
questions.description: The cold chain of perishable food products must not be interrupted at any point in the supply chain.

questions.question: Frozen food products are stored in a freezer at a temperature of -15°C or colder.
questions.description: The temperature in a freezer must be -18°C or colder.

questions.question: It is recommended to use a hand dryer for drying your hands because the air they produce is so hot.
questions.description: Dry your hands with a clean disposable paper towel or a cloth towel.

questions.question: Working surfaces must be dried properly after cleaning.
questions.description: Harmful microbes multiply in damp conditions, so surfaces must be fully dried after cleaning.

questions.question: During the cooling of food microbes are not able to reproduce in the food.
questions.description: The danger zone for food temperatures is between 6 and 60 degrees Celsius. Microbes can reproduce in food when the temperature is within this danger zone. During the cooling of food the food is within this danger zone.

questions.question: Packages of easily perishable food products must have a label indicating their best-before date.
questions.description: Packages of easily perishable food products always require a label indicating the last day of use and storing instructions. The shown date is valid only for unopened products that have been stored in the right temperature.

questions.question: Most food poisoning causing microbes will be destroyed when the temperature of food is more than 75 degrees Celsius.
questions.description: Most food poisoning causing microbes can not live in temperatures over 75 degrees Celsius. However, bacteria-spores can live in much higher temperatures.

questions.question: When food products are stored in the correct temperatures, the microbes in the products will not be able to reproduce and grow into dangerous quantities too quickly.
questions.description: Microbes can not be fully prevented from getting into food products. However, correct temperatures will slow down or prevent the microbes in food from reproducing and growing in hazardous amounts.

questions.question: Smoking is allowed in the food premises storeroom if the employer allows it.
questions.description: Smoking is prohibited in the food premises in those areas where food is prepared, sold, processed or stored.

questions.question: Waste disposal is not a part of the own-check plan.
questions.description: The own-check plan always includes instructions for waste disposal. How much the instructions cover always depends on the activities and what the activities cover. It is important to set daily assignments and responsibility areas.

questions.question: Food products can be cooled in the same freezer where frozen products are stored.
questions.description: Food products must first be cooled with separate cooling equipment and moved afterwards into a freezer for storage.

questions.question: The safety data sheets of detergents (washing chemicals) must always be kept close to their storage location.
questions.description: Safety data sheets must be kept near detergents so that the user of the detergent can read e.g. the first aid instructions.

questions.question: When a kitchen floor is washed properly, there cannot be any microbes on it.
questions.description: Microbes are everywhere, even on newly washed kitchen surfaces.

questions.question: Norovirus is not spread in water.
questions.description: Norovirus infection can also be acquired from contaminated water.

questions.question: Working areas and equipment must always be cleaned by using plenty of water.
questions.description: Water is an important part of cleaning and washing. Water acts as a solvent and substance that transports dirt away. However it is also important to dry the surfaces and equipment properly, because microbes grow and reproduce easily in moist environments.

questions.question: Food poisoning symptoms always start within one day of consuming a perished food product.
questions.description: Food poisoning symptoms can already begin in one hour since consuming a perished food product, but they can also begin after many days of no symptoms.

questions.question: The human skin does not contain microbes.
questions.description: Especially the face, scalp, mouth, nose etc. contain microbes. Food poisoning causing Staphylococcus bacteria can also be found on the skin.

questions.question: When washing dishes, the prewashing must not be done with hot water.
questions.description: Prewashing must be done with cool-temperatured water. Too hot water can burn albumin spots onto the surface of the dish and create biofilm, which is a suitable growing environment for microbes.

questions.question: A cheese roll packed in a tight plastic wrap is protected from microbes.
questions.description: A cheese roll is a perishable food product that is stored and served cold. In addition to being wrapped in plastic film, make sure that it is kept in the correct storage and serving temperatures.

questions.question: There are no microbes in dried food products.
questions.description: Dried products last well due to having no water that bacteria could use to reproduce. However, the microbes have not been destroyed in dried products and the products can contain spores of bacteria, moulds or yeast.

questions.question: The temperature monitoring of cold storages is a part of own-check plans.
questions.description: The temperatures of cold storages must be checked and logged regularly according to the own-check plan. Cold storages must always have thermometers for measurements.

questions.question: The training of personnel is an important part of own-check plans.
questions.description: The training of personnel is an essential part of own-check plans. In the food industry technology, equipment, ingredients, preparation methods and even risks change, so it is important to update knowledge regularly.

questions.question: Salmonella bacteria can be found in fowl or poultry.
questions.description: Salmonella can be found in fowl or poultry. Due to the risk of salmonella, the meat of fowl/poultry must always be cooked to at least 75 degrees Celsius.

questions.question: Sneezing spreads harmful microbes into the surrounding environment in the droplets/spray.
questions.description: There are lots of microbes in the respiratory system and mouth which can spread into the surroundings.

questions.question: Protective gloves are used to protect employees' hands from dirt, so that their hands do not need to be washed as often.
questions.description: Gloves are also used to protect food from microbes spread by hands. Gloves are a great way to keep work hygiene good when tasks must be changed quickly. Gloves must be changed regularly enough while working to keep hygiene good. It is also good to properly wash and dry one's hands when changing gloves. Gloves must always be changed immediately after touching door handles or taps.

questions.question: Eating is not allowed while preparing food.
questions.description: Microbes in the mouth spread onto the hands while eating. Eating must be done in a separate area and after eating hands must be washed.

questions.question: When a food industry workplace, e.g. a sausage factory, is being founded, the workplace must only inform local food control authorities about the activities.
questions.description: When a food industry workplace, e.g. a sausage factory, is being founded, an approval for the activities by local food control authorities is required.

questions.question: Blue cheese doesn't contain living mould.
questions.description: Clean, controlled and living moulds are used when producing blue cheese. The moulds create various taste ingredients in the cheese. The ready cheese still contain these living moulds.

questions.question: Irradiation can be used to destroy microbes in dairy products.
questions.description: Irradiation destroys microbes in dry herbs and spices.

questions.question: Products in protective gas packages do not have any microbes.
questions.description: Products in protective gas packages always contain some microbes. The protective gas is used to prevent microbes that require oxygen from growing.

questions.question: Officials benefit from own-check plans the most because a large part of planning the monitoring is given to the food product industry's companies.
questions.description: Own-check plans that are done well make it easier for companies to upkeep food product safety because resources used for monitoring can be focused on things essential for company activities. Knowledge of the quality of the activities will also improve when the activities are planned. In the best case customer satisfaction, profitability and officials' trust will improve.

questions.question: Food product stores do not require an own-check plan.
questions.description: All workplaces in the food industry need to ensure the safety of their products with an own-check plan. Own-check plans are required in all food industry workplaces.

questions.question: Flies are a hygienic risk for food products.
questions.description: Flies can spread microbes that are harmful or hazardous to the human health onto food products and are a risk because of this.

questions.question: Microbes can not reproduce in dry products.
questions.description: Microbes need water to reproduce. Microbes will not reproduce in dried products but dried products can contain spores of bacteria, moulds or yeast.

questions.question: It is important to visually monitor cleanliness on a daily basis in addition to regular cleaning.
questions.description: Everyone working in a food premises must constantly monitor its cleanliness.

questions.question: When a food industry workplace, e.g. a sausage factory, is being founded, the activities of the workplace must be approved in advance by local food control authorities.
questions.description: Workplaces that handle animal-based food products require an approval for their activities. Only informing of the activities is not enough.

questions.question: Hard rye bread (crisp bread) is an easily perishable food product.
questions.description: Hard rye bread is a dry food product, and because of this microbes can not reproduce in it. Hard rye bread can be stored in room temperature.

questions.question: Dishes do not need to be pre-washed before being put into a washing machine.
questions.description: Before being put into a washing machine, dishes must be pre-washed using cool water to get rid of loose dirt and also to get rid of protein spots so that they will not stick to the surface of the dishes and form biofilm.

questions.question: You are allowed to use snus (nuuska in Finnish) while preparing food.
questions.description: The use of snus (nuuska in Finnish) is prohibited while preparing food.

questions.question: The surfaces of work station tables must be cleaned properly only after the work shift is over.
questions.description: A regular cleaning every 2-4 hours of work station surfaces gets rid of leftover food pieces, fat, dust and other dirt which protects micro-organisms and gives them living space.

questions.question: If one's hands have been carefully washed then food products can be handled with hands.
questions.description: Clean equipment should always be used instead of hands, no matter how well washed, whenever possible.

questions.question: If a can of canned food has bloated and become larger, the contents inside the can must be tasted to make sure if the food is spoiled or not.
questions.description: Bloated, enlargened cans can contain a dangerous toxin called botulin. Even a very small amount of botulin can be lethal.

questions.question: The purity of the air in the food packaging area has no effect on the shelf life of food products.
questions.description: Food products are packed in an area with clean air, as it affects their shelf life.

questions.question: Unpeeled and peeled carrots will last the same amount of time as long as they are stored in the cold.
questions.description: Earthy and dirty, untreated root vegetables will last long in appropriate cold storage units, but all treatments will worsen their lastingness.

questions.question: Optimal temperature means the temperature where microbes reproduce the slowest.
questions.description: All microbes have their own optimal temperatures where reproduction is the fastest. In the insides of humans and animals, the temperature range between 20 and 45 degrees Celsius is the best for microbes. Anything hotter or colder than this causes microbes to reproduce slower.

questions.question: Food poisoning can be caused by careless hand washing.
questions.description: Dirty hands may contain microbes that cause food poisoning.

questions.question: Dirty root vegetables and pre-made food products can be stored in the same cold room.
questions.description: Dirt always contains many microbes. Dirty root vegetables must be handled separately from other products so that the microbes in the dirt do not spread to other food products.

questions.question: Own-check plans are meant for the leadership of food industry companies.
questions.description: Own-check plans include lots of instructions and lists responsibilities. Because of this it is important that all employees get to know the own-check plan and adhere to it while working.

questions.question: Frozen vegetables may contain listeria bacteria.
questions.description: Listeria can be found in unheated food products such as fresh vegetables and products made from these.

questions.question: There is no need to measure the temperature in the freezer because the food products are frozen.
questions.description: Regular monitoring of the freezer temperature is an important part of the own-check plan. The most important aspect of storage management is the regular monitoring and recording of storage room temperatures. Freezers must have a thermometer and a system for recording temperatures regularly.

questions.question: When outside temperatures are very cold, food products can be cooled quickly outside.
questions.description: Food products must not be cooled or stored outside. All equipment and products, e.g. boxes containg baked goods, must be stored inside.

questions.question: Dirty root vegetables must have a separate work space.
questions.description: Dirt always contains many microbes. Dirty root vegetables must be handled separately from other products so that the microbes in the dirt do not spread to other food products.

questions.question: Food must not be served heated for over 2 hours.
questions.description: Food served / sold hot may be kept in a temperature-controlled bath (min +60 degrees) for a maximum of four hours, after which the food must be replaced.

questions.question: Food products can be sold after the last use-by-date if it is sold at a discount price.
questions.description: The last use-by-date must be marked on easily perishable food products. The products can not be used nor sold after this date.

questions.question: Plants can be displayed and sold anywhere in a grocery store as long as adequate ventilation is provided.
questions.description: Plants must be located as far as possible from unpackaged perishable food products. There are lots of microbes on the surface of plants and in the soil, and these may spread to food products.

questions.question: Working areas and surfaces must be cleaned regularly during work shifts and after work is over.
questions.description: Regular cleaning, done every 2-4 hours, of working equipment and surfaces with clean cleaning equipment, substances and water gets rid of leftover pieces of food, dust and other dirt that protects microorganisms and is used as living space by the organisms.

questions.question: Restaurants must have an own-check plan.
questions.description: All workplaces in the food industry need to ensure the safety of their products with an own-check plan. Own-check plans are required in all food industry workplaces.

questions.question: Thawing frozen food products in a sealed container at room temperature does not increase the risk of food poisoning.
questions.description: Food must be thawed in such a way as to minimise the increase of pathogens as much as possible. A frozen food product is defrosted in a cold room so that the temperature of the food product's surface does not rise above the other parts of the product.

questions.question: If one's hands are clean, the temperature of food can be checked with the fingers.
questions.description: It is not possible to see how microbiologically clean one's hands are if only using the bare eye. Microbes can spread from the fingers to cooked food; when measuring the temperature of food a thermometer which can be easily cleaned must be used.

questions.question: Listeria is an environmental bacteria that can reproduce in food products.
questions.description: Listeria monocytogenes is a bacteria that causes diseases in humans; it is common in you environment. The optimal temperature for the bacteria is the internal temperature of humans, 30 to 37 degrees Celsius; however it can also reproduce in refrigeration temperatures. The bacteria can reproduce especially easily in vacuum-packed products because of their long storing times.

questions.question: Kitchens in hospitals should have separate spaces for different work phases such as the treatment of root vegetables, baking and dishwashing.
questions.description: When each work phase is done in its own separate area the work is hygienic and the risk of cross-contamination is smaller.

questions.question: Packages of easily perishable food products must have a label indicating their best-before date.
questions.description: Packages of easily perishable food products always require a label indicating the last day of use and storing instructions. The shown date is valid only for unopened products that have been stored in the right temperature.

questions.question: If an easily perishable food product has been stored in too warm conditions, the product can still be stored until the use-by-date.
questions.description: The use-by-date is reliable only if the product has been stored correctly. Storing products in too warm conditions always makes the products last for shorter periods of times.

questions.question: Bacteria spores die when a product is dried.
questions.description: Spores are the form of bacteria that will last. Spores are able to endure dryness, boiling, salting and the cold. Bacteria can not reproduce in dry products but they will survive as spores.

questions.question: The amount of things covered in the waste disposal instructions must be the same for everyone in the food industry.
questions.description: The own-check plan's waste disposal instructions' coverage depends on what the done activities cover.

questions.question: Vibrio bacteria are found in sea waters at warm geographical locations.
questions.description: Vibrio bacteria have been found in salty coast seawater at warm geographical locations. Seafood that has been heated badly or stored in too warm temperatures are risk food products.

questions.question: Only reproductive microbes are destroyed during sterilization. Bacteria spores are not destroyed.
questions.description: During sterilization (e.g. during canned food production) all microbes and bacteria spores are destroyed. This way easily perishable products will be able to last long in room temperature.

questions.question: Dishes do not need to be pre-washed before being put into a washing machine if the washing temperature is hot enough.
questions.description: Dishes must always be pre-washed before being put into a washing machine. It is important to get rid of protein spots with cool water so that the protein does not stick to the dishes in hot temperatures. The biofilm that the protein creates acts as a living space for microbes.

questions.question: Heat and humidity accelerate vegetable spoilage.
questions.description: The correct storage temperatures and moisture affect the shelf life of vegetables.

questions.question: Blue cheese doesn't contain living mould.
questions.description: Clean, controlled and living moulds are used when producing blue cheese. The moulds create various taste ingredients in the cheese. The ready cheese still contain these living moulds.

questions.question: A cleaning and washing program must be included in the own-check plan.
questions.description: Areas that need to be cleaned, washing and cleaning methods for each area and specific cleaning equipment and substances (if required) must be listed in the own-check plan. The effectiveness of the cleaning must be checked visually daily and the responsible person has to log results for example once a week or always when abnormalities are noticed.

questions.question: Only old cold storage equipment must have a thermometer.
questions.description: All cold storage equipment in food production areas must have a thermometer.

questions.question: Hand towels made out of cloth can be used at a hand washing station in a food production area as long as the towels are changed daily.
questions.description: Cloth hand towels can not be used when working with food products. A cloth hand towel that is rolled from an automated towel dispenser is an exception to this rule.

questions.question: When a food industry workplace, e.g. a sausage factory, is being founded, the workplace must only inform local food control authorities about the activities.
questions.description: When a food industry workplace, e.g. a sausage factory, is being founded, an approval for the activities by local food control authorities is required.

questions.question: Indoor plants can spread harmful microbes to food products.
questions.description: Indoor plants must not be kept in food product preparation areas because microbes live on their surface and in their earth.

questions.question: Small birds flying in a grocery store cause no harm as long as regular cleaning is carried out.
questions.description: Small birds must be prevented from entering food premises. They are a hygiene hazard.

questions.question: Cleaning plans are a part of own-check plans.
questions.description: Cleaning plans are an important part of own-check plans. Cleaning plans include instructions and schedules for cleaning.

questions.question: The training of personnel is an important part of own-check plans.
questions.description: The training of personnel is an essential part of own-check plans. In the food industry technology, equipment, ingredients, preparation methods and even risks change, so it is important to update knowledge regularly.

questions.question: The lastingness of food products can also be improved during treatment by using hygienic work methods, clean surfaces and equipment.
questions.description: Ingredients and their handling equipment must be kept separate from cooked products to prevent cross-contamination. For example, differently colored cutting boards and equipment for different food groups, such as vegetables, fish, meat and cooked food helps to prevent cross-contamination.

questions.question: When roasting or cooking insects, there is no need to be especially careful.
questions.description: When insects are processed, they must be handled in the same way as other perishable food products.

questions.question: You can touch the inside surfaces of food packaging if you have just washed your hands.
questions.description: You should always try not to touch the inside surfaces of food packaging.

questions.question: Hepatitis A is never spread in food products.
questions.description: The most important viruses that reproduce in the intestines of humans are the norovirus and hepatitis A. Both viruses last for a long time and are able to spread in the cold and even in frozen foods.

questions.question: Frozen vegetables may contain listeria bacteria.
questions.description: Listeria can be found in unheated food products such as fresh vegetables and products made from these.

questions.question: If an employee has infected wounds on his or her hands, he or she must not handle food products.
questions.description: Infected wounds contain large amounts of food poisoning causing Staphylococcus aureus bacteria. It is impossible to constantly prevent the bacteria from spreading to food products.

questions.question: Temperature measurements stated in the own-check plan must be done according to the own-check plan.
questions.description: Only regularly done measurements can prove that the own-check plan has been adhered to at a workplace.

questions.question: You must remove all rings before washing your hands to make sure that no dirt remains under the rings.
questions.description: A lot of dirt and microbes live under rings, which means that rings must be removed before washing your hands.

questions.question: The shelf life of food products can be extended by irradiating them.
questions.description: Only dried aromatic herbs, spices and vegetable seasonings are allowed to be irradiated. The purpose of irradiation is to eliminate bacteria and insects as well as to prevent the product from sprouting, for example.

questions.question: The correct concentration of detergent does not have any effect on the cleaning result.
questions.description: Detergents and disinfectants must be measured out in accordance with the manufacturer's instructions. A solution that is stronger than recommended does not usually guarantee a better cleaning result, and a solution that is diluted too much may give a worse result.

questions.question: If the dry storage rooms has no space elsewhere, food products can be stored on the floor of the room for a short time.
questions.description: Food products can not be stored on the floor even for a short time.

questions.question: Food products can be sold after the last use-by-date if it is sold at a discount price.
questions.description: The last use-by-date must be marked on easily perishable food products. The products can not be used nor sold after this date.

questions.question: When unprotected, cooked and uncooked food products must be stored in separate areas.
questions.description: Unprotected cooked and uncooked food products must have separate storage areas to prevent cross-contamination.

questions.question: Cleaning equipment must be cleaned once a week.
questions.description: Cleaning equipment must be cleaned after each use and must then be left to dry.

questions.question: Even thoroughly boiled food contains microbes.
questions.description: Bacteria spores will not be destroyed during boiling. When boiled food cools to less than 60 degrees Celsius the bacteria spores may reproduce again.

questions.question: Chopping vegetables improves their shelf life.
questions.description: Whole vegetables keep better than chopped vegetables. Handling food products impairs their shelf life.

questions.question: If a food premises changes owners, this must always be reported to the local food authority.
questions.description: When a food premises changes owners, this must always be reported to the local food authority.

questions.question: An employee on antibiotics can not spread food poisoning causing microbes.
questions.description: An employee using antibiotics is not free from all food poisoning causing bacteria which can be on the skin, mucosas or in the intestines. The antibiotics might not affect all harmful microbes and so the person could spread microbes even during the use of the antibiotics.

questions.question: When a kitchen floor is washed properly, there cannot be any microbes on it.
questions.description: Microbes are everywhere, even on newly washed kitchen surfaces.

questions.question: The own-check plan helps to make sure that there are fewer unsafe food products.
questions.description: The most important objective of the own-check plan is to improve food safety.

questions.question: Safety data sheets are the same thing as the instruction manual of a device.
questions.description: Safety data sheets include the most important information about detergents (washing chemicals) and also include first aid instructions.

questions.question: Fresh morel mushrooms must be roasted thoroughly before they can be eaten.
questions.description: Fresh morel mushrooms contain natural toxins which can not be removed by only roasting the mushrooms.

questions.question: A cleaning and washing program must be included in the own-check plan.
questions.description: Areas that need to be cleaned, washing and cleaning methods for each area and specific cleaning equipment and substances (if required) must be listed in the own-check plan. The effectiveness of the cleaning must be checked visually daily and the responsible person has to log results for example once a week or always when abnormalities are noticed.

questions.question: Waste disposal is not a part of the own-check plan.
questions.description: The own-check plan always includes instructions for waste disposal. How much the instructions cover always depends on the activities and what the activities cover. It is important to set daily assignments and responsibility areas.

questions.question: The own-check plan of a food production area is not done by a municipality health inspector.
questions.description: Workplaces in the food industry must create their own own-check plan that suits their activities. The plan is supposed to ensure the safety of food products, good lastingness and the following of official rules and directives.

questions.question: The priority of waste laws is to make people working in the food industry responsible for assorting their waste.
questions.description: The priority of waste laws is to lessen the amount of waste and its effects.

questions.question: If a summer restaurant is located next to a lake with clean water, the water in the lake can be used for washing fruits.
questions.description: All food preparation requires the use of water that is tap water quality.

questions.question: Hands must be washed after sneezing and blowing one's nose.
questions.description: Microbes spread onto the hands when sneezing and blowing one's nose. If the hands are not washed, these bacteria will easily spread onto food products.

questions.question: Prepared salads can be stored in room temperature without a risk of food poisoning.
questions.description: Prepared salads are easily perishable food products. For example, chopped or grated vegetables and root vegetables, meat, fish and mayonnaise are often ingredients of prepared salads, so they have to be stored in the cold.

questions.question: Bacillus cereus is not a food poisoning causing bacteria.
questions.description: Bacillus cereus is a food poisoning causing bacteria. Risk food products for this are e.g. raw milk and rice.

questions.question: Bacteria can reproduce in more dry environments than moulds.
questions.description: Only some moulds can reproduce in very dry products. For example, bread becomes spoiled only due to mould; bacteria and yeasts can not reproduce in the bread.

questions.question: Cleaning equipment that is old and in bad condition can spread harmful microbes to a food production area.
questions.description: Cleaning equipment wears down and becomes dirty during use. They often contain microbes even though they are washed regularly. Cleaning equipment should be renewed regularly.

questions.question: The human skin does not contain microbes.
questions.description: Especially the face, scalp, mouth, nose etc. contain microbes. Food poisoning causing Staphylococcus bacteria can also be found on the skin.

questions.question: Ice cube machines do not need to be cleaned separately, because their low temperature prevents microbes from multiplying.
questions.description: Ice cube machines must be cleaned just as regularly and carefully as other cooling equipment.

questions.question: Microbes are only found in places which are visibly dirty.
questions.description: Microbes are everywhere, not only in dirty locations. However it is probable that dirty spots contain more microbes than clean ones.

questions.question: Products in protective gas packages do not have any microbes.
questions.description: Products in protective gas packages always contain some microbes. The protective gas is used to prevent microbes that require oxygen from growing.

questions.question: It is important to change disposable gloves often enough.
questions.description: When working with food, you must change disposable gloves whenever you start a new work phase.

questions.question: The most hygienic tools are well-washed hands.
questions.description: The handling of food products should be done with clean equipment instead of hands whenever possible. Clean and appropriate equipment is one of the most effective ways to prevent food products from contamination.

questions.question: Beneficial microbes cannot be used in the production of cream cheese.
questions.description: Cream cheese is made using beneficial microbes.

questions.question: The shelf life of spices can be prolonged by radiation.
questions.description: UV, infra red and gamma radiation can be used to destroy microbes from for example spices and pastries that are made to last for long periods of storage.

questions.question: Food production employees are not allowed to wear colorless nail polish.
questions.description: Hands must not containt anything extra such as watches, jewellery, fake nails, nail polish or hand cream.

questions.question: Oiva-reports must be placed at the entrance of the café, restaurant etc. so that customers can read them.
questions.description: Oiva-reports are published documents about routine inspections. These reports are also published online at www.oivahymy.fi

questions.question: Easily perishable food products that have been up for retail sale can be frozen and sold as frozen foods.
questions.description: The preparation of frozen foods requires the ingredients to be perfect quality. Frozen foods must be prepared, cooled and frozen without any delay. Frozen foods are prepared only by appropriate production centres. Freezing is allowed in bakeries, households and farm households only if the areas and equipment are approved by officials.

questions.question: The cooling of food products should be done by using cooling cabinets (chillers).
questions.description: Only cooling cabinets can ensure sufficiently fast and effective cooling.

questions.question: The own-check plan only refers to measuring and recording temperatures.
questions.description: The purpose of the own-check plan is to help operators to manage the risks associated with food hygiene. Measuring and recording temperatures is an important part of the own-check system. Other areas of the own-check system include cleaning and tidiness as well as hygienic skills of the staff.

questions.question: The fresh fish that has been up for retail sale during the day can, with the decision and permission of the store, be smoked during the evening and then sold.
questions.description: Fish that has been on the sales counter can not be smoked for the next day's sales. This is against the ethics of food product law and deceives consumers. If fish has been up for retail sale during the day, its sales time must not continue by smoking it.

questions.question: When roasting or cooking insects, there is no need to be especially careful.
questions.description: When insects are processed, they must be handled in the same way as other perishable food products.

questions.question: Campylo bacteria is destroyed when a product is heated properly.
questions.description: Campylo bacteria and salmonella are found naturally in fowl and poultry. Both bacteria are destroyed when the meat is cooked thoroughly to over 75 degrees Celsius.

questions.question: Food production employees are only allowed to wear their work outfit at their workplace, the food production area.
questions.description: The work outfit can only be worn inside the food production area; this prevents microbes from spreading into the area from the clothes.

questions.question: The activity of water contained in food products can be lowered by adding salt or sugar to the product.
questions.description: The activity of water shows how easily the water in a product can be used by microbes. Salt and sugar change the state of water so that the microbes can not use it.

questions.question: Pizza toppings do not need to be cold stored because pizzas are baked in a very hot oven.
questions.description: Perishable food products that require cold storage must always be cold stored.

questions.question: The serving dishes of coffee cream or coffee milk can be filled many times during a day.
questions.description: Coffee cream or coffee milk must always be served from a clean dish, and after the dish is empty it should be changed and washed.

questions.question: If a food premises changes owners, this must always be reported to the local food authority.
questions.description: When a food premises changes owners, this must always be reported to the local food authority.

questions.question: Food products can be used after the last use-by-date if the product does not look spoiled.
questions.description: The last use-by-date must be marked on easily perishable food products. The products can not be used nor sold after this date.

questions.question: The results in Oiva-reports are not allowed to be read by customers.
questions.description: Municipality food control authorities do routine inspections at workplaces. Oiva-reports are published documents about these inspections.

questions.question: People do not have any microbes on their skin if they shower regularly.
questions.description: There are microbes everywhere in soil, water, dust and also on human and animal skin.

questions.question: During food preparation one can go wash one's hands in the staff restroom.
questions.description: There must be a separate hand washing spot in immediate proximity to the food preparation area.

questions.question: Some viruses can last and stay reproductive in water.
questions.description: Viruses can not reproduce in water. However, they can remain able to reproduce later on for a long time while in water.

questions.question: Cleaning equipment must be cleaned once a week.
questions.description: Cleaning equipment must be cleaned after each use and must then be left to dry.

questions.question: Spices cannot cause food poisoning.
questions.description: In some cases spices, too, can cause a risk of food poisoning, and therefore they must be used and stored hygienically and with care just like other food products.

questions.question: It is enough to visually monitor the results of cleaning and washing.
questions.description: The results of cleaning and washing and the need for cleaning needs to be monitored regularly. It is required to name a responsible person for this task in the own-check plan and to form a monitoring plan to use. As well as doing visual inspections, the monitoring can also be done by taking microbiological samples from work surfaces and equipment by for example using Hygicult sample strips.

questions.question: Beneficial bacteria usually make it harder for harmful bacteria to grow.
questions.description: Harmful bacteria have to compete with beneficial bacteria for living space and nutrition. Beneficial bacteria can change living conditions in food products, e.g. the acidity, such that it becomes worse for harmful bacteria and makes them grow slower or not at all.

questions.question: The gas in protective gas packaging completely prevents harmful microbes from growing.
questions.description: The amount of oxygen in protective gas is changed to make it harder for most microbes to grow. Some harmful microbes can withstand exceptional conditions and will be able to reproduce even in protective gas packages. Additionally, the protective gas in the packages will try to equalize with the air around it, so the amount of gas can change.

questions.question: Own-check plans are meant for the leadership of food industry companies.
questions.description: Own-check plans include lots of instructions and lists responsibilities. Because of this it is important that all employees get to know the own-check plan and adhere to it while working.

questions.question: Pasteurization improves the lastingness of food products.
questions.description: In dairies milk products are pasteurized, which means that they are heated to 72 degrees Celsius for 15 seconds and then afterwards cooled immediately. A large amount of bacteria capable of reproducing is destroyed, but this treatment does not destroy all microbes. Pasteurized milk must be stored under 6 degrees Celsius in a refrigerator. Juices are another example of a product which can gain better lastingness when pasteurized during production.

questions.question: Hands must be washed after sneezing and blowing one's nose.
questions.description: Microbes spread onto the hands when sneezing and blowing one's nose. If the hands are not washed, these bacteria will easily spread onto food products.

questions.question: Milk can be stored at room temperature during the breakfast service.
questions.description: Milk and cream are perishable food products and they must be served cold.

questions.question: Employers have the responsibility to monitor the health of employees and thus make sure that they are capable of working.
questions.description: All employees have the responsibility to tell their superiors about illnesses or any symptoms hazardous to food product safety, such as diarrhea, a sore throat, inflamed wounds or inflamed respiratory ducts. Employees with such symptoms must not handle food products.

questions.question: Moulds can not create mould toxins.
questions.description: Some moulds can create mould toxins such as mycotoxins and aflatoxins. Because of this mouldy products should not be used.

questions.question: The temperatures of cold storage equipment do not need to be measured if they feel cold enough.
questions.description: The temperatures of refrigerating equipment, drawers and cabinets must be measured and logged at the same time each day. Atypical measuring results are logged in the own-check forms and necessary measures are taken to restore the right temperature in that piece of equipment.

questions.question: The purpose of the own-check plan is not to manage food-related health hazards.
questions.description: One of the most important objectives of the own-check plan is to manage food-related health hazards.

questions.question: Salmonella bacteria can be found in fowl or poultry.
questions.description: Salmonella can be found in fowl or poultry. Due to the risk of salmonella, the meat of fowl/poultry must always be cooked to at least 75 degrees Celsius.

questions.question: Food poisonings can be prevented by using single-use protective gloves.
questions.description: Single-use protective gloves must be used when handling very easily perishable food products. Protective gloves make it easier to work when employees must change tasks quickly.

questions.question: Food poisoning is always caused by some kind of bacteria or virus.
questions.description: Food poisoning can also be caused by parasites, protozoa, natural toxins (such as in morel mushrooms), poisonous plants or animals, chemicals or some other disease-causing particle.

questions.question: Ingredients should always be handled with clean equipment instead of hands whenever possible.
questions.description: Even washed hands contain some amounts of microbes. Even some healthy people carry food poisoning causing microbes on their skin. Using clean equipment is more hygienic.

questions.question: Bacteria toxins disappear when food is boiled.
questions.description: Some bacteria cause toxins in the food. If toxins have appeared in the food, they weill not disappear during boiling.

questions.question: Listeriosis should be avoided especially during pregnancy.
questions.description: Listeriosis during pregnancy can cause miscarriages or premature birth.

questions.question: The state and cleanliness of the waste management room does not affect the kitchen's hygienic quality.
questions.description: The waste management room must also be kept organised and clean. A dirty waste management room and badly cleaned waste bins can collect pests and spread microbes that are harmful for food products.

questions.question: Waste bins can be placed in the dry food storage room if there is no other place for them.
questions.description: The waste management of food premises must be arranged so that waste and food products do not come into contact with each other.

questions.question: Clostridium perfringens is a bacteria that is often found in earth.
questions.description: Earth contains many microbes, some of which cause food poisoning. To prevent clostridium perfringens food poisonings it is important to properly heat and cool the food and not store it in the dangerous temperature zone of 6 to 60 degrees Celsius.

questions.question: Food poisoning causing microbes can spread only by hands.
questions.description: Working areas and surfaces must be cleaned regularly during work shifts and after work is over.

questions.question: Wooden utensils are well suited for professional kitchens if they are washed in a washing machine on a sufficiently hot program.
questions.description: Wooden utensils should not be used in professional kitchens, as they do not withstand repeated washes in a washing machine. Materials must very durable in order to cope with repeated washes, like for example plastic and steel utensils that are meant for food product related use.

questions.question: Vegetables stored in a vinegared liquid can be kept in room temperature.
questions.description: Sterilized, can-packed and unopened vinegared products can be stored in room temperature. Vinegared products will last long due to the high acidity, but opened packages must be stored in cool temperatures.

questions.question: Boxes meant for transporting food can be stored outside if there is no space indoors.
questions.description: Food transportation boxes must be stored in an area where they do not get dirty. Restaurant and transportation companies agree on the frequency of collection and cleaning of boxes and trolleys.

questions.question: If an employee has infected wounds on his or her hands, he or she must not handle food products.
questions.description: Infected wounds contain large amounts of food poisoning causing Staphylococcus aureus bacteria. It is impossible to constantly prevent the bacteria from spreading to food products.

questions.question: Even thoroughly boiled food contains microbes.
questions.description: Bacteria spores will not be destroyed during boiling. When boiled food cools to less than 60 degrees Celsius the bacteria spores may reproduce again.

questions.question: It is not allowed to use useful microbes in baking.
questions.description: Yeast is used in baking to make dough rise.

questions.question: Temperature does not affect the speed of microbe reproduction.
questions.description: Temperatures are very important for the reproduction abilities of microbes. All microbes have their own optimal temperatures where reproduction is the fastest.

questions.question: Cooked rice is an easily perishable food product.
questions.description: Dry rice lasts in room temperature. Cooked rice contains moisture and because of this it is an easily perishable product.

questions.question: Ultra-high-temperature processing (UHT) uses higher temperatures than pasteurizing.
questions.description: Ultra-high-temperature processing is done in much higher temperatures than pasteurizing. UHT destroys most bacteria spores and because of this products that have been treated with UHT can be stored in room temperature.

questions.question: Suspicions of food poisoning are not a part of own-check plans because health officials will investigate the cause of disease if necessary.
questions.description: Own-check plans must have clear instructions for dealing with food poisoning cases and suspicions. Responsible people and methods of informing should be explained in the own-check plan.

questions.question: Food products must be cooled first by using separate cooling equipment and only then moved into a freezer for storage.
questions.description: Products that are not frozen and are placed into a freezer will raise the temperature of the freezer; this weakens the lastingness of the products in the freezer.

questions.question: Raw milk contains more microbes than pasteurized milk.
questions.description: When milk is pasteurized a large amount of microbes gets destroyed. For example listeria, salmonella and EHEC bacteria are destroyed during pasteurization.

questions.question: A cooked meal and the raw ingredients used to prepare it can be stored in the same container during transport.
questions.description: Cooked meals and raw ingredients are always stored separately in their own clean containers.

questions.question: Thawing frozen products in cold rooms or refrigerators is a hygienic risk because the thawing happens too slowly.
questions.description: If food products are thawed in room temperature, the products' surfaces will melt quicker than the insides. The surfaces will start to spoil even though the insides can still be frozen. Thawing in cold rooms takes a longer amount of time but the cold room's temperature will allow very few microbes to reproduce.

questions.question: The maximum storage temperature for cooked shellfish is +6°C.
questions.description: Cooked molluscs and shellfish are stored at the temperature of melting ice (maximum +2°C).

questions.question: Food poisoning causing bacteria can not be found naturally.
questions.description: Microbes are everywhere: in the air, water, earth, plants, animals and humans. Some of these microbes cause food poisoning.

questions.question: Dirty root vegetables must have a separate work space.
questions.description: Dirt always contains many microbes. Dirty root vegetables must be handled separately from other products so that the microbes in the dirt do not spread to other food products.

questions.question: Microbes reproduce in dry products.
questions.description: Microbes need water to reproduce. Microbes will not reproduce in dried products but dried products can contain spores of bacteria, moulds or yeast.

questions.question: Salmonella bacteria that can be contained in milk products or eggs can be destroyed by pasteurization.
questions.description: Pasteurizing milk, meaning heating to 72 degrees Celsius for 15 seconds, destroys salmonella bacteria. Pasteurization can also be used to treat industrially used batches made from eggs.

questions.question: Microbiological samples of served food are taken only if there is suspicion of there being something wrong with the product.
questions.description: Microbiological samples of served food are taken daily. Samples are kept for 2 weeks, so that potential food poisoning cases can be solved if need be.

questions.question: Bacteria can reproduce in more dry environments than moulds.
questions.description: Only some moulds can reproduce in very dry products. For example, bread becomes spoiled only due to mould; bacteria and yeasts can not reproduce in the bread.

questions.question: The most hygienic way to handle unpacked food products is to use wooden utensils.
questions.description: The most hygienic utensils for handling unpacked food products are made of plastic or steel.

questions.question: Oiva is a system which helps people to self-assess the food product safety of their workplace.
questions.description: Municipality food control authorities make Oiva-reports about the workplaces they inspect. It is not a part of the workplace's self-assessment.

questions.question: The correct concentration of detergent does not have any effect on the cleaning result.
questions.description: Detergents and disinfectants must be measured out in accordance with the manufacturer's instructions. A solution that is stronger than recommended does not usually guarantee a better cleaning result, and a solution that is diluted too much may give a worse result.

questions.question: Waste management must be arranged so that food products and waste do not come into contact with each other.
questions.description: Waste management must be arranged in such a way that waste does not cause any risk to health at any stage.

questions.question: Food production areas' waste bins must be cleaned regularly.
questions.description: The cleanliness and hygiene of waste bins must be taken care of regularly. Waste bins in kitchens should be cleaned always after they are emptied.

questions.question: Cleaning equipment that is old and in bad condition can spread harmful microbes to a food production area.
questions.description: Cleaning equipment wears down and becomes dirty during use. They often contain microbes even though they are washed regularly. Cleaning equipment should be renewed regularly.

questions.question: A cheese roll packed in a tight plastic wrap is protected from microbes.
questions.description: A cheese roll is a perishable food product that is stored and served cold. In addition to being wrapped in plastic film, make sure that it is kept in the correct storage and serving temperatures.

questions.question: The norovirus is not destroyed when a food product is frozen.
questions.description: The norovirus lasts for long amounts of time and is able to spread even in the cold or in frozen foods.

questions.question: Handling money can transfer harmful microbes into food products.
questions.description: Money and easily perishable unpackaged food products should not be handled simultanously, as money can have microbes in it that jeopardize food hygiene.

questions.question: When the temperature of food is being measured, the measurement must be done in the centre of the food mass.
questions.description: Especially in large food masses the temperatures can be very different depending on where the measurement is taken from, such as the sides or the centre.

questions.question: Frozen vegetables may contain listeria bacteria.
questions.description: Listeria can be found in unheated food products such as fresh vegetables and products made from these.

questions.question: Tap water does not contain microbes.
questions.description: Even tap water can contain microbes. Tap water cleanliness must be monitored using the senses. Water samples can also be regularly sent for chemical and microbiological inspections.

questions.question: The purpose of the own-check plan is to make sure that operators manage the risks associated with food hygiene in their operations.
questions.description: Drawing up and following an own-check plan helps operators to manage the risks associated with food hygiene.

questions.question: The same cleaning equipment can be used in both dining areas and food preparation areas.
questions.description: Kitchen facilities and customer areas must have separate cleaning equipment in order to avoid possible disease agents from transferring from one space to the other via cleaning supplies, such as table wiping rags.

questions.question: Irradiation can be used to destroy microbes in dairy products.
questions.description: Irradiation destroys microbes in dry herbs and spices.

questions.question: Berry kisels can be stored in room temperature because the sugar prevents the growth of harmful bacteria.
questions.description: Berry kisels must be stored in cool temperatures because they can perish due to the large quantity of water in them. The sugar in kisels does not prevent harmful bacteria from growing because the sugar density is much lower than in e.g. jams or marmelade.

questions.question: Dirt and dust can make microbes spread to food products.
questions.description: Different kinds of impurities, such as dirt and dust, contain microbes. If dirt or dust gets onto a food product then the microbes contained will also spread onto the product.

questions.question: Workers in the food industry, e.g. the owner of a small café, must inform local food control authorities about their activities.
questions.description: All workers in the food industry must inform food control authorities about their activities. The informing must be done before beginning the activities. When founding a food industry workplace, e.g. a sausage factory, the activities must also be approved by the authorities.

questions.question: The state and cleanliness of the waste management room does not affect the kitchen's hygienic quality.
questions.description: The waste management room must also be kept organised and clean. A dirty waste management room and badly cleaned waste bins can collect pests and spread microbes that are harmful for food products.

questions.question: Customers and employees must have their own, separate toilets.
questions.description: Strict toilet and hand hygiene must be used in food production. This is not possible if toilets are shared with customers.

questions.question: After washing one's hands the tap must be closed using a hand towel, otherwise the hands can become dirty again.
