questions.description: After washing the hands they must be dried using a single-use hand towel and the tap must be closed using the towel. This way any possible microbes on the tap do not spread onto the clean hands.

questions.question: Chefs can use their work shoes only inside the food production area.
questions.description: Work shoes must not be worn outside the workplace to prevent microbes from spreading into the food production area.

questions.question: If a summer restaurant is located next to a lake with clean water, the water in the lake can be used for washing fruits.
questions.description: All food preparation requires the use of water that is tap water quality.

questions.question: One of the reasons for the existence of own-check plans is to make the work of food product industry companies easier.
questions.description: Own-check plans that are done well make it easier for companies to upkeep food product safety because resources used for monitoring can be focused on things essential for company activities. Knowledge of the quality of the activities will also improve when the activities are planned. In the best case customer satisfaction, profitability and officials' trust will improve.

questions.question: Microbes are destroyed when meat is minced.
questions.description: When meat is minced, the bacteria on its surface spread throughout the minced meat.

questions.question: Microbes can not reproduce in dry products.
questions.description: Microbes need water to reproduce. Microbes will not reproduce in dried products but dried products can contain spores of bacteria, moulds or yeast.

questions.question: The most hygienic tools are well-washed hands.
questions.description: The handling of food products should be done with clean equipment instead of hands whenever possible. Clean and appropriate equipment is one of the most effective ways to prevent food products from contamination.

questions.question: Hepatitis A is never spread in food products.
questions.description: The most important viruses that reproduce in the intestines of humans are the norovirus and hepatitis A. Both viruses last for a long time and are able to spread in the cold and even in frozen foods.

questions.question: Dried products last well due to having no water that bacteria could use to reproduce.
questions.description: Water is necessary for microbes to reproduce. Dried products last well due to having no water.

questions.question: Products sold at a fish stall must have a marking if they have been defrosted for sale.
questions.description: Customers must know if they are buying products that have already been defrosted. A product that has been frozen and defrosted once can not be frozen again.

questions.question: Bacteria spores are destroyed when products are boiled (+100 degrees Celsius).
questions.description: Bacteria spores are destroyed only during sterilization. In excess pressure the temperature is raised to about 145 degrees Celsius and this way bacteria spores are also destroyed.

questions.question: Beer is produced with the help of beneficial microbes.
questions.description: Beer is produced with yeast fermentation. Yeast is also used when producing wine.

questions.question: Cleaning equipment must be cleaned once a week.
questions.description: Cleaning equipment must be cleaned after each use and must then be left to dry.

questions.question: Even in small cafés the same cleaning equipment can not be used to clean the customer areas and the kitchen.
questions.description: If the same cleaning equipment is used, microbes can easily spread from customers to the kitchen in the equipment.

questions.question: If there are other companies working in the same estate, then the food production area needs a waste disposal area separate from the other companies' areas.
questions.description: Waste disposal areas can be the same with other companies but the own-check plan's waste disposal instructions must show if the waste disposal and its contract only cover the food production area or the entire estate.

questions.question: A food production area means an area in which food is prepared.
questions.description: A food production area is any building, room, part of a room or some other indoor or outdoor space where food meant to be sold or otherwise handed onwards is prepared, stored, transported, kept on sale, served or treated in some other way.

questions.question: Moulds can produce dangerous toxins in food products.
questions.description: Moulds can grow on food products. While growing, some moulds produce toxins that are hazardous for the human health. Mould toxins will sometimes not get destroyed when heating a food product, even though the mould itself might be destroyed.

questions.question: Washing machines do not need to be washed separately, because the washing temperatures are hot enough to destroy harmful microbes.
questions.description: Washing machines, as well as their dust filters and other removable parts, must be washed and dried regularly. The surfaces of the machines must also be swiped and the lids left open so that the machine's inside dries.

questions.question: Tapeworms can be found in the roe (eggs) and muscles of some lake fish.
questions.description: Tapeworms can be found in the roe (eggs) and muscles of lake fish, such as bass, pike, burbot and ruffe. Proper cooking or freezing (2 days minimum) will destroy the tapeworm.

questions.question: Products in protective gas packages contain microbes.
questions.description: Products in protective gas packages always contain some microbes. The protective gas is used to prevent microbes that require oxygen from growing.

questions.question: The temperature monitoring of cold storages is a part of own-check plans.
questions.description: The temperatures of cold storages must be checked and logged regularly according to the own-check plan. Cold storages must always have thermometers for measurements.

questions.question: Salt can not contain microbes.
questions.description: Salt is dry, so microbes do not grow in it. However, salt can contain spores of bacteria, moulds or yeast.

questions.question: Safety data sheets of detergents (washing chemicals) include first aid instructions.
questions.description: Safety data sheets include the most important information about detergents (washing chemicals) and also include first aid instructions.

questions.question: A cooked food product can be cooled outside or in front of an open window if there is no separate cooler for that purpose.
questions.description: Food products must never be cooled or stored outside. If there is a need to cool cooked products, there must be a designated cooling cabinet or other sufficient cooling space for it. Small batches can also be cooled in a cold bath.

questions.question: Cooked rice left at room temperature is a good breeding ground for various microbes.
questions.description: Bacillus cereus is one of the bacteria that causes food poisoning; it cannot be completely stopped from spreading to food products. Bacillus cereus is found in almost all food products. It is most commonly spread through rice dishes and vegetables.

questions.question: During food preparation one can go wash one's hands in the staff restroom.
questions.description: There must be a separate hand washing spot in immediate proximity to the food preparation area.

questions.question: Using food, that has been served at a buffet table, as an ingredient for preparing new foods increases food poisoning risks.
questions.description: Food that is at a buffet table is often in room temperature and available to be taken by customers themselves. This means that food poisoning causing bacteria spread to these foods easier and reproduce quicker in them. The risk of food poisoning increases when the same foods are used to make new ones. Food from buffet tables must not be used again in food preparation.

questions.question: Rings and other hand jewellery as well as watches must be removed when working with easily perishable food products.
questions.description: Jewellery and watches are not part of a food product employee's work uniform. Microbes, dirt and chemicals can easily stay underneath them even after washing one's hands, and these can later spread while working. Earrings and piercings on one's face can also be a hazard to hygienic working.

questions.question: When outside temperatures are very cold, food products can be cooled quickly outside.
questions.description: Food products must not be cooled or stored outside. All equipment and products, e.g. boxes containg baked goods, must be stored inside.

questions.question: Guide dogs are allowed inside food product stores.
questions.description: Guide dogs are always allowed in areas meant for customers. However, no animals can be taken inside food product handling areas or storage areas.

questions.question: Blue cheese contains living mould.
questions.description: Clean, controlled and living moulds are used when producing blue cheese. The moulds create various taste ingredients in the cheese.

questions.question: The gas in protective gas packaging completely prevents harmful microbes from growing.
questions.description: The amount of oxygen in protective gas is changed to make it harder for most microbes to grow. Some harmful microbes can withstand exceptional conditions and will be able to reproduce even in protective gas packages. Additionally, the protective gas in the packages will try to equalize with the air around it, so the amount of gas can change.

questions.question: The same broom can be used for cleaning the floor and work surfaces.
questions.description: Floors contain a lot more microbes than work surfaces. If floor brooms are used for work surfaces, the microbes on the floor will spread to the work surface from the broom.

questions.question: Health inspectors can not inspect a workplace's own-check plan's monitoring logs.
questions.description: Health inspectors make routine inspections in food production areas. The monitoring logs of the own-check plans are also part of the inspections. The logs must be stored for 1 year in the workplace. Only stored logs can prove that the workplace has followed its own-check plan accordingly.

questions.question: When a new detergent is introduced into a kitchen, the cleaning plan in the own-check plan is updated.
questions.description: It is important that the own-check plan is always up to date. All changes to the own-check plan, e.g. introduction of a new detergent, must be updated in the cleaning plan.

questions.question: Fresh fish and roe must be stored between 0 and 2 degrees Celsius.
questions.description: Fresh fish and roe are very easily perishable food products which must be stored close to the temperature of melting ice, between 0 and 2 degrees Celsius. Certain food perishing causing bacteria, which make fish and roe be considered a risk food product, are able to reproduce even in temperatures as low as 3 degrees Celsius.

questions.question: Potatoes must be washed with water that meets the requirements for domestic water.
questions.description: When preparing food, always use water that meets the requirements for domestic water to ensure that food safety is not compromised.

questions.question: When receiving food products it is enough to check their temperature.
questions.description: When receiving food products it is also required to check the products' appearance, the quality of the packaging and the packaging markings with the senses (visually etc.).

questions.question: Beneficial bacteria usually make it harder for harmful bacteria to grow.
questions.description: Harmful bacteria have to compete with beneficial bacteria for living space and nutrition. Beneficial bacteria can change living conditions in food products, e.g. the acidity, such that it becomes worse for harmful bacteria and makes them grow slower or not at all.

questions.question: Food tasting must be done with a spoon.
questions.description: Food must never be touched with the fingers if it is not necessary. Spoons should be used for tasting.

questions.question: Food poisoning causing bacteria can not be found naturally.
questions.description: Microbes are everywhere: in the air, water, earth, plants, animals and humans. Some of these microbes cause food poisoning.

questions.question: Hand washing areas must be used only for washing hands.
questions.description: Hand washing areas can not be used for other washing purposes; this helps to prevent microbes from spreading in food production areas.

questions.question: Worn down and broken equipment is a hygienic risk.
questions.description: Waste food can get easily stuck in worn or broken equipment. Even small amounts of waste food will give microbes a good growing environment.

questions.question: The acidity of food products affects the reproduction of bacteria in the products.
questions.description: Increasing the acidity of a food product makes it harder for many harmful microbes to reproduce. Because of this, lactic acid fermentation is a good traditional way to store e.g. vegetables. The fermentation is based on how lactic acid works. Lactic acid bacteria (LAB) is a good example of beneficial microbes, which has good health benefits. All microbes are thus not harmful for food products.

questions.question: Temperature does not affect the speed of microbe reproduction.
questions.description: Temperatures are very important for the reproduction abilities of microbes. All microbes have their own optimal temperatures where reproduction is the fastest.

questions.question: The spores of clostridium perfringens bacteria are destroyed only with sterilization.
questions.description: All spores of bacteria can only be destroyed with sterilization.

questions.question: Cleaning plans are not a part of own-check plans.
questions.description: Cleaning plans are an important part of own-check plans. Cleaning plans include instructions and schedules for cleaning.

questions.question: Food that is being served while hot must be at least 55 degrees Celsius during the entire serving period.
questions.description: Food that is being served while hot must be kept at over 60 degrees Celsius during the entire serving period. The temperature must be measured and marked down in own-check logs.

questions.question: If a can of canned food has bloated and become larger, the contents inside the can must not be tasted.
questions.description: Bloated, enlargened cans can contain a dangerous toxin called botulin. Even a very small amount of botulin can be lethal.

questions.question: In commercial kitchens, it is necessary to nominate the people in charge of the own-check plan.
questions.description: Designated persons who have been trained for the task are responsible for the various areas of the own-check plan.

questions.question: Blue cheese contains living mould.
questions.description: Clean, controlled and living moulds are used when producing blue cheese. The moulds create various taste ingredients in the cheese.

questions.question: Raw milk can contain yersinia.
questions.description: Raw milk has not been pasteurized. Yersinia is destroyed when milk is heated to over 70 degrees Celsius; in other words it is destroyed when the milk is pasteurized.

questions.question: Dry flour contains no microbes.
questions.description: The microbes in dry products have not been destroyed. Dry products can contain spores of bacteria, moulds and yeast.

questions.question: It is not required to change single-use gloves worn on the hands if a phone is answered while wearing them.
questions.description: Only one phase of work can be done while wearing the same single-use gloves. If a phone is answered then the hands must be washed and the gloves must be changed.

questions.question: Cleaning equipment that is old and in bad condition can spread harmful microbes to a food production area.
questions.description: Cleaning equipment wears down and becomes dirty during use. They often contain microbes even though they are washed regularly. Cleaning equipment should be renewed regularly.

questions.question: A frozen product may be defrosted in room temperature if the product is needed quickly.
questions.description: Frozen products are always to be defrosted in coolers. If defrosting must be sped up, one can use the defrosting option on a microwave or the product can be kept in its packaging under cold running water.

questions.question: The waste disposal instructions for a food production area need to tell who is responsible for emptying the area's waste into the waste room's recycling bins.
questions.description: The waste disposal instructions need to tell which waste disposal company takes care of transporting waste away from the waste room, but the waste in the food production area needs to always be moved into the waste room at least after the work shift is over.

questions.question: Listeriosis should be avoided especially during pregnancy.
questions.description: Listeriosis during pregnancy can cause miscarriages or premature birth.

questions.question: Ham slices left over from a buffet can be used for lunch the next day.
questions.description: Food products that have been served at a buffet must never be served again. Food starts to perish immediately after cooking. Contamination is slowed down by adhering to the correct temperatures, serving time and hygienic working methods. A buffet, which is visited by a lot of people, offers particularly good conditions for contamination.

questions.question: Vibrio bacteria are found in sea waters at warm geographical locations.
questions.description: Vibrio bacteria have been found in salty coast seawater at warm geographical locations. Seafood that has been heated badly or stored in too warm temperatures are risk food products.

questions.question: The own-check plan has been created to make it easier for health officials to do their job.
questions.description: Own-check plans and measurement charts are the establishment's own documents that are supposed to emphasize the actor's own responsibility in controlling risks. If there are any problems, it is afterwords easier to find out what caused them. Officials check plans and interfere with defects if necessary.

questions.question: Food products can not be sold nor used after the last use-by-date.
questions.description: The last use-by-date must be marked on easily perishable food products. The marking must be based upon research results of lastingness.

questions.question: One of the reasons for the existence of own-check plans is to make the work of food product industry companies easier.
questions.description: Own-check plans that are done well make it easier for companies to upkeep food product safety because resources used for monitoring can be focused on things essential for company activities. Knowledge of the quality of the activities will also improve when the activities are planned. In the best case customer satisfaction, profitability and officials' trust will improve.

questions.question: The correct concentration of detergent significantly affects the cleaning result.
questions.description: Detergents and disinfectants must be measured out in accordance with the manufacturer's instructions. A solution that is stronger than recommended does not usually guarantee a better cleaning result, and a solution that is diluted too much may give a worse result.

questions.question: Kitchen staff do not need to remove jewellery made of precious metal because precious metal is not a hygiene hazard.
questions.description: Wearing jewellery is always a hygiene hazard. Dirt can accumulate under a ring, and a piece of jewellery or part of it can also come off and end up in food.

questions.question: Workers in the food industry, e.g. the owner of a small café, must inform local food control authorities about their activities.
questions.description: All workers in the food industry must inform food control authorities about their activities. The informing must be done before beginning the activities. When founding a food industry workplace, e.g. a sausage factory, the activities must also be approved by the authorities.

questions.question: When there is packaged meat in a delivery load, it can be safely left at room temperature for a few hours.
questions.description: The cold chain of meat products in a delivery load must not be broken.

questions.question: Suspicions of food poisoning are not a part of own-check plans because health officials will investigate the cause of disease if necessary.
questions.description: Own-check plans must have clear instructions for dealing with food poisoning cases and suspicions. Responsible people and methods of informing should be explained in the own-check plan.

questions.question: Disinfecting reduces the amount of microbes from work surfaces and equipment.
questions.description: Correctly done disinfection reduces the amount of microbes excellently on work surfaces and equipment.

questions.question: In Finland the milk found in cartons in stores is rarely pasteurized.
questions.description: In Finland the milk found in cartons in stores is almost always pasteurized milk. Only raw milk that has been bought directly from a dairy farm is not usually pasteurized.

questions.question: Additives may be used in all food products.
questions.description: Only approved additives can be used in the preparation of food products. Additives must undergo a thorough safety assessment before they are approved for use.

questions.question: Salmonella infection can only be acquired from foreign food products.
questions.description: Salmonella can be transmitted through both domestic and foreign food products or water contaminated with animal or human faeces, and it can cause food poisoning.

questions.question: If an employee has inflamed wounds on their hands, they must not handle easily perishable food products.
questions.description: A person with inflamed wounds or other inflamed areas on their hands or other visible skin must not handle unpacked food products. Small wounds in the hands must be cleaned and protected with a water-proof bandage, and single-use gloves must be used.

questions.question: The most hygienic way to dry your hands is to use a cloth towel.
questions.description: The most hygienic way to dry your hands is to use disposable hand towels.

questions.question: Milk can be stored at room temperature during the breakfast service.
questions.description: Milk and cream are perishable food products and they must be served cold.

questions.question: Bacteria spores are destroyed in freezers.
questions.description: Bacteria do not reproduce in freezers. However, the spores of the bacteria do not get destroyed during freezing.

questions.question: Waste bins in food premises may contain microbes that are a health hazard.
questions.description: It is important to make sure that waste bins are regularly emptied and that they are clean by washing them with appropriate detergents.

questions.question: Unpeeled and peeled carrots will last the same amount of time as long as they are stored in the cold.
questions.description: Earthy and dirty, untreated root vegetables will last long in appropriate cold storage units, but all treatments will worsen their lastingness.

questions.question: Smoking is allowed at the loading docks of kitchens.
questions.description: Loading docks are a part of food production areas; smoking is not allowed in food production areas.

questions.question: Thawing frozen food products in a sealed container at room temperature does not increase the risk of food poisoning.
questions.description: Food must be thawed in such a way as to minimise the increase of pathogens as much as possible. A frozen food product is defrosted in a cold room so that the temperature of the food product's surface does not rise above the other parts of the product.

questions.question: There may be flies in a food premises even if the waste management is well organised.
questions.description: Flies in the premises are always a sign of inadequate cleaning.

questions.question: Vacuum-packages have the air removed from them.
questions.description: Vacuum-packages do not include any air and prevent microbes that require oxygen from reproducing.

questions.question: Freezing in a sufficiently cold temperature improves the lastingness of products.
questions.description: Products can be stored by freezing them, but one must notice that freezing affects the quality of different food products. For example, fish, meat and baked goods dry up easily during freezing, so the quality of products stored in freezing must be checked regularly.

questions.question: Temperature measurements stated in the own-check plan must be done according to the own-check plan.
questions.description: Only regularly done measurements can prove that the own-check plan has been adhered to at a workplace.

questions.question: Eating is not allowed while preparing food.
questions.description: Microbes in the mouth spread onto the hands while eating. Eating must be done in a separate area and after eating hands must be washed.

questions.question: Pasteurized dairy products can be stored unopened in room temperature.
questions.description: Pasteurizing does not make it possible to store dairy products in room temperature. UHT-treated dairy products can be stored in room temperature if they are unopened.

questions.question: Temperature measurements stated in own-check plans do not have to made when one is busy.
questions.description: Only regularly done measurements can prove that the own-check plan has been adhered to at a workplace.

questions.question: The most hygienic way to dry your hands is to use a cloth towel.
questions.description: The most hygienic way to dry your hands is to use disposable hand towels.

questions.question: Food products can be cooled in the same freezer where frozen products are stored.
questions.description: Food products must first be cooled with separate cooling equipment and moved afterwards into a freezer for storage.

questions.question: Cleaning plans are not a part of own-check plans.
questions.description: Cleaning plans are an important part of own-check plans. Cleaning plans include instructions and schedules for cleaning.

questions.question: Soup made for the following day can be left to cool overnight on the kitchen counter.
questions.description: The rapid cooling and cold storing of soup prevents or slows down the growth of bacteria.

questions.question: Sterilizing allows easily perishable food products to be stored in room temperature.
questions.description: Canned foods are prepared by sterilizing them. This way canned meat, fish and baby food that has not been opened can be stored in room temperature.

questions.question: Yoghurt and viili contain live probiotics.
questions.description: Lactic acid bacteria play an important role in the production of dairy products.

questions.question: If a can of canned food has bloated and become larger, the contents inside the can must be tasted to make sure if the food is spoiled or not.
questions.description: Bloated, enlargened cans can contain a dangerous toxin called botulin. Even a very small amount of botulin can be lethal.

questions.question: Food products stored in protective gas do not have to be stored in the cold because the protective gas protects the products from perishing.
questions.description: Food products stored in packages with protective gas must always be stored in the cold according to the instructions on the packaging. Protective gas packages have normal air changed into air that contains little or no oxygen to prevent microbes that use oxygen from reproducing. Protective gas prevents e.g. the surface of meat from darkening and thus keeps the product sensually appealling.

questions.question: A food manufacturer is responsible for date labelling (best before date or use by date).
questions.description: A food manufacturer or packer is responsible for correct date labelling.

questions.question: Fresh fish is an easily perishable food product.
questions.description: Fresh fish is a very easily perishable food product. Fresh fish products must be stored at the temperature of melting ice, max 2 degrees Celsius.

questions.question: The post-contamination of a cooked product can be prevented by using appropriate and clean storing containers.
questions.description: Good hand hygiene, clean working equipment and hygienic storing containers protect cooked products from post-contamination due to hazards that affect the safety of the product after heating it.

questions.question: Food poisoning causing bacteria reproduce very quickly in biowaste bins kept in room temperature.
questions.description: Bacteria have good growing conditions in biowaste bins kept in room temperature: the temperature is good and there is plenty of nutrition and moisture. The amount of oxygen is different for different parts of the waste, so bacteria that live well in both oxygen-containing and non-oxygenic environments can reproduce in biowaste bins.

questions.question: You must remove all rings before washing your hands to make sure that no dirt remains under the rings.
questions.description: A lot of dirt and microbes live under rings, which means that rings must be removed before washing your hands.

questions.question: If food does not taste spoiled it can not cause food poisoning.
questions.description: Many food poisoning causing bacteria can reproduce in food without causing changes that can be noticed with the senses (visually, taste etc.)

questions.question: Temperature does not affect the reproduction speed of microbes.
questions.description: Temperatures are very important for the reproduction abilities of microbes. The insides of humans and animals often contain the optimal temperature for microbes, between 20 and 45 degrees Celsius.

questions.question: Food poisonings can be prevented by using single-use protective gloves.
questions.description: Single-use protective gloves must be used when handling very easily perishable food products. Protective gloves make it easier to work when employees must change tasks quickly.

questions.question: Listeria bacteria are not destroyed when a product is frozen.
questions.description: Freezing does not destroy microbes. Listeria can also reproduce in frozen foods.

questions.question: Good cleaning results are verified by taking samples from surfaces.
questions.description: Samples are taken from surfaces in order to verify that cleaning efforts are adequate.

questions.question: The transportation company is responsible for the approproate storing temperature of food during transportation.
questions.description: Drivers ensure that food is being stored in the right temperature, and that packages do not get damaged. The person receiving the delivery inspects the delivery and makes sure products quickly get placed in the appropriate storing place.

questions.question: Old and worn cleaning equipment can spread harmful microbes into food premises.
questions.description: It is important to make sure that cleaning equipment is always clean and in good condition.

questions.question: Cleaning plans are a part of own-check plans.
questions.description: Cleaning plans are an important part of own-check plans. Cleaning plans include instructions and schedules for cleaning.

questions.question: Hepatitis A is never spread in food products.
questions.description: The most important viruses that reproduce in the intestines of humans are the norovirus and hepatitis A. Both viruses last for a long time and are able to spread in the cold and even in frozen foods.

questions.question: Defrosting frozen foods in room temperature increases the risk of food poisoning.
questions.description: Frozen foods' surfaces will defrost faster than the insides. In room temperature the surfaces will become warm enough for microbes to grow even though the insides might still be frozen.

questions.question: Food packaging materials can be stored on a clean floor.
questions.description: Food packaging materials must never be stored directly on the floor but they must be placed on clean racks or other hygienic surfaces.

questions.question: A working and up-to-date collection of recipes is part of the own-check plan.
questions.description: Regularly served food needs to have up-to-date recipes. Recipes can be used to check what different foods contain and how they are prepared during any problematic situations.

questions.question: Viruses can not reproduce in food products.
questions.description: Viruses need living host cells to reproduce, which means they can not reproduce or produce toxins in food products. However, food products can still work as spreaders of viruses.

questions.question: Customer feedback is a part of the own-check plan.
questions.description: It is useful to pay attention to appropriate customer feedback when carrying out the own-check plan. Customer feedback can be viewed as a way to enhance quality of service. Feedback should be written down, discussed with the staff and utilized in developing procedures and protocols.

questions.question: Yeasts often cause spoilage in acidic food products.
questions.description: Bacteria grow in a more restricted pH range than yeast and mould. Yeasts grow best in food products with a pH of 5.

questions.question: Freezing improves the lastingness of food products because microbes are destroyed in the cold.
questions.description: Cold does not destroy microbes. If a product being freezed is microbiologically bad quality, it will be even worse quality after defrosting. However, freezing a good quality product will make it last longer as long as the freezing temperature is cold enough (-18 degrees Celsius or lower) and defrosting happens sufficiently slowly in cold areas.

questions.question: Temperature measurements are to be made only by the superiors of a workplace.
questions.description: The instructions of own-check plans must be adhered to by all employees. Because of this temperature measurements are also the responsibility of all other employees.

questions.question: Vegetables stored in a vinegared liquid can be kept in room temperature.
questions.description: Sterilized, can-packed and unopened vinegared products can be stored in room temperature. Vinegared products will last long due to the high acidity, but opened packages must be stored in cool temperatures.

questions.question: A cheese roll packed in a tight plastic wrap is protected from microbes.
questions.description: A cheese roll is a perishable food product that is stored and served cold. In addition to being wrapped in plastic film, make sure that it is kept in the correct storage and serving temperatures.

questions.question: Microbes reproduce in dry products.
questions.description: Microbes need water to reproduce. Microbes will not reproduce in dried products but dried products can contain spores of bacteria, moulds or yeast.

questions.question: The gutting and proper washing of fish is enough to prevent tapeworm infections.
questions.description: Infectious tapeworm larvas can be inside the muscles or roe of the fish. Tapeworm infections can be prevented by cooking or freezing the fish or roe.

questions.question: Customer feedback is not a part of the own-check plan.
questions.description: Customer feedback is part of a company's own-check plan. The own-check plan should also explain how feedback is used.

questions.question: Food products containing preservatives will also spoil.
questions.description: Preservatives only slow down the spoiling done by microbes. In the European Union all allowed preservatives have an E-code.

questions.question: Temperatures measured under the own-check plan do not need to be recorded if you learn them by heart.
questions.description: It is important to measure and record temperatures.

questions.question: Food control authorities are responsible for monitoring companies' own-check plans.
questions.description: The responsibility of own-check plans is the company's. Officials have a possibility to get to know companies' own-check plans and data while doing checks. However, own-check plan documents are companies' personal documents and the companies have the responsibility of storing them and training any personnel to act according to the own-check plan.

questions.question: All milk products must always be stored in cold storage, where the temperature is less than 6 degrees Celsius.
questions.description: Ultra-high-temperature processing sterilizes milk products. In UHT processing milk is heated for a few seconds to at least 135 degrees Celsius and packed into disinfected packaging in a clean area.This treatment destroys all reproducing micro-organisms and all unopened packages can be stored in room temperature.

questions.question: Working areas and surfaces must be cleaned regularly during work shifts and after work is over.
questions.description: Regular cleaning, done every 2-4 hours, of working equipment and surfaces with clean cleaning equipment, substances and water gets rid of leftover pieces of food, dust and other dirt that protects microorganisms and is used as living space by the organisms.

questions.question: A waiter must be able to tell customers the ingredients of a food product that has not been packed.
questions.description: A waiter must be able to provide customers with information about food products verbally and, if necessary, also in writing.

questions.question: All work phases, such as dishwashing, baking and treatment of root vegetables, can be done in the same area in hospital kitchens.
questions.description: When each work phase is done in its own separate area the work is hygienic and the risk of cross-contamination is smaller.

questions.question: Food products can not be stored on the floor of dry storage rooms.
questions.description: Storing food products on the floor is not a hygienic way to store food. Floors always contain more microbes than shelves.

questions.question: Ultra-high-temperature processing (UHT) uses higher temperatures than pasteurizing.
questions.description: Ultra-high-temperature processing is done in much higher temperatures than pasteurizing. UHT destroys most bacteria spores and because of this products that have been treated with UHT can be stored in room temperature.

questions.question: Lactic acid bacteria often cause food poisoning.
questions.description: Lactic acid bacteria do not cause food poisoning. Lactic acid bacteria are not harmful if used in the treatment of food poisoning, but they have not been scientifically proven to be of any use either.

questions.question: If one's hands are clean, the temperature of food can be checked with the fingers.
questions.description: It is not possible to see how microbiologically clean one's hands are if only using the bare eye. Microbes can spread from the fingers to cooked food; when measuring the temperature of food a thermometer which can be easily cleaned must be used.

questions.question: Cleaning plans are a part of own-check plans.
questions.description: Cleaning plans are an important part of own-check plans. Cleaning plans include instructions and schedules for cleaning.

questions.question: You are allowed to use snus (nuuska in Finnish) while preparing food.
questions.description: The use of snus (nuuska in Finnish) is prohibited while preparing food.

questions.question: Salmonella infection can only be acquired from foreign food products.
questions.description: Salmonella can be transmitted through both domestic and foreign food products or water contaminated with animal or human faeces, and it can cause food poisoning.

questions.question: Dried products can spoil quickly if they become wet.
questions.description: Dried products last long if they are stored dry. If the products become wet the microbes in them will start to reproduce.

questions.question: Sterilizing only destroys microbes capable of reproducing.
questions.description: Sterilizing destroys reproductive spores as well as bacteria spores. Canned foods are produced with sterilization.

questions.question: Food products that contain preservatives can not cause food poisoning.
questions.description: Preservatives prevent and slow down the growth of microbes in food products. However, preservatives do not destroy food poisoning causing bacteria, which makes food poisoning possible.

questions.question: Listeria and yersinia can reproduce in refrigerator temperatures.
questions.description: Earth and various bodies of water contain microbes, such as listeria and yersinia, that are able to survive cold conditions well. Listeria and yersinia can reproduce in very cold refrigerator temperatures.

questions.question: Dirty and clean work clothes must be stored in separate places.
questions.description: There should be a separate place for storing dirty work clothes. Work clothes should also be clean, neat and suitable for food related work.

questions.question: Using own-check plans takes a lot of time and resources.
questions.description: Well-planned own-check plans saves time and resources. Resources used for monitoring can be focused on the most important areas, activities and control points. Resources can also be focused on the most effective preventive actions. In problematic situations correct procedures will be known and mistakes can be fixed quickly.

questions.question: If upon delivery there are any problems in regards to the transportation temperature of easily perishable food products, one should report it to Finnish Food Safety Authority.
questions.description: If there are any problems with the quality of delivered products, they should be returned to the supplier and reported to the driver.

questions.question: Waiters and servers are not required to have headwear.
questions.description: Waiters and servers are allowed to work without headwear.

questions.question: After washing one's hands the tap must be closed using a hand towel, otherwise the hands can become dirty again.
questions.description: After washing the hands they must be dried using a single-use hand towel and the tap must be closed using the towel. This way any possible microbes on the tap do not spread onto the clean hands.

questions.question: Salmonella infections can be symptomless.
questions.description: It is possible for salmonella infections to not be noticed. One might not notice the infection at all, but can still spread the salmonella to others. In practice salmonella can only be spread if one's hands are not washed well after going to the toilet.

questions.question: Tap water can cause food poisoning.
questions.description: Tap water cleanliness must be monitored using the senses. Water samples can also be regularly sent for chemical and microbiological inspections. For example the food poisoning causing norovirus lasts well in water.

questions.question: Food products that have been thawed only once can be refrozen as long as they are packed in hygienic packaging.
questions.description: You must never refreeze food products that have already been thawed.

questions.question: An entire block of cheese spoils faster than cheese that has been sliced.
questions.description: The spoiling of a product usually starts on the surface. The surface contains a lot of oxygen and some amounts of microbes have always been spread onto the surface during production and packing. Products with lots of surface area always spoil faster than similar products that are still in their original entire form.

questions.question: Food products are allowed to freeze during transport and this does not cause any harm.
questions.description: Food must not be frozen during transport as this will impair the hygienic quality of the food products. Perishable food products that require cold storage are transported in temperatures that do not exceed those set for storing perishable food products.

questions.question: Hand washing areas must be used only for washing hands.
questions.description: Hand washing areas can not be used for other washing purposes; this helps to prevent microbes from spreading in food production areas.

questions.question: Mould toxins are destroyed when food products are boiled.
questions.description: Mould toxins can not be destroyed by only boiling them.

questions.question: Eating is not allowed while preparing food.
questions.description: Microbes in the mouth spread onto the hands while eating. Eating must be done in a separate area and after eating hands must be washed.

questions.question: Dishwashing should be done so that dirty dishes and clean dishes are handled separately enough.
questions.description: Clean dishes will become dirty again if they are not kept separate from dirty dishes.

questions.question: Campylo bacteria is naturally found in fowl and poultry.
questions.description: Campylo bacteria and salmonella are found naturally in fowl and poultry. Both bacteria are destroyed when the meat is cooked thoroughly to over 75 degrees Celsius.

questions.question: Wine is produced with the help of beneficial microbes.
questions.description: The production of wine and beer uses yeast. Yeast is a beneficial microbe.

questions.question: The gas in protective gas packaging completely prevents harmful microbes from growing.
questions.description: The amount of oxygen in protective gas is changed to make it harder for most microbes to grow. Some harmful microbes can withstand exceptional conditions and will be able to reproduce even in protective gas packages. Additionally, the protective gas in the packages will try to equalize with the air around it, so the amount of gas can change.

questions.question: Food product employees are required to have good personal hygiene.
questions.description: Good personal hygiene, including regular washing, clean and neat hair, short nails and healthy cuticles are signs of good work hygiene as well.

questions.question: When preparing a own-check plan, all essential food product risk monitoring must be explained.
questions.description: It is essential for the plan to think which parts of done activities are ones where microbes can reproduce and how risks will be monitored, as well as what actions must be taken to fix risk situations.

questions.question: Crates can be stored on the loading dock as long as they are protected from the rain.
questions.description: Storing crates on the loading dock is a hygiene hazard as they attract birds and other animals.

questions.question: When a food product is vacuum packed, food poisoning bacteria cannot grow in it.
questions.description: Food poisoning microbes that tolerate anaerobic and low-oxygen conditions can multiply in a vacuum pack.

questions.question: The maximum storage temperature for cooked shellfish is +6°C.
questions.description: Cooked molluscs and shellfish are stored at the temperature of melting ice (maximum +2°C).

questions.question: Vibrio bacteria are found in sea waters at warm geographical locations.
questions.description: Vibrio bacteria have been found in salty coast seawater at warm geographical locations. Seafood that has been heated badly or stored in too warm temperatures are risk food products.

questions.question: Employees are free to decide who is responsible for the own-check plan at the beginning of each shift.
questions.description: Designated persons who have been trained for the task are responsible for the various areas of the own-check plan.

questions.question: Rings and other hand jewellery as well as watches must be removed when working with easily perishable food products.
questions.description: Jewellery and watches are not part of a food product employee's work uniform. Microbes, dirt and chemicals can easily stay underneath them even after washing one's hands, and these can later spread while working. Earrings and piercings on one's face can also be a hazard to hygienic working.

questions.question: Own-check plans are meant for the leadership of food industry companies.
questions.description: Own-check plans include lots of instructions and lists responsibilities. Because of this it is important that all employees get to know the own-check plan and adhere to it while working.

questions.question: Listeria bacteria are destroyed when a product is frozen.
questions.description: Freezing does not destroy microbes. Listeria can also reproduce in frozen foods.

questions.question: When evaluating or checking the quality of food it is enough to check the dates on the packaging.
questions.description: Along with checking the dates, the food products must also be checked using the senses (visually etc.) because of the possibility of them warming up or partially melting if they have been wrongly stored during transportation.

questions.question: Dairy products that contain lactose keep well at room temperature.
questions.description: Dairy-based products that are produced by using at least pasteurisation are stored at +8 degrees. Ultra-heat treated milk keeps at room temperature for several months.

questions.question: Cleaning equipment that is old and in bad condition can spread harmful microbes to a food production area.
questions.description: Cleaning equipment wears down and becomes dirty during use. They often contain microbes even though they are washed regularly. Cleaning equipment should be renewed regularly.

questions.question: Food products containing preservatives never spoil.
questions.description: Preservatives only slow down the spoiling done by microbes.

questions.question: An animal can be slaughtered in a restaurant if a special permit has been granted.
questions.description: It is prohibited to slaughter animals in restaurants.

questions.question: Transported products and cargo being received do not have to be checked.
questions.description: The quality of arriving products must be checked and the temperatures of easily perishable products must be measured. The results must be written down.

questions.question: EHEC bacteria are intestinal bacteria.
questions.description: EHEC bacteria is found especially in the intestines of cattle. EHEC bacteria create toxins in the intestines of humans. The toxin often causes bloody diarrhea and very uncomfortable stomache pains.

questions.question: Disinfecting reduces the amount of microbes from work surfaces and equipment.
questions.description: Correctly done disinfection reduces the amount of microbes excellently on work surfaces and equipment.

questions.question: Earth does not contain food poisoning causing bacteria.
questions.description: Earth can contain e.g. bacillus cereus or clostridum bacteria. Both of these are common causers of food poisoning.

questions.question: Food poisoning is always caused by some kind of bacteria or virus.
questions.description: Food poisoning can also be caused by parasites, protozoa, natural toxins (such as in morel mushrooms), poisonous plants or animals, chemicals or some other disease-causing particle.

questions.question: During the cooling of food microbes are not able to reproduce in the food.
questions.description: The danger zone for food temperatures is between 6 and 60 degrees Celsius. Microbes can reproduce in food when the temperature is within this danger zone. During the cooling of food the food is within this danger zone.

questions.question: Dirty root vegetables and pre-made food products can not be stored in the same cold room.
questions.description: Dirt always contains many microbes. Dirty root vegetables must be handled separately from other products so that the microbes in the dirt do not spread to other food products.

questions.question: The own-check plan helps to make sure that there are fewer unsafe food products.
questions.description: The most important objective of the own-check plan is to improve food safety.

questions.question: Microbes are only found in places which are visibly dirty.
questions.description: Microbes are everywhere, not only in dirty locations. However it is probable that dirty spots contain more microbes than clean ones.

questions.question: Staphylococcus aureus is a food poisoning bacteria.
questions.description: The human skin, nose and mucous membranes can contain staphylococcus aureus. Good hand hygiene is important due to this.

questions.question: Hand towels made out of cloth can be used at a hand washing station in a food production area as long as the towels are changed daily.
questions.description: Cloth hand towels can not be used when working with food products. A cloth hand towel that is rolled from an automated towel dispenser is an exception to this rule.

questions.question: If the dry storage rooms has no space elsewhere, food products can be stored on the floor of the room for a short time.
questions.description: Food products can not be stored on the floor even for a short time.

questions.question: When a new detergent is introduced into a kitchen, the cleaning plan in the own-check plan is updated.
questions.description: It is important that the own-check plan is always up to date. All changes to the own-check plan, e.g. introduction of a new detergent, must be updated in the cleaning plan.

questions.question: A low activity of water in food products means that the products can contain water, but microbes can't use the water to reproduce.
questions.description: The products can contain water, but microbes can not use it. The water activity can be lowered by adding sugar or salt to the products.

questions.question: Coffee cream and milk may be stored in room temperature, because they will be added to hot coffee.
questions.description: Milk and cream are easily perishable food products, and they must be served cold.

questions.question: Prepared salads can be stored in room temperature without a risk of food poisoning.
questions.description: Prepared salads are easily perishable food products. For example, chopped or grated vegetables and root vegetables, meat, fish and mayonnaise are often ingredients of prepared salads, so they have to be stored in the cold.

questions.question: Own-check plans do not need to include clear instructions on how to act when food poisoning suspicions are raised.
questions.description: When food is prepared for customers, food poisoning events must be planned for in advance. Own-check plans must include clear instructions for these events. It is important to notify health inspectors about suspicions immediately.

questions.question: Frozen fish is thawed on the kitchen counter.
questions.description: Frozen food products are always thawed in a cold room.

questions.question: Fever and the flu are good reasons for a food product employee to not go to work.
questions.description: Food products should not be handled when one has a fever or the flu because causes of the disease spread easily by coughing or sneezing.

questions.question: The amount of things covered in the waste disposal instructions must be the same for everyone in the food industry.
questions.description: The own-check plan's waste disposal instructions' coverage depends on what the done activities cover.

questions.question: When handling food products, employees should not touch their nose if possible.
questions.description: The nose contains lots of microbes which will spread onto the hands if the nose is touched.

questions.question: If a food product includes nuts it does not have to say so on the package.
questions.description: Packaging markings must tell if the product contains ingredients that cause allergic reactions; the EU has a compiled list of these.

questions.question: Cooling cabinets are used only for cooling food.
questions.description: Food should be cooled to less than 6 degrees Celsius within only 4 hours. When the products have been cooled they should be moved into another cold storage unit. Cooling cabinets are only used for cooling food (not storing.)

questions.question: Earth does not contain food poisoning causing bacteria.
questions.description: Earth can contain e.g. bacillus cereus or clostridum bacteria. Both of these are common causers of food poisoning.

questions.question: Food products must never be cooled or stored outside.
questions.description: Food products must not be cooled or stored outside. All equipment and products, e.g. boxes containg baked goods, must be stored inside.

questions.question: Additives may be used in all food products.
questions.description: Only approved additives can be used in the preparation of food products. Additives must undergo a thorough safety assessment before they are approved for use.

questions.question: Bacteria can reproduce in more acidized environments than moulds and yeasts.
questions.description: Bacteria that are a threat to food product safety reproduce the best in the neutral zone. Because of this the growth of these bacteria can be prevented by increasing the acidity of a product.

questions.question: Guide dogs are allowed inside food product stores.
questions.description: Guide dogs are always allowed in areas meant for customers. However, no animals can be taken inside food product handling areas or storage areas.

questions.question: The temperatures of cold storage equipment do not need to be measured if they feel cold enough.
questions.description: The temperatures of refrigerating equipment, drawers and cabinets must be measured and logged at the same time each day. Atypical measuring results are logged in the own-check forms and necessary measures are taken to restore the right temperature in that piece of equipment.

questions.question: A cleaning equipment storage room is not needed in a food production area.
questions.description: It's not always necessary to have a separate storage space for cleaning equipment. Food production areas need a separate storage, maintenance and drying space if the food production area requires it for constructional reasons. It's important to make sure that there are no risks for food safety and the hygienic treatment, maintenance and storage of cleaning equipment are done properly. If necessary the working stages and functions has to be separated structually or timely.

questions.question: A cheese roll packed in a tight plastic wrap is protected from microbes.
questions.description: A cheese roll is a perishable food product that is stored and served cold. In addition to being wrapped in plastic film, make sure that it is kept in the correct storage and serving temperatures.

questions.question: Ice cubes cannot contain harmful microbes, because their temperature is so low.
questions.description: Ice cubes can contain harmful microbes if the ice cube machine or the ice cube container hasn't been properly cleaned. The water used for producing the ice cubes has to meet the standards for clean drinking water.

questions.question: Smoking is not allowed at the loading docks of kitchens.
questions.description: Loading docks are a part of food production areas; smoking is not allowed in food production areas.

questions.question: Production of cheese uses beneficial microbes.
questions.description: Clean, controlled and beneficial microbes are used in cheeses. During storage these microbes will create taste ingredients in the cheese.

questions.question: All milk products must always be stored in cold storage, where the temperature is less than 6 degrees Celsius.
questions.description: Ultra-high-temperature processing sterilizes milk products. In UHT processing milk is heated for a few seconds to at least 135 degrees Celsius and packed into disinfected packaging in a clean area.This treatment destroys all reproducing micro-organisms and all unopened packages can be stored in room temperature.

questions.question: All microbes are harmful to humans.
questions.description: Many food products also have in them naturally beneficial microbes, and with many food manufacturing processes microbes have an essential role, like for example making beer and fermented vegetables.

questions.question: The slime that appears on the surface of meat products is caused by harmful microbes.
questions.description: Some harmful microbes produce slime. For example, slime appearing on the surface of a sausage is a sign of it perishing. Slime-producing microbes reproduce quickly in food products e.g. when the product is stored or served in too high temperatures.

questions.question: Disinfecting reduces the amount of microbes from work surfaces and equipment.
questions.description: Correctly done disinfection reduces the amount of microbes excellently on work surfaces and equipment.

questions.question: There is no need to measure the temperature in the freezer because the food products are frozen.
questions.description: Regular monitoring of the freezer temperature is an important part of the own-check plan. The most important aspect of storage management is the regular monitoring and recording of storage room temperatures. Freezers must have a thermometer and a system for recording temperatures regularly.

questions.question: Organic food does not cause food poisoning as easily as "normal" food.
questions.description: Organic food is produced without fertilizers or pesticides. This does not affect food poisoning almost at all. The risk for food poisoning is the same between "normal" and organic food.

questions.question: BSE is also called mad cow's disease.
questions.description: Mad cow's disease is sometimes found in old cows. During slaughtering the carcasses must be checked so that contaminated meat is not used.

questions.question: Sneezing spreads harmful microbes into the surrounding environment in the droplets/spray.
questions.description: There are lots of microbes in the respiratory system and mouth which can spread into the surroundings.

questions.question: Whipping is one way to improve the shelf life of cream.
questions.description: If you whip cream, you process an unpackaged perishable food product, which shortens its shelf life.

questions.question: Baker's yeast contains living microbes.
questions.description: Baker's yeast itself is living yeast microbes. These yeast microbes will die if the temperature goes over 42 degrees Celsius. Because of this baker's yeast can not be added to a liquid that is too hot.

questions.question: Pasteurisation of milk destroys listeria bacteria.
questions.description: Pasteurisation of milk is a process that destroys listeria bacteria. Milk is pasteurised when heated to 72°C for about 15 seconds.

questions.question: Every employee shares in the responsibility of carrying out the own-check plan.
questions.description: Sharing responsibility is an essential part of a own-check plan. Every task of the plan requires a person who is in charge of that particular task, logs measurements and verifies them with his or her signture. Own-check plans also require continuing staff training and familiarization with relevant tasks.

questions.question: The own-check plan has been created to make it easier for health officials to do their job.
questions.description: Own-check plans and measurement charts are the establishment's own documents that are supposed to emphasize the actor's own responsibility in controlling risks. If there are any problems, it is afterwords easier to find out what caused them. Officials check plans and interfere with defects if necessary.

questions.question: Not all microbes and bacteria-spores in food products can be destroyed using any treatments.
questions.description: Sterilizing or radiating can destroy all bacteria or microbe-spores in food products. Canned food, such as canned tuna and canned baby food is sterilized by heating the packed products. Spices are one example of a product that can be treated by radiation.

questions.question: Food products stored in protective gas do not have to be stored in the cold because the protective gas protects the products from perishing.
questions.description: Food products stored in packages with protective gas must always be stored in the cold according to the instructions on the packaging. Protective gas packages have normal air changed into air that contains little or no oxygen to prevent microbes that use oxygen from reproducing. Protective gas prevents e.g. the surface of meat from darkening and thus keeps the product sensually appealling.

questions.question: Food tasting must be done with a spoon.
questions.description: Food must never be touched with the fingers if it is not necessary. Spoons should be used for tasting.

questions.question: When hot food being served is kept at over 60 degrees Celsius the microbes in the food can not reproduce.
questions.description: If the food is not eaten or cooled immediately after production it must be kept at over 60 degrees Celsius when being served to prevent microbes from reproducing. The serving time is 4 hours at maximum.

questions.question: Tap water does not contain microbes.
questions.description: Even tap water can contain microbes. Tap water cleanliness must be monitored using the senses. Water samples can also be regularly sent for chemical and microbiological inspections.

questions.question: Hand washing areas must be cleaned regularly.
questions.description: A dirty hand washing area is a risk for hand hygiene.

questions.question: Products sold at a fish stall must have a marking if they have been defrosted for sale.
questions.description: Customers must know if they are buying products that have already been defrosted. A product that has been frozen and defrosted once can not be frozen again.

questions.question: Frozen fish is thawed on the kitchen counter.
questions.description: Frozen food products are always thawed in a cold room.

questions.question: Bacteria spores are destroyed in freezers.
questions.description: Bacteria do not reproduce in freezers. However, the spores of the bacteria do not get destroyed during freezing.

questions.question: Fresh fish and roe must be stored between 0 and 2 degrees Celsius.
questions.description: Fresh fish and roe are very easily perishable food products which must be stored close to the temperature of melting ice, between 0 and 2 degrees Celsius. Certain food perishing causing bacteria, which make fish and roe be considered a risk food product, are able to reproduce even in temperatures as low as 3 degrees Celsius.

questions.question: Large central kitchens and small cafés have the same own-check plan.
questions.description: All workplaces must design their own own-check plan that suits their activities. The acitivities, products and customers are different in small cafés and large kitchens. The own-check plans of large kitchens must be more precise and also more broad.

questions.question: Food poisoning can be caused by careless hand washing.
questions.description: Dirty hands may contain microbes that cause food poisoning.

questions.question: Only reproductive microbes are destroyed during sterilization. Bacteria spores are not destroyed.
questions.description: During sterilization (e.g. during canned food production) all microbes and bacteria spores are destroyed. This way easily perishable products will be able to last long in room temperature.

questions.question: A food poisoning epidemic is a situation where at least 10 people have become sick with similar symptoms after consuming the same food product or ingredient.
questions.description: A food poisoning epidemic means a situation where at least 2 people have become sick with similar symptoms after consuming the same food or drink.

questions.question: Intestinal bacteria can spread from hands to food.
questions.description: Intestinal bacteria can spread to food even from the hands.

questions.question: Temperature measurements are to be made only by the superiors of a workplace.
questions.description: The instructions of own-check plans must be adhered to by all employees. Because of this temperature measurements are also the responsibility of all other employees.

questions.question: The own-check plan has been created to make it easier for health officials to do their job.
questions.description: Own-check plans and measurement charts are the establishment's own documents that are supposed to emphasize the actor's own responsibility in controlling risks. If there are any problems, it is afterwords easier to find out what caused them. Officials check plans and interfere with defects if necessary.

questions.question: If you drop a steak onto the floor, you can use it as long as you fry it.
questions.description: A steak that has fallen onto the floor must never be used for cooking. Food products must never be stored on the floor.

questions.question: When washing dishes, the prewashing should be done with water that is as hot as possible.
questions.description: Prewashing must be done with cool-temperatured water. Too hot water can burn albumin spots onto the surface of the dish and create biofilm, which is a suitable growing environment for microbes.

questions.question: Food production employees are allowed to wear colorless nail polish.
questions.description: Hands must not containt anything extra such as watches, jewellery, fake nails, nail polish or hand cream.

questions.question: If an easily perishable food product has been stored in too warm conditions, the use-by-date marked on the package is no longer reliable.
questions.description: The use-by-date is reliable only if the product has been stored correctly. Storing products in too warm conditions always makes the products last for shorter periods of times.

questions.question: The contents of a bulged can of food can be used for food preparation if the product is properly heated.
questions.description: All causes of food poisoning are not eliminated by heating. The contents of a bulged (ie. faulty) can of food must be discarded.

questions.question: If a food premises changes owners, this must always be reported to the local food authority.
questions.description: When a food premises changes owners, this must always be reported to the local food authority.

questions.question: Yeasts often cause spoilage in acidic food products.
questions.description: Bacteria grow in a more restricted pH range than yeast and mould. Yeasts grow best in food products with a pH of 5.

questions.question: Customer feedback is a part of the own-check plan.
questions.description: It is useful to pay attention to appropriate customer feedback when carrying out the own-check plan. Customer feedback can be viewed as a way to enhance quality of service. Feedback should be written down, discussed with the staff and utilized in developing procedures and protocols.

questions.question: Yoghurt and viili contain live probiotics.
questions.description: Lactic acid bacteria play an important role in the production of dairy products.

questions.question: Staphylococcus bacteria, which cause food poisoning, are part of the normal flora on the hands and mucous membranes.
questions.description: The skin is a good environment for many bacteria, and the skin usually has a lot of different bacteria as part of its normal flora.

questions.question: After washing dishes must be dry before they can be piled for storing.
questions.description: Harmful microbes multiply in damp conditions, so dishes must be allowed to fully dry before piling.

questions.question: The own-check plan only refers to measuring and recording temperatures.
questions.description: The purpose of the own-check plan is to help operators to manage the risks associated with food hygiene. Measuring and recording temperatures is an important part of the own-check system. Other areas of the own-check system include cleaning and tidiness as well as hygienic skills of the staff.

questions.question: Actions made after noticing mistakes or abnormalities in the packaging or quality of food products during receival checks must be logged in the own-check plan.
questions.description: Mistakes or abnormalities noticed in the quality or packaging of food products must be logged into the own-check plan. It is also required to detailedly log what actions are made after noticing a mistake or abnormality and who is responsible for informing for example the supplier of the products about it.

questions.question: Dishes do not need to be pre-washed before being put into a washing machine if the washing temperature is hot enough.
questions.description: Dishes must always be pre-washed before being put into a washing machine. It is important to get rid of protein spots with cool water so that the protein does not stick to the dishes in hot temperatures. The biofilm that the protein creates acts as a living space for microbes.

questions.question: Prepared salads can be stored in room temperature without a risk of food poisoning.
questions.description: Prepared salads are easily perishable food products. For example, chopped or grated vegetables and root vegetables, meat, fish and mayonnaise are often ingredients of prepared salads, so they have to be stored in the cold.

questions.question: All plastic containers are suitable for storing food.
questions.description: Materials that come into contact with food must be meant for food use.

questions.question: The post-contamination of a cooked product can be prevented by using appropriate and clean storing containers.
questions.description: Good hand hygiene, clean working equipment and hygienic storing containers protect cooked products from post-contamination due to hazards that affect the safety of the product after heating it.

questions.question: Wooden utensils are well suited for professional kitchens if they are washed in a washing machine on a sufficiently hot program.
questions.description: Wooden utensils should not be used in professional kitchens, as they do not withstand repeated washes in a washing machine. Materials must very durable in order to cope with repeated washes, like for example plastic and steel utensils that are meant for food product related use.

questions.question: The waste bins in waste assortment rooms do not need lids if they are emptied regularly times.
questions.description: The waste bins in waste assortment rooms need to have lids and need to be cleaned regularly enough. This way waste rooms do not attract pest insects and the rooms stay cleaner and more hygienic.

questions.question: Disinfecting reduces the amount of microbes from work surfaces and equipment.
questions.description: Correctly done disinfection reduces the amount of microbes excellently on work surfaces and equipment.

questions.question: Microbes reproduce in dry products.
questions.description: Microbes need water to reproduce. Microbes will not reproduce in dried products but dried products can contain spores of bacteria, moulds or yeast.

questions.question: Minced meat that has been prepared in a store can be sold on the day of preparation and the day after that.
questions.description: Minced meat prepared in a retail store and grounded liver can be sold on the day of preparation and the day after it has been prepared.

questions.question: When a new detergent is introduced into a kitchen, the cleaning plan in the own-check plan is updated.
questions.description: It is important that the own-check plan is always up to date. All changes to the own-check plan, e.g. introduction of a new detergent, must be updated in the cleaning plan.

questions.question: Listeria is an environmental bacteria that can reproduce in food products.
questions.description: Listeria monocytogenes is a bacteria that causes diseases in humans; it is common in you environment. The optimal temperature for the bacteria is the internal temperature of humans, 30 to 37 degrees Celsius; however it can also reproduce in refrigeration temperatures. The bacteria can reproduce especially easily in vacuum-packed products because of their long storing times.

questions.question: Food tasting must be done with a spoon.
questions.description: Food must never be touched with the fingers if it is not necessary. Spoons should be used for tasting.

questions.question: Single-use gloves are used to protect the food preparer from microbes on the food products.
questions.description: The first priority of using single-use gloves is to protect the food products from microbes on the hands.

questions.question: Microbes are found everywhere in our environment.
questions.description: Microbes are everywhere, but they can not be seen with the naked eye. Most microbes are not dangerous for food hygiene.

questions.question: The placement of biowaste bins outside a restaurant does not matter as long as they are not close to an entrance.
questions.description: A waste room's  or recycling area's biowaste bins must be covered from the sun and placed such that pests do not get to them.

questions.question: Health inspectors can not inspect a workplace's own-check plan's monitoring logs.
questions.description: Health inspectors make routine inspections in food production areas. The monitoring logs of the own-check plans are also part of the inspections. The logs must be stored for 1 year in the workplace. Only stored logs can prove that the workplace has followed its own-check plan accordingly.

questions.question: The most hygienic way to dry your hands is to use a cloth towel.
questions.description: The most hygienic way to dry your hands is to use disposable hand towels.

questions.question: Disinfected work surfaces contain no microbes.
questions.description: Correctly done disinfection reduces the amount of microbes excellently on work surfaces and equipment. However, a disinfected work surface is not sterile.

questions.question: The most hygienic tools are well-washed hands.
questions.description: The handling of food products should be done with clean equipment instead of hands whenever possible. Clean and appropriate equipment is one of the most effective ways to prevent food products from contamination.

questions.question: When serving or distributing food products for free, the rules and requirements for handling food products must be followed.
questions.description: Food product handling rules are still required to be followed when serving for free.

questions.question: If one's hands have been carefully washed then food products can be handled with hands.
questions.description: Clean equipment should always be used instead of hands, no matter how well washed, whenever possible.

questions.question: The acidity of food products affects the reproduction of bacteria in the products.
questions.description: Increasing the acidity of a food product makes it harder for many harmful microbes to reproduce. Because of this, lactic acid fermentation is a good traditional way to store e.g. vegetables. The fermentation is based on how lactic acid works. Lactic acid bacteria (LAB) is a good example of beneficial microbes, which has good health benefits. All microbes are thus not harmful for food products.

questions.question: A cheese roll packed in a tight plastic wrap is protected from microbes.
questions.description: A cheese roll is a perishable food product that is stored and served cold. In addition to being wrapped in plastic film, make sure that it is kept in the correct storage and serving temperatures.

questions.question: The waste disposal procedures for professional kitchens, such as recycling, are decided upon between the personnel.
