questions.description: A professional kitchen's waste disposal is based on waste laws as well as regional waste disposal directives.

questions.question: Harmful microbes can multiply at a refrigerator's temperature.
questions.description: Harmful microbes can multiply at a refrigerator's temperature and even at 0°C. Listeria and yersinia are pathogens that are tolerant to cold.

questions.question: Kitchen surfaces and work stations must be washed once a day after one's work shift is over.
questions.description: Surfaces and work stations must always be cleaned properly fter every step or part of work and always whenever it is considered necessary based on visual information. A full cleaning and washing of these areas as well as floors and waste bins after emptying them must be done after the work shift is over, and more times if necessary.

questions.question: Fever and the flu are good reasons for a food product employee to not go to work.
questions.description: Food products should not be handled when one has a fever or the flu because causes of the disease spread easily by coughing or sneezing.

questions.question: The results in Oiva-reports are not allowed to be read by customers.
questions.description: Municipality food control authorities do routine inspections at workplaces. Oiva-reports are published documents about these inspections.

questions.question: Officials will prepare an own-check plan for new companies in the food product industry.
questions.description: Companies in the food product industry must prepare their own own-check plan when starting their activities. The plan must be followed and updated when needed.

questions.question: A cooked food product can be cooled outside or in front of an open window if there is no separate cooler for that purpose.
questions.description: Food products must never be cooled or stored outside. If there is a need to cool cooked products, there must be a designated cooling cabinet or other sufficient cooling space for it. Small batches can also be cooled in a cold bath.

questions.question: Rings can be used when handling unpacked food products.
questions.description: Rings can not be used when handling unpacked food products, because microbes have optimal growth conditions underneath them.

questions.question: Chefs can use their work shoes during their travel to and from their workplace.
questions.description: Work shoes must not be worn outside the workplace to prevent microbes from spreading into the food production area.

questions.question: Unprepared root vegetables can temporarily be stored in a cleaning supply closet or another spacious place.
questions.description: Food products cannot be stored in places that are not meant for that purpose.

questions.question: Jewellery and watches must be removed from one's hands before washing hands.
questions.description: Jewellery and watches must always be removed before washing. They must also not be used while preparing food because they collect microbes which may travel into the prepared food and cause food poisoning risks.

questions.question: Food poisoning bacteria cannot multiply in vacuum packaged food products.
questions.description: A vacuum package does not prevent bacteria from multiplying. Anaerobs, ie. food poisoning bacteria that multiply in spaces free from oxygen can also multiply in vacuum packages.

questions.question: High salt content prevents harmful microbes from multiplying in a product
questions.description: Strong salting of a product changes the state of its water so that microbes can not reproduce. However, salted products such as mushrooms must still be stored in cool temperatures to prevent microbes on their surface from perishing them.

questions.question: A cleaning equipment storage room is not needed in a food production area.
questions.description: It's not always necessary to have a separate storage space for cleaning equipment. Food production areas need a separate storage, maintenance and drying space if the food production area requires it for constructional reasons. It's important to make sure that there are no risks for food safety and the hygienic treatment, maintenance and storage of cleaning equipment are done properly. If necessary the working stages and functions has to be separated structually or timely.

questions.question: People who have been infected with salmonella always have diarrhoea.
questions.description: The symptoms of salmonella infection include nausea, diarrhoea, high temperature and headache. Not everyone with the infection has symptoms.

questions.question: Cleaning plans are not a part of own-check plans.
questions.description: Cleaning plans are an important part of own-check plans. Cleaning plans include instructions and schedules for cleaning.

questions.question: Eating is not allowed while preparing food.
questions.description: Microbes in the mouth spread onto the hands while eating. Eating must be done in a separate area and after eating hands must be washed.

questions.question: The uniform used for food product work can also be used while travelling to work if using one's own car.
questions.description: Using the work uniform outside of work is not allowed. Work uniforms and shoes are meant to protect food products from becoming dirty.

questions.question: Food packaging materials can be stored on a clean floor.
questions.description: Food packaging materials must never be stored directly on the floor but they must be placed on clean racks or other hygienic surfaces.

questions.question: Production of cheese uses beneficial microbes.
questions.description: Clean, controlled and beneficial microbes are used in cheeses. During storage these microbes will create taste ingredients in the cheese.

questions.question: Foreign frozen raspberries can be served without heating because the freezing destroys any possible disease causers.
questions.description: Foreign frozen raspberries must always be heated properly (boiling for 5 minutes) before serving because they may contain the norovirus. Freezing does not destroy disease causers that have gotten into the food product before freezing, because viruses stay able to spread for a long time in different conditions.

questions.question: If there are other companies working in the same estate, then the food production area needs a waste disposal area separate from the other companies' areas.
questions.description: Waste disposal areas can be the same with other companies but the own-check plan's waste disposal instructions must show if the waste disposal and its contract only cover the food production area or the entire estate.

questions.question: If a food premises changes owners, this must always be reported to the local food authority.
questions.description: When a food premises changes owners, this must always be reported to the local food authority.

questions.question: A cooked meal and the raw ingredients used to prepare it can be stored in the same container during transport.
questions.description: Cooked meals and raw ingredients are always stored separately in their own clean containers.

questions.question: The checking of food and the monitoring of temperature when receiving food products is a part of the own-check plan.
questions.description: The correct storing temperatures affect the lastingness and safety of food. The monitoring of temperature by measurements is an important part of the own-check plan when receiving food products.

questions.question: If a product has been cooled once already, heating it again must be done very carefully.
questions.description: Reheating cooled food must be done very carefully to make sure its microbiological quality stays good. Heating the product thoroughly to 70 degrees Celsius should be possible. Because of this a microwave oven is not a good tool for reheating, because different ingredients in the food will heat in different ways.

questions.question: Food products can be used safely after the use-by date if they do not look or smell bad.
questions.description: Perished or contaminated products are not always possible to notice just by using the senses (visually etc.) Easily perishable food products' packages have a use-by date marked on them, and after this date has passed the product must not be used or sold.

questions.question: Food poisoning causing bacteria reproduce quickly in food kept in room temperature.
questions.description: The temperature of food products left in room temperature becomes suitable for bacteria reproduction, which causes the reproduction to become much quicker in the food product.

questions.question: Food poisoning is always caused by bacteria that has been accidentally let into food.
questions.description: Food poisoning can often be caused by storing food for too long in hazardous temperatures, too slow cooling or ineffective heating. These are situations where bacteria have had time to reproduce and multiply.

questions.question: Ascorbic acid (vitamin C) can not be used as a preservative.
questions.description: Ascorbic acid lowers the pH value of food products. The growth of bacteria especially can be slowed down by increasing the acidity of products.

questions.question: Frozen foods can be defrosted on a kitchen table if the liquid from the melting does not pour onto the table.
questions.description: All frozen foods must be defrosted in cold storage units. When defrosting, one must make sure that the defrosting product does not pour liquid onto any other food products placed or stored in the cold storage unit. Defrosted or just partially defrosted products can not be frozen again.

questions.question: Cooked rice is not an easily perishable food product.
questions.description: Dry rice lasts in room temperature. Cooked rice contains moisture and because of this it is an easily perishable product. Cooked rice must be stored under 6 degrees Celsius.

questions.question: A biowaste container that is kept closed can be stored in the kitchen's storage area at room temperature for a few days.
questions.description: Waste must be stored in a designated area that is sufficiently separated from other operations and food products.

questions.question: When you clean a refrigerator, you only need to wipe away visible dirt as microbes do not multiply in such a cold place.
questions.description: Refrigerators must be cleaned regularly with appropriate detergents. Some microbes thrive and even grow at the refrigerator temperature.

questions.question: Bacteria can reproduce in more acidized environments than moulds and yeasts.
questions.description: Bacteria that are a threat to food product safety reproduce the best in the neutral zone. Because of this the growth of these bacteria can be prevented by increasing the acidity of a product.

questions.question: Food production areas do not produce hazardous waste which would require special attention.
questions.description: Cleaning and washing substances as well as their packaging, and for example fluorescent lamps, are hazardous waste and must be recycled appropriately.

questions.question: Food served in a lunch buffet must remain at +60 degrees celsius for the entire duration of the serving.
questions.description: If food that has been prepared by heating or cooking is not served immediately, it must be kept at a temperature of at least 60 degrees throughout the entire serving.

questions.question: Ice cube machines do not need to be cleaned separately, because their low temperature prevents microbes from multiplying.
questions.description: Ice cube machines must be cleaned just as regularly and carefully as other cooling equipment.

questions.question: Biowaste bins do not have to be emptied daily if the bin has not become full.
questions.description: Biowaste bins must be emptied at least once a day because biowaste contains perishing materials.

questions.question: Mashed potato is not an easily perishable food product.
questions.description: Pre-made foods are easily perishable products. Easily perishable foods must be stored in the cold, under 6 degrees Celsius.

questions.question: Cold-stored root vegetables may contain Yersinia bacteria that cause food poisoning.
questions.description: Root vegetables that are cold stored for a long time may contain Yersinia bacteria that cause food poisoning.

questions.question: Visually clean work surfaces guarantee their microbiological cleanliness.
questions.description: Microbiological cleanliness can not be guaranteed by using just the bare eye. Correct cleaning methods and equipment, as well as regular and proper cleaning, guarantee the cleanliness much better. Samples can also be taken of the cleanliness of specific surfaces if required.

questions.question: Protective gloves are used to protect employees' hands from dirt, so that their hands do not need to be washed as often.
questions.description: Gloves are also used to protect food from microbes spread by hands. Gloves are a great way to keep work hygiene good when tasks must be changed quickly. Gloves must be changed regularly enough while working to keep hygiene good. It is also good to properly wash and dry one's hands when changing gloves. Gloves must always be changed immediately after touching door handles or taps.

questions.question: Chopping vegetables improves their shelf life.
questions.description: Whole vegetables keep better than chopped vegetables. Handling food products impairs their shelf life.

questions.question: Workers in the food industry can be found responsible for a customer becoming sick.
questions.description: Product liability laws also cover food products. If a customer is able to provide sufficient evidence, a worker in the food industry can be found responsible for causing a sickness in the customer.

questions.question: The checking of food and the monitoring of temperature when receiving food products is a part of the own-check plan.
questions.description: The correct storing temperatures affect the lastingness and safety of food. The monitoring of temperature by measurements is an important part of the own-check plan when receiving food products.

questions.question: A cooked food product can be cooled outside or in front of an open window if there is no separate cooler for that purpose.
questions.description: Food products must never be cooled or stored outside. If there is a need to cool cooked products, there must be a designated cooling cabinet or other sufficient cooling space for it. Small batches can also be cooled in a cold bath.

questions.question: An entire block of cheese spoils faster than cheese that has been sliced.
questions.description: The spoiling of a product usually starts on the surface. The surface contains a lot of oxygen and some amounts of microbes have always been spread onto the surface during production and packing. Products with lots of surface area always spoil faster than similar products that are still in their original entire form.

questions.question: Biofilm means plastic wrap that is specially made for food products.
questions.description: Biofilm can form onto e.g. the surface of a plate if prewashing is done with too hot water before proper dishwashing. Too hot water can burn albumin spots onto the surface of the dish and create biofilm, which is a suitable growing environment for microbes.

questions.question: During food preparation one can go wash one's hands in the staff restroom.
questions.description: There must be a separate hand washing spot in immediate proximity to the food preparation area.

questions.question: The amount of water a product contains does not significantly affect its lastingness.
questions.description: Harmful microbes need water to reproduce. Because of this dry products last well.

questions.question: EHEC bacteria can be found in milk is the work hygiene during milking is not proper.
questions.description: This intestinal bacteria can only found in food products if the work hygiene is not proper during milking or slaughtering. Pasteurization destroys EHEC in milk.

questions.question: Bacteria can reproduce in more acidized environments than moulds and yeasts.
questions.description: Bacteria that are a threat to food product safety reproduce the best in the neutral zone. Because of this the growth of these bacteria can be prevented by increasing the acidity of a product.

questions.question: Wooden utensils are well suited for professional kitchens if they are washed in a washing machine on a sufficiently hot program.
questions.description: Wooden utensils should not be used in professional kitchens, as they do not withstand repeated washes in a washing machine. Materials must very durable in order to cope with repeated washes, like for example plastic and steel utensils that are meant for food product related use.

questions.question: Dirty root vegetables and pre-made food products can be stored in the same cold room.
questions.description: Dirt always contains many microbes. Dirty root vegetables must be handled separately from other products so that the microbes in the dirt do not spread to other food products.

questions.question: Cleaning plans include accurate instructions about how and when cleaning is done.
questions.description: A cleaning plan is an essential part of an own-check plan. Cleaning plans include more accurate instructions on the cleaning of all parts of a food production area.

questions.question: Botulism, a food poisoning caused by clostridium botulinum, is always a very weak food poisoning.
questions.description: Clostridium botulinum creates a very deadly toxin called botulin. The food poisoning caused by botulin can cause death.

questions.question: Arriving products and cargo must be checked when received.
questions.description: The quality of arriving products must be checked and the temperatures of easily perishable products must be measured. The results must be written down.

questions.question: The spores of clostridium perfringens bacteria are destroyed only with sterilization.
questions.description: All spores of bacteria can only be destroyed with sterilization.

questions.question: It is not essential for hygiene whether hands are washed using liquid soap or soap blocks.
questions.description: Soap used for hand washing must be mild so that it will not damage the skin of the hands. The soap must be liquid and the soap dispenser must also be hygienic. Warm water is used for washing, and it is also important to properly dry one's hands after washing them.

questions.question: Easily perishable food products that have been up for retail sale can be frozen and sold as frozen foods.
questions.description: The preparation of frozen foods requires the ingredients to be perfect quality. Frozen foods must be prepared, cooled and frozen without any delay. Frozen foods are prepared only by appropriate production centres. Freezing is allowed in bakeries, households and farm households only if the areas and equipment are approved by officials.

questions.question: All monitoring logs made for own-check plans must be stored for at least a year at the workplace.
questions.description: Only stored monitoring logs can prove that the own-check plan has been adhered to.

questions.question: When raw frozen chicken is thawed it releases liquid that can contain salmonella.
questions.description: Raw fowl/poultry meat can always contain salmonella, which will not be destroyed in a freezer. If the meat contains salmonella it will also certainly be in the liquid.

questions.question: Kitchens in hospitals should have separate spaces for different work phases such as the treatment of root vegetables, baking and dishwashing.
questions.description: When each work phase is done in its own separate area the work is hygienic and the risk of cross-contamination is smaller.

questions.question: Due to salmonella risks, fowl and poultry meat must always be heated thoroughly to over 75 degrees Celsius.
questions.description: Fowl/poultry can contain salmonella naturally. Salmonella bacteria must be alive to cause an illness. The meat of fowl/poultry is safe if it is heated thoroughly to over 75 degrees Celsius.

questions.question: A restaurant can use food products after their best before date has expired provided that the products are sufficiently well heated well.
questions.description: It is prohibited to sell or use food products after their best before date has expired, and they must not be used in the manufacture of food to be sold or served.

questions.question: Blanching can be used to improve the lastingness of chopped vegetables during freezing.
questions.description: Blanching, which means rapid boiling, stops frozen vegetables' enzymic activity by destroying microbes on their surface.

questions.question: Crates can be stored on the loading dock as long as they are protected from the rain.
questions.description: Storing crates on the loading dock is a hygiene hazard as they attract birds and other animals.

questions.question: Food poisoning is always caused by bacteria that has been accidentally let into food.
questions.description: Food poisoning can often be caused by storing food for too long in hazardous temperatures, too slow cooling or ineffective heating. These are situations where bacteria have had time to reproduce and multiply.

questions.question: Tap water can cause food poisoning.
questions.description: Tap water cleanliness must be monitored using the senses. Water samples can also be regularly sent for chemical and microbiological inspections. For example the food poisoning causing norovirus lasts well in water.

questions.question: In Finland the milk found in cartons in stores is almost always pasteurized milk.
questions.description: Only raw milk that has been bought directly from a dairy farm is not usually pasteurized.

questions.question: The amount of things covered in the waste disposal instructions must be the same for everyone in the food industry.
questions.description: The own-check plan's waste disposal instructions' coverage depends on what the done activities cover.

questions.question: Hard rye bread (crisp bread) is not an easily perishable food product.
questions.description: Hard rye bread is a dry food product, and because of this microbes can not reproduce in it. Hard rye bread can be stored in room temperature.

questions.question: Milk can be stored at room temperature during the breakfast service.
questions.description: Milk and cream are perishable food products and they must be served cold.

questions.question: The only mandatory information on food packaging is the ingredients and the name of the food product.
questions.description: In addition to the name of the food product and the ingredients, the packaging must also state the minimum shelf life and the use by date.

questions.question: Safety data sheets are the same thing as the instruction manual of a device.
questions.description: Safety data sheets include the most important information about detergents (washing chemicals) and also include first aid instructions.

questions.question: Bars of soap are to be used when washing the hands.
questions.description: Microbes on the hands will spread onto bar soap. Because of this bar soap is not hygienic enough.

questions.question: Guide dogs are not allowed inside food product stores.
questions.description: Guide dogs are always allowed in areas meant for customers. However, no animals can be taken inside food product handling areas or storage areas.

questions.question: Own-check plans must also include e.g. cleaning and waste disposal procedures.
questions.description: Own-check plans must, along with microbiological risks, consider the hygiene of personnel, cleaning, receival of products and actions to be done when pests have been noticed.

questions.question: If food does not taste spoiled it can not cause food poisoning.
questions.description: Many food poisoning causing bacteria can reproduce in food without causing changes that can be noticed with the senses (visually, taste etc.)

questions.question: The state and cleanliness of the waste management room does not affect the kitchen's hygienic quality.
questions.description: The waste management room must also be kept organised and clean. A dirty waste management room and badly cleaned waste bins can collect pests and spread microbes that are harmful for food products.

questions.question: Mould that has spread from blue cheese to other cheeses is not hazardous.
questions.description: Mould spreading from blue cheese to other cheeses, which the mould is not supposed to be in, is hazardous and can worsen the quality and also perish the cheeses. However, the spreading of the mould to other cheeses is not always a health risk.

questions.question: It is important to visually monitor cleanliness on a daily basis in addition to regular cleaning.
questions.description: Everyone working in a food premises must constantly monitor its cleanliness.

questions.question: Received food products must be stored where there is the most space for them in the storage facility.
questions.description: Received food products are stored based on the FIFO method (First In, First Out) which means that products already stored in the storage facility are moved to the front to be used or taken first, and any new products are placed behind or after any prior ones. This way the products are taken out of storage in the order they arrived in and the amount of wastage is reduced.

questions.question: Salmonella infections always cause severe symptoms. In other words it is impossible for the person carrying the salmonella to not know about it.
questions.description: It is possible for salmonella infections to not be noticed. One might not notice the infection at all, but can still spread the salmonella to others. In practice salmonella can only be spread if one's hands are not washed well after going to the toilet.

questions.question: There must be an appropriate washing place for large machines and dishes in the food premises.
questions.description: A cleaning plan is made for every machine and device to specify an appropriate place for washing each one of them.

questions.question: Food production areas do not need a written cleaning plan if the procedures have been discussed carefully with the personnel and everyone knows their tasks.
questions.description: The cleaning and washing program always needs to be part of the food production area's own-check plan. The own-check plan is produced on paper before starting activities in the food production area.

questions.question: Microbes are only found in places which are visibly dirty.
questions.description: Microbes are everywhere, not only in dirty locations. However it is probable that dirty spots contain more microbes than clean ones.

questions.question: Production of cheese uses beneficial microbes.
questions.description: Clean, controlled and beneficial microbes are used in cheeses. During storage these microbes will create taste ingredients in the cheese.

questions.question: Prepared salads can be stored in room temperature without a risk of food poisoning.
questions.description: Prepared salads are easily perishable food products. For example, chopped or grated vegetables and root vegetables, meat, fish and mayonnaise are often ingredients of prepared salads, so they have to be stored in the cold.

questions.question: When a food product is vacuum packed, food poisoning bacteria cannot grow in it.
questions.description: Food poisoning microbes that tolerate anaerobic and low-oxygen conditions can multiply in a vacuum pack.

questions.question: EHEC bacteria are not intestinal bacteria.
questions.description: EHEC bacteria is found especially in the intestines of cattle. EHEC bacteria create toxins in the intestines of humans. The toxin often causes bloody diarrhea and very uncomfortable stomache pains.

questions.question: Dried products can spoil quickly if they become wet.
questions.description: Dried products last long if they are stored dry. If the products become wet the microbes in them will start to reproduce.

questions.question: Rings and other hand jewellery as well as watches must be removed when working with easily perishable food products.
questions.description: Jewellery and watches are not part of a food product employee's work uniform. Microbes, dirt and chemicals can easily stay underneath them even after washing one's hands, and these can later spread while working. Earrings and piercings on one's face can also be a hazard to hygienic working.

questions.question: Hand washing areas must be used only for washing hands.
questions.description: Hand washing areas can not be used for other washing purposes; this helps to prevent microbes from spreading in food production areas.

questions.question: Food products are always safe if the best before date has not yet expired.
questions.description: A food product may be contaminated even if there are still several days until the best before date. Contamination may be caused by unhygienic tools or work environment and incorrect temperatures, for example.

questions.question: Listeria can not reproduce in cold fish (e.g. salmon) in vacuum-packages.
questions.description: Listeria and yersinia are rare exceptions of food poisoning causing bacteria, because they can reproduce in refrigerator temperatures.

questions.question: The safety data sheets of detergents (washing chemicals) must always be kept close to their storage location.
questions.description: Safety data sheets must be kept near detergents so that the user of the detergent can read e.g. the first aid instructions.

questions.question: BSE, also called mad cow's disease, is not a food poisoning causing bacteria.
questions.description: BSE is caused by changes in the central nervous system of cows. Humans can get the disease only by eating meat that is contaminated with BSE.

questions.question: Beneficial microbes cannot be used in the production of cream cheese.
questions.description: Cream cheese is made using beneficial microbes.

questions.question: Waste disposal is not a part of the own-check plan.
questions.description: The own-check plan always includes instructions for waste disposal. How much the instructions cover always depends on the activities and what the activities cover. It is important to set daily assignments and responsibility areas.

questions.question: New products that are to be moved into cold storage are placed where there is enough room for them.
questions.description: In cold storage older products are placed in front and newer ones in the back. Older products are always to be used first. This is called the first in-first out principle.

questions.question: If the product being handled is fresh and of good quality, the handling hygiene is not as important.
questions.description: Hygienic handling methods and equipment are always important for the lastingness of products. A fresh and good quality good will still perish easily if it is handled unhygienically.

questions.question: Food that has been heated once is always sterile.
questions.description: Heating food does not make it sterile. Heating might not destroy all of the spores of bacteria and moulds. Microbe growth can start again from the spores in the right conditions, which can cause the food to become perished. Ready food can also be contaminated after heating by e.g. hands of employees.

questions.question: Hand washing sinks can be used for cleaning root vegetables.
questions.description: Enough hand washing areas must be available, and they must only be used for washing hands.

questions.question: Fermented milk products are produced with the help of lactic acid bacteria.
questions.description: Lactic acid bacteria (LAB) are used when producing fermented milk products. LAB create lactic acid in the product, which causes the product to become acidized. Most bacteria are unable to reproduce in acidized products and because of this fermenting milk products makes them last longer.

questions.question: Ice cubes cannot contain harmful microbes, because their temperature is so low.
questions.description: Ice cubes can contain harmful microbes if the ice cube machine or the ice cube container hasn't been properly cleaned. The water used for producing the ice cubes has to meet the standards for clean drinking water.

questions.question: An employee handling unpacked, easily perishable food products can not have nail polish while working.
questions.description: Nail polish can not be worn when handling easily perishable food products because the polish can break off into the products. Microbes also have good growth environments to reproduce under nails and nail polish. Nails and hands must be kept in good condition when working with food products.

questions.question: The temperature checks for received food products that need hot or cold storage are part of the own-check plan.
questions.description: Temperature monitoring of hot or cold storage food products when receiving is an important part of the own-check plan. If the temperatures do not meet set requirements they can be returned to the supplier as faulty products.

questions.question: Cooling cabinets are used only for cooling food.
questions.description: Food should be cooled to less than 6 degrees Celsius within only 4 hours. When the products have been cooled they should be moved into another cold storage unit. Cooling cabinets are only used for cooling food (not storing.)

questions.question: Products in protective gas packages contain microbes.
questions.description: Products in protective gas packages always contain some microbes. The protective gas is used to prevent microbes that require oxygen from growing.

questions.question: Salmonella can only get transmitted through feces.
questions.description: Salmonella can get transmitted through feces by way of poor hand hygiene but also via contaminated food products, such as raw meat and eggs.

questions.question: Frozen products can be thawed in room temperature to make the thawing fast enough.
questions.description: If food products are thawed in room temperature, the products' surfaces will melt quicker than the insides. The surfaces will start to spoil even though the insides can still be frozen.

questions.question: All work phases, such as dishwashing, baking and treatment of root vegetables, can be done in the same area in hospital kitchens.
questions.description: When each work phase is done in its own separate area the work is hygienic and the risk of cross-contamination is smaller.

questions.question: If a summer restaurant is located next to a lake with clean water, the water in the lake can be used for washing fruits.
questions.description: All food preparation requires the use of water that is tap water quality.

questions.question: Equipment used for slicing food products must be cleaned regularly.
questions.description: Equipment used for slicing food products is cleaned regularly by disassembling it and washing the parts with the appropriate washing agent.

questions.question: BSE, also called mad cow's disease, is a food poisoning causing bacteria.
questions.description: BSE is not a food poisoning causing bacteria. BSE is caused by changes in the central nervous system of cows.

questions.question: HACCP is not a food poisoning causing bacteria.
questions.description: HACCP stands for Hazard Analysis and Critical Control Points, which is a part of own-check plans. When working with an own-check plan these critical points must be identified and constantly monitored carefully.

questions.question: The same broom can be used for cleaning the floor and work surfaces.
questions.description: Floors contain a lot more microbes than work surfaces. If floor brooms are used for work surfaces, the microbes on the floor will spread to the work surface from the broom.

questions.question: Food production areas' food waste must be stored in cool temperatures if possible.
questions.description: Food waste should be stored in cold areas specifically meant for the waste if it is possible. However, it is rare to have so many cold areas that they can also be used separately for waste.

questions.question: The own-check plan of a food production area is done by a municipality health inspector.
questions.description: Workplaces in the food industry must create their own own-check plan that suits their activities. The plan is supposed to ensure the safety of food products, good lastingness and the following of official rules and directives.

questions.question: Bacteria spores are not destroyed during boiling.
questions.description: Bacteria spores are destroyed only during sterilization. In excess pressure the temperature is raised to about 145 degrees Celsius and this way bacteria spores are also destroyed.

questions.question: Bacteria reproduce very quickly in products that have high acidity.
questions.description: Bacteria that are a threat to food product safety reproduce the best in the neutral zone. Because of this the growth of these bacteria can be prevented by increasing the acidity of a product.

questions.question: Staphylococcus bacteria, which cause food poisoning, are part of the normal flora on the hands and mucous membranes.
questions.description: The skin is a good environment for many bacteria, and the skin usually has a lot of different bacteria as part of its normal flora.

questions.question: After washing dishes must be dry before they can be piled for storing.
questions.description: Harmful microbes multiply in damp conditions, so dishes must be allowed to fully dry before piling.

questions.question: During the cooling of food microbes are not able to reproduce in the food.
questions.description: The danger zone for food temperatures is between 6 and 60 degrees Celsius. Microbes can reproduce in food when the temperature is within this danger zone. During the cooling of food the food is within this danger zone.

questions.question: Pasteurizing and ultra-high-temperature processing (UHT) mean the same thing.
questions.description: Ultra-high-temperature processing is done in much higher temperatures than pasteurizing. UHT destroys most bacteria spores and because of this products that have been treated with UHT can be stored in room temperature.

questions.question: Listeria bacteria are not destroyed when a product is frozen.
questions.description: Freezing does not destroy microbes. Listeria can also reproduce in frozen foods.

questions.question: Detergents and disinfectants used in food premises can be stored anywhere.
questions.description: Detergents and disinfectants must be stored in such a place that they do not endanger food safety.

questions.question: Single-use gloves are used to protect the food preparer from microbes on the food products.
questions.description: The first priority of using single-use gloves is to protect the food products from microbes on the hands.

questions.question: The post-contamination of a cooked product can be prevented by using appropriate and clean storing containers.
questions.description: Good hand hygiene, clean working equipment and hygienic storing containers protect cooked products from post-contamination due to hazards that affect the safety of the product after heating it.

questions.question: Customers and employees must have their own, separate toilets.
questions.description: Strict toilet and hand hygiene must be used in food production. This is not possible if toilets are shared with customers.

questions.question: The amount of things covered in the waste disposal instructions must be the same for everyone in the food industry.
questions.description: The own-check plan's waste disposal instructions' coverage depends on what the done activities cover.

questions.question: Pasteurized dairy products can be stored unopened in room temperature.
questions.description: Pasteurizing does not make it possible to store dairy products in room temperature. UHT-treated dairy products can be stored in room temperature if they are unopened.

questions.question: The norovirus is destroyed when a food product is frozen.
questions.description: The norovirus lasts for long amounts of time and is able to spread even in the cold or in frozen foods.

questions.question: The purpose of the own-check plan is to make sure that operators manage the risks associated with food hygiene in their operations.
questions.description: Drawing up and following an own-check plan helps operators to manage the risks associated with food hygiene.

questions.question: Mashed potato is not an easily perishable food product.
questions.description: Pre-made foods are easily perishable products. Easily perishable foods must be stored in the cold, under 6 degrees Celsius.

questions.question: Raw milk contains more microbes than pasteurized milk.
questions.description: When milk is pasteurized a large amount of microbes gets destroyed. For example listeria, salmonella and EHEC bacteria are destroyed during pasteurization.

questions.question: The orientation of new employees is not part of the own-check plan.
questions.description: The orientation and training of new employee is an important part of the own-check plan.

questions.question: If there are other companies working in the same estate, then the food production area needs a waste disposal area separate from the other companies' areas.
questions.description: Waste disposal areas can be the same with other companies but the own-check plan's waste disposal instructions must show if the waste disposal and its contract only cover the food production area or the entire estate.

questions.question: Heat and humidity accelerate vegetable spoilage.
questions.description: The correct storage temperatures and moisture affect the shelf life of vegetables.

questions.question: If there are any problems in temperature or sensory quality of delivered food products, a spoken report to one's supervisor is sufficient.
questions.description: Mistakes or abnormalities in temperature or sensory quality of delivered easily perishable products must always be logged in the own-check plan forms.

questions.question: Salmonella can only get transmitted through feces.
questions.description: Salmonella can get transmitted through feces by way of poor hand hygiene but also via contaminated food products, such as raw meat and eggs.

questions.question: Freezing does not always destroy food poisoning microbes.
questions.description: Freezing does not kill microbes, but prevents them from multiplying.

questions.question: Minced meat lasts as long as unprepared meat if it is packaged in a vacuum container or vacuum bag.
questions.description: Minced meat requires that it be stored in a maximum temperature of +4 degrees celsius, whereas whole meat can be stored in +6 degrees celsius.

questions.question: Workers in the food industry, e.g. an online store sselling food products, must inform local food control authorities about their activities.
questions.description: All workers in the food industry must inform food control authorities about their activities. The informing must be done before beginning the activities. When founding a food industry workplace, e.g. a sausage factory, the activities must also be approved by the authorities.

questions.question: A delivery load that contains meat and fish products can be safely left at room temperature for three hours pending transfer into cold storage.
questions.description: The cold chain of perishable food products must not be interrupted at any point in the supply chain.

questions.question: The amount of sugar a product contains does not affect its lastingness.
questions.description: Highly sugared products, such as jams, marmelades and sweets do not perish easily because sugar changes the state of water so that microbes can not reproduce.

questions.question: Food production employees are allowed to wear colorless nail polish.
questions.description: Hands must not containt anything extra such as watches, jewellery, fake nails, nail polish or hand cream.

questions.question: The lastingness of food products can also be improved during treatment by using hygienic work methods, clean surfaces and equipment.
questions.description: Ingredients and their handling equipment must be kept separate from cooked products to prevent cross-contamination. For example, differently colored cutting boards and equipment for different food groups, such as vegetables, fish, meat and cooked food helps to prevent cross-contamination.

questions.question: Lactic acid bacteria (LAB) are used when producing yoghurt.
questions.description: Yoghurt and other fermented milk products use LAB in their production. LAB create lactic acid, which cause acidity in the products.

questions.question: Campylo bacteria is naturally found in fowl and poultry.
questions.description: Campylo bacteria and salmonella are found naturally in fowl and poultry. Both bacteria are destroyed when the meat is cooked thoroughly to over 75 degrees Celsius.

questions.question: Raw ingredients containing gluten must be labelled and stored in closed containers in a storage room.
questions.description: Raw ingredients containing allergens and gluten must be labelled and stored separately in closed containers.

questions.question: When a health inspector inspects a workplace, he or she will also check the workplace's own check plan's monitoring logs.
questions.description: Health inspectors make routine inspections in food production areas. The monitoring logs of the own-check plans are also part of the inspections. The logs must be stored for 1 year in the workplace. Only stored logs can prove that the workplace has followed its own-check plan accordingly.

questions.question: You must remove all rings before washing your hands to make sure that no dirt remains under the rings.
questions.description: A lot of dirt and microbes live under rings, which means that rings must be removed before washing your hands.

questions.question: Bacterial spores are more resistant than bacteria.
questions.description: When bacteria are in an environment where they cannot grow as easily, they turn into spores. Spores are more resistant than bacteria to heat and drought, for example.

questions.question: Defrosting frozen foods in room temperature increases the risk of food poisoning.
questions.description: Frozen foods' surfaces will defrost faster than the insides. In room temperature the surfaces will become warm enough for microbes to grow even though the insides might still be frozen.

questions.question: Temperature measurements stated in the own-check plan must be done according to the own-check plan.
questions.description: Only regularly done measurements can prove that the own-check plan has been adhered to at a workplace.

questions.question: People do not have any microbes on their skin if they shower regularly.
questions.description: There are microbes everywhere in soil, water, dust and also on human and animal skin.

questions.question: Dirty root vegetables and pre-made food products can not be stored in the same cold room.
questions.description: Dirt always contains many microbes. Dirty root vegetables must be handled separately from other products so that the microbes in the dirt do not spread to other food products.

questions.question: Bacteria can reproduce in more dry environments than moulds.
questions.description: Only some moulds can reproduce in very dry products. For example, bread becomes spoiled only due to mould; bacteria and yeasts can not reproduce in the bread.

questions.question: All dangerous food poisoning microbes need oxygen to grow.
questions.description: Most of the bacteria that cause food poisoning are facultative anaerobic bacteria, which means that they can grow in either the presence or absence of oxygen.

questions.question: If a can of canned food has bloated and become larger, the contents inside the can must be tasted to make sure if the food is spoiled or not.
questions.description: Bloated, enlargened cans can contain a dangerous toxin called botulin. Even a very small amount of botulin can be lethal.

questions.question: Pasteurisation of milk destroys listeria bacteria.
questions.description: Pasteurisation of milk is a process that destroys listeria bacteria. Milk is pasteurised when heated to 72°C for about 15 seconds.

questions.question: Cooked rice can be cooled in room temperature.
questions.description: Cooked rice is an easily perishable food product. In room temperature the microbes in the rice can reproduce very quickly and cause food poisoning.

questions.question: Food product employees can use wedding and engagement rings while handling easily perishable goods.
questions.description: Jewellery can not be used when working with food products. No matter how well hands are washed, a large amount of harmful microbes can stay under rings and can later contaminate food products being handled.

questions.question: Botulism, a food poisoning caused by clostridium botulinum, is always a very weak food poisoning.
questions.description: Clostridium botulinum creates a very deadly toxin called botulin. The food poisoning caused by botulin can cause death.

questions.question: Safety data sheets of detergents (washing chemicals) include first aid instructions.
questions.description: Safety data sheets include the most important information about detergents (washing chemicals) and also include first aid instructions.

questions.question: Unpacked raw fish must always be stored separate from other food products.
questions.description: Raw fish must be stored separately from other food products to prevent the risk of cross-contamination.

questions.question: Raw and cooked produce should not be handled at the same time or with the same utensils.
questions.description: Raw and cooked produce should be stored and handled separately. Surfaces should be properly cleaned in between handling raw and cooked produce. Unhygienic cleaning equipment can also contaminate the kitchen surfaces and cause microbes to spread. This type of spreading of microbes is called cross contamination.

questions.question: It is important to change disposable gloves often enough.
questions.description: When working with food, you must change disposable gloves whenever you start a new work phase.

questions.question: The uniform used for food product work can also be used while travelling to work if using one's own car.
questions.description: Using the work uniform outside of work is not allowed. Work uniforms and shoes are meant to protect food products from becoming dirty.

questions.question: Transported products and cargo being received do not have to be checked.
questions.description: The quality of arriving products must be checked and the temperatures of easily perishable products must be measured. The results must be written down.

questions.question: The acidity of food products affects the reproduction of bacteria in the products.
questions.description: Increasing the acidity of a food product makes it harder for many harmful microbes to reproduce. Because of this, lactic acid fermentation is a good traditional way to store e.g. vegetables. The fermentation is based on how lactic acid works. Lactic acid bacteria (LAB) is a good example of beneficial microbes, which has good health benefits. All microbes are thus not harmful for food products.

questions.question: Heating food to 75 degrees Celsius or more is enough to destroy salmonella.
questions.description: Salmonella will be destroyed in heat treatment when food is heated to at least 75 degrees Celsius.

questions.question: EHEC bacteria are intestinal bacteria.
questions.description: EHEC bacteria is found especially in the intestines of cattle. EHEC bacteria create toxins in the intestines of humans. The toxin often causes bloody diarrhea and very uncomfortable stomache pains.

questions.question: An employee handling unpacked, easily perishable food products can not have nail polish while working.
questions.description: Nail polish can not be worn when handling easily perishable food products because the polish can break off into the products. Microbes also have good growth environments to reproduce under nails and nail polish. Nails and hands must be kept in good condition when working with food products.

questions.question: Food poisoning microbes can only spread through the air.
questions.description: Food poisoning microbes can be transmitted into food in many ways such as via hands, soil, contaminated water or airborne dust particles. Rodents, insects and birds can also spread food poisoning microbes.

questions.question: Working surfaces must be dried properly after cleaning.
questions.description: Harmful microbes multiply in damp conditions, so surfaces must be fully dried after cleaning.

questions.question: After washing dishes must be dry before they can be piled for storing.
questions.description: Harmful microbes multiply in damp conditions, so dishes must be allowed to fully dry before piling.

questions.question: Chefs do not require a hygiene proficiency passport if their employment is not permanent.
questions.description: Chefs handle easily perishable food products in their work. This means that chefs must pass a hygiene proficiency test at least 3 months after starting their work.

questions.question: Dry flour contains microbes.
questions.description: Dry products can contain spores of bacteria, moulds and yeast. However, they do not reproduce in dry products.

questions.question: One of the reasons for the existence of own-check plans is to make the work of food product industry companies easier.
questions.description: Own-check plans that are done well make it easier for companies to upkeep food product safety because resources used for monitoring can be focused on things essential for company activities. Knowledge of the quality of the activities will also improve when the activities are planned. In the best case customer satisfaction, profitability and officials' trust will improve.

questions.question: All milk products must always be stored in cold storage, where the temperature is less than 6 degrees Celsius.
questions.description: Ultra-high-temperature processing sterilizes milk products. In UHT processing milk is heated for a few seconds to at least 135 degrees Celsius and packed into disinfected packaging in a clean area.This treatment destroys all reproducing micro-organisms and all unopened packages can be stored in room temperature.

questions.question: If a can of canned food has bloated and become larger, the contents inside the can must be tasted to make sure if the food is spoiled or not.
questions.description: Bloated, enlargened cans can contain a dangerous toxin called botulin. Even a very small amount of botulin can be lethal.

questions.question: The proper washing of hands removes all harmful bacteria from the skin.
questions.description: Even proper washing of hands does not remove all bacteria. Small skin damage and undersides of nails affect the amount of bacteria. Hands must be properly washed between different phases of work.

questions.question: Microbes are only found in places which are visibly dirty.
questions.description: Microbes are everywhere, not only in dirty locations. However it is probable that dirty spots contain more microbes than clean ones.

questions.question: The amount of water a product contains does not significantly affect its lastingness.
questions.description: Harmful microbes need water to reproduce. Because of this dry products last well.

questions.question: Due to salmonella risks, fowl and poultry meat must always be heated thoroughly to over 75 degrees Celsius.
questions.description: Fowl/poultry can contain salmonella naturally. Salmonella bacteria must be alive to cause an illness. The meat of fowl/poultry is safe if it is heated thoroughly to over 75 degrees Celsius.

questions.question: The sampling plan is not part of the own-check plan.
questions.description: The sampling plan is an important part of own-check operations.

questions.question: Tapeworms are parasites found especially in shellfish.
questions.description: Tapeworms can be found in the roe (eggs) and muscles of lake fish, such as bass, pike, burbot and ruffe.

questions.question: If the temperature of food that is to be served while warm is too low it must not be marked down on the own-check plan's monitoring logs.
questions.description: Measured temperatures must be marked down in the own-check plan's monitoring logs, even if they are too high or too low. The logs must also contain information on what fixing procedure has been made to correct the incorrect temperature.

questions.question: All food that is being served needs to be sampled daily.
questions.description: Taken samples must be placed into a container and then placed into a freezer. If food poisonings are suspected, then these samples must be available for research.

questions.question: Blanching can be used to improve the lastingness of chopped vegetables during freezing.
questions.description: Blanching, which means rapid boiling, stops frozen vegetables' enzymic activity by destroying microbes on their surface.

questions.question: The same broom can be used for cleaning the floor and work surfaces.
questions.description: Floors contain a lot more microbes than work surfaces. If floor brooms are used for work surfaces, the microbes on the floor will spread to the work surface from the broom.

questions.question: Bacteria reproduce very quickly in acidized products.
questions.description: Bacteria that are a threat to food product hygiene reproduce the best when in the neutral zone. Bacteria growth especially can be prevented by increasing the acidity of a product.

questions.question: When receiving food products it is enough to check their temperature.
questions.description: When receiving food products it is also required to check the products' appearance, the quality of the packaging and the packaging markings with the senses (visually etc.).

questions.question: Hard rye bread (crisp bread) is not an easily perishable food product.
questions.description: Hard rye bread is a dry food product, and because of this microbes can not reproduce in it. Hard rye bread can be stored in room temperature.

questions.question: Wine is produced with the help of beneficial microbes.
questions.description: The production of wine and beer uses yeast. Yeast is a beneficial microbe.

questions.question: During the cooling of food microbes are not able to reproduce in the food.
questions.description: The danger zone for food temperatures is between 6 and 60 degrees Celsius. Microbes can reproduce in food when the temperature is within this danger zone. During the cooling of food the food is within this danger zone.

questions.question: Berry kisels can be stored in room temperature because the sugar prevents the growth of harmful bacteria.
questions.description: Berry kisels must be stored in cool temperatures because they can perish due to the large quantity of water in them. The sugar in kisels does not prevent harmful bacteria from growing because the sugar density is much lower than in e.g. jams or marmelade.

questions.question: Kitchens in hospitals should have separate spaces for different work phases such as the treatment of root vegetables, baking and dishwashing.
questions.description: When each work phase is done in its own separate area the work is hygienic and the risk of cross-contamination is smaller.

questions.question: Bacillus cereus is a food poisoning causing bacteria.
questions.description: Bacillus cereus is a spore bacteria. Risk food products for this are e.g. raw milk and rice.

questions.question: Raw and cooked produce should not be handled at the same time or with the same utensils.
questions.description: Raw and cooked produce should be stored and handled separately. Surfaces should be properly cleaned in between handling raw and cooked produce. Unhygienic cleaning equipment can also contaminate the kitchen surfaces and cause microbes to spread. This type of spreading of microbes is called cross contamination.

questions.question: Unpeeled and peeled carrots will last the same amount of time as long as they are stored in the cold.
questions.description: Earthy and dirty, untreated root vegetables will last long in appropriate cold storage units, but all treatments will worsen their lastingness.

questions.question: Cleaning plans are a part of own-check plans.
questions.description: Cleaning plans are an important part of own-check plans. Cleaning plans include instructions and schedules for cleaning.

questions.question: An employee on antibiotics can not spread food poisoning causing microbes.
questions.description: An employee using antibiotics is not free from all food poisoning causing bacteria which can be on the skin, mucosas or in the intestines. The antibiotics might not affect all harmful microbes and so the person could spread microbes even during the use of the antibiotics.

questions.question: If the dish washer is not cleaned regularly, harmful microbes can multiply inside the machine and cause a health risk.
questions.description: Dish washers must also be cleaned regularly according to their instructions and allowed to dry afterwards.

questions.question: Chefs can use their work shoes during their travel to and from their workplace.
questions.description: Work shoes must not be worn outside the workplace to prevent microbes from spreading into the food production area.

questions.question: When a health inspector inspects a workplace, he or she will also check the workplace's own check plan's monitoring logs.
questions.description: Health inspectors make routine inspections in food production areas. The monitoring logs of the own-check plans are also part of the inspections. The logs must be stored for 1 year in the workplace. Only stored logs can prove that the workplace has followed its own-check plan accordingly.

questions.question: Using food, that has been served at a buffet table, as an ingredient for preparing new foods increases food poisoning risks.
questions.description: Food that is at a buffet table is often in room temperature and available to be taken by customers themselves. This means that food poisoning causing bacteria spread to these foods easier and reproduce quicker in them. The risk of food poisoning increases when the same foods are used to make new ones. Food from buffet tables must not be used again in food preparation.

questions.question: If canned foods are not sterilized properly, the food can be dangerous for the human health.
questions.description: The cans of canned food can contain spores of clostridium botulinum if the food is not sterilized properly. This spore can create dangerous toxins in the product.

questions.question: Salmonella infection can only be acquired from foreign food products.
questions.description: Salmonella can be transmitted through both domestic and foreign food products or water contaminated with animal or human faeces, and it can cause food poisoning.

questions.question: Food production areas' waste bins must be cleaned regularly.
questions.description: The cleanliness and hygiene of waste bins must be taken care of regularly. Waste bins in kitchens should be cleaned always after they are emptied.

questions.question: Bacterial spores are more resistant than bacteria.
questions.description: When bacteria are in an environment where they cannot grow as easily, they turn into spores. Spores are more resistant than bacteria to heat and drought, for example.

questions.question: Biowaste bins do not have to be emptied daily if the bin has not become full.
questions.description: Biowaste bins must be emptied at least once a day because biowaste contains perishing materials.

questions.question: Bacteria spores are not destroyed during boiling.
questions.description: Bacteria spores are destroyed only during sterilization. In excess pressure the temperature is raised to about 145 degrees Celsius and this way bacteria spores are also destroyed.

questions.question: The own-check system involves monitoring how quickly food products cool down to storage temperature.
questions.description: Monitoring temperatures is an important part of the own-check system.

questions.question: Tapeworms can be found in the roe (eggs) and muscles of some lake fish.
questions.description: Tapeworms can be found in the roe (eggs) and muscles of lake fish, such as bass, pike, burbot and ruffe. Proper cooking or freezing (2 days minimum) will destroy the tapeworm.

questions.question: Earth does not contain food poisoning causing bacteria.
questions.description: Earth can contain e.g. bacillus cereus or clostridum bacteria. Both of these are common causers of food poisoning.

questions.question: The disinfection of working surfaces destroys all harmful microbes and sterilizes the surfaces.
questions.description: Even a thorough cleaning will destroy about 90% of micro-organisms. Disinfectants can be used to destroy nearly all microbes. However, even disinfectants can not sterilize working areas, because not all bacteria-spores die from disinfectants. When cleaning it is not essential to sterilize the environment but instead to regularly and properly clean and wash it.

questions.question: A microbiological sample of a food product can be placed in any container.
questions.description: A microbiological sample of a food product must always be placed in a container that is definitely clean.

questions.question: Food production employees are allowed to wear their work outfit when going outside of the food production area during e.g. their lunch break.
questions.description: The work outfit can only be worn inside the food production area; this prevents microbes from spreading into the area from the clothes.

questions.question: The waste disposal procedures for professional kitchens, such as recycling, are decided upon between the personnel.
questions.description: A professional kitchen's waste disposal is based on waste laws as well as regional waste disposal directives.

questions.question: Viruses can spread into food products by the hands.
questions.description: Food poisoning causing microbes can stay on the skin of the hands e.g. after going to the toilet if the hands have not been properly washed. The microbes can later spread from the hands onto unpacked food products or into work areas.

questions.question: Vacuum-packed meat is deaerated and hermetically sealed.
questions.description: A vacuum pack does not contain any air and prevents the growth of microbes that need oxygen.

questions.question: Additives may be used in all food products.
questions.description: Only approved additives can be used in the preparation of food products. Additives must undergo a thorough safety assessment before they are approved for use.

questions.question: When roasting or cooking insects, there is no need to be especially careful.
questions.description: When insects are processed, they must be handled in the same way as other perishable food products.

questions.question: Dirty root vegetables must have a separate work space.
questions.description: Dirt always contains many microbes. Dirty root vegetables must be handled separately from other products so that the microbes in the dirt do not spread to other food products.

questions.question: During food preparation one can go wash one's hands in the staff restroom.
questions.description: There must be a separate hand washing spot in immediate proximity to the food preparation area.

questions.question: If the temperature of a cold storage unit is too high it must not be marked down on the own-check plan's monitoring logs.
questions.description: Measured temperatures must be marked down in the own-check plan's monitoring logs, even if they are too high or too low. The logs must also contain information on what fixing procedure has been made to correct the incorrect temperature.

questions.question: Listeria bacteria are not destroyed when a product is frozen.
questions.description: Freezing does not destroy microbes. Listeria can also reproduce in frozen foods.

questions.question: Listeria is destroyed when a product is heated to over 70 degrees Celsius.
questions.description: Because listeria is destroyed during heating, products that are not heated are risk food products: vacuum-packed and protective gas packed fish, meat and blue cheese and normal cheese produced from non-pasteurized milk.

questions.question: Yoghurt and viili contain live probiotics.
questions.description: Lactic acid bacteria play an important role in the production of dairy products.

questions.question: Microbes reproduce in dry products.
questions.description: Microbes need water to reproduce. Microbes will not reproduce in dried products but dried products can contain spores of bacteria, moulds or yeast.

questions.question: Good cleaning results are verified by taking samples from surfaces.
questions.description: Samples are taken from surfaces in order to verify that cleaning efforts are adequate.

questions.question: Most harmful microbes reproduce the easiest in temperatures between 6 and 60 degrees Celsius.
questions.description: 6-60 degrees Celsius is a hazardous temperature region where food products should not be stored for long periods of time. Food served from a counter should be kept colder or hotter than this for the entire length of serving, and food to be served later after cooking should be cooled to colder than 6 degrees Celsius quickly (sooner than 4 hours.)

questions.question: Food served in a lunch buffet must remain at +60 degrees celsius for the entire duration of the serving.
questions.description: If food that has been prepared by heating or cooking is not served immediately, it must be kept at a temperature of at least 60 degrees throughout the entire serving.

questions.question: Cooling cabinets are used only for cooling food.
questions.description: Food should be cooled to less than 6 degrees Celsius within only 4 hours. When the products have been cooled they should be moved into another cold storage unit. Cooling cabinets are only used for cooling food (not storing.)

questions.question: A waiter must be able to tell customers the ingredients of a food product that has not been packed.
questions.description: A waiter must be able to provide customers with information about food products verbally and, if necessary, also in writing.

questions.question: An employee handling unpacked, easily perishable food products can not have nail polish while working.
questions.description: Nail polish can not be worn when handling easily perishable food products because the polish can break off into the products. Microbes also have good growth environments to reproduce under nails and nail polish. Nails and hands must be kept in good condition when working with food products.

questions.question: Food products containing preservatives never spoil.
questions.description: Preservatives only slow down the spoiling done by microbes.

questions.question: Bacteria reproduce very quickly in products that have high acidity.
questions.description: Bacteria that are a threat to food product safety reproduce the best in the neutral zone. Because of this the growth of these bacteria can be prevented by increasing the acidity of a product.

questions.question: Indoor plants can spread harmful microbes to food products.
questions.description: Indoor plants must not be kept in food product preparation areas because microbes live on their surface and in their earth.

questions.question: Milk can be stored at room temperature during the breakfast service.
questions.description: Milk and cream are perishable food products and they must be served cold.

questions.question: Workers in the food industry, e.g. an online store sselling food products, must inform local food control authorities about their activities.
questions.description: All workers in the food industry must inform food control authorities about their activities. The informing must be done before beginning the activities. When founding a food industry workplace, e.g. a sausage factory, the activities must also be approved by the authorities.

questions.question: The amount of sugar a product contains does not affect its lastingness.
questions.description: Highly sugared products, such as jams, marmelades and sweets do not perish easily because sugar changes the state of water so that microbes can not reproduce.

questions.question: Windows in food premises can be opened for ventilation.
questions.description: Windows and doors in food premises must be kept closed to prevent pests from entering the premises.

questions.question: Foreign frozen raspberries can be served without heating because the freezing destroys any possible disease causers.
questions.description: Foreign frozen raspberries must always be heated properly (boiling for 5 minutes) before serving because they may contain the norovirus. Freezing does not destroy disease causers that have gotten into the food product before freezing, because viruses stay able to spread for a long time in different conditions.

questions.question: Ingredients should always be handled with clean equipment instead of hands whenever possible.
questions.description: Even washed hands contain some amounts of microbes. Even some healthy people carry food poisoning causing microbes on their skin. Using clean equipment is more hygienic.

questions.question: BSE, also called mad cow's disease, is a food poisoning causing bacteria.
questions.description: BSE is not a food poisoning causing bacteria. BSE is caused by changes in the central nervous system of cows.

questions.question: Cleaning rags must be changed regularly.
questions.description: The hygiene of cleaning rags in areas with food products is very important. The rags must be washed and changed regularly so that they will not spread food poisoning bacteria or microbes.

questions.question: Even in small cafés the same cleaning equipment can not be used to clean the customer areas and the kitchen.
questions.description: If the same cleaning equipment is used, microbes can easily spread from customers to the kitchen in the equipment.

questions.question: Milk spoils faster than sour milk.
questions.description: The pH value of milk is 7, which means it is neutral. The pH value of sour milk is lower, which means sour milk is acidized. It is harder for bacteria to reproduce in acidized milk products than in neutral products.

questions.question: Food tasting must be done with a spoon.
questions.description: Food must never be touched with the fingers if it is not necessary. Spoons should be used for tasting.

questions.question: The priority of waste laws is to make people working in the food industry responsible for assorting their waste.
questions.description: The priority of waste laws is to lessen the amount of waste and its effects.

questions.question: Food production employees are only allowed to wear their work outfit at their workplace, the food production area.
questions.description: The work outfit can only be worn inside the food production area; this prevents microbes from spreading into the area from the clothes.

questions.question: Most harmful microbes reproduce the easiest in temperatures between 6 and 60 degrees Celsius.
questions.description: 6-60 degrees Celsius is a hazardous temperature region where food products should not be stored for long periods of time. Food served from a counter should be kept colder or hotter than this for the entire length of serving, and food to be served later after cooking should be cooled to colder than 6 degrees Celsius quickly (sooner than 4 hours.)

questions.question: Old and worn cleaning equipment can spread harmful microbes into food premises.
questions.description: It is important to make sure that cleaning equipment is always clean and in good condition.

questions.question: Thawing frozen products in cold rooms or refrigerators is a hygienic risk because the thawing happens too slowly.
questions.description: If food products are thawed in room temperature, the products' surfaces will melt quicker than the insides. The surfaces will start to spoil even though the insides can still be frozen. Thawing in cold rooms takes a longer amount of time but the cold room's temperature will allow very few microbes to reproduce.

questions.question: If an employee has inflamed wounds on their hands, they must not handle easily perishable food products.
questions.description: A person with inflamed wounds or other inflamed areas on their hands or other visible skin must not handle unpacked food products. Small wounds in the hands must be cleaned and protected with a water-proof bandage, and single-use gloves must be used.

questions.question: Cleaning equipment storage rooms must be cleaned regularly.
questions.description: All parts of a food production area must be cleaned regularly according to the cleaning plan.

questions.question: You can touch the inside surfaces of food packaging if you have just washed your hands.
questions.description: You should always try not to touch the inside surfaces of food packaging.

questions.question: The own-check plan of a food production area is done by a municipality health inspector.
questions.description: Workplaces in the food industry must create their own own-check plan that suits their activities. The plan is supposed to ensure the safety of food products, good lastingness and the following of official rules and directives.

questions.question: Tap water does not contain microbes.
questions.description: Even tap water can contain microbes. Tap water cleanliness must be monitored using the senses. Water samples can also be regularly sent for chemical and microbiological inspections.

questions.question: It is recommended to use a hand dryer for drying your hands because the air they produce is so hot.
questions.description: Dry your hands with a clean disposable paper towel or a cloth towel.

questions.question: The amount of water a product contains does not significantly affect its lastingness.
questions.description: Harmful microbes need water to reproduce. Because of this dry products last well.

questions.question: BSE is also called mad cow's disease.
questions.description: Mad cow's disease is sometimes found in old cows. During slaughtering the carcasses must be checked so that contaminated meat is not used.

questions.question: The use of snus (similar to chewing tobacco) is not allowed during food preparation.
questions.description: When handling food products personal hygiene is important; snus must not be used because of hygienic reasons.

questions.question: The incorrect storing temperature of food is a major cause for food poisoning.
questions.description: If food is stored in too warm temperatures, microbes that cause food poisoning will reproduce quickly. Because of this the temperatures of cold storage units and freezers must be monitored regularly using thermometers.

questions.question: If a fish is dropped on a freshly washed floor, it can still be cooked as long as it is sufficiently well heated.
questions.description: A fish that has fallen onto the floor must never be used for cooking. Food products must never be stored on the floor.

questions.question: HACCP is not a food poisoning causing bacteria.
