questions.description: HACCP stands for Hazard Analysis and Critical Control Points, which is a part of own-check plans. When working with an own-check plan these critical points must be identified and constantly monitored carefully.

questions.question: Pet dogs can be taken inside a café with the permission of the owner of the café.
questions.description: If the owner gives permission, a pet dog can be taken inside the customer areas of a café.

questions.question: Intestinal bacteria cannot spread from hands to food.
questions.description: Intestinal bacteria can spread to food even from the hands.

questions.question: Oiva-reports must be placed at the entrance of the café, restaurant etc. so that customers can read them.
questions.description: Oiva-reports are published documents about routine inspections. These reports are also published online at www.oivahymy.fi

questions.question: A food poisoning epidemic is a situation where at least 10 people have become sick with similar symptoms after consuming the same food product or ingredient.
questions.description: A food poisoning epidemic means a situation where at least 2 people have become sick with similar symptoms after consuming the same food or drink.

questions.question: Dishwashing should be done so that dirty dishes and clean dishes are handled separately enough.
questions.description: Clean dishes will become dirty again if they are not kept separate from dirty dishes.

questions.question: It is important to visually monitor cleanliness on a daily basis in addition to regular cleaning.
questions.description: Everyone working in a food premises must constantly monitor its cleanliness.

questions.question: Customers and employees are allowed to use the same toilet.
questions.description: Strict toilet and hand hygiene must be used in food production. This is not possible if toilets are shared with customers. Customers may have diseases, can be drunk or they can be small children; in each case the use of the same toilets is a risk.

questions.question: Organic food does not cause food poisoning as easily as "normal" food.
questions.description: Organic food is produced without fertilizers or pesticides. This does not affect food poisoning almost at all. The risk for food poisoning is the same between "normal" and organic food.

questions.question: The mould used to make mould-ripened cheese cannot grow anywhere else.
questions.description: The mould used to make mould-ripened cheese can grow on other food products. It causes mould to grow on the surfaces of food products that spoils them.

questions.question: Actions made after noticing mistakes or abnormalities in the packaging or quality of food products during receival checks must be logged in the own-check plan.
questions.description: Mistakes or abnormalities noticed in the quality or packaging of food products must be logged into the own-check plan. It is also required to detailedly log what actions are made after noticing a mistake or abnormality and who is responsible for informing for example the supplier of the products about it.

questions.question: Intestinal bacteria can spread from hands to food.
questions.description: Intestinal bacteria can spread to food even from the hands.

questions.question: Indoor plants can spread harmful microbes to food products.
questions.description: Indoor plants must not be kept in food product preparation areas because microbes live on their surface and in their earth.

questions.question: Beneficial microbes cannot be used in the production of cream cheese.
questions.description: Cream cheese is made using beneficial microbes.

questions.question: Foreign frozen raspberries can be served without heating because the freezing destroys any possible disease causers.
questions.description: Foreign frozen raspberries must always be heated properly (boiling for 5 minutes) before serving because they may contain the norovirus. Freezing does not destroy disease causers that have gotten into the food product before freezing, because viruses stay able to spread for a long time in different conditions.

questions.question: All E-numbered additives improve the lastingness of food products.
questions.description: Food products can be made to last longer by adding preservatives to them. In the European Union, allowed preservatives have an E-number: for example, E 200 is sorbic acid and E 296 is malic acid. Preservatives that are allowed can be found, along with other additives, in an E-number list. Some preservatives can be found naturally in berries and fruits, such as in lingonberries and citrus fruit. E-numbers are also used to identify additives other than ones that improve lastingness. For example, color additives do not improve the lastingness of food products.

questions.question: The lastingness of food products can also be improved during treatment by using hygienic work methods, clean surfaces and equipment.
questions.description: Ingredients and their handling equipment must be kept separate from cooked products to prevent cross-contamination. For example, differently colored cutting boards and equipment for different food groups, such as vegetables, fish, meat and cooked food helps to prevent cross-contamination.

questions.question: If food does not taste spoiled it can not cause food poisoning.
questions.description: Many food poisoning causing bacteria can reproduce in food without causing changes that can be noticed with the senses (visually, taste etc.)

questions.question: Wastebins must be cleaned regularly.
questions.description: Wastebins must not be broken, must include a lid and must also be cleaned regularly.

questions.question: Customer feedback is a part of the own-check plan.
questions.description: It is useful to pay attention to appropriate customer feedback when carrying out the own-check plan. Customer feedback can be viewed as a way to enhance quality of service. Feedback should be written down, discussed with the staff and utilized in developing procedures and protocols.

questions.question: You can wear disposable gloves instead of washing your hands when preparing food in a restaurant tent.
questions.description: Washing your hands thoroughly and often enough is the basis for safe food handling and general hygiene, and it is important to also wear disposable gloves, for example.

questions.question: If the product being handled is fresh and of good quality, the handling hygiene is not as important.
questions.description: Hygienic handling methods and equipment are always important for the lastingness of products. A fresh and good quality good will still perish easily if it is handled unhygienically.

questions.question: Sugar can contain microbes.
questions.description: Sugar is dry, so microbes do not grow in it. However, salt can contain spores of bacteria, moulds or yeast.

questions.question: Reheated products must be heated to +75 degrees celsius before serving.
questions.description: Reheated food products, such as appropriately cooled food that has been prepared the previous day, must be thoroughly heated to +75 degrees before serving.

questions.question: Food production areas need to have a changing room.
questions.description: Employees need a changing room which has a separate storage space for clean work clothes.

questions.question: When preparing a own-check plan, all essential food product risk monitoring must be explained.
questions.description: It is essential for the plan to think which parts of done activities are ones where microbes can reproduce and how risks will be monitored, as well as what actions must be taken to fix risk situations.

questions.question: People who have been infected with salmonella always have diarrhoea.
questions.description: The symptoms of salmonella infection include nausea, diarrhoea, high temperature and headache. Not everyone with the infection has symptoms.

questions.question: Campylo bacteria is destroyed when a product is heated properly.
questions.description: Campylo bacteria and salmonella are found naturally in fowl and poultry. Both bacteria are destroyed when the meat is cooked thoroughly to over 75 degrees Celsius.

questions.question: Food poisoning only spreads by contaminated food products or drinking water.
questions.description: Food poisoning can also spread due to bad work or hand hygiene. Food poisoning bacteria such as salmonella can spread human-to-human without any intermediate due to bad hand hygiene. Disease carriers without symptoms can also spread salmonella to other people.

questions.question: The amount of water a product contains does not significantly affect its lastingness.
questions.description: Harmful microbes need water to reproduce. Because of this dry products last well.

questions.question: All food that is being served needs to be sampled daily.
questions.description: Taken samples must be placed into a container and then placed into a freezer. If food poisonings are suspected, then these samples must be available for research.

questions.question: An employee handling unpacked, easily perishable food products can not have nail polish while working.
questions.description: Nail polish can not be worn when handling easily perishable food products because the polish can break off into the products. Microbes also have good growth environments to reproduce under nails and nail polish. Nails and hands must be kept in good condition when working with food products.

questions.question: Defrosting frozen foods in room temperature increases the risk of food poisoning.
questions.description: Frozen foods' surfaces will defrost faster than the insides. In room temperature the surfaces will become warm enough for microbes to grow even though the insides might still be frozen.

questions.question: Visually clean work surfaces guarantee their microbiological cleanliness.
questions.description: Microbiological cleanliness can not be guaranteed by using just the bare eye. Correct cleaning methods and equipment, as well as regular and proper cleaning, guarantee the cleanliness much better. Samples can also be taken of the cleanliness of specific surfaces if required.

questions.question: Sneezing spreads harmful microbes into the surrounding environment in the droplets/spray.
questions.description: There are lots of microbes in the respiratory system and mouth which can spread into the surroundings.

questions.question: Own-check plans must not be changed.
questions.description: Own-check plans must be updated when changes happen in the workplace.

questions.question: When a food industry workplace, e.g. a sausage factory, is being founded, the workplace must only inform local food control authorities about the activities.
questions.description: When a food industry workplace, e.g. a sausage factory, is being founded, an approval for the activities by local food control authorities is required.

questions.question: All plastic containers are suitable for storing food.
questions.description: Materials that come into contact with food must be meant for food use.

questions.question: The disinfection of working surfaces destroys all harmful microbes and sterilizes the surfaces.
questions.description: Even a thorough cleaning will destroy about 90% of micro-organisms. Disinfectants can be used to destroy nearly all microbes. However, even disinfectants can not sterilize working areas, because not all bacteria-spores die from disinfectants. When cleaning it is not essential to sterilize the environment but instead to regularly and properly clean and wash it.

questions.question: Temperature measurements are to be made only by the superiors of a workplace.
questions.description: The instructions of own-check plans must be adhered to by all employees. Because of this temperature measurements are also the responsibility of all other employees.

questions.question: Dirty root vegetables must have a separate work space.
questions.description: Dirt always contains many microbes. Dirty root vegetables must be handled separately from other products so that the microbes in the dirt do not spread to other food products.

questions.question: The same knife can be used for cutting raw and cooked meat.
questions.description: Heated food must be protected from contamination after being heated. Ingredients and the equipment used to handle those ingredients must be kept separate from cooked products to prevent cross-contamination.

questions.question: When a food industry workplace, e.g. a sausage factory, is being founded, the activities of the workplace must be approved in advance by local food control authorities.
questions.description: Workplaces that handle animal-based food products require an approval for their activities. Only informing of the activities is not enough.

questions.question: Smoking is allowed at the loading docks of kitchens.
questions.description: Loading docks are a part of food production areas; smoking is not allowed in food production areas.

questions.question: The only mandatory information on food packaging is the ingredients and the name of the food product.
questions.description: In addition to the name of the food product and the ingredients, the packaging must also state the minimum shelf life and the use by date.

questions.question: The post-contamination of a cooked product can be prevented by using appropriate and clean storing containers.
questions.description: Good hand hygiene, clean working equipment and hygienic storing containers protect cooked products from post-contamination due to hazards that affect the safety of the product after heating it.

questions.question: Cold fish products (e.g. salmon) in vacuum-packages has sometimes been found to contain listeria.
questions.description: Cold fish products in vacuum-packages have a risk to cause listeriosis because the fish has not been heated and the storing time is long.

questions.question: Yeasts often cause spoilage in acidic food products.
questions.description: Bacteria grow in a more restricted pH range than yeast and mould. Yeasts grow best in food products with a pH of 5.

questions.question: If the film/foil of a vacuum-package is loose or tensionless the package is damaged.
questions.description: The package has probably been broken and air has entered it. The lastingness of the product can not be estimated after this, because the use-by-date marked on the package is based on the assumption that the package contains no air (oxygen that microbes can use to grow.)

questions.question: Health inspectors can not inspect restaurant kitchens.
questions.description: The work of health inspectors requires making inspections in food production areas such as food stores and restaurants.

questions.question: Yoghurt and viili contain live probiotics.
questions.description: Lactic acid bacteria play an important role in the production of dairy products.

questions.question: Cooling cabinets may also be used for storing food.
questions.description: Food should be cooled to less than 6 degrees Celsius within only 4 hours. When the products have been cooled they should be moved into another cold storage unit. Cooling cabinets are only used for cooling food (not storing.)

questions.question: Worn down and broken equipment is a hygienic risk.
questions.description: Waste food can get easily stuck in worn or broken equipment. Even small amounts of waste food will give microbes a good growing environment.

questions.question: Baker's yeast contains living microbes.
questions.description: Baker's yeast itself is living yeast microbes. These yeast microbes will die if the temperature goes over 42 degrees Celsius. Because of this baker's yeast can not be added to a liquid that is too hot.

questions.question: One of the reasons for the existence of own-check plans is to make the work of food product industry companies easier.
questions.description: Own-check plans that are done well make it easier for companies to upkeep food product safety because resources used for monitoring can be focused on things essential for company activities. Knowledge of the quality of the activities will also improve when the activities are planned. In the best case customer satisfaction, profitability and officials' trust will improve.

questions.question: When receiving frozen goods, their temperature does not need to be measured if the product feels cold.
questions.description: It is recommended that one occasionally measures the temperature of frozen deliveries, especially if there are any doubts about the accuracy of transportation temperature.

questions.question: An establishment's own-check plan is in effect for 10 years at a time.
questions.description: The own-check plan must be updated if need arises. It is useful to go over the plan regularly and to assess whether or not there have been changes in the establishment's functioning or protocols that require changes to made in the plan as well. Changes in the regulations of the food industry may necessitate changes in own-check plans as well.

questions.question: Useful microbes are used in baking.
questions.description: Yeast is used in baking to make dough rise.

questions.question: Soup made for the following day can be left to cool overnight on the kitchen counter.
questions.description: The rapid cooling and cold storing of soup prevents or slows down the growth of bacteria.

questions.question: The spores of clostridium perfringens bacteria are destroyed only with sterilization.
questions.description: All spores of bacteria can only be destroyed with sterilization.

questions.question: The disinfection of working surfaces destroys all harmful microbes and sterilizes the surfaces.
questions.description: Even a thorough cleaning will destroy about 90% of micro-organisms. Disinfectants can be used to destroy nearly all microbes. However, even disinfectants can not sterilize working areas, because not all bacteria-spores die from disinfectants. When cleaning it is not essential to sterilize the environment but instead to regularly and properly clean and wash it.

questions.question: Temperature measurements stated in own-check plans do not have to made when one is busy.
questions.description: Only regularly done measurements can prove that the own-check plan has been adhered to at a workplace.

questions.question: The norovirus is not destroyed when a food product is frozen.
questions.description: The norovirus lasts for long amounts of time and is able to spread even in the cold or in frozen foods.

questions.question: Pasteurized dairy products can be stored unopened in room temperature.
questions.description: Pasteurizing does not make it possible to store dairy products in room temperature. UHT-treated dairy products can be stored in room temperature if they are unopened.

questions.question: Microbiological samples of served food are taken only if there is suspicion of there being something wrong with the product.
questions.description: Microbiological samples of served food are taken daily. Samples are kept for 2 weeks, so that potential food poisoning cases can be solved if need be.

questions.question: Dry flour contains microbes.
questions.description: Dry products can contain spores of bacteria, moulds and yeast. However, they do not reproduce in dry products.

questions.question: If there are other companies working in the same estate, then the food production area needs a waste disposal area separate from the other companies' areas.
questions.description: Waste disposal areas can be the same with other companies but the own-check plan's waste disposal instructions must show if the waste disposal and its contract only cover the food production area or the entire estate.

questions.question: Food control authorities are responsible for monitoring companies' own-check plans.
questions.description: The responsibility of own-check plans is the company's. Officials have a possibility to get to know companies' own-check plans and data while doing checks. However, own-check plan documents are companies' personal documents and the companies have the responsibility of storing them and training any personnel to act according to the own-check plan.

questions.question: Kitchen staff do not need to remove jewellery made of precious metal because precious metal is not a hygiene hazard.
questions.description: Wearing jewellery is always a hygiene hazard. Dirt can accumulate under a ring, and a piece of jewellery or part of it can also come off and end up in food.

questions.question: The own-check plan only refers to measuring and recording temperatures.
questions.description: The purpose of the own-check plan is to help operators to manage the risks associated with food hygiene. Measuring and recording temperatures is an important part of the own-check system. Other areas of the own-check system include cleaning and tidiness as well as hygienic skills of the staff.

questions.question: A cleaning equipment storage room must be included in a food production area.
questions.description: It's not always necessary to have a separate storage space for cleaning equipment. Food production areas need a separate storage, maintenance and drying space if the food production area requires it for constructional reasons. It's important to make sure that there are no risks for food safety and the hygienic treatment, maintenance and storage of cleaning equipment are done properly. If necessary the working stages and functions has to be separated structually or timely.

questions.question: Fresh fish is not an easily perishable food product.
questions.description: Fresh fish is a very easily perishable food product. Fresh fish products must be stored at the temperature of melting ice, max 2 degrees Celsius.

questions.question: Cold-stored root vegetables may contain Yersinia bacteria that cause food poisoning.
questions.description: Root vegetables that are cold stored for a long time may contain Yersinia bacteria that cause food poisoning.

questions.question: Food that is being served while hot must be at least 55 degrees Celsius during the entire serving period.
questions.description: Food that is being served while hot must be kept at over 60 degrees Celsius during the entire serving period. The temperature must be measured and marked down in own-check logs.

questions.question: When there is packaged meat in a delivery load, it can be safely left at room temperature for a few hours.
questions.description: The cold chain of meat products in a delivery load must not be broken.

questions.question: Listeriosis should be avoided especially during pregnancy.
questions.description: Listeriosis during pregnancy can cause miscarriages or premature birth.

questions.question: Mould that has spread from blue cheese to other cheeses is not hazardous.
questions.description: Mould spreading from blue cheese to other cheeses, which the mould is not supposed to be in, is hazardous and can worsen the quality and also perish the cheeses. However, the spreading of the mould to other cheeses is not always a health risk.

questions.question: Detergents (washing chemicals) must always be stored in their original packages.
questions.description: Only the original packages can be used to make sure that the correct detergent is being used for the situation.

questions.question: Dishwashing should be done so that dirty dishes and clean dishes are handled separately enough.
questions.description: Clean dishes will become dirty again if they are not kept separate from dirty dishes.

questions.question: Intestinal bacteria cannot spread from hands to food.
questions.description: Intestinal bacteria can spread to food even from the hands.

questions.question: Small birds flying in a grocery store cause no harm as long as regular cleaning is carried out.
questions.description: Small birds must be prevented from entering food premises. They are a hygiene hazard.

questions.question: The contents of a bulged can of food can be used for food preparation if the product is properly heated.
questions.description: All causes of food poisoning are not eliminated by heating. The contents of a bulged (ie. faulty) can of food must be discarded.

questions.question: Beneficial bacteria usually make it harder for harmful bacteria to grow.
questions.description: Harmful bacteria have to compete with beneficial bacteria for living space and nutrition. Beneficial bacteria can change living conditions in food products, e.g. the acidity, such that it becomes worse for harmful bacteria and makes them grow slower or not at all.

questions.question: If the temperature of a cold storage unit is too high it must not be marked down on the own-check plan's monitoring logs.
questions.description: Measured temperatures must be marked down in the own-check plan's monitoring logs, even if they are too high or too low. The logs must also contain information on what fixing procedure has been made to correct the incorrect temperature.

questions.question: Cleaning equipment do not need a separate storage area.
questions.description: It's not always necessary to have a separate storage space for cleaning equipment. Food production areas need a separate storage, maintenance and drying space if the food production area requires it for constructional reasons. It's important to make sure that there are no risks for food safety and the hygienic treatment, maintenance and storage of cleaning equipment are done properly. If necessary the working stages and functions has to be separated structually or timely.

questions.question: Bacteria reproduce very quickly in products that have high acidity.
questions.description: Bacteria that are a threat to food product safety reproduce the best in the neutral zone. Because of this the growth of these bacteria can be prevented by increasing the acidity of a product.

questions.question: Own-check plans must include clear instructions on how to act when food poisoning suspicions are raised.
questions.description: When food is prepared for customers, food poisoning events must be planned for in advance. Own-check plans must include clear instructions for these events. It is important to notify health inspectors about suspicions immediately.

questions.question: You are allowed to use snus (nuuska in Finnish) while preparing food.
questions.description: The use of snus (nuuska in Finnish) is prohibited while preparing food.

questions.question: Customers and employees are allowed to use the same toilet.
questions.description: Strict toilet and hand hygiene must be used in food production. This is not possible if toilets are shared with customers. Customers may have diseases, can be drunk or they can be small children; in each case the use of the same toilets is a risk.

questions.question: Prepared salads can be stored in room temperature without a risk of food poisoning.
questions.description: Prepared salads are easily perishable food products. For example, chopped or grated vegetables and root vegetables, meat, fish and mayonnaise are often ingredients of prepared salads, so they have to be stored in the cold.

questions.question: Workers in the food industry can be found responsible for a customer becoming sick.
questions.description: Product liability laws also cover food products. If a customer is able to provide sufficient evidence, a worker in the food industry can be found responsible for causing a sickness in the customer.

questions.question: Raw and cooked produce should not be handled at the same time or with the same utensils.
questions.description: Raw and cooked produce should be stored and handled separately. Surfaces should be properly cleaned in between handling raw and cooked produce. Unhygienic cleaning equipment can also contaminate the kitchen surfaces and cause microbes to spread. This type of spreading of microbes is called cross contamination.

questions.question: Raw milk can contain yersinia.
questions.description: Raw milk has not been pasteurized. Yersinia is destroyed when milk is heated to over 70 degrees Celsius; in other words it is destroyed when the milk is pasteurized.

questions.question: The correct concentration of detergent significantly affects the cleaning result.
questions.description: Detergents and disinfectants must be measured out in accordance with the manufacturer's instructions. A solution that is stronger than recommended does not usually guarantee a better cleaning result, and a solution that is diluted too much may give a worse result.

questions.question: You can wear disposable gloves instead of washing your hands when preparing food in a restaurant tent.
questions.description: Washing your hands thoroughly and often enough is the basis for safe food handling and general hygiene, and it is important to also wear disposable gloves, for example.

questions.question: Food poisoning is always caused by some kind of bacteria or virus.
questions.description: Food poisoning can also be caused by parasites, protozoa, natural toxins (such as in morel mushrooms), poisonous plants or animals, chemicals or some other disease-causing particle.

questions.question: The state and cleanliness of the waste management room does not affect the kitchen's hygienic quality.
questions.description: The waste management room must also be kept organised and clean. A dirty waste management room and badly cleaned waste bins can collect pests and spread microbes that are harmful for food products.

questions.question: Food products can not be stored on the floor of dry storage rooms.
questions.description: Storing food products on the floor is not a hygienic way to store food. Floors always contain more microbes than shelves.

questions.question: Cleaning equipment that is old and in bad condition can spread harmful microbes to a food production area.
questions.description: Cleaning equipment wears down and becomes dirty during use. They often contain microbes even though they are washed regularly. Cleaning equipment should be renewed regularly.

questions.question: The contents of a bulged can of food can be used for food preparation if the product is properly heated.
questions.description: All causes of food poisoning are not eliminated by heating. The contents of a bulged (ie. faulty) can of food must be discarded.

questions.question: A food product can only be a health hazard if it has a contaminated area that is visible to the naked eye.
questions.description: Growth on the surfaces of food products caused by moulds and yeasts are visible to the naked eye, but microbes are usually microorganisms that are not visible to the naked eye.

questions.question: Cleaning equipment must be cleaned once a week.
questions.description: Cleaning equipment must be cleaned after each use and must then be left to dry.

questions.question: Minced meat produced in a store can be sold on the day of production and the day after that.
questions.description: Minced meat is an easily perishable food product. Because of this the safety of minced meat produced in a store can not be ensured for a longer period of time. Minced meat should be stored at 4 degrees Celsius.

questions.question: Food products containing preservatives will also spoil.
questions.description: Preservatives only slow down the spoiling done by microbes. In the European Union all allowed preservatives have an E-code.

questions.question: The placement of biowaste bins outside a restaurant does not matter as long as they are not close to an entrance.
questions.description: A waste room's  or recycling area's biowaste bins must be covered from the sun and placed such that pests do not get to them.

questions.question: Yeasts often cause spoilage in acidic food products.
questions.description: Bacteria grow in a more restricted pH range than yeast and mould. Yeasts grow best in food products with a pH of 5.

questions.question: If a food authority representative wants to see your own-check plan, you must present it to him/her.
questions.description: If a food authority representative wants to see an operator's own-check plan, the operator is obliged to present it.

questions.question: Prepared salads can be stored in room temperature without a risk of food poisoning.
questions.description: Prepared salads are easily perishable food products. For example, chopped or grated vegetables and root vegetables, meat, fish and mayonnaise are often ingredients of prepared salads, so they have to be stored in the cold.

questions.question: During food preparation one can go wash one's hands in the staff restroom.
questions.description: There must be a separate hand washing spot in immediate proximity to the food preparation area.

questions.question: Food tasting must be done with a spoon.
questions.description: Food must never be touched with the fingers if it is not necessary. Spoons should be used for tasting.

questions.question: Open cartons of long-life (UHT) milk and pasteurised milk are stored in the same way.
questions.description: Open cartons of long-life (UHT) milk and pasteurised milk are kept in cold storage.

questions.question: Food can be tasted with the fingers.
questions.description: Food must never be touched with the fingers if it is not necessary. Spoons should be used for tasting.

questions.question: The toxins contained in fresh morel mushrooms can not be removed by only roasting the mushrooms.
questions.description: Morel mushrooms must be boiled twice for at least 5 minutes and washed thoroughly between the boilings.

questions.question: Officials will prepare an own-check plan for new companies in the food product industry.
questions.description: Companies in the food product industry must prepare their own own-check plan when starting their activities. The plan must be followed and updated when needed.

questions.question: The norovirus is destroyed when a food product is frozen.
questions.description: The norovirus lasts for long amounts of time and is able to spread even in the cold or in frozen foods.

questions.question: All E-numbered additives improve the lastingness of food products.
questions.description: Food products can be made to last longer by adding preservatives to them. In the European Union, allowed preservatives have an E-number: for example, E 200 is sorbic acid and E 296 is malic acid. Preservatives that are allowed can be found, along with other additives, in an E-number list. Some preservatives can be found naturally in berries and fruits, such as in lingonberries and citrus fruit. E-numbers are also used to identify additives other than ones that improve lastingness. For example, color additives do not improve the lastingness of food products.

questions.question: When a food product is vacuum packed, food poisoning bacteria cannot grow in it.
questions.description: Food poisoning microbes that tolerate anaerobic and low-oxygen conditions can multiply in a vacuum pack.

questions.question: Temperatures measured under the own-check plan do not need to be recorded if you learn them by heart.
questions.description: It is important to measure and record temperatures.

questions.question: Dirty root vegetables must have a separate work space.
questions.description: Dirt always contains many microbes. Dirty root vegetables must be handled separately from other products so that the microbes in the dirt do not spread to other food products.

questions.question: EHEC bacteria are not intestinal bacteria.
questions.description: EHEC bacteria is found especially in the intestines of cattle. EHEC bacteria create toxins in the intestines of humans. The toxin often causes bloody diarrhea and very uncomfortable stomache pains.

questions.question: The incorrect storing temperature of food is a major cause for food poisoning.
questions.description: If food is stored in too warm temperatures, microbes that cause food poisoning will reproduce quickly. Because of this the temperatures of cold storage units and freezers must be monitored regularly using thermometers.

questions.question: If one's hands have been carefully washed then food products can be handled with hands.
questions.description: Clean equipment should always be used instead of hands, no matter how well washed, whenever possible.

questions.question: HACCP is not a food poisoning causing bacteria.
questions.description: HACCP stands for Hazard Analysis and Critical Control Points, which is a part of own-check plans. When working with an own-check plan these critical points must be identified and constantly monitored carefully.

questions.question: Waste does not cause a hygiene risk because it is stored in separate containers.
questions.description: Bad waste management hygiene or food products getting into contact with waste can cause hygiene risks.

questions.question: Food that is being served while hot must be at least 60 degrees Celsius during the entire serving period.
questions.description: The temperature must also be measured and marked down in own-check logs. The food can be kept in service while hot for a maximum of 4 hours.

questions.question: Waste bins can be placed in the dry food storage room if there is no other place for them.
questions.description: The waste management of food premises must be arranged so that waste and food products do not come into contact with each other.

questions.question: Food packaging materials can be stored on a clean floor.
questions.description: Food packaging materials must never be stored directly on the floor but they must be placed on clean racks or other hygienic surfaces.

questions.question: Bacteria reproduce very quickly in acidized products.
questions.description: Bacteria that are a threat to food product hygiene reproduce the best when in the neutral zone. Bacteria growth especially can be prevented by increasing the acidity of a product.

questions.question: Bacterial spores are more resistant than bacteria.
questions.description: When bacteria are in an environment where they cannot grow as easily, they turn into spores. Spores are more resistant than bacteria to heat and drought, for example.

questions.question: Bacteria spores can not be found inside the cans of canned food.
questions.description: Canned foods are produced with sterilization which destroys all bacteria spores.

questions.question: If food is prepared to be served later, the finished products must be cooled as soon as possible for storage.
questions.description: Hot, cooked food must be cooled to under 6 degrees Celsius in under 4 hours. Cooling large amounts of products requires the use of actual cooling devices, from which the cooled products must be moved to their appropriate cold storage units.

questions.question: Food products that contain preservatives can not cause food poisoning.
questions.description: Preservatives prevent and slow down the growth of microbes in food products. However, preservatives do not destroy food poisoning causing bacteria, which makes food poisoning possible.

questions.question: Pet animals can carry food poisoning causing parasites and protozoa.
questions.description: Pet animals can carry different disease causers in their fur, paws and feces. Pet animals can not be allowed inside food preparation areas. Pet animals are allowed in dining areas if the merchant allows it.

questions.question: Handling money can transfer harmful microbes into food products.
questions.description: Money and easily perishable unpackaged food products should not be handled simultanously, as money can have microbes in it that jeopardize food hygiene.

questions.question: An establishment's own-check plan is in effect for 10 years at a time.
questions.description: The own-check plan must be updated if need arises. It is useful to go over the plan regularly and to assess whether or not there have been changes in the establishment's functioning or protocols that require changes to made in the plan as well. Changes in the regulations of the food industry may necessitate changes in own-check plans as well.

questions.question: If food does not taste spoiled it can not cause food poisoning.
questions.description: Many food poisoning causing bacteria can reproduce in food without causing changes that can be noticed with the senses (visually, taste etc.)

questions.question: Foreign raspberries may be used for making food if the product will be kept well refrigerated.
questions.description: Foreign raspberies must always be properly heated by boiling before serving. Using non-heated foreign rasberries creates a risk of listeria.

questions.question: Waste bins to be used in kitchens must be water-proof and easily cleanable.
questions.description: Waste bins to be used in kitchens must be water-proof so that waste liquids do not pour onto the floor. They must also be easy to clean so that the cleaning process during emptying is as easy as possible.

questions.question: The maximum storage temperature for cooked shellfish is +6°C.
questions.description: Cooked molluscs and shellfish are stored at the temperature of melting ice (maximum +2°C).

questions.question: The purpose of the own-check plan is not to manage food-related health hazards.
questions.description: One of the most important objectives of the own-check plan is to manage food-related health hazards.

questions.question: If a product or ingredient is suspected to be the cause of food poisoning in a customer, the product or ingredient should be gotten rid of as soon as possible.
questions.description: Suspected causes of food poisoning must not be gotten rid of but must instead be stored so that it can be examined in a laboratory to find the cause of the poisoning.

questions.question: Kitchen cloths can include lots of microbes even if they are visually clean-looking.
questions.description: Kitchen cloths are often wet and can contain waste food. Microbes can reproduce quickly in these conditions.

questions.question: The same cleaning equipment can be used in both dining areas and food preparation areas.
questions.description: Kitchen facilities and customer areas must have separate cleaning equipment in order to avoid possible disease agents from transferring from one space to the other via cleaning supplies, such as table wiping rags.

questions.question: Health inspectors can not inspect a workplace's own-check plan's monitoring logs.
questions.description: Health inspectors make routine inspections in food production areas. The monitoring logs of the own-check plans are also part of the inspections. The logs must be stored for 1 year in the workplace. Only stored logs can prove that the workplace has followed its own-check plan accordingly.

questions.question: Cooked rice can be cooled in room temperature.
questions.description: Cooked rice is an easily perishable food product. In room temperature the microbes in the rice can reproduce very quickly and cause food poisoning.

questions.question: Pasteurisation of milk destroys listeria bacteria.
questions.description: Pasteurisation of milk is a process that destroys listeria bacteria. Milk is pasteurised when heated to 72°C for about 15 seconds.

questions.question: Foreign frozen raspberries can be served without heating because the freezing destroys any possible disease causers.
questions.description: Foreign frozen raspberries must always be heated properly (boiling for 5 minutes) before serving because they may contain the norovirus. Freezing does not destroy disease causers that have gotten into the food product before freezing, because viruses stay able to spread for a long time in different conditions.

questions.question: Waste bins in food premises may contain microbes that are a health hazard.
questions.description: It is important to make sure that waste bins are regularly emptied and that they are clean by washing them with appropriate detergents.

questions.question: Cold fish products (e.g. salmon) in vacuum-packages has sometimes been found to contain listeria.
questions.description: Cold fish products in vacuum-packages have a risk to cause listeriosis because the fish has not been heated and the storing time is long.

questions.question: Bacteria spores die when a product is dried.
questions.description: Spores are the form of bacteria that will last. Spores are able to endure dryness, boiling, salting and the cold. Bacteria can not reproduce in dry products but they will survive as spores.

questions.question: The safety data sheets of detergents (washing chemicals) must always be kept close to their storage location.
questions.description: Safety data sheets must be kept near detergents so that the user of the detergent can read e.g. the first aid instructions.

questions.question: Raw milk contains less microbes than pasteurized milk.
questions.description: When milk is pasteurized a large amount of microbes gets destroyed. For example listeria, salmonella and EHEC bacteria are destroyed during pasteurization. The bacteria in raw milk have not been destroyed with heat treatment.

questions.question: Vegetables stored in a vinegared liquid can be kept in room temperature.
questions.description: Sterilized, can-packed and unopened vinegared products can be stored in room temperature. Vinegared products will last long due to the high acidity, but opened packages must be stored in cool temperatures.

questions.question: Properly heated food products can not contain bacteria that causes food poisoning.
questions.description: Even properly heated food products can contain food poisoning causing bacteria; the bacteria can spread to the food due to bad handling hygiene or dirty equipment during e.g. chopping or serving.

questions.question: Own-check plans help to lessen the amount of food products that is unfit or needs to be gotten rid of.
questions.description: By law, merchants are required to identify and list critical points in food product preparation and handling to do with food product rules, and to also take action to make sure these points are monitored regularly. When possible problems are taken notice of in time, the amount of food products that are unfit and need to be gotten rid of will become smaller.

questions.question: Products sold at a fish stall must have a marking if they have been defrosted for sale.
questions.description: Customers must know if they are buying products that have already been defrosted. A product that has been frozen and defrosted once can not be frozen again.

questions.question: Food products containing food poisoning bacteria can always be noticed by bad smells and other visual perishing symptoms.
questions.description: Food poisoning bacteria can not be noticed using the senses (visually etc.) in food products. Perished food products might contain food poisoning bacteria, but the bacteria might not cause any changes in the appearance of the food product.

questions.question: When unprotected, cooked and uncooked food products must be stored in separate areas.
questions.description: Unprotected cooked and uncooked food products must have separate storage areas to prevent cross-contamination.

questions.question: Hand washing areas must be used only for washing hands.
questions.description: Hand washing areas can not be used for other washing purposes; this helps to prevent microbes from spreading in food production areas.

questions.question: Chefs are required to have a hygiene proficiency passport even if their employment is not permanent.
questions.description: Chefs handle easily perishable food products in their work. This means that chefs must pass a hygiene proficiency test at least 3 months after starting their work.

questions.question: Most food poisoning causing microbes will be destroyed when the temperature of food is more than 75 degrees Celsius.
questions.description: Most food poisoning causing microbes can not live in temperatures over 75 degrees Celsius. However, bacteria-spores can live in much higher temperatures.

questions.question: Food that is being served while hot must be at least 60 degrees Celsius during the entire serving period.
questions.description: The temperature must also be measured and marked down in own-check logs. The food can be kept in service while hot for a maximum of 4 hours.

questions.question: Bacteria toxins can require boiling for 5 hours before they disappear from food.
questions.description: If toxins have appeared in the food, they can cause food poisoning. Only a very long boiling time will get rid of the toxins.

questions.question: Freezing does not always destroy food poisoning microbes.
questions.description: Freezing does not kill microbes, but prevents them from multiplying.

questions.question: Temperature does not affect the reproduction speed of microbes.
questions.description: Temperatures are very important for the reproduction abilities of microbes. The insides of humans and animals often contain the optimal temperature for microbes, between 20 and 45 degrees Celsius.

questions.question: Bacteria spores are not destroyed during boiling.
questions.description: Bacteria spores are destroyed only during sterilization. In excess pressure the temperature is raised to about 145 degrees Celsius and this way bacteria spores are also destroyed.

questions.question: Own-check plans must include clear instructions on how to act when food poisoning suspicions are raised.
questions.description: When food is prepared for customers, food poisoning events must be planned for in advance. Own-check plans must include clear instructions for these events. It is important to notify health inspectors about suspicions immediately.

questions.question: It is not allowed to use useful microbes in baking.
questions.description: Yeast is used in baking to make dough rise.

questions.question: The ice kept in transport cases for fresh fish must meet the purity requirements.
questions.description: Ice used with food products must only be made of water that meets the requirements for domestic water.

questions.question: The transportation company is responsible for the approproate storing temperature of food during transportation.
questions.description: Drivers ensure that food is being stored in the right temperature, and that packages do not get damaged. The person receiving the delivery inspects the delivery and makes sure products quickly get placed in the appropriate storing place.

questions.question: When outside temperatures are very cold, food products can be cooled quickly outside.
questions.description: Food products must not be cooled or stored outside. All equipment and products, e.g. boxes containg baked goods, must be stored inside.

questions.question: The toxins contained in fresh morel mushrooms can not be removed by only roasting the mushrooms.
questions.description: Morel mushrooms must be boiled twice for at least 5 minutes and washed thoroughly between the boilings.

questions.question: The maximum storage temperature for cooked shellfish is +6°C.
questions.description: Cooked molluscs and shellfish are stored at the temperature of melting ice (maximum +2°C).

questions.question: If one's hands are clean, the temperature of food can be checked with the fingers.
questions.description: It is not possible to see how microbiologically clean one's hands are if only using the bare eye. Microbes can spread from the fingers to cooked food; when measuring the temperature of food a thermometer which can be easily cleaned must be used.

questions.question: The amount of water a product contains does not significantly affect its lastingness.
questions.description: Harmful microbes need water to reproduce. Because of this dry products last well.

questions.question: When receiving products one must make sure that they are moved into their appropriate, separate storage areas as soon as possible after the receival check.
questions.description: Products should be moved into their own storage areas as soon as possible after the receival check. Easily perishable food products can not be stored in room temperature for longer than 10-15 minutes.

questions.question: Clostridium perfringens is a bacteria that is often found in earth.
questions.description: Earth contains many microbes, some of which cause food poisoning. To prevent clostridium perfringens food poisonings it is important to properly heat and cool the food and not store it in the dangerous temperature zone of 6 to 60 degrees Celsius.

questions.question: Oiva is a system which helps to assess the food product safety of different workplaces.
questions.description: Municipality food control authorities do routine inspections at workplaces. Oiva is the publishing system for the results of these inspections, and is co-ordinated by Ruokavirasto.

questions.question: Cold fish products (e.g. salmon) in vacuum-packages has sometimes been found to contain listeria.
questions.description: Cold fish products in vacuum-packages have a risk to cause listeriosis because the fish has not been heated and the storing time is long.

questions.question: The only mandatory information on food packaging is the ingredients and the name of the food product.
questions.description: In addition to the name of the food product and the ingredients, the packaging must also state the minimum shelf life and the use by date.

questions.question: Food that is being served while hot must be at least 55 degrees Celsius during the entire serving period.
questions.description: Food that is being served while hot must be kept at over 60 degrees Celsius during the entire serving period. The temperature must be measured and marked down in own-check logs.

questions.question: Beneficial microbes cannot be used in the production of cream cheese.
questions.description: Cream cheese is made using beneficial microbes.

questions.question: Food that is being served only requires temperature measurements if it is being served hot.
questions.description: Temperature measurements must also be done for food that is being served cold.

questions.question: Pasteurized dairy products can be stored unopened in room temperature.
questions.description: Pasteurizing does not make it possible to store dairy products in room temperature. UHT-treated dairy products can be stored in room temperature if they are unopened.

questions.question: In commercial kitchens, it is necessary to nominate the people in charge of the own-check plan.
questions.description: Designated persons who have been trained for the task are responsible for the various areas of the own-check plan.

questions.question: Brooms and mops can be stored on the floor in the corner of a cleaning equipment storage room.
questions.description: Brooms and mops will not dry if they are stored on the floor. Microbes can reproduce quickly in wet cleaning equipment.

questions.question: The gutting and proper washing of fish is enough to prevent tapeworm infections.
questions.description: Infectious tapeworm larvas can be inside the muscles or roe of the fish. Tapeworm infections can be prevented by cooking or freezing the fish or roe.

questions.question: You can touch the inside surfaces of food packaging if you have just washed your hands.
questions.description: You should always try not to touch the inside surfaces of food packaging.

questions.question: Detergents (washing chemicals) can be stored in soda bottles.
questions.description: Only the original packages can be used to make sure that the correct detergent is being used for the situation.

questions.question: Heating food to 75 degrees Celsius or more is enough to destroy salmonella.
questions.description: Salmonella will be destroyed in heat treatment when food is heated to at least 75 degrees Celsius.

questions.question: Food products must be traceable, i.e. it must be possible, if necessary, to prove from where the raw materials were obtained.
questions.description: Traceability is used to prove from where the raw materials were obtained and to where the finished products have been delivered.

questions.question: The slime that appears on the surface of meat products is caused by harmful microbes.
questions.description: Some harmful microbes produce slime. For example, slime appearing on the surface of a sausage is a sign of it perishing. Slime-producing microbes reproduce quickly in food products e.g. when the product is stored or served in too high temperatures.

questions.question: Baker's yeast contains living microbes.
questions.description: Baker's yeast itself is living yeast microbes. These yeast microbes will die if the temperature goes over 42 degrees Celsius. Because of this baker's yeast can not be added to a liquid that is too hot.

questions.question: Minced meat that has been prepared in a store can be sold on the day of preparation and the day after that.
questions.description: Minced meat prepared in a retail store and grounded liver can be sold on the day of preparation and the day after it has been prepared.

questions.question: When a new detergent is introduced into a kitchen, the cleaning plan in the own-check plan is updated.
questions.description: It is important that the own-check plan is always up to date. All changes to the own-check plan, e.g. introduction of a new detergent, must be updated in the cleaning plan.

questions.question: A frozen product may be defrosted in room temperature if the product is needed quickly.
questions.description: Frozen products are always to be defrosted in coolers. If defrosting must be sped up, one can use the defrosting option on a microwave or the product can be kept in its packaging under cold running water.

questions.question: Food production employees are only allowed to wear their work outfit at their workplace, the food production area.
questions.description: The work outfit can only be worn inside the food production area; this prevents microbes from spreading into the area from the clothes.

questions.question: A food manufacturer is responsible for date labelling (best before date or use by date).
questions.description: A food manufacturer or packer is responsible for correct date labelling.

questions.question: The smaller the pieces of chopped vegetables, the longer their shelf life.
questions.description: The more you handle and chop food products, the shorter their shelf life is.

questions.question: The correct concentration of detergent does not have any effect on the cleaning result.
questions.description: Detergents and disinfectants must be measured out in accordance with the manufacturer's instructions. A solution that is stronger than recommended does not usually guarantee a better cleaning result, and a solution that is diluted too much may give a worse result.

questions.question: The results of Oiva-reports can be viewed by anyone online.
questions.description: The Oiva system is used to allow consumers to view the results of routine inspections.

questions.question: Bacteria are always harmful on human skin or in the intestines.
questions.description: Beneficial bacteria exist on the skin and in the intestines that protect humans from harmful bacteria and strengthen the immune system.

questions.question: Food production areas need to have a changing room.
questions.description: Employees need a changing room which has a separate storage space for clean work clothes.

questions.question: Packages for non-easily perishable food products must have a label indicating their best-before date.
questions.description: Packaging labels for non-easily perishable food products show the best-before date. The accuracy of the date is determined by the product's shelf life. The product may be used after the date if its sensory qualities, such as smell, taste and look are impeccable.

questions.question: Received food products must be stored where there is the most space for them in the storage facility.
questions.description: Received food products are stored based on the FIFO method (First In, First Out) which means that products already stored in the storage facility are moved to the front to be used or taken first, and any new products are placed behind or after any prior ones. This way the products are taken out of storage in the order they arrived in and the amount of wastage is reduced.

questions.question: Dishwashing should be done so that dirty dishes and clean dishes are handled separately enough.
questions.description: Clean dishes will become dirty again if they are not kept separate from dirty dishes.

questions.question: Samples taken from batches of food prepared in large kitchens must be stored for 1-2 months.
questions.description: Samples are taken from large kitchens' food batches to trace possible food poisoning causes easier. Samples must be taken daily from all batches being somehow served or sold and the samples must be stored appropriately marked in a freezer for 1-2 weeks. During this time a majority of food poisoning symptoms start to appear.

questions.question: Chefs are allowed to handle money and prepare food without washing their hands in between.
questions.description: Notes and coins contain a lot of microbes, and you must always wash your hands after handling money before you start cooking.

questions.question: Whipping is one way to improve the shelf life of cream.
questions.description: If you whip cream, you process an unpackaged perishable food product, which shortens its shelf life.

questions.question: An establishment's own-check plan is in effect for 10 years at a time.
questions.description: The own-check plan must be updated if need arises. It is useful to go over the plan regularly and to assess whether or not there have been changes in the establishment's functioning or protocols that require changes to made in the plan as well. Changes in the regulations of the food industry may necessitate changes in own-check plans as well.

questions.question: Food products must be cooled first by using separate cooling equipment and only then moved into a freezer for storage.
questions.description: Products that are not frozen and are placed into a freezer will raise the temperature of the freezer; this weakens the lastingness of the products in the freezer.

questions.question: Ultra-high-temperature processing (UHT) uses higher temperatures than pasteurizing.
questions.description: Ultra-high-temperature processing is done in much higher temperatures than pasteurizing. UHT destroys most bacteria spores and because of this products that have been treated with UHT can be stored in room temperature.

questions.question: Food production areas' food waste must be stored in cool temperatures if possible.
questions.description: Food waste should be stored in cold areas specifically meant for the waste if it is possible. However, it is rare to have so many cold areas that they can also be used separately for waste.

questions.question: If a salmonella infection is asymptomatic, it cannot spread into handled food products via an employee.
questions.description: A salmonella infection can spread even if the person who carries it has no symptoms. This is why it is important to have a salmonella test before the employment starts.

questions.question: Wounds on the hands should be covered with both a bandage and a single-use glove.
questions.description: When both a bandage and a single-use glove are used, the wound is protected well enough and is also made more waterproof.

questions.question: Food products can not be stored on the floor of dry storage rooms.
questions.description: Storing food products on the floor is not a hygienic way to store food. Floors always contain more microbes than shelves.

questions.question: If the dish washer is not cleaned regularly, harmful microbes can multiply inside the machine and cause a health risk.
questions.description: Dish washers must also be cleaned regularly according to their instructions and allowed to dry afterwards.

questions.question: The shelf life of spices can be prolonged by radiation.
questions.description: UV, infra red and gamma radiation can be used to destroy microbes from for example spices and pastries that are made to last for long periods of storage.

questions.question: Beer is produced with the help of beneficial microbes.
questions.description: Beer is produced with yeast fermentation. Yeast is also used when producing wine.

questions.question: Bacteria reproduce very quickly in products that have high acidity.
questions.description: Bacteria that are a threat to food product safety reproduce the best in the neutral zone. Because of this the growth of these bacteria can be prevented by increasing the acidity of a product.

questions.question: If the product being handled is fresh and of good quality, the handling hygiene is not as important.
questions.description: Hygienic handling methods and equipment are always important for the lastingness of products. A fresh and good quality good will still perish easily if it is handled unhygienically.

questions.question: Waste disposal is not a part of the own-check plan.
questions.description: Waste disposal is a part of the own-check plan. Health inspectors also pay attention to how well waste is disposed of in food related premises. The regular emptying and cleaning of waste containers must be looked after.

questions.question: Listeria can not reproduce in cold fish (e.g. salmon) in vacuum-packages.
questions.description: Listeria and yersinia are rare exceptions of food poisoning causing bacteria, because they can reproduce in refrigerator temperatures.

questions.question: A product can not be used for food preparation after the product's best-before date.
questions.description: Best before dates tell that the product's main attributes and characteristics will remain the same up to the marked date, as long as it is stored correctly. The product can be used and sold after the best before date. The usability and quality of the product can be checked using the senses (visually etc.) after the best before date.

questions.question: All E-numbered additives improve the lastingness of food products.
questions.description: Food products can be made to last longer by adding preservatives to them. In the European Union, allowed preservatives have an E-number: for example, E 200 is sorbic acid and E 296 is malic acid. Preservatives that are allowed can be found, along with other additives, in an E-number list. Some preservatives can be found naturally in berries and fruits, such as in lingonberries and citrus fruit. E-numbers are also used to identify additives other than ones that improve lastingness. For example, color additives do not improve the lastingness of food products.

questions.question: Food products containing food poisoning bacteria can always be noticed by bad smells and other visual perishing symptoms.
questions.description: Food poisoning bacteria can not be noticed using the senses (visually etc.) in food products. Perished food products might contain food poisoning bacteria, but the bacteria might not cause any changes in the appearance of the food product.

questions.question: If one's hands are clean, the temperature of food can be checked with the fingers.
questions.description: It is not possible to see how microbiologically clean one's hands are if only using the bare eye. Microbes can spread from the fingers to cooked food; when measuring the temperature of food a thermometer which can be easily cleaned must be used.

questions.question: Bacteria spores are always found inside the cans of canned food.
questions.description: Canned foods are produced with sterilization which destroys all bacteria spores. The sterilization has failed bacteria spores are found inside the can.

questions.question: The maximum storage temperature for cooked shellfish is +6°C.
questions.description: Cooked molluscs and shellfish are stored at the temperature of melting ice (maximum +2°C).

questions.question: Products that have gone through ultra-high-temperature treatment (UHT) can not be stored in room temperature.
questions.description: During UHT products are sterilized with quick heating. Unopened packages can be stored in room temperature because most bacteria spores have been destroyed.

questions.question: A porcelain plate that is chipped is a hygiene hazard.
questions.description: Only use dishes that have an undamaged surface.

questions.question: All bacteria are harmful for food products.
questions.description: Certain bacteria are beneficial for food preparation. For example, yoghurt, cheese and sour cabbage preparation uses bacteria such as lactic acid bacteria (LAB) beneficially.

questions.question: HACCP is a food poisoning causing bacteria.
questions.description: HACCP stands for Hazard Analysis and Critical Control Points, which is a part of own-check plans. When working with an own-check plan these critical points must be identified and constantly monitored carefully.

questions.question: Sugar can contain microbes.
questions.description: Sugar is dry, so microbes do not grow in it. However, salt can contain spores of bacteria, moulds or yeast.

questions.question: Dirt and dust can make microbes spread to food products.
questions.description: Different kinds of impurities, such as dirt and dust, contain microbes. If dirt or dust gets onto a food product then the microbes contained will also spread onto the product.

questions.question: When the temperature of food is being measured, the measurement must be done in the centre of the food mass.
questions.description: Especially in large food masses the temperatures can be very different depending on where the measurement is taken from, such as the sides or the centre.

questions.question: If food is cooled too slowly it can lead to food poisoning.
questions.description: Too slow cooling of food is a very common reason for food poisoning. Cooling should happen quickly (in under 4 hours) so that the microbes in the food can not reproduce and grow into large hazardous quantities. During cooling food has a dangerous temperature (between 6 and 60 degrees Celsius) where microbes reproduce very quickly.

questions.question: Bacteria spores are destroyed during sterilization.
questions.description: During sterilization (e.g. during canned food production) all microbes and bacteria spores are destroyed. This way easily perishable products will be able to last long in room temperature.

questions.question: Guide dogs are allowed inside food product stores.
questions.description: Guide dogs are always allowed in areas meant for customers. However, no animals can be taken inside food product handling areas or storage areas.

questions.question: Pasteurizing destroys all bacteria from a food product.
questions.description: During pasteurization the food product is heated to +degrees celsius. This temperature destroys a large percentage of microbes, but the product still requires cold storage. For example pasteurized milk must be kept at a temperature of +6 degrees or less.

questions.question: Salmonella bacteria can not be found in fowl or poultry.
questions.description: Salmonella can be found in fowl or poultry. Due to the risk of salmonella, the meat of fowl/poultry must always be cooked to at least 75 degrees Celsius.

questions.question: The own-check plan helps to make sure that there are fewer unsafe food products.
questions.description: The most important objective of the own-check plan is to improve food safety.

questions.question: Dirty root vegetables and pre-made food products can be stored in the same cold room.
questions.description: Dirt always contains many microbes. Dirty root vegetables must be handled separately from other products so that the microbes in the dirt do not spread to other food products.

questions.question: The purpose of own-check plans is to prevent mistakes and problematic situations from occurring during food preparation and serving.
questions.description: Good own-check plans as well as good knowledge of the own-check plan's contents by the personnel prevents problematic situations and makes it easier to identify the causes of any noticed problems.

questions.question: Soup made for the following day can be left to cool overnight on the kitchen counter.
questions.description: The rapid cooling and cold storing of soup prevents or slows down the growth of bacteria.

questions.question: When serving or distributing food products for free, the rules and requirements for handling food products must be followed.
questions.description: Food product handling rules are still required to be followed when serving for free.

questions.question: Hard rye bread (crisp bread) is not an easily perishable food product.
questions.description: Hard rye bread is a dry food product, and because of this microbes can not reproduce in it. Hard rye bread can be stored in room temperature.

questions.question: The more microbes there are in a cleaning cloth, the worse it smells.
questions.description: Microbes are usually odourless microorganisms that are invisible to the naked eye.

questions.question: Wastebins do not need to be cleaned.
questions.description: Wastebins must not be broken, must include a lid and must also be cleaned regularly.

questions.question: All microbes in earth and the ground are beneficial decomposing microbes which do not cause harm to consumers when they spread to food products.
questions.description: There are many harmful microbes in earth and the ground that can cause food poisoning if they spread to food products.

questions.question: Waiters and servers are not required to have headwear.
questions.description: Waiters and servers are allowed to work without headwear.

questions.question: When raw frozen chicken is thawed it releases liquid that can contain salmonella.
questions.description: Raw fowl/poultry meat can always contain salmonella, which will not be destroyed in a freezer. If the meat contains salmonella it will also certainly be in the liquid.

questions.question: Food poisoning causing microbes can spread only by hands.
questions.description: Working areas and surfaces must be cleaned regularly during work shifts and after work is over.

questions.question: If a fish is dropped on a freshly washed floor, it can still be cooked as long as it is sufficiently well heated.
questions.description: A fish that has fallen onto the floor must never be used for cooking. Food products must never be stored on the floor.

questions.question: Reheated products must be heated to +75 degrees celsius before serving.
questions.description: Reheated food products, such as appropriately cooled food that has been prepared the previous day, must be thoroughly heated to +75 degrees before serving.

questions.question: HACCP is a food poisoning causing bacteria.
questions.description: HACCP stands for Hazard Analysis and Critical Control Points, which is a part of own-check plans. When working with an own-check plan these critical points must be identified and constantly monitored carefully.

questions.question: Intestinal bacteria can spread from hands to food.
questions.description: Intestinal bacteria can spread to food even from the hands.

questions.question: Liquid soap is to be used when washing the hands.
questions.description: Liquid soap is hygienic. The dispenser of the liquid soap should be one which can be pressed with the forearm instead of the hands.

questions.question: All own-check plan related measurements must be recorded in own-check plan forms.
questions.description: Though recording all own-check related measurements is essential, all measurements do not need to be logged. For example, it is good to pay daily attention to the temperatures of cold storage, but only a weekly log entry is sufficient.

questions.question: Tap water can cause food poisoning.
questions.description: Tap water cleanliness must be monitored using the senses. Water samples can also be regularly sent for chemical and microbiological inspections. For example the food poisoning causing norovirus lasts well in water.

questions.question: When receiving products one must make sure that they are moved into their appropriate, separate storage areas as soon as possible after the receival check.
questions.description: Products should be moved into their own storage areas as soon as possible after the receival check. Easily perishable food products can not be stored in room temperature for longer than 10-15 minutes.

questions.question: Food products must never be cooled or stored outside.
questions.description: Food products must not be cooled or stored outside. All equipment and products, e.g. boxes containg baked goods, must be stored inside.

questions.question: When roasting or cooking insects, there is no need to be especially careful.
questions.description: When insects are processed, they must be handled in the same way as other perishable food products.

questions.question: Acidity in a food product prevents the reproduction of bacteria.
questions.description: Bacteria that are a threat to food product safety reproduce the best in the neutral zone. Because of this the growth of these bacteria can be prevented by increasing the acidity of a product.

questions.question: Whipping is one way to improve the shelf life of cream.
questions.description: If you whip cream, you process an unpackaged perishable food product, which shortens its shelf life.

questions.question: There are no microbes in dried food products.
questions.description: Dried products last well due to having no water that bacteria could use to reproduce. However, the microbes have not been destroyed in dried products and the products can contain spores of bacteria, moulds or yeast.

questions.question: Milk can be stored at room temperature during the breakfast service.
questions.description: Milk and cream are perishable food products and they must be served cold.

questions.question: Products that have gone through ultra-high-temperature treatment (UHT) can be stored in room temperature.
questions.description: During UHT products are sterilized with quick heating. Unopened packages can be stored in room temperature because most bacteria spores have been destroyed.

questions.question: A cleaning and washing program must be included in the own-check plan.
questions.description: Areas that need to be cleaned, washing and cleaning methods for each area and specific cleaning equipment and substances (if required) must be listed in the own-check plan. The effectiveness of the cleaning must be checked visually daily and the responsible person has to log results for example once a week or always when abnormalities are noticed.

questions.question: Crates can be stored on the loading dock as long as they are protected from the rain.
questions.description: Storing crates on the loading dock is a hygiene hazard as they attract birds and other animals.

questions.question: If food is prepared to be served later, the finished products must be cooled as soon as possible for storage.
questions.description: Hot, cooked food must be cooled to under 6 degrees Celsius in under 4 hours. Cooling large amounts of products requires the use of actual cooling devices, from which the cooled products must be moved to their appropriate cold storage units.

questions.question: Fungi and plants can also cause food poisoning.
questions.description: Causes of food poisoning include microbes, toxins produced by microbes, parasites, poisonous animals, plants and fungi.

questions.question: It is not essential for hygiene whether hands are washed using liquid soap or soap blocks.
