questions.description: Soap used for hand washing must be mild so that it will not damage the skin of the hands. The soap must be liquid and the soap dispenser must also be hygienic. Warm water is used for washing, and it is also important to properly dry one's hands after washing them.

questions.question: The creation and following requirements of own-check plans include all companies that handle food products.
questions.description: The creation and use of an own-check plan is a requirement by law, which has included all companies handling food products since 1995. All employees in a company are responsible for the implementation of own-check plans.

questions.question: Due to salmonella risks, fowl and poultry meat must always be heated thoroughly to over 75 degrees Celsius.
questions.description: Fowl/poultry can contain salmonella naturally. Salmonella bacteria must be alive to cause an illness. The meat of fowl/poultry is safe if it is heated thoroughly to over 75 degrees Celsius.

questions.question: Botulism, a food poisoning caused by clostridium botulinum, can be lethal.
questions.description: Clostridium botulinum creates a very deadly toxin called botulin. The food poisoning caused by botulin can cause death.

questions.question: Unpeeled and peeled carrots will last the same amount of time as long as they are stored in the cold.
questions.description: Earthy and dirty, untreated root vegetables will last long in appropriate cold storage units, but all treatments will worsen their lastingness.

questions.question: Defrosting frozen foods in room temperature increases the risk of food poisoning.
questions.description: Frozen foods' surfaces will defrost faster than the insides. In room temperature the surfaces will become warm enough for microbes to grow even though the insides might still be frozen.

questions.question: The purity of the air in the food packaging area has no effect on the shelf life of food products.
questions.description: Food products are packed in an area with clean air, as it affects their shelf life.

questions.question: Cold fish products (e.g. salmon) in vacuum-packages has sometimes been found to contain listeria.
questions.description: Cold fish products in vacuum-packages have a risk to cause listeriosis because the fish has not been heated and the storing time is long.

questions.question: Employees are free to decide who is responsible for the own-check plan at the beginning of each shift.
questions.description: Designated persons who have been trained for the task are responsible for the various areas of the own-check plan.

questions.question: Food production areas' waste bins must be cleaned regularly.
questions.description: The cleanliness and hygiene of waste bins must be taken care of regularly. Waste bins in kitchens should be cleaned always after they are emptied.

questions.question: Parboiling can be used to prolong the shelf life of frozen vegetables.
questions.description: Parboiling, in other words rapid boiling, prolongs the shelf life of frozen vegetables, because enzymatic activity in the product stops and the microbes on the surface are destroyed.

questions.question: Listeria bacteria are not destroyed when a product is frozen.
questions.description: Freezing does not destroy microbes. Listeria can also reproduce in frozen foods.

questions.question: Smoking is allowed at the loading docks of kitchens.
questions.description: Loading docks are a part of food production areas; smoking is not allowed in food production areas.

questions.question: Beneficial bacteria usually make it harder for harmful bacteria to grow.
questions.description: Harmful bacteria have to compete with beneficial bacteria for living space and nutrition. Beneficial bacteria can change living conditions in food products, e.g. the acidity, such that it becomes worse for harmful bacteria and makes them grow slower or not at all.

questions.question: If the product being handled is fresh and of good quality, the handling hygiene is not as important.
questions.description: Hygienic handling methods and equipment are always important for the lastingness of products. A fresh and good quality good will still perish easily if it is handled unhygienically.

questions.question: Listeria can not reproduce in cold fish (e.g. salmon) in vacuum-packages.
questions.description: Listeria and yersinia are rare exceptions of food poisoning causing bacteria, because they can reproduce in refrigerator temperatures.

questions.question: When there is packaged meat in a delivery load, it can be safely left at room temperature for a few hours.
questions.description: The cold chain of meat products in a delivery load must not be broken.

questions.question: Bacteria can reproduce in more dry environments than moulds.
questions.description: Only some moulds can reproduce in very dry products. For example, bread becomes spoiled only due to mould; bacteria and yeasts can not reproduce in the bread.

questions.question: The same cleaning equipment can be used to clean the customer areas and the kitchen in small cafés.
questions.description: If the same cleaning equipment is used, microbes can easily spread from customers to the kitchen in the equipment.

questions.question: Beer is not produced with the help of beneficial microbes.
questions.description: Beer is produced with yeast fermentation. Yeast is a beneficial microbe.

questions.question: All E-numbered additives improve the lastingness of food products.
questions.description: Food products can be made to last longer by adding preservatives to them. In the European Union, allowed preservatives have an E-number: for example, E 200 is sorbic acid and E 296 is malic acid. Preservatives that are allowed can be found, along with other additives, in an E-number list. Some preservatives can be found naturally in berries and fruits, such as in lingonberries and citrus fruit. E-numbers are also used to identify additives other than ones that improve lastingness. For example, color additives do not improve the lastingness of food products.

questions.question: When food products are stored in the correct temperatures, the microbes in the products will not be able to reproduce and grow into dangerous quantities too quickly.
questions.description: Microbes can not be fully prevented from getting into food products. However, correct temperatures will slow down or prevent the microbes in food from reproducing and growing in hazardous amounts.

questions.question: The cooling of food products should be done by using cooling cabinets (chillers).
questions.description: Only cooling cabinets can ensure sufficiently fast and effective cooling.

questions.question: Workers in the food industry, e.g. an online store sselling food products, must inform local food control authorities about their activities.
questions.description: All workers in the food industry must inform food control authorities about their activities. The informing must be done before beginning the activities. When founding a food industry workplace, e.g. a sausage factory, the activities must also be approved by the authorities.

questions.question: After washing one's hands the tap must be closed using a hand towel, otherwise the hands can become dirty again.
questions.description: After washing the hands they must be dried using a single-use hand towel and the tap must be closed using the towel. This way any possible microbes on the tap do not spread onto the clean hands.

questions.question: If a salmonella infection is asymptomatic, it cannot spread into handled food products via an employee.
questions.description: A salmonella infection can spread even if the person who carries it has no symptoms. This is why it is important to have a salmonella test before the employment starts.

questions.question: Wine is produced with the help of beneficial microbes.
questions.description: The production of wine and beer uses yeast. Yeast is a beneficial microbe.

questions.question: Ice makers do not need to be washed because microbes do not multiply in such a cold environment.
questions.description: Ice makers must be washed regularly. Ice makers and utensils for picking up ice must be kept clean and in good condition, and their lids must be kept closed to prevent dirt from entering the machines. The high number of microbes in ice cubes causes a deterioration in the quality of food products and even food poisoning.

questions.question: Food production employees are allowed to wear their work outfit when going outside of the food production area during e.g. their lunch break.
questions.description: The work outfit can only be worn inside the food production area; this prevents microbes from spreading into the area from the clothes.

questions.question: Earth does not contain food poisoning causing bacteria.
questions.description: Earth can contain e.g. bacillus cereus or clostridum bacteria. Both of these are common causers of food poisoning.

questions.question: The creation and following requirements of own-check plans include all companies that handle food products.
questions.description: The creation and use of an own-check plan is a requirement by law, which has included all companies handling food products since 1995. All employees in a company are responsible for the implementation of own-check plans.

questions.question: Only old cold storage equipment must have a thermometer.
questions.description: All cold storage equipment in food production areas must have a thermometer.

questions.question: It is important to visually monitor cleanliness on a daily basis in addition to regular cleaning.
questions.description: Everyone working in a food premises must constantly monitor its cleanliness.

questions.question: You can leave your rings on your fingers while you wash your hands.
questions.description: A lot of dirt and microbes live under rings, which means that rings must be removed before washing your hands.

questions.question: Sugar can contain microbes.
questions.description: Sugar is dry, so microbes do not grow in it. However, salt can contain spores of bacteria, moulds or yeast.

questions.question: The human skin naturally contains microbes.
questions.description: Especially the face, scalp, mouth, nose etc. contain microbes. Food poisoning causing Staphylococcus bacteria can also be found on the skin.

questions.question: There must be an appropriate washing place for large machines and dishes in the food premises.
questions.description: A cleaning plan is made for every machine and device to specify an appropriate place for washing each one of them.

questions.question: Not all microbes and bacteria-spores in food products can be destroyed using any treatments.
questions.description: Sterilizing or radiating can destroy all bacteria or microbe-spores in food products. Canned food, such as canned tuna and canned baby food is sterilized by heating the packed products. Spices are one example of a product that can be treated by radiation.

questions.question: All plastic containers are suitable for storing food.
questions.description: Materials that come into contact with food must be meant for food use.

questions.question: Temperature does not affect the speed of microbe reproduction.
questions.description: Temperatures are very important for the reproduction abilities of microbes. All microbes have their own optimal temperatures where reproduction is the fastest.

questions.question: The ice kept in transport cases for fresh fish must meet the purity requirements.
questions.description: Ice used with food products must only be made of water that meets the requirements for domestic water.

questions.question: The amount of sugar a product contains does not affect its lastingness.
questions.description: Highly sugared products, such as jams, marmelades and sweets do not perish easily because sugar changes the state of water so that microbes can not reproduce.

questions.question: Prepared salads can be stored in room temperature without a risk of food poisoning.
questions.description: Prepared salads are easily perishable food products. For example, chopped or grated vegetables and root vegetables, meat, fish and mayonnaise are often ingredients of prepared salads, so they have to be stored in the cold.

questions.question: Bacteria spores will stay alive even when a product is dried.
questions.description: Spores are the form of bacteria that will last. Spores are able to endure dryness, boiling, salting and the cold. Bacteria can not reproduce in dry products but they will survive as spores.

questions.question: Listeria is destroyed when a product is heated to over 70 degrees Celsius.
questions.description: Because listeria is destroyed during heating, products that are not heated are risk food products: vacuum-packed and protective gas packed fish, meat and blue cheese and normal cheese produced from non-pasteurized milk.

questions.question: If a food authority representative wants to see your own-check plan, you must present it to him/her.
questions.description: If a food authority representative wants to see an operator's own-check plan, the operator is obliged to present it.

questions.question: When receiving products one must make sure that they are moved into their appropriate, separate storage areas as soon as possible after the receival check.
questions.description: Products should be moved into their own storage areas as soon as possible after the receival check. Easily perishable food products can not be stored in room temperature for longer than 10-15 minutes.

questions.question: Cold fish products (e.g. salmon) in vacuum-packages has sometimes been found to contain listeria.
questions.description: Cold fish products in vacuum-packages have a risk to cause listeriosis because the fish has not been heated and the storing time is long.

questions.question: Easily perishable food products that have been up for retail sale can be frozen and sold as frozen foods.
questions.description: The preparation of frozen foods requires the ingredients to be perfect quality. Frozen foods must be prepared, cooled and frozen without any delay. Frozen foods are prepared only by appropriate production centres. Freezing is allowed in bakeries, households and farm households only if the areas and equipment are approved by officials.

questions.question: The incorrect storing temperature of food is a major cause for food poisoning.
questions.description: If food is stored in too warm temperatures, microbes that cause food poisoning will reproduce quickly. Because of this the temperatures of cold storage units and freezers must be monitored regularly using thermometers.

questions.question: All food that is being served needs to be sampled daily.
questions.description: Taken samples must be placed into a container and then placed into a freezer. If food poisonings are suspected, then these samples must be available for research.

questions.question: Sterilizing allows easily perishable food products to be stored in room temperature.
questions.description: Canned foods are prepared by sterilizing them. This way canned meat, fish and baby food that has not been opened can be stored in room temperature.

questions.question: Minced meat lasts as long as unprepared meat if it is packaged in a vacuum container or vacuum bag.
questions.description: Minced meat requires that it be stored in a maximum temperature of +4 degrees celsius, whereas whole meat can be stored in +6 degrees celsius.

questions.question: The post-contamination of a cooked product can be prevented by using appropriate and clean storing containers.
questions.description: Good hand hygiene, clean working equipment and hygienic storing containers protect cooked products from post-contamination due to hazards that affect the safety of the product after heating it.

questions.question: Food production employees are allowed to wear colorless nail polish.
questions.description: Hands must not containt anything extra such as watches, jewellery, fake nails, nail polish or hand cream.

questions.question: Safety data sheets are the same thing as the instruction manual of a device.
questions.description: Safety data sheets include the most important information about detergents (washing chemicals) and also include first aid instructions.

questions.question: Only supervisors carry out the activities described in the own-check plan.
questions.description: Everyone working in a food premises is responsible for carrying out the activities described in the own-check plan.

questions.question: Food products can be used safely after the use-by date if they do not look or smell bad.
questions.description: Perished or contaminated products are not always possible to notice just by using the senses (visually etc.) Easily perishable food products' packages have a use-by date marked on them, and after this date has passed the product must not be used or sold.

questions.question: The temperature monitoring of cold storages is a part of own-check plans.
questions.description: The temperatures of cold storages must be checked and logged regularly according to the own-check plan. Cold storages must always have thermometers for measurements.

questions.question: A frozen product may be defrosted in room temperature if the product is needed quickly.
questions.description: Frozen products are always to be defrosted in coolers. If defrosting must be sped up, one can use the defrosting option on a microwave or the product can be kept in its packaging under cold running water.

questions.question: The most hygienic way to handle unpacked food products is to use wooden utensils.
questions.description: The most hygienic utensils for handling unpacked food products are made of plastic or steel.

questions.question: Using food, that has been served at a buffet table, as an ingredient for preparing new foods increases food poisoning risks.
questions.description: Food that is at a buffet table is often in room temperature and available to be taken by customers themselves. This means that food poisoning causing bacteria spread to these foods easier and reproduce quicker in them. The risk of food poisoning increases when the same foods are used to make new ones. Food from buffet tables must not be used again in food preparation.

questions.question: The maximum storage temperature for cooked shellfish is +6°C.
questions.description: Cooked molluscs and shellfish are stored at the temperature of melting ice (maximum +2°C).

questions.question: A disinfectant detergent never needs to be replaced.
questions.description: It is possible for a disinfectant detergent to become ineffective against certain bacteria, and it is therefore important to change the detergent regularly.

questions.question: Whipping is one way to improve the shelf life of cream.
questions.description: If you whip cream, you process an unpackaged perishable food product, which shortens its shelf life.

questions.question: Food production areas need to have a changing room.
questions.description: Employees need a changing room which has a separate storage space for clean work clothes.

questions.question: Reheated products must be heated to +75 degrees celsius before serving.
questions.description: Reheated food products, such as appropriately cooled food that has been prepared the previous day, must be thoroughly heated to +75 degrees before serving.

questions.question: EHEC bacteria can be found in milk is the work hygiene during milking is not proper.
questions.description: This intestinal bacteria can only found in food products if the work hygiene is not proper during milking or slaughtering. Pasteurization destroys EHEC in milk.

questions.question: The creation and following requirements of own-check plans include all companies that handle food products.
questions.description: The creation and use of an own-check plan is a requirement by law, which has included all companies handling food products since 1995. All employees in a company are responsible for the implementation of own-check plans.

questions.question: Listeria and yersinia can not reproduce in refrigerator temperatures.
questions.description: Earth and various bodies of water contain microbes, such as listeria and yersinia, that are able to survive cold conditions well. Listeria and yersinia can reproduce in very cold refrigerator temperatures.

questions.question: Marinating prevents meat from spoiling.
questions.description: Meat can contain harmful microbes even if it is marinated.

questions.question: Bacteria can reproduce in more dry environments than moulds.
questions.description: Only some moulds can reproduce in very dry products. For example, bread becomes spoiled only due to mould; bacteria and yeasts can not reproduce in the bread.

questions.question: Salt can not contain microbes.
questions.description: Salt is dry, so microbes do not grow in it. However, salt can contain spores of bacteria, moulds or yeast.

questions.question: Waste disposal is an essential part of hygienic working in a professional kitchen.
questions.description: Appropriate waste bins and their regular emptying and cleaning, as well as the appropriate assortment and storage areas for waste that is going to be transported away, are all a part of good hygienic working. A professional kitchen's waste disposal is based on waste laws as well as regional waste disposal directives.

questions.question: Fermented milk products are produced with the help of lactic acid bacteria.
questions.description: Lactic acid bacteria (LAB) are used when producing fermented milk products. LAB create lactic acid in the product, which causes the product to become acidized. Most bacteria are unable to reproduce in acidized products and because of this fermenting milk products makes them last longer.

questions.question: Moulds can not create mould toxins.
questions.description: Some moulds can create mould toxins such as mycotoxins and aflatoxins. Because of this mouldy products should not be used.

questions.question: Chefs are required to have a hygiene proficiency passport even if their employment is not permanent.
questions.description: Chefs handle easily perishable food products in their work. This means that chefs must pass a hygiene proficiency test at least 3 months after starting their work.

questions.question: When outside temperatures are very cold, food products can be cooled quickly outside.
questions.description: Food products must not be cooled or stored outside. All equipment and products, e.g. boxes containg baked goods, must be stored inside.

questions.question: Food products can not be sold nor used after the last use-by-date.
questions.description: The last use-by-date must be marked on easily perishable food products. The marking must be based upon research results of lastingness.

questions.question: Food products containing food poisoning bacteria can always be noticed by bad smells and other visual perishing symptoms.
questions.description: Food poisoning bacteria can not be noticed using the senses (visually etc.) in food products. Perished food products might contain food poisoning bacteria, but the bacteria might not cause any changes in the appearance of the food product.

questions.question: The disinfection of working surfaces destroys all harmful microbes and sterilizes the surfaces.
questions.description: Even a thorough cleaning will destroy about 90% of micro-organisms. Disinfectants can be used to destroy nearly all microbes. However, even disinfectants can not sterilize working areas, because not all bacteria-spores die from disinfectants. When cleaning it is not essential to sterilize the environment but instead to regularly and properly clean and wash it.

questions.question: When handling food products, employees should not touch their nose if possible.
questions.description: The nose contains lots of microbes which will spread onto the hands if the nose is touched.

questions.question: Workers in the food industry, e.g. the owner of a small café, must inform local food control authorities about their activities.
questions.description: All workers in the food industry must inform food control authorities about their activities. The informing must be done before beginning the activities. When founding a food industry workplace, e.g. a sausage factory, the activities must also be approved by the authorities.

questions.question: Heat and humidity accelerate vegetable spoilage.
questions.description: The correct storage temperatures and moisture affect the shelf life of vegetables.

questions.question: If an employee has infected wounds on his or her hands, he or she must not handle food products.
questions.description: Infected wounds contain large amounts of food poisoning causing Staphylococcus aureus bacteria. It is impossible to constantly prevent the bacteria from spreading to food products.

questions.question: Disinfecting reduces the amount of microbes from work surfaces and equipment.
questions.description: Correctly done disinfection reduces the amount of microbes excellently on work surfaces and equipment.

questions.question: When preparing a own-check plan, all essential food product risk monitoring must be explained.
questions.description: It is essential for the plan to think which parts of done activities are ones where microbes can reproduce and how risks will be monitored, as well as what actions must be taken to fix risk situations.

questions.question: Earth can contain lots of food poisoning causing bacteria.
questions.description: Earth can contain e.g. bacillus cereus or clostridum bacteria. Earthy vegetables must be treated and stored such that the earth does not spread onto other food products.

questions.question: Mould toxins are destroyed when food products are boiled.
questions.description: Mould toxins can not be destroyed by only boiling them.

questions.question: Arriving products and cargo must be checked when received.
questions.description: The quality of arriving products must be checked and the temperatures of easily perishable products must be measured. The results must be written down.

questions.question: Only old cold storage equipment must have a thermometer.
questions.description: All cold storage equipment in food production areas must have a thermometer.

questions.question: Food packaging materials can be stored on a clean floor.
questions.description: Food packaging materials must never be stored directly on the floor but they must be placed on clean racks or other hygienic surfaces.

questions.question: Sour milk spoils faster than milk.
questions.description: The pH value of milk is 7, which means it is neutral. The pH value of sour milk is lower, which means sour milk is acidized. It is harder for bacteria to reproduce in acidized milk products than in neutral products.

questions.question: Food poisoning causing bacteria are found naturally.
questions.description: Microbes are everywhere: in the air, water, earth, plants, animals and humans. Some of these microbes cause food poisoning.

questions.question: Food can be tasted with the fingers.
questions.description: Food must never be touched with the fingers if it is not necessary. Spoons should be used for tasting.

questions.question: Vibrio bacteria are found in sea waters at warm geographical locations.
questions.description: Vibrio bacteria have been found in salty coast seawater at warm geographical locations. Seafood that has been heated badly or stored in too warm temperatures are risk food products.

questions.question: Vinegar lowers the pH value of a product and in this way makes the product last for a shorter amount of time.
questions.description: Especially the growth of bacteria can be prevented by increasing the acidity of a product.

questions.question: Waste bins to be used in kitchens must be water-proof and easily cleanable.
questions.description: Waste bins to be used in kitchens must be water-proof so that waste liquids do not pour onto the floor. They must also be easy to clean so that the cleaning process during emptying is as easy as possible.

questions.question: Bacillus cereus is not a food poisoning causing bacteria.
questions.description: Bacillus cereus is a food poisoning causing bacteria. Risk food products for this are e.g. raw milk and rice.

questions.question: Unpacked raw fish must always be stored separate from other food products.
questions.description: Raw fish must be stored separately from other food products to prevent the risk of cross-contamination.

questions.question: Vacuum-packages have the air removed from them.
questions.description: Vacuum-packages do not include any air and prevent microbes that require oxygen from reproducing.

questions.question: The results in Oiva-reports are not allowed to be read by customers.
questions.description: Municipality food control authorities do routine inspections at workplaces. Oiva-reports are published documents about these inspections.

questions.question: Appropriate freezing improves the lastingness of a product.
questions.description: Freezing prevents microbe reproduction because frozen water can not be used by microbes for reproduction. Frozen products have recommended storing times, and freezing never improves the microbiological quality of a product. Frozen products should be defrosted slowly in a cold storage unit when they are going to be used. A product that has been defrosted once can not be frozen again.

questions.question: Kitchen waste bins are always emptied after a work shift.
questions.description: Kitchen waste bins are emptied into the waste assortment room always when necessary during a work shift. At the same time the emptied waste bins must be washed.

questions.question: Chefs can use their work shoes during their travel to and from their workplace.
questions.description: Work shoes must not be worn outside the workplace to prevent microbes from spreading into the food production area.

questions.question: Products that have gone through ultra-high-temperature treatment (UHT) can not be stored in room temperature.
questions.description: During UHT products are sterilized with quick heating. Unopened packages can be stored in room temperature because most bacteria spores have been destroyed.

questions.question: Wine is produced with the help of beneficial microbes.
questions.description: The production of wine and beer uses yeast. Yeast is a beneficial microbe.

questions.question: Food products are always safe if the best before date has not yet expired.
questions.description: A food product may be contaminated even if there are still several days until the best before date. Contamination may be caused by unhygienic tools or work environment and incorrect temperatures, for example.

questions.question: Some viruses can last and stay reproductive in water.
questions.description: Viruses can not reproduce in water. However, they can remain able to reproduce later on for a long time while in water.

questions.question: Packages of easily perishable food products must have a label indicating their best-before date.
questions.description: Packages of easily perishable food products always require a label indicating the last day of use and storing instructions. The shown date is valid only for unopened products that have been stored in the right temperature.

questions.question: EHEC bacteria are intestinal bacteria of cattle.
questions.description: This intestinal bacteria can only found in food products if the work hygiene is not proper during milking or slaughtering.

questions.question: Smoking is allowed in the food premises storeroom if the employer allows it.
questions.description: Smoking is prohibited in the food premises in those areas where food is prepared, sold, processed or stored.

questions.question: Ice cube machines do not need to be cleaned separately, because their low temperature prevents microbes from multiplying.
questions.description: Ice cube machines must be cleaned just as regularly and carefully as other cooling equipment.

questions.question: The own-check plan must include cleaning instructions that are up-to-date.
questions.description: Cleaning instructions for equipment and work areas must be available and known to the personnel, so that cleaning procedures will be the same and integrated between everyone, and so that employees will be able to easily disassemble equipment to clean them properly.

questions.question: Food poisoning causing bacteria reproduce quickly in food kept in room temperature.
questions.description: The temperature of food products left in room temperature becomes suitable for bacteria reproduction, which causes the reproduction to become much quicker in the food product.

questions.question: Biofilm means plastic wrap that is specially made for food products.
questions.description: Biofilm can form onto e.g. the surface of a plate if prewashing is done with too hot water before proper dishwashing. Too hot water can burn albumin spots onto the surface of the dish and create biofilm, which is a suitable growing environment for microbes.

questions.question: Food poisoning symptoms always start within one day of consuming a perished food product.
questions.description: Food poisoning symptoms can already begin in one hour since consuming a perished food product, but they can also begin after many days of no symptoms.

questions.question: Hepatitis A is never spread in food products.
questions.description: The most important viruses that reproduce in the intestines of humans are the norovirus and hepatitis A. Both viruses last for a long time and are able to spread in the cold and even in frozen foods.

questions.question: During the cooling of food microbes are able to reproduce in the food.
questions.description: The danger zone for food temperatures is between 6 and 60 degrees Celsius. Microbes can reproduce in food when the temperature is within this danger zone. During the cooling of food the food is within this danger zone.

questions.question: Food poisonings can be prevented by using single-use protective gloves.
questions.description: Single-use protective gloves must be used when handling very easily perishable food products. Protective gloves make it easier to work when employees must change tasks quickly.

questions.question: A cleaning equipment storage room must be included in a food production area.
questions.description: It's not always necessary to have a separate storage space for cleaning equipment. Food production areas need a separate storage, maintenance and drying space if the food production area requires it for constructional reasons. It's important to make sure that there are no risks for food safety and the hygienic treatment, maintenance and storage of cleaning equipment are done properly. If necessary the working stages and functions has to be separated structually or timely.

questions.question: Listeria is an environmental bacteria that can reproduce in food products.
questions.description: Listeria monocytogenes is a bacteria that causes diseases in humans; it is common in you environment. The optimal temperature for the bacteria is the internal temperature of humans, 30 to 37 degrees Celsius; however it can also reproduce in refrigeration temperatures. The bacteria can reproduce especially easily in vacuum-packed products because of their long storing times.

questions.question: Washed, clean dishes can only be handled with clean hands.
questions.description: If clean dishes are handled with dirty hands, microbes and dirt will spread from the hands onto the dishes.

questions.question: All E-numbered additives improve the lastingness of food products.
questions.description: Food products can be made to last longer by adding preservatives to them. In the European Union, allowed preservatives have an E-number: for example, E 200 is sorbic acid and E 296 is malic acid. Preservatives that are allowed can be found, along with other additives, in an E-number list. Some preservatives can be found naturally in berries and fruits, such as in lingonberries and citrus fruit. E-numbers are also used to identify additives other than ones that improve lastingness. For example, color additives do not improve the lastingness of food products.

questions.question: Plastic wrappers for food packaging can be stored outdoors, protected from rain.
questions.description: Plastic and paper wrappers for packing food are stored in a clean indoor space. Packaging materials must be stored sufficiently far away from contaminating materials such as waste or food.

questions.question: In Finland the milk found in cartons in stores is rarely pasteurized.
questions.description: In Finland the milk found in cartons in stores is almost always pasteurized milk. Only raw milk that has been bought directly from a dairy farm is not usually pasteurized.

questions.question: The gutting and proper washing of fish is enough to prevent tapeworm infections.
questions.description: Infectious tapeworm larvas can be inside the muscles or roe of the fish. Tapeworm infections can be prevented by cooking or freezing the fish or roe.

questions.question: Products sold at a fish stall must have a marking if they have been defrosted for sale.
questions.description: Customers must know if they are buying products that have already been defrosted. A product that has been frozen and defrosted once can not be frozen again.

questions.question: Campylo bacteria is naturally found in fowl and poultry.
questions.description: Campylo bacteria and salmonella are found naturally in fowl and poultry. Both bacteria are destroyed when the meat is cooked thoroughly to over 75 degrees Celsius.

questions.question: Frozen vegetables may contain listeria bacteria.
questions.description: Listeria can be found in unheated food products such as fresh vegetables and products made from these.

questions.question: HACCP is not a food poisoning causing bacteria.
questions.description: HACCP stands for Hazard Analysis and Critical Control Points, which is a part of own-check plans. When working with an own-check plan these critical points must be identified and constantly monitored carefully.

questions.question: Easily perishable food products do not require a storage instruction label if it is a commonly known product.
questions.description: Packages of easily perishable food products always require a label indicating the last day of use and storing instructions. The shown date is valid only for unopened products that have been stored in the right temperature.

questions.question: Irradiation can be used to destroy microbes in dairy products.
questions.description: Irradiation destroys microbes in dry herbs and spices.

questions.question: All transport companies can transport food to restaurants provided that their vehicles are spacious enough.
questions.description: Professional transporting of food requires certification from the appropriate authorities as well as an own-check plan.

questions.question: Dishes do not need to be pre-washed before being put into a washing machine.
questions.description: Before being put into a washing machine, dishes must be pre-washed using cool water to get rid of loose dirt and also to get rid of protein spots so that they will not stick to the surface of the dishes and form biofilm.

questions.question: Prepared salads can be stored in room temperature without a risk of food poisoning.
questions.description: Prepared salads are easily perishable food products. For example, chopped or grated vegetables and root vegetables, meat, fish and mayonnaise are often ingredients of prepared salads, so they have to be stored in the cold.

questions.question: Easily perishable food products that have been up for retail sale can be frozen and sold as frozen foods.
questions.description: The preparation of frozen foods requires the ingredients to be perfect quality. Frozen foods must be prepared, cooled and frozen without any delay. Frozen foods are prepared only by appropriate production centres. Freezing is allowed in bakeries, households and farm households only if the areas and equipment are approved by officials.

questions.question: A food poisoning epidemic is a situation where at least 10 people have become sick with similar symptoms after consuming the same food product or ingredient.
questions.description: A food poisoning epidemic means a situation where at least 2 people have become sick with similar symptoms after consuming the same food or drink.

questions.question: When raw frozen chicken is thawed it releases liquid that can contain salmonella.
questions.description: Raw fowl/poultry meat can always contain salmonella, which will not be destroyed in a freezer. If the meat contains salmonella it will also certainly be in the liquid.

questions.question: Viruses can not reproduce in food products.
questions.description: Viruses need living host cells to reproduce, which means they can not reproduce or produce toxins in food products. However, food products can still work as spreaders of viruses.

questions.question: Wastebins do not need to be cleaned.
questions.description: Wastebins must not be broken, must include a lid and must also be cleaned regularly.

questions.question: The waste disposal procedures for professional kitchens, such as recycling, are decided upon between the personnel.
questions.description: A professional kitchen's waste disposal is based on waste laws as well as regional waste disposal directives.

questions.question: Bacteria in our environment can not be seen with the bare eye.
questions.description: Single bacteria can not be seen without using a microscope.

questions.question: Salmonella bacteria can be found in fowl or poultry.
questions.description: Salmonella can be found in fowl or poultry. Due to the risk of salmonella, the meat of fowl/poultry must always be cooked to at least 75 degrees Celsius.

questions.question: Yeasts often cause spoilage in acidic food products.
questions.description: Bacteria grow in a more restricted pH range than yeast and mould. Yeasts grow best in food products with a pH of 5.

questions.question: The own-check plan must include cleaning instructions that are up-to-date.
questions.description: Cleaning instructions for equipment and work areas must be available and known to the personnel, so that cleaning procedures will be the same and integrated between everyone, and so that employees will be able to easily disassemble equipment to clean them properly.

questions.question: If you have just washed your hands carefully with soap, you can taste food with your finger.
questions.description: You can only taste food using clean cutlery, never with your fingers.

questions.question: Coffee cream and milk may be stored in room temperature, because they will be added to hot coffee.
questions.description: Milk and cream are easily perishable food products, and they must be served cold.

questions.question: Hepatitis A is never spread in food products.
questions.description: The most important viruses that reproduce in the intestines of humans are the norovirus and hepatitis A. Both viruses last for a long time and are able to spread in the cold and even in frozen foods.

questions.question: Salt can not contain microbes.
questions.description: Salt is dry, so microbes do not grow in it. However, salt can contain spores of bacteria, moulds or yeast.

questions.question: Due to salmonella risks, fowl and poultry meat must always be heated thoroughly to over 75 degrees Celsius.
questions.description: Fowl/poultry can contain salmonella naturally. Salmonella bacteria must be alive to cause an illness. The meat of fowl/poultry is safe if it is heated thoroughly to over 75 degrees Celsius.

questions.question: If a member of staff becomes infected with salmonella while abroad, he or she cannot spread the infection in Finland.
questions.description: Most cases of salmonella infection are acquired abroad, and an infection acquired abroad can also spread in Finland.

questions.question: Fermented milk products are produced with the help of lactic acid bacteria.
questions.description: Lactic acid bacteria (LAB) are used when producing fermented milk products. LAB create lactic acid in the product, which causes the product to become acidized. Most bacteria are unable to reproduce in acidized products and because of this fermenting milk products makes them last longer.

questions.question: It is not allowed to use useful microbes in baking.
questions.description: Yeast is used in baking to make dough rise.

questions.question: A working and up-to-date collection of recipes is part of the own-check plan.
questions.description: Regularly served food needs to have up-to-date recipes. Recipes can be used to check what different foods contain and how they are prepared during any problematic situations.

questions.question: You can wear disposable gloves instead of washing your hands when preparing food in a restaurant tent.
questions.description: Washing your hands thoroughly and often enough is the basis for safe food handling and general hygiene, and it is important to also wear disposable gloves, for example.

questions.question: The maximum storage temperature for cooked shellfish is +6°C.
questions.description: Cooked molluscs and shellfish are stored at the temperature of melting ice (maximum +2°C).

questions.question: If a fish is dropped on a freshly washed floor, it can still be cooked as long as it is sufficiently well heated.
questions.description: A fish that has fallen onto the floor must never be used for cooking. Food products must never be stored on the floor.

questions.question: Packages of easily perishable food products must have a label indicating their best-before date.
questions.description: Packages of easily perishable food products always require a label indicating the last day of use and storing instructions. The shown date is valid only for unopened products that have been stored in the right temperature.

questions.question: Rings can be used when handling unpacked food products.
questions.description: Rings can not be used when handling unpacked food products, because microbes have optimal growth conditions underneath them.

questions.question: Customers and employees are allowed to use the same toilet.
questions.description: Strict toilet and hand hygiene must be used in food production. This is not possible if toilets are shared with customers. Customers may have diseases, can be drunk or they can be small children; in each case the use of the same toilets is a risk.

questions.question: Raw milk is not suitable for people with a weakened immune system.
questions.description: Because raw milk has not been pasteurized it can contain pathogens (disease-causing bacteria.) The most important bacteria that can cause danger to food safety in raw milk are EHEC, listeria, salmonella and campylo bacteria.

questions.question: Microbes are destroyed when meat is minced.
questions.description: When meat is minced, the bacteria on its surface spread throughout the minced meat.

questions.question: Frozen foods can be defrosted on a kitchen table if the liquid from the melting does not pour onto the table.
questions.description: All frozen foods must be defrosted in cold storage units. When defrosting, one must make sure that the defrosting product does not pour liquid onto any other food products placed or stored in the cold storage unit. Defrosted or just partially defrosted products can not be frozen again.

questions.question: Women that are pregnant should not eat vacuum-packed salmon due to the higher risk of listeriosis.
questions.description: Risk food products are products that have not been heated and have a long selling time. Vacuum-packed salmon has not been heated and has a long selling time. The vacuum-package does not prevent listeria from reproducing because listeria can grow in conditions without oxygen. Proper cold storage does not prevent the risk either because listeria can reproduce in refrigerator temperatures.

questions.question: Disinfecting reduces the amount of microbes from work surfaces and equipment.
questions.description: Correctly done disinfection reduces the amount of microbes excellently on work surfaces and equipment.

questions.question: Salmonella bacteria can not be found in fowl or poultry.
questions.description: Salmonella can be found in fowl or poultry. Due to the risk of salmonella, the meat of fowl/poultry must always be cooked to at least 75 degrees Celsius.

questions.question: Intestinal bacteria cannot spread from hands to food.
questions.description: Intestinal bacteria can spread to food even from the hands.

questions.question: The purpose of own-check plans is to prevent mistakes and problematic situations from occurring during food preparation and serving.
questions.description: Good own-check plans as well as good knowledge of the own-check plan's contents by the personnel prevents problematic situations and makes it easier to identify the causes of any noticed problems.

questions.question: Temperature affects the speed of microbe reproduction.
questions.description: Temperatures are very important for the reproduction abilities of microbes. All microbes have their own optimal temperatures where reproduction is the fastest.

questions.question: Lactic acid bacteria often cause food poisoning.
questions.description: Lactic acid bacteria do not cause food poisoning. Lactic acid bacteria are not harmful if used in the treatment of food poisoning, but they have not been scientifically proven to be of any use either.

questions.question: The human skin naturally contains microbes.
questions.description: Especially the face, scalp, mouth, nose etc. contain microbes. Food poisoning causing Staphylococcus bacteria can also be found on the skin.

questions.question: If a food product includes nuts it must say so on the package.
questions.description: Packaging markings must tell if the product contains ingredients that cause allergic reactions; the EU has a compiled list of these.

questions.question: Plants can be displayed and sold anywhere in a grocery store as long as adequate ventilation is provided.
questions.description: Plants must be located as far as possible from unpackaged perishable food products. There are lots of microbes on the surface of plants and in the soil, and these may spread to food products.

questions.question: Few bacteria can reproduce in acidized products.
questions.description: Bacteria that are a threat to food product hygiene reproduce the best when in the neutral zone. Bacteria growth especially can be prevented by increasing the acidity of a product.

questions.question: The waste bins in waste assortment rooms do not need lids if they are emptied regularly times.
questions.description: The waste bins in waste assortment rooms need to have lids and need to be cleaned regularly enough. This way waste rooms do not attract pest insects and the rooms stay cleaner and more hygienic.

questions.question: Chopping vegetables improves their shelf life.
questions.description: Whole vegetables keep better than chopped vegetables. Handling food products impairs their shelf life.

questions.question: Raw milk can contain yersinia.
questions.description: Raw milk has not been pasteurized. Yersinia is destroyed when milk is heated to over 70 degrees Celsius; in other words it is destroyed when the milk is pasteurized.

questions.question: Thawing frozen food products in a sealed container at room temperature does not increase the risk of food poisoning.
questions.description: Food must be thawed in such a way as to minimise the increase of pathogens as much as possible. A frozen food product is defrosted in a cold room so that the temperature of the food product's surface does not rise above the other parts of the product.

questions.question: Working areas and surfaces must be cleaned regularly during work shifts and after work is over.
questions.description: Regular cleaning, done every 2-4 hours, of working equipment and surfaces with clean cleaning equipment, substances and water gets rid of leftover pieces of food, dust and other dirt that protects microorganisms and is used as living space by the organisms.

questions.question: Own-check plans must also include e.g. cleaning and waste disposal procedures.
questions.description: Own-check plans must, along with microbiological risks, consider the hygiene of personnel, cleaning, receival of products and actions to be done when pests have been noticed.

questions.question: Temperature measurements stated in own-check plans do not have to made when one is busy.
questions.description: Only regularly done measurements can prove that the own-check plan has been adhered to at a workplace.

questions.question: Health inspectors can not inspect restaurant kitchens.
questions.description: The work of health inspectors requires making inspections in food production areas such as food stores and restaurants.

questions.question: During food preparation one can sometimes go wash one's hands in the staff restroom.
questions.description: There must be a separate hand washing spot in immediate proximity to the food preparation area.

questions.question: Easily perishable food products do not require a storage instruction label if it is a commonly known product.
questions.description: Packages of easily perishable food products always require a label indicating the last day of use and storing instructions. The shown date is valid only for unopened products that have been stored in the right temperature.

questions.question: The own-check plan of a food production area is done by a municipality health inspector.
questions.description: Workplaces in the food industry must create their own own-check plan that suits their activities. The plan is supposed to ensure the safety of food products, good lastingness and the following of official rules and directives.

questions.question: Chopping vegetables improves their shelf life.
questions.description: Whole vegetables keep better than chopped vegetables. Handling food products impairs their shelf life.

questions.question: Viruses can spread into food products by the hands.
questions.description: Food poisoning causing microbes can stay on the skin of the hands e.g. after going to the toilet if the hands have not been properly washed. The microbes can later spread from the hands onto unpacked food products or into work areas.

questions.question: Bacterial spores are more resistant than bacteria.
questions.description: When bacteria are in an environment where they cannot grow as easily, they turn into spores. Spores are more resistant than bacteria to heat and drought, for example.

questions.question: Most harmful microbes reproduce the easiest in temperatures between 6 and 60 degrees Celsius.
questions.description: 6-60 degrees Celsius is a hazardous temperature region where food products should not be stored for long periods of time. Food served from a counter should be kept colder or hotter than this for the entire length of serving, and food to be served later after cooking should be cooled to colder than 6 degrees Celsius quickly (sooner than 4 hours.)

questions.question: Fever and the flu are good reasons for a food product employee to not go to work.
questions.description: Food products should not be handled when one has a fever or the flu because causes of the disease spread easily by coughing or sneezing.

questions.question: Fermented milk products are produced with the help of lactic acid bacteria.
questions.description: Lactic acid bacteria (LAB) are used when producing fermented milk products. LAB create lactic acid in the product, which causes the product to become acidized. Most bacteria are unable to reproduce in acidized products and because of this fermenting milk products makes them last longer.

questions.question: Oiva is a system which helps to assess the food product safety of different workplaces.
questions.description: Municipality food control authorities do routine inspections at workplaces. Oiva is the publishing system for the results of these inspections, and is co-ordinated by Ruokavirasto.

questions.question: Easily perishable food products that require cold storage must be served at a temperature below +8 degrees celsius.
questions.description: During serving easily perishable food products that require cold storage may be +12 degrees celsius at most. The maximum serving time is 12 hours, after which the products must be discarded.

questions.question: If a fish is dropped on a freshly washed floor, it can still be cooked as long as it is sufficiently well heated.
questions.description: A fish that has fallen onto the floor must never be used for cooking. Food products must never be stored on the floor.

questions.question: Waste does not cause a hygiene risk because it is stored in separate containers.
questions.description: Bad waste management hygiene or food products getting into contact with waste can cause hygiene risks.

questions.question: The correct concentration of detergent significantly affects the cleaning result.
questions.description: Detergents and disinfectants must be measured out in accordance with the manufacturer's instructions. A solution that is stronger than recommended does not usually guarantee a better cleaning result, and a solution that is diluted too much may give a worse result.

questions.question: Instructions for waste disposal are included in the own-check plan.
questions.description: The own-check plan for a food premises always includes instructions for food waste disposal.

questions.question: Thawing frozen food products in a sealed container at room temperature does not increase the risk of food poisoning.
questions.description: Food must be thawed in such a way as to minimise the increase of pathogens as much as possible. A frozen food product is defrosted in a cold room so that the temperature of the food product's surface does not rise above the other parts of the product.

questions.question: Waste bins to be used in kitchens must be water-proof and easily cleanable.
questions.description: Waste bins to be used in kitchens must be water-proof so that waste liquids do not pour onto the floor. They must also be easy to clean so that the cleaning process during emptying is as easy as possible.

questions.question: The purpose of own-check plans is to prevent mistakes and problematic situations from occurring during food preparation and serving.
questions.description: Good own-check plans as well as good knowledge of the own-check plan's contents by the personnel prevents problematic situations and makes it easier to identify the causes of any noticed problems.

questions.question: Ham slices left over from a buffet can be used for lunch the next day.
questions.description: Food products that have been served at a buffet must never be served again. Food starts to perish immediately after cooking. Contamination is slowed down by adhering to the correct temperatures, serving time and hygienic working methods. A buffet, which is visited by a lot of people, offers particularly good conditions for contamination.

questions.question: Bacteria in our environment can not be seen with the bare eye.
questions.description: Single bacteria can not be seen without using a microscope.

questions.question: A piece of rotten fruit affects the shelf life of other pieces of fruit that are near it.
questions.description: A piece of rotten fruit also spoils other pieces of fruit kept in the same dish, so it is important to dispose of rotten fruit.

questions.question: The amount of sugar a product contains does not affect its lastingness.
questions.description: Highly sugared products, such as jams, marmelades and sweets do not perish easily because sugar changes the state of water so that microbes can not reproduce.

questions.question: A disinfectant detergent never needs to be replaced.
questions.description: It is possible for a disinfectant detergent to become ineffective against certain bacteria, and it is therefore important to change the detergent regularly.

questions.question: Cold storage units should not be filled beyond their set fill limits because the food products might not stay cold enough.
questions.description: The fill limit is an instruction on usage by the producer of the cold storage unit. The limit should not be crossed because food products outside the limit will not stay cold enough.

questions.question: It is not allowed to use useful microbes in baking.
questions.description: Yeast is used in baking to make dough rise.

questions.question: Temperature does not affect the reproduction speed of microbes.
questions.description: Temperatures are very important for the reproduction abilities of microbes. The insides of humans and animals often contain the optimal temperature for microbes, between 20 and 45 degrees Celsius.

questions.question: The creation and following requirements of own-check plans include all companies that handle food products.
questions.description: The creation and use of an own-check plan is a requirement by law, which has included all companies handling food products since 1995. All employees in a company are responsible for the implementation of own-check plans.

questions.question: Not all microbes and bacteria-spores in food products can be destroyed using any treatments.
questions.description: Sterilizing or radiating can destroy all bacteria or microbe-spores in food products. Canned food, such as canned tuna and canned baby food is sterilized by heating the packed products. Spices are one example of a product that can be treated by radiation.

questions.question: Guide dogs are allowed inside food product stores.
questions.description: Guide dogs are always allowed in areas meant for customers. However, no animals can be taken inside food product handling areas or storage areas.

questions.question: Mould that has spread from blue cheese to other cheeses is not hazardous.
questions.description: Mould spreading from blue cheese to other cheeses, which the mould is not supposed to be in, is hazardous and can worsen the quality and also perish the cheeses. However, the spreading of the mould to other cheeses is not always a health risk.

questions.question: Frozen products can be thawed in room temperature to make the thawing fast enough.
questions.description: If food products are thawed in room temperature, the products' surfaces will melt quicker than the insides. The surfaces will start to spoil even though the insides can still be frozen.

questions.question: Salmonella bacteria can be found in fowl or poultry.
questions.description: Salmonella can be found in fowl or poultry. Due to the risk of salmonella, the meat of fowl/poultry must always be cooked to at least 75 degrees Celsius.

questions.question: Frozen food products are stored in a freezer at a temperature of -15°C or colder.
questions.description: The temperature in a freezer must be -18°C or colder.

questions.question: The own-check system involves monitoring how quickly food products cool down to storage temperature.
questions.description: Monitoring temperatures is an important part of the own-check system.

questions.question: Temperature measurements stated in the own-check plan must be done according to the own-check plan.
questions.description: Only regularly done measurements can prove that the own-check plan has been adhered to at a workplace.

questions.question: Food products containing preservatives will also spoil.
questions.description: Preservatives only slow down the spoiling done by microbes. In the European Union all allowed preservatives have an E-code.

questions.question: When handling food products, employees should not touch their skin if possible.
questions.description: The skin and mouth contain large amounts of different bacteria, including food poisoning causing bacteria. Because of this touching the skin should be avoided when working with food products.

questions.question: The ice kept in transport cases for fresh fish must meet the purity requirements.
questions.description: Ice used with food products must only be made of water that meets the requirements for domestic water.

questions.question: Salmonella can only get transmitted through feces.
questions.description: Salmonella can get transmitted through feces by way of poor hand hygiene but also via contaminated food products, such as raw meat and eggs.

questions.question: Bacteria toxins disappear when food is boiled.
questions.description: Some bacteria cause toxins in the food. If toxins have appeared in the food, they weill not disappear during boiling.

questions.question: UHT-treated milk products can be stored in room temperature.
questions.description: In UHT (ultra high temperature) -treatment products are rapidly heated to a high temperature and packaged in sterilized packaging. This is why treated products cana be kept in room temperature.

questions.question: Pasteurisation of milk destroys listeria bacteria.
questions.description: Pasteurisation of milk is a process that destroys listeria bacteria. Milk is pasteurised when heated to 72°C for about 15 seconds.

questions.question: Food poisoning microbes can only spread through the air.
questions.description: Food poisoning microbes can be transmitted into food in many ways such as via hands, soil, contaminated water or airborne dust particles. Rodents, insects and birds can also spread food poisoning microbes.

questions.question: If a food product includes nuts it does not have to say so on the package.
questions.description: Packaging markings must tell if the product contains ingredients that cause allergic reactions; the EU has a compiled list of these.

questions.question: Marinating prevents meat from spoiling.
questions.description: Meat can contain harmful microbes even if it is marinated.

questions.question: When there is packaged meat in a delivery load, it can be safely left at room temperature for a few hours.
questions.description: The cold chain of meat products in a delivery load must not be broken.

questions.question: During food preparation one can go wash one's hands in the staff restroom.
questions.description: There must be a separate hand washing spot in immediate proximity to the food preparation area.

questions.question: Utensils used in the preparation of food must be dried carefully after washing.
questions.description: Drying utensils after they have been used prevents microbial growth in them.

questions.question: Detergents (washing chemicals) must always be stored in their original packages.
questions.description: Only the original packages can be used to make sure that the correct detergent is being used for the situation.

questions.question: In vegetables, only perished areas that can be noticed visually are health hazards.
questions.description: Due to cultivation and treatments the surface of vegetables can have impurities which can not be seen with the bare eye. Harmful microbes can also be on areas that are not visually perished. Vegetables are a health risk when they are not washed properly before use.

questions.question: If the film/foil of a vacuum-package is loose or tensionless the package is damaged.
questions.description: The package has probably been broken and air has entered it. The lastingness of the product can not be estimated after this, because the use-by-date marked on the package is based on the assumption that the package contains no air (oxygen that microbes can use to grow.)

questions.question: Food products must be cooled first by using separate cooling equipment and only then moved into a freezer for storage.
questions.description: Products that are not frozen and are placed into a freezer will raise the temperature of the freezer; this weakens the lastingness of the products in the freezer.

questions.question: Fungi and plants can also cause food poisoning.
questions.description: Causes of food poisoning include microbes, toxins produced by microbes, parasites, poisonous animals, plants and fungi.

questions.question: Food poisoning suspicions must always be informed to health officials.
questions.description: Informing health officials is only required if more than 5 people have become sick. Informing must also be done if the epidemic has spread in a school, hospital or other institution or if the cause is suspected to be in a commercial food product or in a some other way wide-spread product.

questions.question: When a kitchen floor is washed properly, there cannot be any microbes on it.
questions.description: Microbes are everywhere, even on newly washed kitchen surfaces.

questions.question: Samples taken from batches of food prepared in large kitchens must be stored for 1-2 months.
questions.description: Samples are taken from large kitchens' food batches to trace possible food poisoning causes easier. Samples must be taken daily from all batches being somehow served or sold and the samples must be stored appropriately marked in a freezer for 1-2 weeks. During this time a majority of food poisoning symptoms start to appear.

questions.question: Easily perishable food products that have been up for retail sale can be frozen and sold as frozen foods.
questions.description: The preparation of frozen foods requires the ingredients to be perfect quality. Frozen foods must be prepared, cooled and frozen without any delay. Frozen foods are prepared only by appropriate production centres. Freezing is allowed in bakeries, households and farm households only if the areas and equipment are approved by officials.

questions.question: If the temperature of food that is to be served while warm is too low it must not be marked down on the own-check plan's monitoring logs.
questions.description: Measured temperatures must be marked down in the own-check plan's monitoring logs, even if they are too high or too low. The logs must also contain information on what fixing procedure has been made to correct the incorrect temperature.

questions.question: It is enough to visually monitor the results of cleaning and washing.
questions.description: The results of cleaning and washing and the need for cleaning needs to be monitored regularly. It is required to name a responsible person for this task in the own-check plan and to form a monitoring plan to use. As well as doing visual inspections, the monitoring can also be done by taking microbiological samples from work surfaces and equipment by for example using Hygicult sample strips.

questions.question: Tapeworms can be found in the roe (eggs) and muscles of some lake fish.
questions.description: Tapeworms can be found in the roe (eggs) and muscles of lake fish, such as bass, pike, burbot and ruffe. Proper cooking or freezing (2 days minimum) will destroy the tapeworm.

questions.question: The human skin naturally contains microbes.
questions.description: Especially the face, scalp, mouth, nose etc. contain microbes. Food poisoning causing Staphylococcus bacteria can also be found on the skin.

questions.question: The own-check plan of a food production area is done by a municipality health inspector.
questions.description: Workplaces in the food industry must create their own own-check plan that suits their activities. The plan is supposed to ensure the safety of food products, good lastingness and the following of official rules and directives.

questions.question: Bacteria spores are destroyed during sterilization.
questions.description: During sterilization (e.g. during canned food production) all microbes and bacteria spores are destroyed. This way easily perishable products will be able to last long in room temperature.

questions.question: A delivery load that contains meat and fish products can be safely left at room temperature for three hours pending transfer into cold storage.
questions.description: The cold chain of perishable food products must not be interrupted at any point in the supply chain.

questions.question: HACCP is not a food poisoning causing bacteria.
questions.description: HACCP stands for Hazard Analysis and Critical Control Points, which is a part of own-check plans. When working with an own-check plan these critical points must be identified and constantly monitored carefully.

questions.question: Water is not necessary for microbes to reproduce.
questions.description: Dried products last well due to having no water that bacteria could use to reproduce. Microbes can't reproduce in dried products.

questions.question: Some microbes can reproduce even in food products that are in a protective gas package.
questions.description: Protective gas packages contain little or no oxygen. This prevents microbes that require oxygen from growing. However, the product can also contain microbes that do not need oxygen.

questions.question: Frozen foods can be defrosted on a kitchen table if the liquid from the melting does not pour onto the table.
questions.description: All frozen foods must be defrosted in cold storage units. When defrosting, one must make sure that the defrosting product does not pour liquid onto any other food products placed or stored in the cold storage unit. Defrosted or just partially defrosted products can not be frozen again.

questions.question: Fermented milk products are produced with the help of lactic acid bacteria.
questions.description: Lactic acid bacteria (LAB) are used when producing fermented milk products. LAB create lactic acid in the product, which causes the product to become acidized. Most bacteria are unable to reproduce in acidized products and because of this fermenting milk products makes them last longer.

questions.question: After washing dishes must be dry before they can be piled for storing.
questions.description: Harmful microbes multiply in damp conditions, so dishes must be allowed to fully dry before piling.

questions.question: The temperature monitoring of cold storages is a part of own-check plans.
questions.description: The temperatures of cold storages must be checked and logged regularly according to the own-check plan. Cold storages must always have thermometers for measurements.

questions.question: If food is prepared to be served later, the finished products must be cooled as soon as possible for storage.
questions.description: Hot, cooked food must be cooled to under 6 degrees Celsius in under 4 hours. Cooling large amounts of products requires the use of actual cooling devices, from which the cooled products must be moved to their appropriate cold storage units.

questions.question: Safety data sheets are the same thing as the instruction manual of a device.
questions.description: Safety data sheets include the most important information about detergents (washing chemicals) and also include first aid instructions.

questions.question: The more microbes there are in a cleaning cloth, the worse it smells.
questions.description: Microbes are usually odourless microorganisms that are invisible to the naked eye.

questions.question: Ice makers do not need to be washed because microbes do not multiply in such a cold environment.
questions.description: Ice makers must be washed regularly. Ice makers and utensils for picking up ice must be kept clean and in good condition, and their lids must be kept closed to prevent dirt from entering the machines. The high number of microbes in ice cubes causes a deterioration in the quality of food products and even food poisoning.

questions.question: Using own-check plans takes a lot of time and resources.
questions.description: Well-planned own-check plans saves time and resources. Resources used for monitoring can be focused on the most important areas, activities and control points. Resources can also be focused on the most effective preventive actions. In problematic situations correct procedures will be known and mistakes can be fixed quickly.

questions.question: Frozen products can be thawed in room temperature to make the thawing fast enough.
questions.description: If food products are thawed in room temperature, the products' surfaces will melt quicker than the insides. The surfaces will start to spoil even though the insides can still be frozen.

questions.question: The use of snus (similar to chewing tobacco) is not allowed during food preparation.
questions.description: When handling food products personal hygiene is important; snus must not be used because of hygienic reasons.

questions.question: When a food product is vacuum packed, food poisoning bacteria cannot grow in it.
questions.description: Food poisoning microbes that tolerate anaerobic and low-oxygen conditions can multiply in a vacuum pack.

questions.question: A cleaning equipment storage room is not needed in a food production area.
questions.description: It's not always necessary to have a separate storage space for cleaning equipment. Food production areas need a separate storage, maintenance and drying space if the food production area requires it for constructional reasons. It's important to make sure that there are no risks for food safety and the hygienic treatment, maintenance and storage of cleaning equipment are done properly. If necessary the working stages and functions has to be separated structually or timely.

questions.question: Customers and employees must have their own, separate toilets.
questions.description: Strict toilet and hand hygiene must be used in food production. This is not possible if toilets are shared with customers.

questions.question: Water is not necessary for microbes to reproduce.
questions.description: Dried products last well due to having no water that bacteria could use to reproduce. Microbes can't reproduce in dried products.

questions.question: Properly heated food products can not contain bacteria that causes food poisoning.
questions.description: Even properly heated food products can contain food poisoning causing bacteria; the bacteria can spread to the food due to bad handling hygiene or dirty equipment during e.g. chopping or serving.

questions.question: Intestinal bacteria can spread from hands to food.
questions.description: Intestinal bacteria can spread to food even from the hands.

questions.question: If an easily perishable food product has been stored in too warm conditions, the use-by-date marked on the package is no longer reliable.
questions.description: The use-by-date is reliable only if the product has been stored correctly. Storing products in too warm conditions always makes the products last for shorter periods of times.

questions.question: Washed, clean dishes can only be handled with clean hands.
questions.description: If clean dishes are handled with dirty hands, microbes and dirt will spread from the hands onto the dishes.

questions.question: Fungi and plants can also cause food poisoning.
questions.description: Causes of food poisoning include microbes, toxins produced by microbes, parasites, poisonous animals, plants and fungi.

questions.question: During the cooling of food microbes are not able to reproduce in the food.
questions.description: The danger zone for food temperatures is between 6 and 60 degrees Celsius. Microbes can reproduce in food when the temperature is within this danger zone. During the cooling of food the food is within this danger zone.

questions.question: Food products containing preservatives never spoil.
questions.description: Preservatives only slow down the spoiling done by microbes.
