questions.question: Rings can be used when handling unpacked food products.
questions.description: Rings can not be used when handling unpacked food products, because microbes have optimal growth conditions underneath them.

questions.question: Headwear is used in kitchens to protect the employee's hair from getting dirty.
questions.description: Headwear is used to prevent the employee's hair from getting into the prepared food.

questions.question: All own-check plan related measurements must be recorded in own-check plan forms.
questions.description: Though recording all own-check related measurements is essential, all measurements do not need to be logged. For example, it is good to pay daily attention to the temperatures of cold storage, but only a weekly log entry is sufficient.

questions.question: Food production employees are allowed to wear colorless nail polish.
questions.description: Hands must not containt anything extra such as watches, jewellery, fake nails, nail polish or hand cream.

questions.question: Permitted food additives are marked with E numbers.
questions.description: In addition to the category that indicates the intended use, additives also have a name or numerical code, i.e. an E number.

questions.question: Smoking is not allowed at the loading docks of kitchens.
questions.description: Loading docks are a part of food production areas; smoking is not allowed in food production areas.

questions.question: Sneezing spreads harmful microbes into the surrounding environment in the droplets/spray.
questions.description: There are lots of microbes in the respiratory system and mouth which can spread into the surroundings.

questions.question: The uniform used for food product work can also be used while travelling to work if using one's own car.
questions.description: Using the work uniform outside of work is not allowed. Work uniforms and shoes are meant to protect food products from becoming dirty.

questions.question: The temperature monitoring of cold storages is a part of own-check plans.
questions.description: The temperatures of cold storages must be checked and logged regularly according to the own-check plan. Cold storages must always have thermometers for measurements.

questions.question: Most microbes grow poorly when the pH is close to neutral (pH 7).
questions.description: Most microbes grow best in neutral pH conditions, in the pH range from 6.6 to 7.5.

questions.question: If your protective clothing gets dirty when you take out the rubbish, you must change into clean ones before you continue cooking.
questions.description: Staff must make sure that their work clothes are always clean when they handle and prepare food.

questions.question: Harmful microbes can multiply at a refrigerator's temperature.
questions.description: Harmful microbes can multiply at a refrigerator's temperature and even at 0°C. Listeria and yersinia are pathogens that are tolerant to cold.

questions.question: Carrots covered with soil do not contain harmful microbes because soil is a pure natural product.
questions.description: Many microbes are part of the normal microbial growth in soil, which means that carrots covered in soil contain microbes.

questions.question: A bar of soap is unhygienic when used by staff in food premises.
questions.description: It is recommended to use liquid soap to wash your hands. A bar of soap is not hygienic enough.

questions.question: Sugar can contain microbes.
questions.description: Sugar is dry, so microbes do not grow in it. However, salt can contain spores of bacteria, moulds or yeast.

questions.question: Hand washing areas must be cleaned regularly.
questions.description: A dirty hand washing area is a risk for hand hygiene.

questions.question: When handling food products, employees should not touch their skin if possible.
questions.description: The skin and mouth contain large amounts of different bacteria, including food poisoning causing bacteria. Because of this touching the skin should be avoided when working with food products.

questions.question: Bacteria toxins disappear when food is boiled.
questions.description: Some bacteria cause toxins in the food. If toxins have appeared in the food, they weill not disappear during boiling.

questions.question: Food must not be served heated for over 2 hours.
questions.description: Food served / sold hot may be kept in a temperature-controlled bath (min +60 degrees) for a maximum of four hours, after which the food must be replaced.

questions.question: You are allowed to use snus (nuuska in Finnish) while preparing food.
questions.description: The use of snus (nuuska in Finnish) is prohibited while preparing food.

questions.question: Yersinia bacteria has been found on fields and in fresh vegetables that have been spoiled during storage.
questions.description: Yersinia is destroyed when heating a product to over 70 degrees Celsius. Fresh vegetables are often served non-heated, so possible yersinia is not destroyed. Yersinia can also reproduce during storage in refrigerator temperatures.

questions.question: The fresh fish that has been up for retail sale during the day can, with the decision and permission of the store, be smoked during the evening and then sold.
questions.description: Fish that has been on the sales counter can not be smoked for the next day's sales. This is against the ethics of food product law and deceives consumers. If fish has been up for retail sale during the day, its sales time must not continue by smoking it.

questions.question: Visually clean work surfaces guarantee their microbiological cleanliness.
questions.description: Microbiological cleanliness can not be guaranteed by using just the bare eye. Correct cleaning methods and equipment, as well as regular and proper cleaning, guarantee the cleanliness much better. Samples can also be taken of the cleanliness of specific surfaces if required.

questions.question: Moulds can produce dangerous toxins in food products.
questions.description: Moulds can grow on food products. While growing, some moulds produce toxins that are hazardous for the human health. Mould toxins will sometimes not get destroyed when heating a food product, even though the mould itself might be destroyed.

questions.question: The disinfection of working surfaces destroys all harmful microbes and sterilizes the surfaces.
questions.description: Even a thorough cleaning will destroy about 90% of micro-organisms. Disinfectants can be used to destroy nearly all microbes. However, even disinfectants can not sterilize working areas, because not all bacteria-spores die from disinfectants. When cleaning it is not essential to sterilize the environment but instead to regularly and properly clean and wash it.

questions.question: An establishment's own-check plan is in effect for 10 years at a time.
questions.description: The own-check plan must be updated if need arises. It is useful to go over the plan regularly and to assess whether or not there have been changes in the establishment's functioning or protocols that require changes to made in the plan as well. Changes in the regulations of the food industry may necessitate changes in own-check plans as well.

questions.question: Handling money can transfer harmful microbes into food products.
questions.description: Money and easily perishable unpackaged food products should not be handled simultanously, as money can have microbes in it that jeopardize food hygiene.

questions.question: Vegetables and fruit must be washed prior to food preparation with water that meets the requirements of household water.
questions.description: Taps in any food preparation space must provide water that meets the requirements of household water, which is used in preparing and making food as well as by staff to wash their hands.

questions.question: Acidity in a food product prevents the reproduction of bacteria.
questions.description: Bacteria that are a threat to food product safety reproduce the best in the neutral zone. Because of this the growth of these bacteria can be prevented by increasing the acidity of a product.

questions.question: The activity of water contained in food products can be lowered by adding salt or sugar to the product.
questions.description: The activity of water shows how easily the water in a product can be used by microbes. Salt and sugar change the state of water so that the microbes can not use it.

questions.question: The purity of the air in the food packaging area has no effect on the shelf life of food products.
questions.description: Food products are packed in an area with clean air, as it affects their shelf life.

questions.question: All E-numbered additives improve the lastingness of food products.
questions.description: Food products can be made to last longer by adding preservatives to them. In the European Union, allowed preservatives have an E-number: for example, E 200 is sorbic acid and E 296 is malic acid. Preservatives that are allowed can be found, along with other additives, in an E-number list. Some preservatives can be found naturally in berries and fruits, such as in lingonberries and citrus fruit. E-numbers are also used to identify additives other than ones that improve lastingness. For example, color additives do not improve the lastingness of food products.

questions.question: Appropriate freezing improves the lastingness of a product.
questions.description: Freezing prevents microbe reproduction because frozen water can not be used by microbes for reproduction. Frozen products have recommended storing times, and freezing never improves the microbiological quality of a product. Frozen products should be defrosted slowly in a cold storage unit when they are going to be used. A product that has been defrosted once can not be frozen again.

questions.question: Working areas and equipment must always be cleaned by using plenty of water.
questions.description: Water is an important part of cleaning and washing. Water acts as a solvent and substance that transports dirt away. However it is also important to dry the surfaces and equipment properly, because microbes grow and reproduce easily in moist environments.

questions.question: A food manufacturer is responsible for date labelling (best before date or use by date).
questions.description: A food manufacturer or packer is responsible for correct date labelling.

questions.question: The training of personnel is an important part of own-check plans.
questions.description: The training of personnel is an essential part of own-check plans. In the food industry technology, equipment, ingredients, preparation methods and even risks change, so it is important to update knowledge regularly.

questions.question: UHT-treated milk products can be stored in room temperature.
questions.description: In UHT (ultra high temperature) -treatment products are rapidly heated to a high temperature and packaged in sterilized packaging. This is why treated products cana be kept in room temperature.

questions.question: A delivery load that contains meat and fish products can be safely left at room temperature for three hours pending transfer into cold storage.
questions.description: The cold chain of perishable food products must not be interrupted at any point in the supply chain.

questions.question: Permitted food additives are marked with E numbers.
questions.description: In addition to the category that indicates the intended use, additives also have a name or numerical code, i.e. an E number.

questions.question: Food production areas need to have a changing room.
questions.description: Employees need a changing room which has a separate storage space for clean work clothes.

questions.question: Food poisoning causing microbes can spread only by hands.
questions.description: Working areas and surfaces must be cleaned regularly during work shifts and after work is over.

questions.question: When a food industry workplace, e.g. a sausage factory, is being founded, the workplace must only inform local food control authorities about the activities.
questions.description: When a food industry workplace, e.g. a sausage factory, is being founded, an approval for the activities by local food control authorities is required.

questions.question: BSE, also called mad cow's disease, is a food poisoning causing bacteria.
questions.description: BSE is not a food poisoning causing bacteria. BSE is caused by changes in the central nervous system of cows.

questions.question: The priority of waste laws is to make people working in the food industry responsible for assorting their waste.
questions.description: The priority of waste laws is to lessen the amount of waste and its effects.

questions.question: You can touch the inside surfaces of food packaging if you have just washed your hands.
questions.description: You should always try not to touch the inside surfaces of food packaging.

questions.question: Bacteria can reproduce in more acidized environments than moulds and yeasts.
questions.description: Bacteria that are a threat to food product safety reproduce the best in the neutral zone. Because of this the growth of these bacteria can be prevented by increasing the acidity of a product.

questions.question: When evaluating or checking the quality of food it is enough to check the dates on the packaging.
questions.description: Along with checking the dates, the food products must also be checked using the senses (visually etc.) because of the possibility of them warming up or partially melting if they have been wrongly stored during transportation.

questions.question: Received food products must be stored where there is the most space for them in the storage facility.
questions.description: Received food products are stored based on the FIFO method (First In, First Out) which means that products already stored in the storage facility are moved to the front to be used or taken first, and any new products are placed behind or after any prior ones. This way the products are taken out of storage in the order they arrived in and the amount of wastage is reduced.

questions.question: Whipping is one way to improve the shelf life of cream.
questions.description: If you whip cream, you process an unpackaged perishable food product, which shortens its shelf life.

questions.question: Pet dogs can be taken inside a café with the permission of the owner of the café.
questions.description: If the owner gives permission, a pet dog can be taken inside the customer areas of a café.

questions.question: It is not required to change single-use gloves worn on the hands if money is handled while wearing them.
questions.description: Only one phase of work can be done while wearing the same single-use gloves. If money is handled then the hands must be washed and the gloves must be changed.

questions.question: EHEC bacteria are not intestinal bacteria.
questions.description: EHEC bacteria is found especially in the intestines of cattle. EHEC bacteria create toxins in the intestines of humans. The toxin often causes bloody diarrhea and very uncomfortable stomache pains.

questions.question: Working areas and surfaces must be cleaned regularly during work shifts and after work is over.
questions.description: Regular cleaning, done every 2-4 hours, of working equipment and surfaces with clean cleaning equipment, substances and water gets rid of leftover pieces of food, dust and other dirt that protects microorganisms and is used as living space by the organisms.

questions.question: The contents of a bulged can of food can be used for food preparation if the product is properly heated.
questions.description: All causes of food poisoning are not eliminated by heating. The contents of a bulged (ie. faulty) can of food must be discarded.

questions.question: Moulds and yeasts can reproduce in more acidized environments than bacteria.
questions.description: Most bacteria reproduce the best in the neutral zone. Moulds and yeasts can reproduce on a very broad pH zone, including products with acidity.

questions.question: Chefs are required to have a hygiene proficiency passport even if their employment is not permanent.
questions.description: Chefs handle easily perishable food products in their work. This means that chefs must pass a hygiene proficiency test at least 3 months after starting their work.

questions.question: The temperature checks for received food products that need hot or cold storage are part of the own-check plan.
questions.description: Temperature monitoring of hot or cold storage food products when receiving is an important part of the own-check plan. If the temperatures do not meet set requirements they can be returned to the supplier as faulty products.

questions.question: Intestinal bacteria can spread from hands to food.
questions.description: Intestinal bacteria can spread to food even from the hands.

questions.question: Dirt and dust can make microbes spread to food products.
questions.description: Different kinds of impurities, such as dirt and dust, contain microbes. If dirt or dust gets onto a food product then the microbes contained will also spread onto the product.

questions.question: Products sold at a fish stall must have a marking if they have been defrosted for sale.
questions.description: Customers must know if they are buying products that have already been defrosted. A product that has been frozen and defrosted once can not be frozen again.

questions.question: Plants can be displayed and sold anywhere in a grocery store as long as adequate ventilation is provided.
questions.description: Plants must be located as far as possible from unpackaged perishable food products. There are lots of microbes on the surface of plants and in the soil, and these may spread to food products.

questions.question: Vacuum-packed smoked fish does not contain microbes.
questions.description: Vacuum-packages do not include any air and prevent microbes that require oxygen from reproducing. However, the products can still contain microbes that can survive without oxygen.

questions.question: Hands must be washed after sneezing and blowing one's nose.
questions.description: Microbes spread onto the hands when sneezing and blowing one's nose. If the hands are not washed, these bacteria will easily spread onto food products.

questions.question: Listeria bacteria are not destroyed when a product is frozen.
questions.description: Freezing does not destroy microbes. Listeria can also reproduce in frozen foods.

questions.question: Eating is not allowed while preparing food.
questions.description: Microbes in the mouth spread onto the hands while eating. Eating must be done in a separate area and after eating hands must be washed.

questions.question: During the cooling of food microbes are not able to reproduce in the food.
questions.description: The danger zone for food temperatures is between 6 and 60 degrees Celsius. Microbes can reproduce in food when the temperature is within this danger zone. During the cooling of food the food is within this danger zone.

questions.question: When receiving frozen goods, their temperature does not need to be measured if the product feels cold.
questions.description: It is recommended that one occasionally measures the temperature of frozen deliveries, especially if there are any doubts about the accuracy of transportation temperature.

questions.question: Washed, clean dishes can only be handled with clean hands.
questions.description: If clean dishes are handled with dirty hands, microbes and dirt will spread from the hands onto the dishes.

questions.question: Products that have gone through ultra-high-temperature treatment (UHT) can not be stored in room temperature.
questions.description: During UHT products are sterilized with quick heating. Unopened packages can be stored in room temperature because most bacteria spores have been destroyed.

questions.question: Actions made after noticing mistakes or abnormalities in the packaging or quality of food products during receival checks must be logged in the own-check plan.
questions.description: Mistakes or abnormalities noticed in the quality or packaging of food products must be logged into the own-check plan. It is also required to detailedly log what actions are made after noticing a mistake or abnormality and who is responsible for informing for example the supplier of the products about it.

questions.question: Food products can not be sold nor used after the last use-by-date.
questions.description: The last use-by-date must be marked on easily perishable food products. The marking must be based upon research results of lastingness.

questions.question: Salmonella infection can only be acquired from foreign food products.
questions.description: Salmonella can be transmitted through both domestic and foreign food products or water contaminated with animal or human faeces, and it can cause food poisoning.

questions.question: Earth does not contain food poisoning causing bacteria.
questions.description: Earth can contain e.g. bacillus cereus or clostridum bacteria. Both of these are common causers of food poisoning.

questions.question: All cold storage units in food production areas must contain a thermometer.
questions.description: The monitoring and logging of temperatures is an important part of the . Thermometers are a vital tool for this and must be used.

questions.question: The only mandatory information on food packaging is the ingredients and the name of the food product.
questions.description: In addition to the name of the food product and the ingredients, the packaging must also state the minimum shelf life and the use by date.

questions.question: Baker's yeast contains living microbes.
questions.description: Baker's yeast itself is living yeast microbes. These yeast microbes will die if the temperature goes over 42 degrees Celsius. Because of this baker's yeast can not be added to a liquid that is too hot.

questions.question: Vacuum-packed meat is deaerated and hermetically sealed.
questions.description: A vacuum pack does not contain any air and prevents the growth of microbes that need oxygen.

questions.question: Temperature does not affect the speed of microbe reproduction.
questions.description: Temperatures are very important for the reproduction abilities of microbes. All microbes have their own optimal temperatures where reproduction is the fastest.

questions.question: Chefs can use their work shoes during their travel to and from their workplace.
questions.description: Work shoes must not be worn outside the workplace to prevent microbes from spreading into the food production area.

questions.question: Employees are free to decide who is responsible for the own-check plan at the beginning of each shift.
questions.description: Designated persons who have been trained for the task are responsible for the various areas of the own-check plan.

questions.question: When raw frozen chicken is thawed it releases liquid that can contain salmonella.
questions.description: Raw fowl/poultry meat can always contain salmonella, which will not be destroyed in a freezer. If the meat contains salmonella it will also certainly be in the liquid.

questions.question: Freezing improves the lastingness of food products because microbes are destroyed in the cold.
questions.description: Cold does not destroy microbes. If a product being freezed is microbiologically bad quality, it will be even worse quality after defrosting. However, freezing a good quality product will make it last longer as long as the freezing temperature is cold enough (-18 degrees Celsius or lower) and defrosting happens sufficiently slowly in cold areas.

questions.question: Temperature does not affect the reproduction speed of microbes.
questions.description: Temperatures are very important for the reproduction abilities of microbes. The insides of humans and animals often contain the optimal temperature for microbes, between 20 and 45 degrees Celsius.

questions.question: Beer is produced with the help of beneficial microbes.
questions.description: Beer is produced with yeast fermentation. Yeast is also used when producing wine.

questions.question: During the cooling of food microbes are not able to reproduce in the food.
questions.description: The danger zone for food temperatures is between 6 and 60 degrees Celsius. Microbes can reproduce in food when the temperature is within this danger zone. During the cooling of food the food is within this danger zone.

questions.question: Blanching can be used to improve the lastingness of chopped vegetables during freezing.
questions.description: Blanching, which means rapid boiling, stops frozen vegetables' enzymic activity by destroying microbes on their surface.

questions.question: Salmonella bacteria can not be found in fowl or poultry.
questions.description: Salmonella can be found in fowl or poultry. Due to the risk of salmonella, the meat of fowl/poultry must always be cooked to at least 75 degrees Celsius.

questions.question: A food product can be sold if it is packed in a vacuum pack that has softened only a little.
questions.description: Air has entered a softened vacuum pack, which means that the product is no longer safe.

questions.question: The waste disposal instructions for a food production area need to tell who is responsible for emptying the area's waste into the waste room's recycling bins.
questions.description: The waste disposal instructions need to tell which waste disposal company takes care of transporting waste away from the waste room, but the waste in the food production area needs to always be moved into the waste room at least after the work shift is over.

questions.question: Thoroughly boiled food does not contain any microbes.
questions.description: Bacteria spores will not be destroyed during boiling. When boiled food cools to less than 60 degrees Celsius the bacteria spores may reproduce again.

questions.question: When handling food products, employees should not touch their skin if possible.
questions.description: The skin and mouth contain large amounts of different bacteria, including food poisoning causing bacteria. Because of this touching the skin should be avoided when working with food products.

questions.question: Food poisoning causing bacteria reproduce quickly in Karelian pasties kept in room temperature.
questions.description: Karelian pasties are usually filled with rice porridge boiled in milk. Easily perishable food products, such as Karelian pasties, must be kept in cool temperatures. In room temperature the bacteria in pasties will reproduce quicker.

questions.question: The activity of water contained in food products can be lowered by adding salt or sugar to the product.
questions.description: The activity of water shows how easily the water in a product can be used by microbes. Salt and sugar change the state of water so that the microbes can not use it.

questions.question: Microbiological samples of served food are taken only if there is suspicion of there being something wrong with the product.
questions.description: Microbiological samples of served food are taken daily. Samples are kept for 2 weeks, so that potential food poisoning cases can be solved if need be.

questions.question: During food preparation one can sometimes go wash one's hands in the staff restroom.
questions.description: There must be a separate hand washing spot in immediate proximity to the food preparation area.

questions.question: Dishwashing should be done so that dirty dishes and clean dishes are handled separately enough.
questions.description: Clean dishes will become dirty again if they are not kept separate from dirty dishes.

questions.question: Liquid soap is to be used when washing the hands.
questions.description: Liquid soap is hygienic. The dispenser of the liquid soap should be one which can be pressed with the forearm instead of the hands.

questions.question: The maximum storage temperature for cooked shellfish is +6°C.
questions.description: Cooked molluscs and shellfish are stored at the temperature of melting ice (maximum +2°C).

questions.question: If the dish washer is not cleaned regularly, harmful microbes can multiply inside the machine and cause a health risk.
questions.description: Dish washers must also be cleaned regularly according to their instructions and allowed to dry afterwards.

questions.question: The lastingness of food products can also be improved during treatment by using hygienic work methods, clean surfaces and equipment.
questions.description: Ingredients and their handling equipment must be kept separate from cooked products to prevent cross-contamination. For example, differently colored cutting boards and equipment for different food groups, such as vegetables, fish, meat and cooked food helps to prevent cross-contamination.

questions.question: BSE, also called mad cow's disease, is not a food poisoning causing bacteria.
questions.description: BSE is caused by changes in the central nervous system of cows. Humans can get the disease only by eating meat that is contaminated with BSE.

questions.question: Easily perishable food products that require cold storage must be served at a temperature below +8 degrees celsius.
questions.description: During serving easily perishable food products that require cold storage may be +12 degrees celsius at most. The maximum serving time is 12 hours, after which the products must be discarded.

questions.question: Listeriosis should be avoided especially during pregnancy.
questions.description: Listeriosis during pregnancy can cause miscarriages or premature birth.

questions.question: A waiter must be able to tell customers the ingredients of a food product that has not been packed.
questions.description: A waiter must be able to provide customers with information about food products verbally and, if necessary, also in writing.

questions.question: Food poisoning is always caused by bacteria.
questions.description: The cause of food poisoning can, in addition to bacteria, also be a virus, mould fungus or protozoan.

questions.question: Monitoring the temperature when taking samples, storing and serving products is an essential part of own-check plans.
questions.description: Taking samples from products to be served and the hygienic state of food preparation areas, as well as monitoring the temperature of storing areas, are important parts of daily activities in food preparation. When measurements have been regularly logged it is easier to begin fixing procedures during possible problematic situations, and to prove that good hygiene is being used.

questions.question: Protective gloves are used to protect employees' hands from dirt, so that their hands do not need to be washed as often.
questions.description: Gloves are also used to protect food from microbes spread by hands. Gloves are a great way to keep work hygiene good when tasks must be changed quickly. Gloves must be changed regularly enough while working to keep hygiene good. It is also good to properly wash and dry one's hands when changing gloves. Gloves must always be changed immediately after touching door handles or taps.

questions.question: If your protective clothing gets dirty when you take out the rubbish, you must change into clean ones before you continue cooking.
questions.description: Staff must make sure that their work clothes are always clean when they handle and prepare food.

questions.question: Kitchen waste bins are always emptied after a work shift.
questions.description: Kitchen waste bins are emptied into the waste assortment room always when necessary during a work shift. At the same time the emptied waste bins must be washed.

questions.question: Bacteria toxins disappear when food is boiled.
questions.description: Some bacteria cause toxins in the food. If toxins have appeared in the food, they weill not disappear during boiling.

questions.question: Brooms and mops can be stored on the floor in the corner of a cleaning equipment storage room.
questions.description: Brooms and mops will not dry if they are stored on the floor. Microbes can reproduce quickly in wet cleaning equipment.

questions.question: If a summer restaurant is located next to a lake with clean water, the water in the lake can be used for washing fruits.
questions.description: All food preparation requires the use of water that is tap water quality.

questions.question: The cleanliness of waste rooms is not essential for hygiene because only waste is stored in those rooms.
questions.description: The cleanliness and hygiene of waste rooms is an essential part of taking care of food product hygiene because employees enter the waste room during the work day while wearing their work clothes, which they wear everywhere else as well. Waste rooms must be kept clean and organised.

questions.question: When hot food being served is kept at over 60 degrees Celsius the microbes in the food can not reproduce.
questions.description: If the food is not eaten or cooled immediately after production it must be kept at over 60 degrees Celsius when being served to prevent microbes from reproducing. The serving time is 4 hours at maximum.

questions.question: A cooked meal and the raw ingredients used to prepare it can be stored in the same container during transport.
questions.description: Cooked meals and raw ingredients are always stored separately in their own clean containers.

questions.question: A grated carrot spoils faster than an entire carrot.
questions.description: Treating a carrot and grating it shortens the time it lasts. During grating microbes spread onto the carrot and water inside the carrot becomes available for the microbes to use. Grated products also have more surface area than intact products; microbes, especially ones that require oxygen, are suitable to live on the surface of products.

questions.question: Workers in the food industry, e.g. the owner of a small café, must inform local food control authorities about their activities.
questions.description: All workers in the food industry must inform food control authorities about their activities. The informing must be done before beginning the activities. When founding a food industry workplace, e.g. a sausage factory, the activities must also be approved by the authorities.

questions.question: If you forget to take the measurements related to the own-check plan, you can estimate the measurements later.
questions.description: The monitoring of temperatures and recording of the results must always be based on actual measurements.

questions.question: If there are other companies working in the same estate, then the food production area needs a waste disposal area separate from the other companies' areas.
questions.description: Waste disposal areas can be the same with other companies but the own-check plan's waste disposal instructions must show if the waste disposal and its contract only cover the food production area or the entire estate.

questions.question: Wounds on the hands should be covered with both a bandage and a single-use glove.
questions.description: When both a bandage and a single-use glove are used, the wound is protected well enough and is also made more waterproof.

questions.question: Soup made for the following day can be left to cool overnight on the kitchen counter.
questions.description: The rapid cooling and cold storing of soup prevents or slows down the growth of bacteria.

questions.question: High salt content prevents harmful microbes from multiplying in a product
questions.description: Strong salting of a product changes the state of its water so that microbes can not reproduce. However, salted products such as mushrooms must still be stored in cool temperatures to prevent microbes on their surface from perishing them.

questions.question: Equipment used for slicing food products must be cleaned regularly.
questions.description: Equipment used for slicing food products is cleaned regularly by disassembling it and washing the parts with the appropriate washing agent.

questions.question: Salmonella bacteria can not be found in fowl or poultry.
questions.description: Salmonella can be found in fowl or poultry. Due to the risk of salmonella, the meat of fowl/poultry must always be cooked to at least 75 degrees Celsius.

questions.question: The disinfection of working surfaces destroys all harmful microbes and sterilizes the surfaces.
questions.description: Even a thorough cleaning will destroy about 90% of micro-organisms. Disinfectants can be used to destroy nearly all microbes. However, even disinfectants can not sterilize working areas, because not all bacteria-spores die from disinfectants. When cleaning it is not essential to sterilize the environment but instead to regularly and properly clean and wash it.

questions.question: Pasteurisation of milk destroys listeria bacteria.
questions.description: Pasteurisation of milk is a process that destroys listeria bacteria. Milk is pasteurised when heated to 72°C for about 15 seconds.

questions.question: During food preparation one can go wash one's hands in the staff restroom.
questions.description: There must be a separate hand washing spot in immediate proximity to the food preparation area.

questions.question: In lunch restaurants a control measurement of the temperature of food served from serving equipment is done once a week.
questions.description: Control measurements on served products are performed daily. Exceptions are always written down and all temperatures are logged in the own-check plan forms once a week.

questions.question: Windows in food premises can be opened for ventilation.
questions.description: Windows and doors in food premises must be kept closed to prevent pests from entering the premises.

questions.question: Chefs can use their work shoes during their travel to and from their workplace.
questions.description: Work shoes must not be worn outside the workplace to prevent microbes from spreading into the food production area.

questions.question: Waiters and servers are not required to have headwear.
questions.description: Waiters and servers are allowed to work without headwear.

questions.question: Blue cheese doesn't contain living mould.
questions.description: Clean, controlled and living moulds are used when producing blue cheese. The moulds create various taste ingredients in the cheese. The ready cheese still contain these living moulds.

questions.question: Food poisoning causing bacteria are found naturally.
questions.description: Microbes are everywhere: in the air, water, earth, plants, animals and humans. Some of these microbes cause food poisoning.

questions.question: The use of snus (similar to chewing tobacco) is not allowed during food preparation.
questions.description: When handling food products personal hygiene is important; snus must not be used because of hygienic reasons.

questions.question: Dried products can spoil quickly if they become wet.
questions.description: Dried products last long if they are stored dry. If the products become wet the microbes in them will start to reproduce.

questions.question: If a food authority representative wants to see your own-check plan, you must present it to him/her.
questions.description: If a food authority representative wants to see an operator's own-check plan, the operator is obliged to present it.

questions.question: Appropriate freezing improves the lastingness of a product.
questions.description: Freezing prevents microbe reproduction because frozen water can not be used by microbes for reproduction. Frozen products have recommended storing times, and freezing never improves the microbiological quality of a product. Frozen products should be defrosted slowly in a cold storage unit when they are going to be used. A product that has been defrosted once can not be frozen again.

questions.question: Fresh fish is an easily perishable food product.
questions.description: Fresh fish is a very easily perishable food product. Fresh fish products must be stored at the temperature of melting ice, max 2 degrees Celsius.

questions.question: Every employee shares in the responsibility of carrying out the own-check plan.
questions.description: Sharing responsibility is an essential part of a own-check plan. Every task of the plan requires a person who is in charge of that particular task, logs measurements and verifies them with his or her signture. Own-check plans also require continuing staff training and familiarization with relevant tasks.

questions.question: Sterilizing only destroys microbes capable of reproducing.
questions.description: Sterilizing destroys reproductive spores as well as bacteria spores. Canned foods are produced with sterilization.

questions.question: The more microbes there are in a cleaning cloth, the worse it smells.
questions.description: Microbes are usually odourless microorganisms that are invisible to the naked eye.

questions.question: Food that is being served while hot must be at least 60 degrees Celsius during the entire serving period.
questions.description: The temperature must also be measured and marked down in own-check logs. The food can be kept in service while hot for a maximum of 4 hours.

questions.question: Most harmful microbes reproduce the easiest in temperatures between 6 and 60 degrees Celsius.
questions.description: 6-60 degrees Celsius is a hazardous temperature region where food products should not be stored for long periods of time. Food served from a counter should be kept colder or hotter than this for the entire length of serving, and food to be served later after cooking should be cooled to colder than 6 degrees Celsius quickly (sooner than 4 hours.)

questions.question: Heat and humidity accelerate vegetable spoilage.
questions.description: The correct storage temperatures and moisture affect the shelf life of vegetables.

questions.question: Berry kisels can be stored in room temperature because the sugar prevents the growth of harmful bacteria.
questions.description: Berry kisels must be stored in cool temperatures because they can perish due to the large quantity of water in them. The sugar in kisels does not prevent harmful bacteria from growing because the sugar density is much lower than in e.g. jams or marmelade.

questions.question: The waste disposal procedures for professional kitchens, such as recycling, are decided upon between the personnel.
questions.description: A professional kitchen's waste disposal is based on waste laws as well as regional waste disposal directives.

questions.question: Food must not be served heated for over 2 hours.
questions.description: Food served / sold hot may be kept in a temperature-controlled bath (min +60 degrees) for a maximum of four hours, after which the food must be replaced.

questions.question: Food poisoning only spreads by contaminated food products or drinking water.
questions.description: Food poisoning can also spread due to bad work or hand hygiene. Food poisoning bacteria such as salmonella can spread human-to-human without any intermediate due to bad hand hygiene. Disease carriers without symptoms can also spread salmonella to other people.

questions.question: All bacteria are harmful for food products.
questions.description: Certain bacteria are beneficial for food preparation. For example, yoghurt, cheese and sour cabbage preparation uses bacteria such as lactic acid bacteria (LAB) beneficially.

questions.question: When receiving products one must make sure that they are moved into their appropriate, separate storage areas as soon as possible after the receival check.
questions.description: Products should be moved into their own storage areas as soon as possible after the receival check. Easily perishable food products can not be stored in room temperature for longer than 10-15 minutes.

questions.question: The own-check plan only refers to measuring and recording temperatures.
questions.description: The purpose of the own-check plan is to help operators to manage the risks associated with food hygiene. Measuring and recording temperatures is an important part of the own-check system. Other areas of the own-check system include cleaning and tidiness as well as hygienic skills of the staff.

questions.question: The temperature checks for received food products that need hot or cold storage are part of the own-check plan.
questions.description: Temperature monitoring of hot or cold storage food products when receiving is an important part of the own-check plan. If the temperatures do not meet set requirements they can be returned to the supplier as faulty products.

questions.question: Working areas and equipment must always be cleaned by using plenty of water.
questions.description: Water is an important part of cleaning and washing. Water acts as a solvent and substance that transports dirt away. However it is also important to dry the surfaces and equipment properly, because microbes grow and reproduce easily in moist environments.

questions.question: When a food industry workplace, e.g. a sausage factory, is being founded, the activities of the workplace must be approved in advance by local food control authorities.
questions.description: Workplaces that handle animal-based food products require an approval for their activities. Only informing of the activities is not enough.

questions.question: Self-service sales points need to be protected from droplets that spread into the air when someone coughs.
questions.description: Self-service sales points are protected from droplet transmissions from customers who cough.

questions.question: If a food premises changes owners, this must always be reported to the local food authority.
questions.description: When a food premises changes owners, this must always be reported to the local food authority.

questions.question: Chefs are required to have a hygiene proficiency passport even if their employment is not permanent.
questions.description: Chefs handle easily perishable food products in their work. This means that chefs must pass a hygiene proficiency test at least 3 months after starting their work.

questions.question: The waste disposal instructions for a food production area need to tell who is responsible for emptying the area's waste into the waste room's recycling bins.
questions.description: The waste disposal instructions need to tell which waste disposal company takes care of transporting waste away from the waste room, but the waste in the food production area needs to always be moved into the waste room at least after the work shift is over.

questions.question: Food product employees can use wedding and engagement rings while handling easily perishable goods.
questions.description: Jewellery can not be used when working with food products. No matter how well hands are washed, a large amount of harmful microbes can stay under rings and can later contaminate food products being handled.

questions.question: Detergents (washing chemicals) must always be stored in their original packages.
questions.description: Only the original packages can be used to make sure that the correct detergent is being used for the situation.

questions.question: Dairy products that contain lactose keep well at room temperature.
questions.description: Dairy-based products that are produced by using at least pasteurisation are stored at +8 degrees. Ultra-heat treated milk keeps at room temperature for several months.

questions.question: Waste does not cause a hygiene risk because it is stored in separate containers.
questions.description: Bad waste management hygiene or food products getting into contact with waste can cause hygiene risks.

questions.question: Dried products can spoil quickly if they become wet.
questions.description: Dried products last long if they are stored dry. If the products become wet the microbes in them will start to reproduce.

questions.question: Biowaste bins do not have to be emptied daily if the bin has not become full.
questions.description: Biowaste bins must be emptied at least once a day because biowaste contains perishing materials.

questions.question: Hepatitis A is never spread in food products.
questions.description: The most important viruses that reproduce in the intestines of humans are the norovirus and hepatitis A. Both viruses last for a long time and are able to spread in the cold and even in frozen foods.

questions.question: When a food industry workplace, e.g. a sausage factory, is being founded, the workplace must only inform local food control authorities about the activities.
questions.description: When a food industry workplace, e.g. a sausage factory, is being founded, an approval for the activities by local food control authorities is required.

questions.question: Officials will prepare an own-check plan for new companies in the food product industry.
questions.description: Companies in the food product industry must prepare their own own-check plan when starting their activities. The plan must be followed and updated when needed.

questions.question: Listeria bacteria are not destroyed when a product is frozen.
questions.description: Freezing does not destroy microbes. Listeria can also reproduce in frozen foods.

questions.question: Food products stored in protective gas do not have to be stored in the cold.
questions.description: Protective gas protects a food product's surface from drying up and enzymic darkening, but the products must still be stored in the cold just like similar products with no protective gas.

questions.question: Fever and the flu are good reasons for a food product employee to not go to work.
questions.description: Food products should not be handled when one has a fever or the flu because causes of the disease spread easily by coughing or sneezing.

questions.question: Useful microbes are used in baking.
questions.description: Yeast is used in baking to make dough rise.

questions.question: Cold fish products (e.g. salmon) in vacuum-packages has sometimes been found to contain listeria.
questions.description: Cold fish products in vacuum-packages have a risk to cause listeriosis because the fish has not been heated and the storing time is long.

questions.question: Due to salmonella risks, fowl and poultry meat must always be heated thoroughly to over 75 degrees Celsius.
questions.description: Fowl/poultry can contain salmonella naturally. Salmonella bacteria must be alive to cause an illness. The meat of fowl/poultry is safe if it is heated thoroughly to over 75 degrees Celsius.

questions.question: In commercial kitchens, it is necessary to nominate the people in charge of the own-check plan.
questions.description: Designated persons who have been trained for the task are responsible for the various areas of the own-check plan.

questions.question: The human skin does not contain microbes.
questions.description: Especially the face, scalp, mouth, nose etc. contain microbes. Food poisoning causing Staphylococcus bacteria can also be found on the skin.

questions.question: Every employee shares in the responsibility of carrying out the own-check plan.
questions.description: Sharing responsibility is an essential part of a own-check plan. Every task of the plan requires a person who is in charge of that particular task, logs measurements and verifies them with his or her signture. Own-check plans also require continuing staff training and familiarization with relevant tasks.

questions.question: Intestinal bacteria cannot spread from hands to food.
questions.description: Intestinal bacteria can spread to food even from the hands.

questions.question: There may be flies in a food premises even if the waste management is well organised.
questions.description: Flies in the premises are always a sign of inadequate cleaning.

questions.question: Food must not be served heated for over 2 hours.
questions.description: Food served / sold hot may be kept in a temperature-controlled bath (min +60 degrees) for a maximum of four hours, after which the food must be replaced.

questions.question: If the dish washer is not cleaned regularly, harmful microbes can multiply inside the machine and cause a health risk.
questions.description: Dish washers must also be cleaned regularly according to their instructions and allowed to dry afterwards.

questions.question: A cheese roll packed in a tight plastic wrap is protected from microbes.
questions.description: A cheese roll is a perishable food product that is stored and served cold. In addition to being wrapped in plastic film, make sure that it is kept in the correct storage and serving temperatures.

questions.question: Milk can be stored at room temperature during the breakfast service.
questions.description: Milk and cream are perishable food products and they must be served cold.

questions.question: All transport companies can transport food to restaurants provided that their vehicles are spacious enough.
questions.description: Professional transporting of food requires certification from the appropriate authorities as well as an own-check plan.

questions.question: Smoking is allowed in the food premises storeroom if the employer allows it.
questions.description: Smoking is prohibited in the food premises in those areas where food is prepared, sold, processed or stored.

questions.question: Dry flour contains no microbes.
questions.description: The microbes in dry products have not been destroyed. Dry products can contain spores of bacteria, moulds and yeast.

questions.question: It is important to change disposable gloves often enough.
questions.description: When working with food, you must change disposable gloves whenever you start a new work phase.

questions.question: Dishes do not need to be pre-washed before being put into a washing machine.
questions.description: Before being put into a washing machine, dishes must be pre-washed using cool water to get rid of loose dirt and also to get rid of protein spots so that they will not stick to the surface of the dishes and form biofilm.

questions.question: If the product being handled is fresh and of good quality, the handling hygiene is not as important.
questions.description: Hygienic handling methods and equipment are always important for the lastingness of products. A fresh and good quality good will still perish easily if it is handled unhygienically.
